Apparently, he's the only one who knows NX in this school so he made the CAD assignments for IFE, thank god they were easy. It sucks that freshmen are forced to take CAD with this tool.

This has to be the worst professor at the school. You will never know what you are doing wrong unless you explicitly ask the poor TA's. This guy does nothing for you and hates students. The whole class is a series of YouTube videos recorded in 2018 on a different version of the cad program we used. ***AVOID AT ALL COSTS***
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: I would give him a zero if I could. He makes this one credit class more work than my major-specific courses. He is lazy and rude. I once asked for an extension on an assignment days before it was due, and he told me that if I'm too stupid to not be able to do it in an hour then I have bigger problems. Has not been teaching on campus in seven years.
Unclear grading criteria and unnecessary amount of work for a 1 credit class. Try to avoid this class if you can.

Knows his information, but if you ask for help, he treats you like you're an idiot for not knowing something briefly mentioned in the lecture video. I asked for help once and he talked down to the person before me, to me, and to the person after me. I've talked to other people and they experienced the same. Way too much work for a 1 credit class.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Tough grader

comment: He never shows up to class and expects you to learn via youtube video only, which can be difficult for first time CAD students. He gives grades without explaining why you got the grade you did. I have worked with CAD for years, and I find myself struggling in his class because of his unknown grading criteria. Do not take this class.

You never going to see him in the class except the first day. The class is taught by recorded lectures. TAs did all the grading. However, he is quite helpful in office hours. It is a one credit course, but time consuming at the beginning cuz CAD. Beside CAD, other projects are straightforward.

I honestly couldn't have a lower opinion on this guy. His "lectures" are a series of prerecorded YouTube videos. You'll never see him again after the first day of class. Total joke of a professor. I have had many great professors at this school, and it's a shame that he is a part of the faculty.
You will literally never see this man and for some reason if you need to contact him he will be sure to be extra rude and not understanding.

Assignments other than CAD are extremely easy but CAD with NX is ridiculously confusing and the explanation videos are long. Apparently you can get a lot of passes on late work and incomplete assignments if you visit the professor but office hours clash with regular class time and he doesnt reply quickly to email

I personally loved Morris for Engineering Communications. The other ratings are right, he shows up the first day of class and you will only see your TA's in class afterwards. I used to skip class and just go to his office hours, and he'll help me finish 3 projects in a day. If you watch the videos and still don't understand, he helps!

Be sure to WATCH THE VIDEOS he posts on LMS!! I loved Professor Morris! If you feel like there's a subject that you do not understand in class/the , definitely go to his office hours. He makes it his duty to help his students get all of the assistance they need. 10/10 would recommend. I would love to take his class again if I could.

You will see Jeff Morris once during this course- the 5 TAs are your graders. This class is rough and is mostly online cuz it is a 1 credit course with the work of a 4 credit class. NX-12 is the used program and honestly it super sucks- bit this class is kinda required :/. Expect lots of work and try to make buddies with CAD experienced peoples.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Morris doesnt even teach the class he just shows up on the first day to tell you what you have to do for the course and thats the last time you'll see for the semester. Only a 1 credit hour class but requires probably about 2 hours of video watching and 2-3 hours of work each week

This man is never in class. He can't even be called a professor since he doesn't teach. Watch the broken videos to learn the skills that you need to complete assignments in class and you'll do well. You've got to be lucky with TAs as well since sometimes, even they don't know what they're doing.

Not what I thought it was going to be. I thought it was going to be mostly in lab assignments that were guided by him. Instead, he shows up the first session and lets you know that the class is based purely of his pre-recorded lectures which are long and boring. Had to get help from friends often. He is available for help but can be cocky.

My interaction with Professor Morris was pretty much watching the videos he made for class. To that extent, they're well laid out and edited, but the class isn't the best. Since the majority of your interaction is with TAs, you don't see Morris much. However, it's not a difficult class at all.

Jeff is an awesome professor!  He's fairly tough for CAD grading but he is the best IED teacher ever!  Jeff is clear and cuts the bull that permeates this class.  My friends always complained about cryptic assignments and annoying questions, but Jeff is just helpful, polite, and reasonable.  Great professor!

I can only comment on Morris concerning the video lectures he provided for a 1-credit class and from the one time that I attended his (busy) office hours for extra help. His expectations are clear and he provides all the information you need. To get an A just watch his videos, do your work, and be nice to the TAs. Good engineering professor.
Had his videos for an engr communications class. I had to go to his office hours once and he was quick and helpful.  Young guy, solid pick for leading any class.
well it's CAD. you can't go wrong with that. Easy explanation, easy grading, easy A

Had Jeff for IED. I didn't realize how lucky I was until after speaking with people in other IED sections. He's acts in this course like a true engr supervisor and will give you a feeling for the real world. He checks up on your design and makes sure you're on track, but then LEAVES YOUR TEAM ALONE to do your work. Would recommend him to anyone.

My opinion of this man couldn't be lower. Useless video lectures explained nothing and had nothing to do with the assignments. The non-CAD portion of the class was a waste and clearly ad-libbed at the last minute. The TAs tried their hardest but couldn't salvage the class from Mr. Morris' incompetence and vagueness.

So he went to class the first day and that's because he just happened to be around. Guy's totally a d***. I went to office hours once and he cut them short to go to his other job... DJing the hockey games. I didn't look at the video lectures for many reasons: his annoying clicker, the uselessness, and the time spent watching. Befriend a TA.

Video lectures meant he never showed up in class. The CAD segment of the class was obscenely hard in NX(bad software), many of the videos were of little/no help, if not for tons of help from a friend I would've failed. The rest of the class was easy & pointless, the TAs weren't necessarily more helpful than other students in the class.
The NX segment of his class sucks. It's insanely difficult to understand, but after that the rest of the class is a walk in the park.

I only saw him once when he was trouble shooting my computer during the "Word" part of class. Pretty much the TAs are the only ones who do anything. I liked the CAD part of the class, but totally disliked the part prior to labview. The videos for word are useless. All the talk about are making pizzas

Prof. Morris's video lectures were almost entirely useless. CAD cannot be taught be throwing bunches of random features at the viewer and requesting that s/he turn them into a part. Prof. Morris also does not know proper drawing style, dimensioning rules, etc. His drawings are among the worst I have ever seen- worse than freshmen in my high school.
doesn't actually exist.
This class was a joke.  It may have been a lot of work for a 1 credit class but none of it was hard and you had to try to not get a 100 in this class.

Everything but the last few projects are easy, but those last projects are harder, and the final is nearly impossible.  The videos either explain something twenty times or none, but are useful (mostly).  I guess it really does depend on your TA's though, because he isn't really responsible for your grade at all.

Eh, well, the videos were...not exactly the best way to teach CAD, in my humble opinion.  However, I did all my work and got the A.  Helpful in his optional live lectures; bring specific questions to that and he'll help you out.  Simple philosophy: Do your work.  In reality though, not the easiest to follow through; hard work for a 1-credit class.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

Completely ridiculous amount of work for a 1 CREDIT course...At least its  not that hard, once you sit and watch his boring lectures, which have the potential to put you to sleep more than once. Just hope you get good TA's, mine pretty much did the work for me, and gave me perfect scores on labs that weren't perfect.        = )

The class was taught entirely using video lectures, which basically meant you never actually saw him unless you sought him out.  Otherwise you have to trust the TAs, and since this year we switched over to NX, they didn't really know what they were doing.  He could have been hibernating all semester, for all I know.

Professor Ecker is one of the kindest people Ive met in the teaching field. He knows that there is no point beating around the bush with what he expects us to know for upcoming quizzes and exams. This rating is more of a testimony to his mastery of teaching than advice towards his class because he is retiring this year. Great job, enjoy retirement
Kindest professor I ever had. He cares for the students, understands their situations, and gives fair difficulty exam. He is awesome!

He makes the knowledge easier, and he can let you understand them clearly. Not much homework, but remember to review for the exam and quiz. This year is his last year to teach. Hope he will be nice in the future.

He is one of the best teacher in the whole school, very nice and kind. On exam, he would not try to make the questions hard. The thing that he consider is whether students understand the knowledge or not.

I love his lecture, it's amazing. He gives you clear notes and annotations, which makes it easier to understand. He also gives you some examples and explained those examples. Our grades are made up of two parts: quizzes and exams. Homework is not mandatory, but make sure to do your homework, study for your tests. He is the best professor!!!!!!!!!!!
I'v e heard this is his 52nd year teaching and his last year teaching in RPI. Best wishes for him.

Joe Ecker is one of the nicest people you will meet at RPI. Great guy, lectures are good, and plenty of teaching experience. 50 years teaching at RPI! Quizzes are based directly off of HW problems, tests are fine if you study for them. HW not required. If you have the option to take him for Calculus, do it! Can't say enough good about this man.

He was honestly the best for Calc 2. I feel like I learned everything clearly with out having to worry about hard tests (they are very similar to examples in class and back exams) . He is such a nice man, and you can tell he genuinely cares about his students.

When I took him it was his 101st semester at RPI. He is a funny old man but a great caring guy that takes the time to try and learn each of his students names. He is very reasonable on what exactly he will cover. He explicitly explains what cases he wont test you over. He isn't that good with technology so he sometimes cant figure it out.

Hmmm... this is basically a calculus class for Business, Arch, and Liberal Arts (HASS) students. Much much much easier than regular Calculus I. Attendance is not mandatory, and notes are emailed after each lecture. Weekly quizzes which are basically free 100s. The tests are also exactly like the backtests (EXACTLY). Easy A, even if you suck at math

Demonstrated kindness to his students and I wasn't really expecting to encounter such a considerate professor during my college years. I actually decided to enroll in his class because many of my upperclassmen friends told me about his wonderful teaching style and kindheartedness. And, he made the effort to memorize the names of his 100+ students.

Joe Ecker is the true full package of professors. He is incredibly sweet and truly cares about his students. He makes a usually very challenging course extremely digestible (arguably easy) and actually exciting to learn. If you're considering taking a course with Joe, don't hesitate.
They don't make professors like this anymore. Other professors can learn from his delivery and dedication.

Chill professor but material was not that easy. However, I missed half of the lectures, but still got an A because he sent all lecture notes through email. The TA was also extremely nice and an easy grader, so the class was a lot easier. Test questions are basically given the lecture before the exams so you can memorize them and get a 100.
cool guy, emails the notes to all students everyday after class so you don't have to worry if you miss a class

This guy is an absolute legend. If you can get a class with this man teaching it, you have struck gold. Quizzes are easy, homework is helpful (but by no means necessary), tests are straight forward. If he was able to teach every class at RPI, I would take them all with him and NEVER get bored. Absolute beast.
Cute old guy, he emails you all of the slides from his lectures, and all of the quizzes are questions from the homework that you get the answers to in recitation
Best professor!
Ecker is hands down the best prof in RPI. He remembered everyone's name in the first week. Tests looked very similar to the back exams. Final was easy too. Very nice guy!

Ecker made an effort to get to know all the students personally and tried to remember all 250 of our names.  It seemed successful, too, as every time I saw him outside of the lecture hall he addressed me by name.  All the quizzes consisted of questions from homework assignments, and the final was made up of questions from previous unit tests.
He is so kind and good, even if sometimes do not have very clear mind to teach some things.
Joe Ecker is the bomb. Favorite professor at RPI.
Ecker is a very fun teacher who posts the class notes every day.  I would definitely recommend him as a teacher if you need to take calc 2. It's been a blast with him.

Great man, I hope he recovers from his stroke. He has photographic memory, and remembers everyone's name, its quite amazing. He is sweet and you will like him immediately. He also emails lecture notes and back tests that he has made. There is no final.

Best calc professor ever. Really makes an effort to know the students (he will remember EVERYBODY'S name) and is very clear on all material he teaches. He also emails everyone the notes after each class.

Ecker is easily the best math professor I've ever had. He connects with the students and genuinely wants his student to succeed. He's easy to understand and doesn't trick students. I wish I could take more classes with him!!

Very helpful and easy to understand. Some might find class slow-moving if they've already taken Calculus. Makes an effort to know everyone's name, even in classes of 80+ students. Exams/quizzes not difficult - picks most questions directly from homework/practice tests.

Ecker's an awesome teacher. He is friendly, unassuming, and very easy to ask for help, if you'll ever need to. The pace of his teaching seems slower, which makes it easier to learn the material in comparison to many other classes (Ex Physics). It's useful to memorize equivalent expressions, such as double angles. Easy A AND learned.
Best teacher I had this semester. The class was both easy and informative - not something I can say about a lot of classes here.
He is totally awesome. he will try to help you do well and makes the class fun and easy
Favorite professor for the semester
Awesome guy, makes this class super easy. Just study his back tests and you'll get an easy A...He also learns all 100 of his students names.

Ecker really cares about his students, and even goes through the trouble of learning everyone's name.  His tests are exactly like the back tests, and he'll spend a class before the exam just to go over exactly how to do each problem.  Be sure to get into his class!
As he says himself all the time: "what a guy". He is easy to understand, tells you exactly whats going to be on each test. and is super funny.

Ecker is awesome. Super nice, super peppy. Lectures are clear and understandable, makes powerpoint drawings during lecture explaining everything and emails them everyday. Exams are just like the back tests. Exams are also relatively easy, just study a bit.

Joe Ecker is hands down the man.  He learns everyone's name and is extremely helpful with whatever you need.  He wants everyone to succeed and he outlines the curriculum as such.  He makes his own tests cutting out the middle man.  Get into his class!!!
Joe Ecker is the man.
Easiest A earned at RPI hands down. His backtests are almost identical and he emails you the notes from each class.
Easiest Calc 2 class ever. His test are super easy and he is really nice.
Knows how to teach! Only assigned practice problems and never tried to trick us on TA/Skill quizzes or exams. Very assistant, very funny and very smart.
He gives out back tests that are almost identical to each upcoming test.

Loved the class. Practically gives you what's going to be on the exam. He tends to go into some pretty theoretical stuff during his lectures, but he only gives big picture questions on his exams. Final was exact questions from previous tests from the semester.
Dr. Ecker is great. He explains everything and gives you the back test form the previous year, then just changes a few things around. He is very helpful during office hours, too.

Best teacher I have ever had at RPI.  I love Joe Ecker! He was personable, learned everyone's name, engaged students and taught easy material very clearly.  Take calc with him if you can!  Great TA Adam went over every problem before quizes.  Used maple for labs and tests.  No final!

EASY A..however, you should go to class. Two-hour lectures are very boring but going is very helpful. He goes over every test  with you, and some of the questions are the same ones you will find on the test.
very helpful in & out of class; upbeat, easy to tune in to; goes the extra mile & helps inspire enthusiasm for the material
AWESOME! Easy A
ecker is the freakin man... no tests, no final, EASY grader =)
Good prof. Fun and Easy.  Go to every class and its an easy A. He pretty much does your homework and gives you the test before you take it.
No Comments
Aces all the way
Ecker is the man!

Here is how the grade is determined:  Labs are 25 points, quizzes are 15 points and tests are 60 points.  He practically does the labs for you and the quizzes are simple as hell.  All you need to do is get around a 50/60 on the 3 exams...88+ = A
BEST PROF I HAVE EVER HAD!!!
No Comments
Outstanding professor! Reasonable, understanding and an all-round good teacher.
Very nice professor and understands students when they have a specific problem.  I just hope I have him one more time as a professor.
Taught Calc II while Kapila was away. Great guy, gave tons of extra credit, and funny too.
Joe Ecker is the man!

Ecker is the professor to have---he answers any questions you have in class--teaches the material u should and tells you exactly what to know for tests--he's such a sweet heart and i hope i have him for more classes--no ones better!!!!!
awesome guy . easy class
Ecker rocks!
I wish every RPI professor was like him
best math prof. ever. i better have him for more classes.
The best math teacher I have ever had
Awesome professor. I hope to take more classes from him.
great guy and an amazing teacher!!!
U can't get a betta math prof than JOE ECKER!! What a sweetheart!!!!!
No Comments

She was a great professor if you want to actually improve. Some students sometimes forget pain and gain. Don't underestimate the professor. Start your hw early, make friends, and work hard. If you try hard she will know it. However, her graders are kinda volatile. I had a grader who really hated me for no reason. Anyway, have fun.

Homeworks are very difficult, mine took on average 20 hours across multiple days and dominated my course schedule. Cutler asks students to write code during lecture, you should either participate or write your own solution in parallel, do not play minesweeper during class. Complete all the practice problems & do the extra credit, start HW on Sat.

Data Structures is a hard class, but with Cutler it was way harder. She has premade lecture notes for class which is fine, but we only finished covering the notes in about 3 lectures all semester. The homework assignments also take way too long. The class should be worth more than 4 credits with Cutler for the amount of time you spend in work.

Be prepared to for possibly 20-40 hours of homework per week. Don't start two days before it's due. 
Go to lectures. They help--especially ones before a break. 
Homework 6 will suck. You'll be better from it. 
Find people to study+review with. 
Don't use ChatGPT as a crutch. 
This is meant to be a hard class, but you'll learn a lot. 
Don't worry
A lot of work but definitely worth it. Learning a lot! CUTLERRR IS THE GOATTTTT!!!!!

An infamously difficult class at RPI. Clearly the weeder class for first year CS students. Took it first semester freshman year, had to retake it (first grade disappeared and didn't impact GPA).
Despite being so painful it is a incredible informative and useful course. Cutler is an especially talented and experienced professor.

dr. cutler is probably one of the best teachers in RPI. she has an answer to every question no matter how niche and the structure of the class is well thought out and organized. tests and homeworks are rough but if you go to office hours she will do her best to help you out. i wish i had a lighter load so i can fully focus on her class this sem.

Data structures is, and should be a very hard class. Her homework's, labs, and exams are very challenging, but I promise you that if you take the time to properly go through them you'll learn so much. Perseverance, patience, time management, and hard work are near essential to succeed in this course. You can do this!

Terrible professor.  Wasn't lenient with grades at all - in fact, she would lower your grade if you requested a regrade for your test and she found a mistake she over looked before. Gave more homework than I did for my next three four-credit classes combined. Values only top 1% of students. Would leave RPI than ever take another course with her.

Data Structures with Prof. Cutler was tough because of the workload and difficulty of tests. I think she is just not suited to teach a lecture to 350+ students at a time, which, to be fair, seems very hard. Every time I went to her 1-on-1 she was very helpful and considerate of my issues. I would consider taking a much smaller class with her.

Cutler was a great professor. The course was very challenging but I gained a lot from it. The homework was time-consuming but helped me to learn the material and each of the assignments were interesting. The tests were very difficult, but Cutler was fair in curving the course. I feel well prepared for the upper-level CS courses.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework

comment: Incredibly incredibly disrespectful in 1-on-1 encounters. Don't expect her to help you. Completely unfair grader. I have never had a professor verbally torment students for asking questions. Absolutely ridiculous and an embarrassment to the CS department.

She was so consistently disrespectful to me. She was uncompromising when I had COVID and didn't want to take a test with 300 other people. I sent her five emails about the next class and she never responded to me (and still hasn't 3 months later). After the add deadline, she wouldn't let me audit. A poor showing for the CS department.

People hate on her just because her class is hard, but I thought she and the course were both very fair. She is very strict about deadlines and homework, but that probably prepares you pretty well for the real world. The course material itself isn't hard to understand, but the workload is very tough.

She's extremely smart, and knowledgeable, and sprinkles her own personality into lectures. Honestly, the worst thing about her is how cutthroat she can be. It seems like even if you have a life circumstance like illness, she'll expect that homework in on Thursday regardless.

She is very knowledgable around the class material and reflects that through her lectures. Homework takes up 10-12 hours a week and often describe the objective very vaguely. For a few of them she made some emergency changes to the files without clear notice which caused students' code to break on submitty.
Tough class. It had lots of homework and was very fast paced, and that made me a much better computer scientist.

So hard! I don't know if it's this class that's hard or GSAS that's too easy, but it was the hardest class (I would like to rate 6 out of 5 for difficulty). It was not fun at all, but I must admit that I learned a lot.
What can I say? It's that bad
I overheard her at the union talking about how she wanted to make data structures more difficult because there were "too many CS students." Do with that what you will. Hard pass.

Overall, Professor Cutler is a very knowledgeable individual. However, I find that she did a mediocre job of conveying her knowledge and giving lectures. The homework assignments are lengthy — but given good time management and a strong work ethic — are doable. I averaged ~8 hours per assignment. Tests are not too bad if you review back exams.
This class is a lot of work and you have to manage your time well, you should take it during a semester when the rest of your classes are easy. The exams are also really hard.

Professor Cutler does a well enough job teaching a subject which seeks to strike down most Comp. Sci. majors. She knows the subject material very well, and if you ask questions during class, she will answer. Outside of that, it can be hard to get a hold of her.
rating_tags: Respected--Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Doesn't answer critical questions about homework in a timely manner.

She seems nice at first, but she is an extremely difficult professor and enjoys throwing students into the deep end. The weekly homework assigned are often far beyond necessary or reasonable difficulty and often have mistakes. She rarely gives helpful feedback, and rarely follows her own ridiculous grading standards in her provided code.
Seems nice in lecture but is actually *very* rude. Often can be unnecessarily strict on less important parts of the course. Would not recommend this professor to other students.

Assigments are weekly. One lab done in groups, typically around 2 hours, and one large homework assignment every week. The HW is quite long and takes around 10 hours to complete (a couple of times more), however they are very fun and I enjoyed them a lot. The class is very hard and exam grading is very harsh. In two words: enjoyable suffering
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--Tough grader

comment: Cutler appears nice on the surface but in all reality cares little for the success of her students.

Hw is weekly and for me took at least 8 hours (usually many more). Cutler assigns interesting and challenging hw problems and by the end of each one you will probably feel exhausted but also a real sense of accomplishment.

She seems nice in lecture but is actually insanely strict. Exam time limits are not ample. Homeworks can be a bit vague and time consuming. Submitty is slightly buggy/slow. The first lecture taught code that exhibits undefined behavior as if it were correct.

Her lectures are boring and little helpful. Her homework are really hard and will take lots of time to complete. Exams are difficult and the time limit is really intense. Also, the professor is unreasonable since I submitted a regrade request and the professor said there is no need for regrading so I got -1 point on that exam.

Well spoken, introduces material in a clear and concise manner. Very accessible and cares about the success of her students. Very well organized, all materials (past and present) are available online for review outside of class.
Weak course objective, though sometimes inspirational. Obscure instructions.

For a student that got an easy 5 on the AP CSA exam, Data Structures was, by far, the hardest computer science course I have ever taken. The homeworks made me cry, the tests made me question myself. And now looking back at my experience, I have gotten the most out of that class than any other. Taking DS with Cutler is painful, but worth it.
One of the hardest freshman courses at RPI, but make it through the course and you'll know what you're doing when it comes to coding.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Really difficult homework
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Tough Data Structures curriculum. From my understanding, she designs the curriculum for all semesters even though she doesn't teach them all. Not sure if this is true. Tests are very orderly to the point where everyone has an assigned seat. Expect weekly homework assignments that take 10+ hours to complete (minimum).
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: If this is not your required courses to graduate. Please don't take it. You can't learn how to do c++ in this course because c++ is the prerequisit not the main course content.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Took this class as an elective when I was initially really interested and ended up hating it.  Lectures are super dull.  Some of the homeworks are actually really interesting but most are completely asinine or just badly realized.   If you're not a CSCI student, you're better off just learning the same material independently.
The material is challenging but there is no exams so the grading is relatively easy
She is the gatekeeper for computer science majors, if you can't do well here, you should consider changing majors
The most important class I've ever taken. You will either learn the most you've ever learned in your life or you will fail.
Cutler's graphics class is the best class I've taken at RPI. she's a fantastic lecturer and her homeworks are really interesting!

Class is extremely hard. Notes online are more useful than lectures. Hws were extremely hard and it would have been easier to take algorithms first. Normally took at least 20 hours on most (not all) hws. Hardest cs class (took it spring 2013). Tests are long and hard. If you do well on a homework that everyone does well on the curve can hurt you.
Worst professor that I've ever had.
It's hard but helpful, and curved at a good amount

Best class I've taken at RPI. It isn't easy, but the hws (while challenging) are not impossible and actually fun. Tests sometimes are a bit long, but possible...if you know the material. Don't worry, the hws shouldn't take you more than 6 hours if you go to lecture...this stuff about them taking 20 hours is just ridiculous.
Avoid her if you can! Incredibly flawed grade curving system.
Avoid if possible.
Homework and tests are too difficult (homeworks take like 10-20 hours and are assigned almost every week). Also, the curve for the final grade CAN hurt you.
she assigns difficult homework and the tests are challenging, but she's fantastic at teaching the material, and grades with the mindset that her exams are SUPPOSED to be hard (she curves them)
The lectures are 'eh,' but the notes she provides are excellent and the homeworks, while lengthy, are extremely well-designed. You'll definitely know your stuff by the end of this class.

Excellent lecturer, knows the material very well and is extremely helpful. Well organized. Homeworks were hard but doable, labs were fun, but knowing the course material wasn't necessarily sufficient for the exams -- expected ability to solve logic problems as well.

Her teaching style is just reading a PDF that she posts before class. She calls on a student to program the examples, which is boring to listen to. Homeworks are brutal and take 10ish hours on average. Labs are easy and tests aren't TOO bad if you know what you are doing and study the sample test.

Extremely helpful and knowledgeable -- The course isn't the easiest and the homeworks take a lot of time (especially if programming isn't your thing), but you get a lot out of the them. Tests cover a lot, but nothing that hasn't been covered in class, and you can bring notes. Lectures are decent, but you can also read the notes online and be fine.
Gives a lot of work, but it really teaches you well.

She's absolutely one of the best teachers I have ever met. Not only because she's very smart, but also because she has high expectations. Her tests for most people are hard, but if you keep up with class work, you'll think they're easy like me. Her homeworks can be very time consuming, but that's with good intentions. In all, I enjoyed her class.

For people who don't go into the class with more experience than CSCI 1100, the class is very difficult. It requires a lot of time catching up on basic principles that are skipped by most professors, resulting in a struggle to understand what is happening at any given time. The key to success in this case is enlisting the help of the TA's

The tests are fairly difficult and this was my most challenging class for my first semester at RPI. Most of the labs were easy but some were pretty tough. There's one homework project per week; they usually take 5-7 hours but on some weeks take 10-15. Lectures are absurdly boring but the exercises done during lecture are very valuable.

Dr. Culter is very nice, especially if you talk with her one on one, but her assignments are long and nasty. Start them early. Warning: homework #6 is always a killer. Don't think because you were a whiz in high school you'll be able to coast through here. You will learn everything well, especially if you come and participate in class.
Her lectures are long and boring, her homeworks are insanely time consuming. I didn't pay attention in lecture, completed all the homeworks and had a crypt sheet for every test and I got an A-.
One of the better CS teachers, I had her for CSII. The HW could be a little long at times, but the course was taught well and all of the important material was covered.
Her class took up all of my time, but it was wonderful.

Excellent CS2 professor. Lectures are full of valuable information and plenty of examples. If you want to do well, take notes on the in-class examples as they often show up on the tests. Exams are quite long and hard, but they cover the material adequately. Dr. Cutler is very nice and helpful in person.
The tests contained more material than what is appropriate.  The lectures were boring but got the key points across.  The homework assignments were reasonable.
great teacher for my class (advanced computer graphics). knows everything about subject. class assumes a lot from people but most students taking it have a graphics background

She doesn't seem or pretend to care for her students.  Sometimes, he doesn't understand the lectures she gave in class because the lecture notes she uses were recycled from previous professors.  She could at least prepare or read it before class.  IMO, she is a disappointment; the fact that she graduated from MIT.

The best computer science teacher I've had yet. Lectures can sometimes be boring, but she makes the attempt to keep them interesting. I'd say that if you have to take CS2, pray that she's your professor.
Extremely intelligent, however her lectures and exams assume everyone else also has a masters in C++ from MIT. Second time taking the course and somehow did worse with her.
horrible

Professor Cutler is very nice and approchable. She is very helpful when you see her with questions. Lectures are easy to follow. She makes the class as interesting as it can be (for being csci 2) and she seems to enjoy teaching. Homeworks are reasonible, especially if you don't wait till the day they are due to start.
Professor Cutler is not one of the beter professors at RPI. Her lecturs are extremely boring and make people fall asleep. Maybe that is why most of the class does not show up anymore.
Dr. Cutler is incredibly cute however she usually dresses modestly and so we can usually pay attention in class.
No Comments

I think Ditursi is a decent lecturer, but he was very unprepared and we suffered from that. Every lab the TAs wouldn't have the answer key because he wouldn't make them until half way through. His tests demand a lot in a short period of time. It doesn't help that he rarely posted study material and was late to uploading his lectures.

The most disorganized class of this size I have ever taken. Considering it is required for many majors and has been taught for years, it's hard to understand how a professor would not know the curriculum. His lectures were useless, he claimed to be too busy to give us test practice/study materials, and was condescending when questions were asked.

To Dan's few supporters: as someone who took FOCS last year and mentored it this semester, FOCS is not an easy class but most students tend to get good grades. Many students are putting in tremendous effort only to be unfairly penalized by excessively difficult exams and lack of enough support, leaving them with outcomes they don't deserve.

rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Very good, took Strengths of Materials with this guy did a great job!!

This professor is, quite frankly, one of the worst educators I've ever encountered. The teaching style or lack thereof is abysmal—we're left to figure things out on our own. The grading is unfair, with no clear explanations for deduction. It's mind-boggling that someone who can't pass his own tests is tasked with teaching and grading us. womp womp
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: why yall remove that Chinese comment bro was spitting facts bring him back it was a goated response. free my man fr
Not a coincidence that the biggest Dan supporter (review below mine) is illiterate.

He tries to make lectures interesting,but his teaching leaves you confused. Labs complicated with almost no guidance help understand. Exams overloaded with hard questions. Barely curve! Posts in submitty about student concerns were deleted. He shows little consideration for students. He made mistakes in lecs and labs but sometimes blamed TA.

His class was one of the most difficult I have taken thus far, but this is partially because it is difficult material. He was more strict in grading at the beginning of the semester but a little more lenient afterward to help students' grades a bit. His lectures are a bit fast, but overall, they are okay since he posts them afterward.

You absolutely need to attend lectures if you want to keep up in this course. The material can be confusing without some sort of guidance and the lectures, while quick, are good enough for you to keep up. Would've appreciated more practice material beyond homework assignments.

Man, this was not a fun class. Ditursi did not do a great job at anything really - the lectures were way too fast, homeworks and labs were very challenging, and the tests were impossible to complete within the allotted time because of how many problems he put on there. I would strongly suggest taking focs with someone else if you can

If it gives you what to expect from Prof. Ditursi, regrade requests for most of the semester was something I didn't even bother to do because of the escalating risk they provided. Each bad regrade req after 1 bad one led to a 2 to the power of however many bad regrade requests you have done this semester point reduction.
Do not take.

You cannot learn anything if you don't attend the lecture although attendance isn't mandatory. I suggest the prof put more practice problems on slides so we can actually learn something. The test is hard and almost impossible to complete on time.
avoid at all costs, this man has no business being a professor considering his lack of consideration and support for students, i'm very disappointed that rpi chose to hire him of all people
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dan is a magician. He magically makes even the most simple of concepts seem complex, disappears from class to ref children's football, and won't pull a rabbit out of a hat but will pull some oblivious condescension out of his ass. He is a joke of a professor. -NaN/10

rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Oh where to begin with him. First off, he seems to be more invested with reffing kids games than creating practice problems for the singular class he currently teaches. You are basically flying blind during the tests but fear not, for he puts inspirational quotes on every page of the tests so maybe you can find a will to live as you cry over DFAs.

This is the first teacher I have ever seen who did not come to a lecture because he had to wait for a repairman before exam2. This may not be a very important thing, but it shows that the teacher does not care about his students. You can only get a bit help from the hw for the exam. The exam weights about 60%
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: After an insurmountable time studying, I definitely just failed the exam I just took. Talking to others, I am not close to the only one. Not only did he not print enough exams, but a mere handful of people actually managed to finish the exam before time was up. Of course, there will be no curve. Also managed to be passive aggressive during an exam!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: There is a lot that I could say, but I just took an exam that I would consider to be the nail in the coffin. Essentially no one finished - the exam room was full when the time ran out. He didn't print enough exams, so a huge group of people were left waiting for 20+ minutes after the time had started for their exam. Probably no curve...

If you listen to one of these ratings let it be this one. Avoid this professor at all cost, I don't like being mean but I personally wouldn't even call him one, He's very bad. He's a rough grader, even his TA's don't know what to do. He constantly makes mistakes in his own lecture in which in later lectures correct. He's also unavailable in OH.

I can't even tell you if attendance is mandatory because he actively punishes students for not attending lecture even though attendance is not part of the grade--in this, he completely fails to consider different that students might have different learning styles. He's given the entire class a headache; I can't even begin to describe him. Avoid.

He lectures with sanctimony and doesn't respond to students in OH/Class Forums in a professional or timely manner. Insists grades don't matter while allotting negative points on exam questions. He literally didn't attend the lecture prior to exam 2 or provide needed practice material (as he did on exam 1). His answer keys are frequency erroneous.

I just find it a shame. This class feels like hell. I feel as though the homeworks, what should be practice, are take home exams. The exams are terribly hard, and not only that, THEYRE AT 8 AM. The class feels like the hardest version of what it could be. This should be a 4000 level course and that's only due to Dan's horrible teaching style.

Fails to convey material clearly or explain, is rude to students when presented with genuine concerns about the course, gives one thing for homework and then something completely different on tests, and does not care enough to make himself accessible outside of class or at least give extra material to help students. Avoid this guy at all costs.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Ditursi represents the worst of going to tech school. He is pretentious, and masks his apathy with reminders of "caring for your mental health" while arguing with students with genuine concerns. He does not give sufficient material to study for his ruthless exams and has shown that we are not a priority to him compared to his little league games.

The only reason I have a semi-decent grade in this class is bc of Prof. Malik's youtube videos. Ditursi constantly posts materials late and lashes out at students on discussion forums. The TA's barely know what's going on as his answer keys never include the actual answer. I'm disappointed in RPI for hiring this joke of a professor.

It is now the end of the semester and he is trying to make up for his horrible teaching and lack of compassion for students by starting to give the materials that we have asked for and needed since the beginning of the semester. Don't fall for it though, he's only doing it for a desperate attempt to retain his job.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Worst professor at RPI. If you like to live a happy live ado not take this class with this guy. His tests are terrible, He isn't available at his office hours. and he's a tough grader. Take this class at a community college for your own sanity.

I feel cheated by RPI. This content seemed like it could have been interesting or at least useful if we hadnt been the guinea pigs with this incapable teacher. FOCS studying has been mental gymnastics to organize the mess Ditursi leaves in my mind after he has attempted to teach me. Hundreds of hours of studying for a grade much less than deserved.

answer keys are always wrong, labs are consistently harder than material done in class. professor comes across incredibly rude at times. this is on top of difficult tests with ambiguous wording for questions, where you need to argue with the professor over points lost over ambiguous wording. don't take ditursi if you value your grade or your sanity
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: As an ALAC tutor, Ditursi is awful. I took FOCS with Goldschmidt, and it was one of my favorite classes. Ditursi has lacked focus on classic FOCS content such as graphs, runtime, and NP-completeness. He grades incredibly harshly, with no partial credit for near-correct answers. Grading is inconsistent as he provides no answer keys for hw or labs.
BEWARE!! RUN WHILE YOU CAN

Whoever gave him the 4.0 is either trolling or a member of course staff to boost his rating. Nobody in their right mind would say that this guy has engaging lectures or is helpful in office hours, let alone even accessible at all outside of class. Save yourself from a semester-long migraine by avoiding any course this so-called professor teaches.

You're better off going to the crackheads downtown to learn the material that this guy "teaches". Lectures are useless, HW and exams have topics much harder than the ones presented in class, and the professor will not hesitate to show that he does not care about his students' or their understanding of the material. Somebody get him fired please!!!!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Everyone agrees with me when I say this is the worst professor at RPI. There's a 4.0 Rating from someone and it's very hard to believe that it's a student. There's an extremely high chance that the professor himself wrote it to increase his overall rating.
Not great at teaching and gives little to no partial credit.

Positives: His lectures are never boring in my opinion.

Negatives: He is pretty disorganized. Mentors are sometimes given incomplete answer keys. Exam grading is just inconsistent. Exams are a bit too long. Refuses to offer any kind of practice for exams, so you go in blind. Can be sassy in the forum. Will NOT acknowledge terrible class average.

Came in from Siena (shocker...) and completely changed the format and teachings of the course. Now mentors and TAs have no idea what's happening and can't help students. lectures and labs are confusing, and again, mentors and TAs are not even given answers to the labs or decent explanations. Professor is clearly having a power trip, avoid for GPA.
I'm in the thick of it.

His presentations shed no light on the content he tests us on. I am not convinced he understands the material. The sparse resources he gives us are ambiguous. Awful teacher that then gives us disproportionately hard tests considering his inability to teach. I put a lot of time into this course and he mentioned he doesn't care about our grades. wtf.

I am disappointed in the decision to hire Dan, IMMENSE waste of time. At RPI, I've earned mostly A's, and I've dedicated hundreds of hours to this class, only for him to undermine my effort with grades that don't reflect my understanding. He encouraged withdrawals (likely to lower his fail rate), and TAs say the content he provides is inaccurate.

First day of class I thought he was a funny professor. It was up until his sassy comments on Submitty, but to be fair some students were asking not so smart questions that did not need to be asked. His tests are hard but fair to an extent until he pulls a question you've never encountered before. AKA using pascals identity to prove something which.

Useless slides; not responsive and nearly unaccessible outside of the class; difficult labs, assignments and exams; the professor himself even make mistakes while giving the answers of the labs and assignments; offensive and ignore students' requests or questions sometimes.
This is the worst professor at RPI. Avoid him at all costs.

I go to every lecture and am engaged for a good majority of the time. However, the slides are terrible and unintuitive, as are his explanations. The exams are the worst part--he is not lenient and does not receive feedback well at all. Genuinely the worst prof I have had thus far. His course had me questioning my passion and decision to study CS.

DiTursi is regularly condescending and rude to students. His regrade policy takes off an exponentially increasing amount of points from exams if he decides it wasn't valid, all for "wasting [his] time." Entirely unprofessional and it is obscene that nothing is being done by administration regarding his position and habits.

Though the reviews here may sound critical, they're very much true. He gives NO extra practice to tests even when they are worth a large percentage of your grade. The examples discussed in lectures barely prepare you for the exam, hence their difficulty. Don't take him if you can.
Avoid him at all costs.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: An awful professor who does not cover the material well and looks annoyed and sarcastic when asked questions. Half the class is failing or close to failing, and he tells students not to worry about grades and just learn the material, but ironically, no one understands the material. Homework is as hard as exams, and exams are overly difficult.
He is a terrible professor.

He seems like he might be nice outside of acedemia… other than that he's got nothing. works only a few hours a week and does an insufficient job then. His minimal approach produces consistent incorrect answer keys, insufficient lecture notes and minimal study material. He pairs this with the hardest exams noting he doesn't care about grades.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Online Savvy

comment:
This guy probably shouldn't be a professor here:
- lecture examples are much easier than exams (steps and process aren't shown in slides at all)
- negative attitude towards helping students 
- TAs and mentors dislike him because he gives them no support and he gets half of the answer keys wrong (they have to fix them)
- seems like class is failing

- he puts 0 effort into the course
-- admits being too lazy to give us more practice
-- slacks on releasing notes
-- snarky comments to genuine questions
- he doesn't care if anyone fails or succeeds
-- gives negative points on exams if he believes it is too incorrect
-- exams are WAY harder than the practice material we are given (+no back exams)

DiTursi is the worst professor I' ever had. His lectures are unclear and lack explanation of concepts, his tests are unreasonably difficult, and he fails to show a care for students that's clear from his attitude towards them when asked for extra help. His grading system is brutal, and he refuses to come to fair terms with students on their grades.
He deserves to get tickled for what he have done.

Doesn't teach clearly or with any level of detail, gives RIGOROUS homeworks that don't reflect what is "taught" in lectures, tests are near IMPOSSIBLE, and gives NO partial credit or curves despite the OVERALL course average being almost FAILING. EXTREMELY rude when asked for any type of extra help with anything. DON'T TAKE ANY CLASS WITH HIM!!!!!!

The worst professor in history. Literally everyone is failing because his exams are impossible, and his lectures are completely useless. He's barely available during office hours since he's too busy refereeing kids' little league games. Don't take him if you value your GPA or sanity. Honestly, he should be fired immediately. Avoid at all costs!

Dr. DiTursi has been one of the worst professors I've ever had here at RPI. His lectures are awful for people who attend, and if you don't attend the slides are always not descriptive enough. He's an extremely tough grader on exams, either you get it or you don't. The average of the class is near failing yet he has nothing to say about it.

If I could give him a 0, I would but I can't on this website. He's not a good lecturer and does not explain concepts well. He is not a helpful professor, and even when the exam averages are 60s he refuses to curve. His tests are unreasonably hard. It is so demoralizing to keep studying and putting in work for his class when its not paying off.

Professor DiTursi has got to be one of the worst professors I've had. The class average is currently a failing score and he refuses to curve exams. Several students, including myself, have asked him for help and resources, and he told us that since he didn't study for exams in his undergrad, he could be of no help to us. If you can, don't take him.

He is a very bad professor. When we asked him about how to study for the class, he said (verbatim) that he was not the correct person to ask about this and that he had never studied for it as an undergrad. We asked him about online resources & he again said he couldn't help us. He gets answers wrong for homework and labs the TAs have to correct.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He is a tough professor who will forego study sessions for refereeing children's football. He doesn't post practice questions, doesn't review content, and if you ask him for help, he will essentially say it is a you problem. The only reason I got through this class was because of the incredible TA Eric. Take this class with someone else if you can.

Dr. Ditursi gets increasingly condescending, gives problems his own TAs can't solve, deletes forum posts or responds rudely, and was completely inconsiderate to students trying to cope with the death of a friend. The current class OVERALL average is almost failing. He is purposely unhelpful, VERY narcissistic, and WILL blame you for struggling.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Dan does not care. He misses his office hours, does the minimum and undermines his students. Some students including myself will study 40+ hours for his exam, attend all the lectures and still get a D. He can not teach if his life depended on it and your only hope is resources online or the TA's.

Dr. DiTursi is a great guy and I don't want to judge him bc he teaches a notorious course, his lectures are good but the slides are pm useless when studying. Exams are very rough, with the average grade being in the low 60s, and he didn't post a study guide or practice ?s after the first Exam. The lack of support on Exams is killer in my opinion.

Professor Malik made me excited to attend each lecture. He cares that students learn and frequently pauses the lecture briefly so that everyone can try to finish the calculation on their own and make sure they understand it. I love his chalk-on-blackboard style which is so much better paced and engaging than Powerpoint slides.
My pronouns are he, not him. Because I'll never be him.

One of the most amazing professors at RPI, his lectures are so enthusiastic and he knows what he is talking about.

He gives pep talks in class about how to do well in life and for our future, he really CARES about his students.

Professor Malik is an enthusiastic man with passion when teaching. I love his pre-recorded lecture as it teaches me so much and I can review things I don't understand immediately. The quizzes and tests are not that hard tbh; if you study hard on the homework you will get a good grade.

Prof. Malik teaches amazing lectures. You can feel his passion even it's on the screen. Personally, FOCS is a kinda easy class for me. The first half-semester is pretty easy and the second half is just a little challenging, especially about TM. The quizzes and the midterm are really easy except the final is a little hard.

Very knowledge teacher, he is trying very hard to make this hard course interesting. Feels rewarding if you do your work but its really really hard. You will learn a lot. Don't drop the course, I know you want to.

Professor Malik is a brilliant Professor, incredibly smart guy. The lectures are crystal clear and the concepts presented with no logical gaps and theory from the ground up. But when you ask Malik questions, he tries to stop the conversation instead of expand on them and it stifles more curious students who would benefit from conversation with him.
Great lectures and be prepared for hard tests
Exams are impossible and no curve despite a D- average
Really great lectures, super helpful and passionate, homeworks were hard but graded easy
rating_tags: Amazing lectures--Graded by few things--Get ready to read

comment: Good

He's definitely got the enthusiasm and he's pretty good at explaining certain concepts, but it's harder to understand his explanations for the harder concepts and he just throws really hard problems at you and expects you to not seek external help to solve those problems. I think he should provide more examples of where the concepts can be applied.

Malik is my favorite professor at RPI. The enthusiasm that he brought to FOCS despite it being online made me excited to attend the class every day. I genuinely cannot express how much of a pleasure it was to take a class taught by him. I highly, HIGHLY recommend taking FOCS or Machine Learning with him specifically. Those who don't are missing out

Professor Ismail is impressive. He gives amazing lectures and you can actually learn a lot from his lectures. His exams are kind of skills based but as long as you put effort in his homework, you should be fine.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Amazing lectures

comment: Phenomenal professor. Makes you really work to get the grade you want - but with lectures as engaging as he offers, if you put in the effort, you'll get a lot out of the class. I know I did.
Absolutely fantastic. FOCS is not an easy course under him, but you feel very rewarded when you do well. He clearly cares and puts effort into his teaching to make the content interesting.
don't cheat.

His lectures are decent, but the tests are kind of bad. It was basically a math class and a ton of points came from multiple choice questions that didn't have any partial credit. That being said, if you put in more work, it would probably be a solid choice.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Very good lecturer, and YOU WILL LEARN. He doesn't make it easy, though. In fact, he makes it hard. You'll really have to work for a decent grade.

Honestly, one of the best professors I've ever had at RPI. I have yet to see a professor as passionate as Professor Malik about the material he teaches. While this class will definitely make you work for the grade you get, it is a phenomenal learning experience and I hope to have Malik as a professor again.

His class was one of my favorites. His lectures are very specific and you can really tell he wants you to learn. If you're having trouble he is there for you and will make sure you leave happy. If you put in the work you will definitely see the fruits of your labor as he is a great professor. Also there is extra credit if you just go to class!

I took FOCS with Professor Malik, and he is extremely knowledgeable. He's very patient with students who don't understand and will take his time to walk through problems for them. He also uses easier problems as an example to help students understand the more difficult ones better. He is by far one of my favorite professors at RPI!

Dr. Malik is so funny, engaging, and passionate. When you ask a question, he makes sure to turn around and check that you're following. His quizzes are fair in my opinion, most questions are similar to back quizzes and all the homework assignments and such are relevant. Not to mention, he wrote his own textbook which he gives for free. Love him!
Good Prof

Grading scheme is awful and does not promote "trying." Exams are multiple choice with work being required, but no partial credit for this work. Homeworks are long and worth little. Your entire grade is pretty much determined by your answer on the few "hard" (non-gimmie) questions on each test. This has been my absolute worst experience at RPI.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Fantastic lecturer, one of the best I've ever seen. He has super high expectations, the class will be difficult. But you will learn a huge amount of material that is all very useful in CS. Malik is super intelligent and if you listen to him you will learn more in his off comments than in some other entire classes.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: One of the smartest professors in CS. Very challenging course and homework. It's not easy to understand everything, but at least I'll always remember some basic concepts in machine learning that would be very helpful if I'll use them one day.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Inspirational--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES

comment: Great guy, engaging lectures. Course is paced well, but a bit challenging.
TOUGH GRADER... NOT RESPECTFUL FOR STUDENTS

One of the best professors at RPI. He is a very good lecturer and is clear and easy to understand. His courses are not the easiest, but very much worth it. Very knowledgeable in his research field and is a funny guy.
The hardest course in RPI I've ever experienced. Got an A, which soaked up all my spare time last semester.
Mind-crushingly difficult professor. Dauntingly intelligent. Sometimes expects too much of students who learn slower than others.
Malik Magdon Ismail's CSCI 4100, Machine Learning, is by far the best course I have ever taken. It was an eye-opening experience, hard as hell, and enjoyable to take.
It's tough, but you can learn a lot from this course. Prepare yourself for the peculiar discrete math world.
knows what he's talking about
Excellent professor, but merciless in his homeworks. Helped write the book for his Machine Learning class.
His method of teaching is very effective. He is overall a good teacher.
Probably my most influential prof, actually challenges students. Uses real math in compsci courses which many profs in compsci don't. Very smart insanely good memory.
Went from teaching us cin and cout to file input, arrays, and sort in a week.  Definitely not a CS1 professor.

I am a CS who took CS1 with him. I ended up with a 106% grade in the class. For homework you choose a level of difficulty 1-5 and if you complete the level that you have choosen then you get that level*10 number of points. Most of the level 5s  required previous CS experience. Beware of Word Ladders. Grades were given on a full/half/none basis.

A note to anyone who reads his rating from here on out- he is not going to discuss how to solve all of the homework problems he gives you. But there is this funny aspect of Computer Science where the question is not what you know but what you can figure out. Thus, he is doing what he should. Get used to it.

Homework assignments were either very easy, or very difficult (or impossible; Malik assigned problems that have yet to be completely solved [NP problems]).  Lecture was useful, Lab was not.  Tests aren't bad if you know the material.  Known to confuse other professors on campus with his intellect.

Homework projects ranged from being too easy to absurdly hard. Ways to solve harder project questions were NOT discussed in lecture. Lectures were  very repetitive and downright useless by the end of the semester. Tests were fairly easy overall. I succeeded in the class (A-) by reading the book and Google searching the material for more examples.

Class was very difficult especially if you don't know programming before taking this course. Labs were easy and Projects not bad. Lots of opportunity for bonus points, but at some points I felt as though we were programming Google. Not a good teacher for a low level course, but he does know his stuff.

tough for an intro class, but if you apply yourself and think about the projects it's not as bad as some will say. he tests you with the projects and labs, as a result exams (provided you did the projects and labs) are much simpler. no half credit but bonus points galore, which helps make up for it. kept me entertained, funny guy, cool accent.
Class wasnt that hard, Pleanty of bonus points on every thing, it wasn't an easy A but atleast we learned something
wow, too hard of a class. I wish I knew how to program before I took this class...
Teaches way too fast...he doesn't teach in sync with the projects/labs. Class is funny though....

He doesn't quite know how to teach Comp Sci 1; he flies through the material and often what he's teaching doesn't sync up with the assignments he gives us (he teaches us how to do something after we have to do it). His grading policies are way too harsh for CS1: any mistake at all, no matter how minor, means half points. He's HILARIOUS though.

terrible professor. he is going way too fast and deep for comp sci 1. i have heard that this course was easy in the past. we passed comp sci 2 material within two weeks of class. his grading system is HORRIBLE. full, 1/2 or no credit... i fyou make one simple mistake you get HALF of the answer wrong!! doesn't teach most of the material on his exams

He treats the class like it were DSA which means really really hard but it's a lot better than the last csci 100 professor where the students didn't learn anything. I recommend Malik since he's a really good teacher.
too hard for just an intro to comp sci and c++

This is a very hard course, but keep up with all the practice problems and you should do fine.  Malik is an interesting person, I love it when he finishes explaining something and says "BOOM".  But yeah, the course is kinda hard.
if you can keep up with he's a good professor otherwise you're screwed
This is one person who can lecture and lecture and lecture, but you don't get sick of listening.  Was extremely clear; I could always follow him.
Good Lecturer but gives us the answers.  That's how learn.  I mean I'm not going to go to your office hours for every answer on the Final question Sheet.
Good lecturer, very tough grader. Not much of an accent.

Excellent lecturer. Very hard grading, but has available pool of test problems. Gave decent curve for the course grade, but it was certainly needed. One time, took off 7/50 points on project for not having something that wasn't asked for.

Abysmal professor. Projects were ludicrous, everyone failed the midterm. 1 of my friends was 1 of 4 people he gaves As to, and only because he memorized all the answers from the pool of final exam questions. Most people couldn't do them at home (incl. me)
It was all a game ! a very useful game.
He is able to explain the material so that i can have an understanding of what is going on but then he expects expertise almost immediately after
Impossibly hard course.  Malik obviously understands the material very well, but can't understand how to measure the difficulty of his own problems.
I've never considered killing myself, before taking this class.
Amazing professor, one of the best at RPI, and the best Comp Sci professor I've had to date.
Good Teacher, one of the best here.
Don't regret having him.  He is energetic and funny, not bad on grading.
Very good lecturer. HIs lectures are phun

Professor Foley is absolutely terrible. He is incredibly unorganized and is very unclear about assignments. He will grade extremely hard and will grade based off of rubrics that are not provided to the class at all. His lectures are barley even lectures and just turn into mindless rambling. Avoid at all costs.

Terrible professor. Doesn't understand the projects he assigns and then deducts points for things his pin head doesnt hear during your presentation. unaccountable and has a very surface level knowledge of all subjects. Attending his office hours is like trying to ask questions to a monkey.

He was not a great lecturer, I never paid attention to the lectures. You have to read the textbook. The most useful thing was his workbook problem videos. I spent most of my time with the TA, who was great. Lots of homework, but test are mostly what's graded. Tests are not super similar to homework. You have to go to lectures to turn in CPE.
Just no. It gets extremely frustrating especially when you take his course not knowing the way he teaches

Prof. Foley is a pretty boring lecturer. Material can be learned straight out of the book and isnt too hard. A lot of busy work and one homework assignment per week. Make sure you use ExcelOM to save yourself a bunch of time on the work. Exams are open book, notes, laptop.

He is not a good professor. But if you watch all of the video's he posts before exams, and make sure you submit all of the class exercises and all of the homework you'll do decent in the class. Avoid him if possible, but you know what you're getting when you take a class with him.

Foley was a decent professor for IED. He graded fairly and was helpful in the lab when working on our main project. He has a strange sense of humor and tries his best to keep his lectures interesting. Overall not a bad choice for IED.

Always talking about something interesting, he is super knowledgeable. But he doesn't really teach much. Stopped going to lectures because even if I went I had to read through the online material to learn anyways. Not a tough class though. Great guy, just a lot of homework. If you do what you're supposed to do you'll get like a B+

He will make you work for your grade. You are drilled with work after work. So, if you slack off for half a week, you'll be behind. He is accessible outside of class. Still a reasonable professor, expects a lot from you, and will keep you on your toes with work. You'll definitely come out learning something.

DON'T DON'T DON'T TAKE HIS CLASS UNLESS YOU WANT TO CHALLENGE YOURSELF REALLY BAD. HE MIGHT KNOW WHAT HE IS DOING, HE MIGHT NOT. NO MATTER WHAT, HE DOESN'T MAKE SENSE IN THE CLASS AND IS NOT A VERY NICE PROFESSOR TO STUDENTS. I TOOK IED AND OR FROM HIM. BOTH WERE AWEFUL EXPERIENCES:(
The only reason I did alright was because of the textbook.  Awful professor but if you are an IME, there is no way to avoid him.  Good luck!

He doesn't grade fairly nor does he offer help. He goes on tangents throughout all of class on topics that have no relevance to the course. He does not go through example problems and his lecture slides are not helpful when studying.  His exams are way too difficult because he does not teach clearly enough. Take MAU with a different professor.

Maybe people at RPI are just used to bad professors.  I can't comprehend why anyone would rate him highly.  This man is the worst educator I have ever encountered in my entire life.  Every negative comment I've read about him has been far more accurate than the positives.  Avoid this man at all costs.  His arrogance is only matched by his ignorance
Useless with any help at all
Rants a lot during class, somewhat tough grader. A little awkward, laughs at his own jokes. Pushes you really hard to do well.

he is a really bad teacher who doesnt know anything and pretend that he is the smartest person in the whole world. he doesn't care about his students and talk about his stupid cars all the time which are like bmw 1 series and Volkswagen beetle...

At first I though he was unreasonably hard.  He is a really good guy and will push you beyond your comfort zone.  As long as he sees that you go don't just do the minimum you will do very well in his classes.  Very strange sense of humor and funny laugh.  Ended up being one of my best experiences with a professor.

Very difficult, grades favorites higher. Tries to push you beyond your goal. Sleeps and eats sandwiches. You must talk to him and show him that your doing work otherwise you will not do well. your project must show engineering process otherwise you will do poorly. Our project worked but he didnt like how it looked gave us a D-.

Relates course material to real life situations on a regular basis.  Willing to help you outside of class during office hours or through e-mail if it is obvious that you made an effort to find the answer on your own. Any bad reviews about this professor are from people upset that they couldn't find back tests to cheat off.

Girls - get ready for him to hit on you in a weird, old guy fashion. Guys - try to refrain yourself from punching him in the face whenever he's the only one maniacally laughing at his own jokes... He's more interested in himself than the class. Get another professor if possible.

He often went on rants in the middle of class.  His test are very hard, but he will help you if you ask.  If you put in the work you'll be fine.  Stick with him though.  Don't just give up on the first test if you do badly.

Worthless. Claims students are getting dumber by the year, yet has no regard to his own substandard teaching. Has no interest in helping students understand the material. Worst professor I have ever had.

Nice guy. Doesn't go out of his way to help students at all. Has barely anything on LMS; no practice problems or backtests. Worst thing about him is the lack of answers on the in class problems. How am I supposed to know if I'm right? Useless.

Great professor.  He is a bit full of himself, but if you go out of your way and do crazy interesting things, he will reward you for it.  He says it's all about the process, and it truly is - if you fail, but your process succeeds, then you will get a decent grade.

He is awful to have for a professor. He doesn't know how to teach and all he does is read slides for 2 hours. He does not grade fairly and he is useless in office hours. He thinks he knows everything. If you are a good looking girl however, be sure to be aware he will be rather creepy towards you but will give you good grades based on likes.
Great Professor in my opinion. Does go off topic some times but he is easy to understand and has been a really fun professor. He is very knowlegable in economics and project mangment.

procrastinators beware..his homeworks can take hours if you want 90+ and are usually due the same day as  tests, he offers flexibilty on tests, has really high standards for his students, insightful but sometimes rather boastful of his ego which can/will get annoying

Foley is one of those professors that makes sure you know he's a Ph.D and PE at every possibility by flaunting his credentials to secure his superiority over his students.  Shame he doesn't spend more time trying to teach design instead, or the class might not have come down to a last ditch effort to find something that impresses him to get an A.

Ok professor.  If he likes you, you'll prolly get an A.  Can go off onto some weird tangents when us tart talking to him.  He's very knowledgeable though.  Sometimes i get the impression that he doesn't care about students, like he's sometimes  short with me when I go to see him in his office to ask a few questions, but that just be the way he is.

The guy's kind of a pain in the ass.  But he does know what he's talking about (most of the time).  The class really isn't engineering design, it's "make the project that pleases foley the most" design.
Totally self absorbed.  Likes to talk and waste your group's building time with theory that's not applicable at all.  Take any other IED professor over him.

Homeworks were hard but very helpful in preparing for the tests. Tests were fair and the material on the tests was exactly what he taught. Interesting lectures even if it was 8am. You could get help always if you wanted by going to the office hours.

Homeworks were byfar the hardest part of the class.Homework questions would be very involved, while the tests were as simple as possible.There was never any "catch" on the tests; everything came straight from back tests or the book and the tests were open book/open notes.Lectures fairly interesting.

If you do the assigned work in his class, Foley will respect you and give you an A. Everyone that hates him probably did a****ty job on their notebook and such and thus got ripped apart by Foleys grading.  He is knowledgable in many respects, and is a very nice guy. Is vague about due dates however

Falls alseep and doesn't appear to pay much attention during presentations.  His lectures are somewhat scattered.  Is vague with instructions, doesn't always answer questions clearly.  Not that bad though, could be a lot worse.

This man is very unhelpful in class, and has an awesome tendancy to fall asleep during presentations. Stpent most of the class eating turkey sandwiches instead of doing something productive. Don't take IED from this man.
all around bad experience...he wasn't helpfull and at the end of the IED he still didn't know anyone's name.  Try to get any other professor for this class.

Foley is an absolute idiot.  He doesn't know his left elbow from an Op-Amp.  Teaches erroneous information, useless information, and denies class discusion in a course where it is a must.  He has the worst jokes on the planet, and he is the only one actually laughing, very annoying.  Horrendous!
he may be crazy, but he's all around a nice guy. easy class too :)
IDIOT.  the man is only concerned w/ himself.
