Very unhelpful especially to EE's and has a very vague grading system. Didnt find helpful at all
No Comments

Although vauge and mean at the front of the room, if you talk to him individually you see just what it is that he's after.  He sees more ability in you than he lets on and pushes you to it.  Great for that and cares about his students and their work.
No Comments

Has no ability to describe what he wants. IED is a very difficult course to start with, when you have no idea what he wants or when, the course becomes impossible. Assignments and project requirements are given roughly 2 day before they are due. Horrible.
seems a little strict and unusual at first but if you take the time to get to know him he's actually not such a bad guy
Vague about what he wants, I was confused even after going to office hours. He does seem to care about students however
No Comments
Prof. takes too long to respond to emails.  Very vague project requirements.  Students must rely on themselves.
he definately puts you in your place. frank and straightforward...great teach.
horrible.

had him 3 times... hated him at first. but ask him for help or just go talk to him for a bit. he's actually a good guy and really does care about his students. he definitely makes you do better than you ever thought you could. he really helped me a lot.
this man truly IS evil
Seemed questionable at first but eventually proved to be a good teacher.  Very helpful, really cares.

Failed me on a loophole clause in the syllubus, the next time I took the course the syllubus was changed to fit the situation.  Actually had the **** to tell me I needed therapy without any grounds.  Inconsistent and has no practical experience
No Comments

implimentation of the team based groups was a total waste of effort on our part.  Not a single  ball-testing-machine  became what could even remotely resemble a functioning product.  Foley did nothing to help up work together.
Again, he's very rought on your ego... but it's well worth it when you look back at the end.  He makes you do more than you think you could.
he was SO mean at the beginning but it turned out to be the best thing because our project rocked in the end... and mostly because he was so critical to begin with
talk to him face to face, you'll thank yourself for it
Felt like I was in kindergarten during his Wednesday IED lectures
No Comments
He gave great advice on our project, and was genuinely excited about the class.
No Comments
what a class... but Foley is a terrific instructor.

Whoever says that he is difficult to understand is crazy; he has an accent but is very clear. The subject matter is pretty fun, and while I can't say I know that it will be impactful in my career, it was interesting. If you attend lectures the homework should be easy. And if you do the homework the exams should be easy.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: Honestly, his lectures are useless & incomprehensible, and same with his slides. But, the course material isn't too difficult, so you can teach yourself. Also the back exams make getting good exam scores fairly alright. Don't bother with lecture at all, and be prepared to learn by yourself. I suggest Haskell over Oz and Erlang over SALSA. Good luck
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: Avoid this class at all costs if you can. Most content consists of "languages" he either made up and imposes on you as a student from his own textbook. Because of this content and documentation is hard to learn and almost non existent. SALSA, Oz, and AMST are used quite a bit and outside this class seem to not exist.

Lectures are recorded but the lectures are very confusing and boring. You have a better chance of understanding the material by studying by yourself. Grades are based on only 3 hws and 3 exams. If it's not required, don't take this course because the material is useless. Learn lambda calculus on your own time if you want.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Exams and homeworks are quite doable, but the class itself is just awful. I don't feel like I'm actually learning anything. Never going near any of this material again.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Cannot understand what he's saying, confusing lectures
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Very difficult but insightful course
rating_tags: Group projects--Amazing lectures --Graded by few things

comment: I do not know what he is saying

Be prepared to study by yourself. The other prof who teaches on even years does better than he does (just a little better tho). There are 3 exams and 3 HWs where the lowest will count as 10% and the other two count as 20% each. I would go with Haskell, Erlang, and Prolog. Salsa will drive you crazy! Good luck if you plan to take PL with him......

This class is great if you want to learn about the most irrelevant information that you will never use outside of class. No company will use it. He teaches Salsa which no one on Earth besides him uses, and the documentation sucks beyond belief. I could not deal with lectures because they are so boring and confusing. It's a **** show. Good luck.

In a class with almost 300 people registered, it is nearly empty every class session. The lectures are boring and near impossible to follow. Most of my learning from this class was from watching youtube videos on each language. There are 3 homeworks and 3 tests which sucks. Can't write everything here, but this is the worst class I have ever taken.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: You would get a better lecture by going downtown and asking the local crackheads to read the slides for you. He cannot teach, his content is horrible, he doesnt bother to understand the difficulties of students, and he uses lms instead of submitty. I am convinced that he actually just hates his students. Salsa.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: This is the worst class I have taken in my 21 years of life. I would give him a zero if it was possible. His lectures are so uninspiringly boring that my only regret is that I could only skip them once. He has poop diagrams, his examples are terrible so you cannot understand what is going on. I would bash him longer but there is a 350 character lim
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: by far the worst class I have ever taken at RPI.

salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa salsa
His class is hard to get help in. The TAs don't help and if they help they can be wrong, and he doesn't care and says its still your fault for being wrong. He also will not help.
Does not put in any effort into his class.

Be ready to be self-taught! He does not provide help in class or outside. The TAs are also very unhelpful and couldn't fix my code once during the semester. A TA once told me how to do my code so I did it that way and they said it looked good and got a 50 on it bc another TA said it was wrong and the professor said never trust the TAs...

He needs to give more hands-on examples to help w/ understanding of semantics before moving to new stuff. Bad course grading scheme w/ only 3 HWs. Grading method sometimes differed from rubric given on hw handout. Got an A, but can guarantee I don't know the material better than the average student who got a B-. Doing well just came down to luck :(

Worst professor I've ever had. His lectures were borderline boring and disgustingly confusing, so much so that I completely gave up on attending. Prog Lang in of itself is a joke class that puts you through hell even when it has zero implications for the future. The idea of 3 HWs and 3 exams combined with a ridiculous professor  absurd
Horrible professor. He won't help you with anything, especially hw. He said it's not the TAs job to get your code to work, nor is it his to help with HW. Avoid at all costs
Very dismissive when you need help.

Varela's lectures were such a pain to sit through. The most important lectures were saved for the last couple of weeks, with the exception of unit testing. Though I was lucky enough to have known the class material ahead of time, I can guarantee you that a good chunk of our class doesn't know how to properly apply design patterns. It's laughable.

Lectures were dull and some slides contained false information. Coursework was from another professor in a different school. Homeworks were interesting, but vague. Tests had material that was not covered or emphasized in class or lectures. Waited hours for help in office hours. He knows the material well, and is understanding of peer difficulties.

Not very accessible and although the homeworks were not terrible but still questionable, his exams were awful. Exams consisted of coding and many multiple choice/true or false questions that were very unclear. Furthermore, he allowed us to use class powerpoints but would later say these powerpoints had incorrect information. Very badly run class.

Although its his first time teaching this class, Prof. Varela is very good at explaining the materials. Exams are fair. Homework takes quite a while but as long as you put in your effort its a grade booster.

If you ignore the fact that he has compounding homeworks, gives brutal exams, blames students for his mistakes, doesn't give out answer keys, steals course materials from UW, does not respond to discussion posts, and that he seems to show disdain for his students, he's a pretty decent professor.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Terrible prof. Course content was taken from UDub; he barely knew the slides. Exams were awful, featuring ?s with 40+ T/F options about stuff we never covered & trick questions given to random students. Refused to provide answer key after tests, making it hard to contest the incorrect grading. He seems to have absolute contempt for students.

Went out of my way to make an account just to give a 1 star. Class is genuinely the most awful class I have ever taken. Boring lectures & homework. I would be able to look past this if the tests were not so excruciatingly awful. Bad questions w/ rigid grading, sudden changes mid test no one knew about, questions covering topics we barely went over.

First professor that made me consider switching majors, the homeworks are tediously long and almost half of them build off the previous one so if you mess up on the first one, it just gets worse. Tests are also absurdly long filled with 15 choice MC questions and the homework grading scheme is super unforgiving, it's all or nothing

The information given in lectures was often contradictory. 90% of it was taken from another school's courses from 10 years ago. The tests covered material we had never covered. The homework built on each other and was very vague. If you designed the first homework wrong you will fail the rest.

this class is the worst. i highly recommend avoiding him if you can. boring, bad at teaching, unclear homework directions that take a long time to complete, exams are impossible (in terms of finishing within time given and they don't test you on material from lecture) i hate this class
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: Bad

HW are copied from other school. Hard and wired. He is professional in his field but he is not a good teacher. He doesn't know how to teach. He copied other schools' hw. In the hw it asked us to write reflection. But the thing is, nobody's ever care about our reflection. Everything just keep going like usual.

Professor Varela's PSoft course is terrible compared to the courses I've taken with other professors in the CS department. His homework assignments are cumulative, so don't miss a thing. He is poor at explaining concepts, lectures are impossibly dull, and exams are too long. Do not waste your time with Varela, I've already made that mistake.

Prof. Varela is the only professor that has ever made me consider dropping my CS major to avoid his PSoft and his ProgLang courses. He is very technically knowledgable in his fields but he cannot teach nor coordinate a course to save his life. Long-winded and repetitive lectures, circuitous homework specs, impossible exams, and requiring Dafny.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: This class was literally so painful. I have never hated a class at this school until I took this one. I can't completely blame prof varela for this because he is a nice guy but he was definitely very unclear at times and not great at explaining. Homeworks were not the easiest. Exams were extremely difficult and way too long for the time alotted.

The homeworks were alright and you just need to follow the instructions, but some documents can be long. The exams are what really irk me as they assess things that were never covered in lectures, and trick questions and inconsistent grading are common as well. I really think he should summarize things better, be it the homeworks or lecture notes.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Varela was kind and understanding when I struggled, but the class was a nightmare. The only material you have to study are the slides he presents, and they sometimes contain incorrect material. The tests often have trick questions and material that was never covered in class, and you have nothing else to study from. Don't take this class.

Homeworks are easy enough. Documentation is bad, though. Spent more time figuring out what they wanted than actually doing the work. Tests are absurd. Material is not covered in class, and then is graded incorrectly - given 0 points for correct answers. The class test average was a D-, and no answer key was released.

I feel bad for his TAs. He doesn't use his own lecture content, and seems surprised by each new slide (basically just reads off them and ad-libs). Assesses on things we weren't taught (you can rewatch lectures mid-test, so I'm sure of this), doesn't notify about lecture cancellations or exams, and pushes everything onto the TAs.
Professor Varela clearly cares about teaching and his students. He is very accessible to help before, during, & after class. I found his lectures very clear and interesting.

All I want to say is Prof Varela works really hard to improve the course. The class is in much better shape when I took it the second time(dropped it the first time). He might not be a fantastic lecturer, but he is a very respectable professor.

I have to say, he does want to be a good teacher. That being said, he's not.  I got an A, but looking back, I didn't learn anything from his class. I don't think professors have to take any classes on how to teach, but he should.

Awful. Awful. Other students warned me not to take his class. I should have listened. Grading is comically inconsistent. He could barely explain the material, which was poorly chosen to begin with. He was NEVER prepared and can barely use a computer. Seriously, he has had a significant negative impact on my education and my respect for RPI.

He's extremely enthusiastic, he finds a way to challenge you so you will reach your full potential. Do not take his class if you're not willing to learn and work hard. This guy will make hell look like a walk in the park but will reward good efforts.

Absolutely horrible. Insisted on using poorly documented languages (including one he wrote). Promised at the beginning of semester that no one who tried would fail, then kept to a conventional grading scheme. Avoid Varela at all costs.

For proglang. Common phrase, but take this with sincerity: Varela is the worst teacher that I've ever had. Approx 70% class eventually dropped. HWs take _all_ of your time. Varela acknowledges this. Only way to pin him down is in class or department mandatory office hours (phone is no help). Hung bell curve at low C on remaining 30% of class. GL

The fact is ProgLang is a very difficult course. However, people only really have trouble with it because no other course demands so much of the people in it at times. Granted he doesn't teach it extraordinarily well; how would anyone else teach it better? If you ask for help he'll give it and if you do well he'll recommend you for any grad school.

The class was ridiculous! I would understand all the inclass material, but the projects and tests had little to NO relation to the lectures. He makes students learn a language he wrote! Salsa was written by him, NOT documented by him, and used by..... JUST HIM!!! Out of the 135 people that started the class, 17 kids were at the final! no real curve
lectures with running examples to follow material, hard exams and homeworks but reasonable curves, knows the material very well, tough at times but you will learn alot in this class

he means well, but is a strong believer in the philosophy of teaching that "no student should ever be bored" - which means that quite a few students get completely lost - timing structure of the class stinks, projects which tend to make you learn the formalities instead of theoeretical things - only good aspect was curve (79,60,45,29 this semester)

Absolutely terrible professor.  Lectures are not useful, tests and projects are not about the same material.  Refuses to give out enough practice material for exams and what little he does refuses to give out the solutions to.  It took me over a month to even determine what the class was about.
quite possibly the worst professor i have ever had.  taught things in a most illogical order and, rarely supplemented the text, and his own lectures slides, with examples.
proglanging langing prog proglanging... ha ha ha . you betcha taking varelas class will make you a lot crazier than me!
Undoubtedly the worst professor I've ever had.

Single handedly ruined my GPA!! teaches you the concepts the day the projects are due and assigns projects in alpha-release software languages (no documentation for those languages either!!! have to figure everything out yourself)
varela isnt really that bad. he wants to help you but i think he just doesnt know how to .
varela sucks period. He almost managed to destroy my gpa. but i was lucky.
he is a horrid professor that will make you use alpha-release software for your projects. you have been warned.

varela is single handedly the worst professor at RPI. he doesnt know how to teach and gives ridiculously hard and time consuming homeworks. If you are thinking of taking prog langs with him...think again.
BEFORE YOU TAKE CARLOS VARELAS MAKE SURE YOU TIE A ROCK TO YOUR HEAD AND JUMP IN A RIVER!! YOU WILL RECEIVE A MUCH BETTER FATE!!
He is terrible!  Single handedly destroyed my GPA!!!

Language barriers aside; he is the single worst professor I have encountered at RPI.    I can only hope his teachin ability will improve, and he will invest a lot of effort in revising his lesson plan and teaching methods.
He doesn't explain well in class, always waste time getting his computer up. He's not willing to answer students' questions, and he expects his students to be genius.

A great teacher.  His philosophy: make the work and material difficult to challenge top students then curve the class.  He usually knows what he's talking about and is very energetic, which is great.  Many people dislike his methods, especially projects.
Martin Hardwick is a very nice professor. very patient and kind. I took database system with him

To say Martin Hardwick is a real gem is an understatement. Not only does he read off of LaPre's slides and use past homeworks, but he also plays Shrek Spooky Stories in the middle of lecture when he gets bored. Labs can be done 1 hour before class starts and quizzes are similar to back tests. If your schedule is rough Martin Hardwick is a must.
Be prepared, this is a meme class.... And make sure show respect to Prof Gold schemit

Database systems is a decent class if you have no experience with mySQL. Lectures are pretty boring and generally not worth attending. The grading for quizzes and homeworks is brutally easy. Free A as long as you do the homeworks and quizzes/exams (you don't even have to do them right. Just write something down and get an A)
Literally read power point from start to end

He is clear and straight forward in his lectures, while being interested and knowledgeable in the subject. Additionally he is willing and ready to answer specific questions about subject matter, and even listens to reasonable requests for grade reviews.
I WANT MARTIN HARDWICK TO TEACH ALL MY CLASSES.

If there's no quiz, don't go to class unless you have a beverage of choice. If you do, drink every time his code doesn't compile. Finish your drink if it compiles on the first time(it never does)...All kidding aside, useless professor, with no knowledge of the subject. If you have good TA's you can be ok...
Not worth going to class

Professor Hardwick has been an inspiration for me. I never realized that being a professor was so easy:Missing semicolons whenever you please; having students debug your software in class; making the TAs do everything for you; strutting around the lecture hall, basking in the admiration of freshmen. I strive to follow in his footsteps of greatness.
Although I found the gist of the course to be less than satisfactory, there's something to be said of Hardwick and his alluring British accent."

After going to lectures I knew I would never be able to program. After looking hopelessly at my program that wont compile because it is missing a semicolon, I would frequently debate suicide. Then I would look up and see Haawwwwdwick and instead debate pick up lines. :-D
Bad with technology, often includes coding mistakes into lecture (not on purpose). Not helpful for coding or using as a code reference.
The lectures were practically useless. If you don't have programming experience prior to taking this class, you are in for a tough time.
Seriously cannot teach. He can't even compile a program correctly. His class is a relatively easy A if you memorize the quizzes from the internet early though.

This dude seems like he has no idea what he's doing sometimes. Really awful class. Luckily I took programming before this, otherwise I'd be completely lost. I feel like I didn't get any solid learning from this class.
If you haven't programmed before, this class is awful. It's definitely tailored to people who have had experience programming.
I learned nothing from his class and now I am no longer interested in Computer systems engineering! way to crush my hopes and dreams!

He expects beginning programmers to complete between intermediate to hard programming after giving you little to no information during his useless lectures. Evey time he has built a program in front of the class, it has come up with hundreds of errors, and it's usually the class who tells him whats wrong.

For someone who was never exposed to C++ before this class, you're in for a living hell. The man cannot teach for his life, and when coupled with his assumptions that you already know what he's teacher, be prepared to receive a lot of low grades. If you're lucky youll get a helpful TA, but most times, they help you just as much as him: very little.
Worst professor/teacher I've ever had. This guy doesn't even know what hes talking about, much less how to teach others what he's trying to talk about.

Professor Hardwick was a decent professor.  His lectures were ok and not mandatory (labs are), not great.  Some students would be able to skip lectures and do fine.  I had never had any programming experience and ended up with an A- due to a generous curve.  I think that there are better CS I professors, but Hardwick really is not a bad professor.

Lectures are pointless. I just got more confused by going. He post all the lectures so just read over them before the lab. Just show up for quizzes and do the homework's and you should get at least a B

Hardwick is the worst comp sci professor I've ever seen. He teaches kids WRONG. He will literaly tell you incorrect information which then has to be corrected by the comp sci II professors. If I didn't already know how to program before taking his class I would have failed.

Have you ever googled him?  He clearly knows what he is talking about, and if he seems distracted it's because he has a million things to think about.  Although he was a hard grader, if you go in and talk to him he will always help you out.  I hope I can get a job for him one day.

Ok, I wanted to learn Programming, so I took CompSci 1.  I had no prior experience before I took this class.  He was the worst teacher I ever had. I never knew what I was doing, I was un-confident beyond belief.  It was torture not knowing what to do half of the time.  If he's your teacher make sure you have some experiance or your screwed.

Hardwickfails horridly as a programmer, especially since he teaches the introductory level course.  On the very first day, he told students to always use double over floating-point because "Computers have so much memory now it doesn't matter anyway."  Yes, that's true, but you don't say that to kids who have never seen code before...
He taught us off Wikipedia! Half the time his programs don't work, he is incomprehensible and he doesn't really make me interested in the class. Just read the textbook and show up for the quizzes.

Albeit he is easy to understand and not a ridiculous grader, he is unenthusiastic about his class and often has bugs in his examples which he makes up on the spot.  The saving grace of the class is the TA's because I learned almost nothing from the lectures.

Absolutely fantastic teacher. One of the best professors I have ever and will ever have. Explains everything with perfect clarity and really cares about his students. Shows up 30 minutes early to lecture to help students out and stays a little late too. He will always answer your questions. I've learned so much from him. Oh **** a compiler error.

Hardwick is an "ehh" teacher. He basically goes through the PowerPoints"." He gives a quiz once a week, but he gives past quizzes to study from. The homeworks are a pain, but he usually goes over them in class. You learn material in labs. Take course at a Community College if not major
SO many typos! Not a bad teacher if you have some idea of what he's talking about, but generally not too clear for people with no background. Interesting labs - good TA's made it nice for me.
I've been told that if you actually go to his office hours, he is helpful, but I more of relied on my TAs for help. His notes are typically right, but watch his code, he has poor spelling.

Good professor, interesting British accent ;p Prior knowledge helps with labs and HW (more of a refresher because Comp Sci 2 was too big a leap imo). Labs can be done if you just look at the lecture notes for code and adjust it a bit. If you go to lectures, he sometimes codes most of the hw for you...the rest you can ask a TA (mine was v. helpful).

Not recommended for beginners.  Only a couple weeks in, it's pretty easy to identify those with prior experience in C++ and those who are totally new. Those who say his class is "easy" have likely already taken courses in high school, so don't be misled. Grades are curved at the end, but you might have a weak foundation for subsequent CS courses.

Honestly, I've never had to post a comment like this about a teach or professor, but this guy should not be teaching CS1.  He really has no clue what he's saying half the time, and makes more typos in his code than anyone I know.  He confused most my friends... I'm glad I took CPP programming in HS before CS1 or I would have HATED this class.

not a very good teacher.  i didn't feel like he really understood the material.  his assignments were confusing and contradictory, and half of the labs were based on material we hadn't learned yet.  there were also not enough TAs for the labs.  i only had one, and if you had a question you had to sit there for 20-45 minutes with your hand up
OMG did he not know what he was doing. I learned everything by buying a textbook and going to labs. And there were not enough TAs in all the sections. Bloody awful course.
Doesn't even know what he's teaching at this point and expects us to be able to complete the labs. Not that great. If you can skip having a class with him - do it.
He DOES NOT care if the students learn the material or not.  Refused to post past quiz solutions for students to see.  He gets a -10 for effort as a professor.
Moody, bored and boring. Uninterested in students' learning. Overall a horrible classroom experience. Only plus, looks humble and tries to improve from time to time.
Very easy class.  Lectures are not required, but I went cause I felt bad for the guy.  Class is a joke.

The lectures *are* pointless, but he'll make announcements that you won't want to miss. He knows what he's doing, and his accent or whatever it is rocks. Don't bother emailing him with a question, he uses some kind of computer system to answer you without reading it. Email your T.A. instead.
Course is structured very well, and it is easy to obtain an A if you do the work.  No need to go to lecture.
no point in going to lecture, he just reads the slides...if you want to do well, read them at home and do the stuff on your own

he's really superb.altho he cant run some of his program he's really cool..he sang "old mcdonald" while teaching the course..pretty hillarious..hoho..but the course seem easy tho..if u r a begginer, dont hesitate to join his class..
This course was very easy and I liked it. He was an understanding professor.

OK professor, but does not test on the most relavent material.  Needs to get his head out of his ass when it comes to answers.  He will not give you credit if its not exactly what he's looking for.  Wont give you an A if you have an 89.999999999999
Don't go to lecture, he just reads the slides (which are online) and then fails at running a program.  Labs are very easy, but if you want to actually learn stuff you need to do it on your own

I can relate with all these other comments. I had him 3 years ago and he read off slides and produced broken programs. I failed cs2 the first time because I didn't learn anything in this class... and I got an A in it! There are much better professors who actually know the language they are teaching.

HOW THE HELL CAN I LEARN WHEN THE PROFESSOR DOESN'T KNOW WHAT THE HELL HE'S DOING????????  Possibly the worst professor ever.  He reads off a powerpoint that he didn't even make himself.  And then he loads the program and it crashes and the kids help him fix it.  What an idiot.
I couldn't understand him, his "r" sound was more like that of a "w." Lectures were hard to pay attention to. Tests and labs were easy.
online lectures are key

I learned NOTHING in this class...absolutely nothing...I passed with just memorizing stuff for exams.  Not a very understand professor either, not willing to help students out.  During class he would have trouble debugging his own code
very easy course. don't take it if you want to learn something.
easiest class ever. never went to lecture. he put me right to sleep. i wouldn't get him again, i'd be scared of dying of boredom
I just love when he screws up the programs.  Without his errors, (not the ones he does on purpose) the class would be over in a half hour.  Thank God the lectures are on WebCT!
Boring as hell and circles things constantly on powerpoint. However lectures can be avoided entirely as all the powerpoint is posted online. Studios are cake and never take more than half an hour.

He doesn't really seem to understand programming himself, some exams can be tricky and he's a big ****. Tends to not know what he's looking for on homework/exams and so there are corrections frequently. All in all not a horrible guy, just not too clear.
Pretty easy if you put in some effort.  Tests are straightforward and easy if you study.
No Comments
It's easy to deal with his british accent by not going to lecture.  Studios can be cake if you pay attention.  Tests are easier even.
It depends on how much into com sci you are. His lectures are designed for ppl who know what programming is already. But he's easy to understand and he's very helpful if you have any questions.
This class was easy...with a moo moo here, and a moo moo there

Taking MATH 4090 from him online. He doesn't reply to student emails. None of my classmates know about their grades 3 months into the semester and no feedback on assignment. Homework expects you to apply definitions, which he doesn't teach you in lectures. This class is also latex heavy but he doesn't teach how to use latex either.

Doesn't share lecture recordings, answer emails or give back any grades whatsoever. Nobody knows how they're doing in the class at this point. He's a nice guy and cares about the topic, but an awful professor. Wish he would use a textbook because his teaching is incomprehensible. (He's also my advisor and has never, in 3 years, answered an email)
He Speaks of his notes rather than showing the student how to complete the work. the TA help more than him.

Professor McLaughlin is super passionate about math and truly cares about his students. Homework optional (test questions pulled from HW), quizzes are extra credit (can only help you), notes given in class. Not hard to do well if you go through the problems and see him for help. Also, get to know him in office hours. He is a great guy all around.

Prof. McLaughlin loves math; his lectures, lecture notes, and textbook are all filled with intricate math theory. If you are more interested in the practitioner's perspective, it can be hard to decipher the often unnecessarily complex mathematical justifications. His tests are completely based on the worksheets, so it's easy A.

One of the best professors at RPI. Lectures are fantastic and McLaughlin is charming. Even if you don't go to lectures, you can read his thorough and easily understood lecture notes that he sells for $25 at Market Block Bookstore (he claims that he usually doesn't profit off of them). He is very caring about his students. His class was a privilege.

I like to call him "Grandpa Calculus." His lectures are thought-provoking, and they often lead to discussions which help his students to understand the material. I think this name suits him because he is a great calculus teacher, whom I feel truly cares about his students. He doesn't want you to just know things, but he encourages you to think!
Mclaughlin seriously cares about his students. Make an effort to go to class, study, ask questions, and visit him in office hours. He wants you to pass, and it's easy to do so.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Very intelligent Mathematician, and good professor.  His notation threw me off my first semester freshman year in Calc II, and I quickly found that I learned the material better on my own simply reading his excellent provided lecture notes.  Go to class for the first while, then you can stop going if you read the notes and do the worksheets.

If you like tests that do not resemble the backtests and that consist of topics that aren't covered in lecture, then you'll probably enjoy this course. Although he tries to be helpful, he covers almost none of the material that will be on the test, in lecture. I would recommend against taking MultiVar with MacLaughlin. Save yourself; take Schmidt.

Every practice exam question provided by McLaughlin in my semester had no answer. He would tell you "come to lectures to get it" but it was never there. If you miss the lectures, you will never find his class note online. Also his class is not very friendly to foreign students.
His lectures are confusing sometimes. Mainly because he talks about theories a lot. The tests are based on homework and textbook  questions. Go to office hours.
Takes test and final exam problems straight from his worksheets  and example problems in his lecture notes. Doesn't use an actual textbook and you buy his lecture notes instead.

McLaughlin is a very smart man, but not the best prof. I found that his course notes were excellent to learn from, so I didn't go to many lectures. Quizzes are very easy, and he gives a ton of partial credit on exams. This course shouldn't be a problem if you study. Do the worksheets, as the test questions are exact copies from the worksheets.

Some dislike the level of mathematical rigor that Harry employs. I consider my use of mathematics more practical than artful, so this aspect of his class was not initially enjoyable to me. However, he is a fantastic teacher and has taken my understanding of mathematics to another level. Highly recommend. (P.S. there is a steep learning curve)

Complete theory, poor explanations, and absolutely no examples in class. His exams are very easy but I had already taking Multivar when I went into his class, so I could ignore most of his confusing notation. Be prepared to teach yourself Calculus.

Goes into WAY more detail than anyone who isnt a math major needs. Uses his own textbook instead of the one every other prof uses, and his is practically useless.  He also randomly changed the test format halfway through the semester, making half of it no partial credit.  uses formal notation, and never explains any of it, just expects you to know.

I attended every lecture, took diligent notes and did all of the homework assignments. Got 100% average on the skills quizzes and a 60% on the exams. The exams are all problems you have seen before but I have only meet people who were successful in his class by memorizing all of the problems presented in homework and class work.

I had Mclaughlin for Calc II (Math 1020). The course consists of 4 exams, skills quizzes, and a final. The exams are not difficult; only 4 or 5 of the 6 questions per test are graded (generously, I might add). I only went to recitation to collect quizzes andor exams. The recitations lagged behind lectures in terms of content. Do the worksheets  A

Harry is an inspiration. He is the embodiment of pure commitment to what he teaches. Of course, taking Analysis II with him has a much different flavor than Analysis with Kovacic. That being said, I thoroughly enjoyed both courses. Harry structured the course in a way such that he felt like more of a colleague than a lecturer, which was nice.

He's a good professor for Math majors who want to know every detail and beyond what we're supposed to learn for Multivar Calc & Linear Algebra.  However, for any other major who just wants to pass and move on, he says a lot of unnecessary stuff that makes it all confusing, especially for Linear Algebra.  He's a super nice guy though.

This instructor writes his own lecture notes which he goes over and talks about during lectures. At first, they seemed unfamiliar but I come realize that I took away so much more from his notes and lectures than any other texts I've used for any class. I would recomend this course to those who seek a 'higher' understanding of mathematics.

Awful. Did not use the textbook most of us already had (since its the same text for Calc I) and most of us would need later (for MultiVar). Instead he told all of us to *buy his notes*! If you're looking to just pass Calc II instead of actually LEARNING anything from it, go ahead. But if you want to actually know the material, stay away.
Professor McLaughlin is the most experienced lecturer and kindest professor at RPI. Being part of his lecture has been a privilege.
Wants you to succeed, but is so smart he is unable to communicate effectively with his students
Very steep curve on all tests, designed to help people get 100%.  Quizzes are extra credit and lectures are clear and worthwhile.
Professor McLaughlin is by far the best professor I have had at RPI.

McLaughlin is a really nice guy and tries hard to make his students do well. I really wasn't a fan of his teaching approach, though. He skips the theory and jumps right to examples because he thinks that's a better way to learn the theory. Only 4 out of 6 test questions are graded, so tests aren't bad.

Not a very comprehensive teacher. His tests are supposedly easy but not when his lectures are like decoding the Rosetta Stone. His lectures have absolutely no transition. The hieroglyphics he writes during lecture are seen as so because he nose dives into topics. His classes are based off of doing problems and not the theory of the math.

McLaughlin is undeniably one of the esier A's to get at RPI. Go to recitation and his office hours and memorize all of the worksheet problems, then you will get an A in the couse, he uses the same problems. He's also a great guy to talk to, especially if you have a few minutes to hear from an experienced guy on pretty much any subject.
Tests are very simple. It's easy to get 100 as long as you have a decent grasp of the material. Harry is friendly and enthusiastic about the material.
Great teacher gives you the lecture before hand so you can read up on your stuff

I liked him as a professor, you could tell he really cared. He has examples in his lectures and sends out lecture notes that are really helpful and clear and have loads of examples. Homework in this class is optional. Your grade is entirely your test scores. Tests were set up so you answer 6 questions and your best 4 make up your grade.
Had him for calc I and II one of my favorite proffs of all time good guy words things kinda complicated but tests are identical to inclass problems/worksheets so do them

Dont go to lecture, the only way you will be able to comprehend what he is saying is if you have a phd in math.  Tests are really easy compared to what he teaches, on top of that he is an easy grader.  I would take calc II with this professor, just dont bother going to class.
He wrote his own lecture notes, I still kept them in my mailbox because they're so helpful

It depends on what kind of students you are, but unless you are an unthinking, blind-memorizing type, you won't like this professor. He expects you to memorize every theorem he taught in his class word for word. He is not a true mathematician and he would excell at it if and only if he were a biology professor.

Professor McLaughlin is a very good professor.  He is very helpful and will answer all questions in class.  His lectures could be a bit complicated and confusing, but PDF lecture notes clear everything up.  Exams are comprised of questions from lecture notes with different or exactly the same numbers/solutions.  Never used the text book once.
He is a genius in math and sometimes goes over concepts way over your head. He is extremely fair on grading and allows the final to be your final grade if you do very well.
Best Professor I've had yet.
Harry delivers a great calculus curriculum. It isn't easy but it'll prepare you for later classes, which an easy calc class won't necessarily. Go to class!

Harry knows what he talking about. You as a student might have an issue following it, but Harry tries real hard to interact with the class and have the class grasp the material. If you are having trouble stop by his office. He is a really nice guy who love mathematics. If you are a math major take all your courses with him. If not, go to Schmidt...

Excellent professor. He sets up the course so that you pretty much get the highest grade possible. Really passionate about calculus. I took Calc I in high school and he taught me the same stuff from different angles. This I really enjoyed course from him.

Harry is the man! He has a real passion for mathematics and teaches the class in a unique fashion. For those that have taken Calculus already, Harry provides a new spin from a geometry point of view. I hate geometry, but he makes it interesting. His exams are straight forward and he e-mails detailed lecture notes for studying.Might be confusing tho

Real nice guy. Discrete isn't the best class in the world. Gives pretty good test references, and his tests have a nice grading scheme. If you don't do well in this class it's because you aren't putting the work in.
nicest guy ever.  the class is hard and hes very persistent on making you figure everything out but he lets you know what will be on the test and grades pretty easy.
Very good
No Comments

This is my second course with Harry and he met every expectation I could ever have. Harry is not only one of the brightest guys on campus, he is also one of the most effective teachers I have ever seen. His style is unique, intriguing, and most of all it will grab your attention. Highly recommended!

He waxes a love for mathematics that is really hard to find.  The work is nowhere near easy, but he makes you want to learn the material.  Taking Fund. of Math. in preparation isn't crucial, but I'd recommend it.  Harry's one of the most interesting, eloquent, and capable teachers I've ever had.

Best profesor I have met at RPI. Truly an amazing teacher and an extremely interesting person. Take his class if you have the remote opportunity, and definitely DO NOT miss going to the office hours, you'll get more out of them than just a good grade. The work is hard but do-able.

Honestly the best course I have taken in my time in college. Harry has an amazing teaching style and allows you to discover the answers on your own which really makes it stick. You could be tired entering the class and you'll leave it awake and energized. If you have a chance take a course with him.

I must admit that having Harry for Calc 1 was quite difficult. Having never taken any calculus before, he jumps directly into it on the first day. However, he is always willing to help, is a very nice guy, and has very fair grading schemes.
No Comments
He's truly a great professor! He really knows his stuff, keeps class interesting, and knows how to communicate difficult concepts to others. Great grading methods too =D.

I had a class with Harry last year. He was great. Encouraged developing objective and creative way of thinking. Put emphasis on understanding of material, not grades, and was available for help. Without a doubt, one of the best profs in this hell-hole.
Harry is the best.
This guy is the man.  He is the best math professor I have ever had, but don't take a classs with him if you don't care about the subject.

Dr. McLaughlin is by far one of the best professors in the Math Department.  He expects you to put in a lot of work, but you will end up learning a lot more because of it.  He has the best grading scheme ever and is always ready to offer help.

Excellent professor, as long as you like math. He makes the learning experience very interactive. The course is a nice break from the normal process of going to class and falling asleep. He gives good feedback as well...
on numerous occasions has reffered to math as an artform.  and when asked how he got to an answer responded with because smarter people before us figured it out and we just accept it.
Don't sign up for him unless you're a total math wiz and have taken Calc AB/BC before.  He teaches randomly and will put you in Chapter 9 in the third week of class.
He was Great!!

An odd character, but a good teacher. Sticks to his word. Be prepared to learn. Very informative and ran the course well. Understood that Multivar and Matrix Alg are two courses combined, and taught accordingly.

Burt can be confusing, and contradictory, but he is also motivating and inspiring. You will do things to appease him, and focus much more on concept than on design details.You will have to work on a project with an empathetic or environmental focus. Inventor's was stressful, difficult, and fun. And has changed the way I see myself and the world.

Inventor's Studio is all about the creative process, and this is no easy thing to learn, let alone teach, and Burt does a great job if you listen to him. Some people have difficulty learning this because they are too narrow-minded and focus on the destination and not the journey. My advice is to keep an open mind and you will succeed.

I took Swersey's new class "Creativity, Innovation and Entrep." It was an interesting class, but very disorganized. His philosophy and his speeches sometimes conflict and are hypocritical. Puts down innovative ideas that aren't philanthropic. He  sometimes alienates students by thinking that his meaning of "innovation" is only right. Easy A doe

Burt genuinely cares about helping his students to reach their potential. Advice: go to his office hours, actually try some of the creative exercises, and don't feel self conscious about doing something out of your comfort zone.  If you approach this course with the intent to learn and become creative, you will.

Burt is an amazing teacher. He demands a lot of work and is a bit disorganized but will push you to your creative limits to create something to change the world. The best teacher I've had overall at RPI. He doesn't just teach innovation, he inspires it.

Warning: If you can't deal with a vague, unstructured and highly demanding class, don't sign up for a class with Burt. It's very frustrating. That said, you can learn a lot from him if you can put up with him.

Burt does a lot of good for RPI, and for the world beyond, by challenging people to think outside the box and push themselves to the brink. His classes are generally extremely disorganized, and he often asks for you to work beyond what is reasonable for any course. But if you don't get too frustrated, you'll find him to be extremely insightful.

Burt is a vision and an inspiration to all those who want to make a difference in this world. He WILL drive you absolutely crazy at times, but at the end you will realize the value of his dedication to pushing everyone in new directions. Don't be afraid to take chances and be ready to commit yourself to this class.

This is not a typical class: if you are a motivated person who wants to make a big impact on the world Burt can help you get there. Yes it is a lot of work, and Burt will push you, but it is because we are capable of doing so much more than we realize. This class changed my life.
Nice, vague, disorganized

Single best professor I've had at RPI. Can lead you down a rabbit hole if you cannot extract meaning from his words/assignments. Unparalleled vision for innovation. He pushes students harder then most students care to work but the results can be amazing. I ended up with a patent as a result. To get the "A" you need to show interest and initiative.

Wow. What a class. Stretches you to the limit but for good reason. Felt like I learned more than any other class at RPI. Those who didnt enjoy the class arent flexible enough! Its not your typical engineering class with clear goals...its much more, and if you participate you may create something amazing.

He was either very vague as to what he wanted or wanted way more than could be completed in the time allocated.  He thinks that this is the only class students are taking and expects them to invest all their time in  it.  Make sure to decide on a project you want to work on or else risk having a torturous semester.

this guy is out there in the ether. he doesnt ever have class planned out, and is always scattered. He is always brining in expert guests to replace the need for him to teach himself. the class gives you sweet opportunities if you want to take them, but swersey thinks that his class is the only thing that matters in your life, it can get really old

His classes are the MOST difficult, frustrating, and painful that you will ever find at this school. You will be emotionally and physically stretched past your limits. However, along the way you may learn crucial life lessons that cost people jobs and relationships. Take at your own risk (and only if your other courses are <11 credits and easy).

Has had no official training as a teacher, thus has no idea how to teach or even guide students.  Under no circumstances should you take any class with this professor.  He simply doesn't live in the real world (we call it Swerseyland).  He will make unreasonable demands of your time and energy, and will then criticize your best work next class...

Worst professor I have ever had. If you get stuck in his IED section, then get out! It's not worth taking his course. He teaches based on the principle of "my way or the highway." If he tells you to make a car with 3 wheels, next time you see him that car better have 3 wheels. Extremely hard to understand. No accent, just ridiculous. Immature! Fail

Unfortunately we figured him out too late in the semester. The key is to fully write up your report, then delete half and hand it in. When he asks you to resubmit, give him the full original for a A/B grade. If you give him the full originally, you'll fail and still have to resubmit it.

Terrible at describing what he wants.  Would advise only taking in Inventor Studio if you already have an idea or product you want to develop, having him give you very vague problems to solve (Fix global warming) is awful.

Nice guy, worst prof ive ever had.  Never actually explains what he wants.  Contradicts himself constantly.  Rambles for hrs about things that dont apply to the class.  Often tells students they are wrong with no factual basis for it.  Absolutly cannot handle being dissagreed with.  Ruined the class for me.

Burt Swersey is a nice guy at heart, and a very smart guy as well.  However, that in no way translates to him being a good professor.  He doesn't make it clear at all what he is looking for, and when he does attempt to say what he wants, it is usually unreasonable.  Overall, this was the worst class i have ever taken.  I DON'T reccomend this class.

Good guy with good intentions, but way too vague. He definitely needs to have a structured lesson plan, with a timeline, and he needs to stick to it. He's easy to get on your good side, though. If you show some initiative and be a leader in your group (IED or Inventor's) he'll like you.
Robert Ingalls of engineering.
Seems like a nice guy but it's very difficult to understand what he wants in the assignments. Also, occasionally talks about random and unnecessary things in class.
Prof. Swersery cares about what you learn. He more concerned about building a solid foundation so that you will exceed in the real world. He is a really good man..
If you want to do well in IED, DO WHAT SWERSEY suggests!! and have a good notebook.  All grade is based on his opion of you and your notebook.

For this course, the only way to get an A is to document everything you did in the notebook & list down all the new things u learned from the beginning to the end of the course(Very2 important). Recipe for A in his class.

He's garnered a lot of experience over his career and I think he truely wants to share that with us for our benefit.  But despite how long he's been teaching, he doesn't seem to have developed a steady lesson plan to do that.  Very vauge requirements, inconsistent, and prone to playing favorites.
helps you develop your ideas to actually be patentable and commericially feasible
Confusing lectures and requirements.  Not recommended.

He really makes you want to do well.  I thought he was a very nice person and did his job well.  He will always push you to do better no matter how well you may be doing.  He cares about how much you improve and how much effort you give.  The end result is not always important to him.  Great Guy.
NOT GOOD for PDI majors...  Swersey thinks he knows a lot about everything, especially patents.  He's really just an old, confused man that needs a one way ticket to the home.
No Comments
Do not sign anything he gives you. Be wary of any legal/patent advice he gives you.

Swersey is the true american idol. He totally kicks ass. He is very helpful when you are stuck with sumthin. If you do your work, there is no way you can get lower than a B. All you have to do is try. It's all about the learning!
He's a nice guy, but he's just exceedingly vague. Take an easygoing art teacher and put him at RPI. You've got Swersy.
Not recommended for engineers...  Horrible.
With any luck the guy retires like he should have years ago.  Avoid him and his rambling lectures as best you can.  Horrible professor, but a decent guy.
Bad for engineering.
Possibly the worst professor on campus.

It's about learning folks.  He wants you to learn more than you possibly can.  He emphasizes learning at all costs, not success, not finishing the project.  He changes his mind often, just disregard most of his suggestions and do what you think is right.
Unless you are a mechanical engineer, Swersey will not know what is going on (or where he is) when you talk to him.

Professors like Swersey ruin RPI's reputation and discourage its students from the field of engineering.  A conversation with a rock makes more sense and is more productive than with Swersey.  I wish there was a -1,000 rating for Helpfulness and Clarity.

Very helpful when approached for advice. Following his advice had successful results.He is accused of being vague, but the course is designed to be open ended to enhance the learning process.Such a nice guy.Honestly a very good teacher if given a chance.

He really tries to help us. If you do your work and do what he says, you will do fine. If he gives you a suggestion, ask him if that is really what he wants you to do, then document it. If he changes his mind about it, show him your documentation.
Horrible teacher. Very unclear, makes class extremely frustrating. His classes are a total waste of time. He may mean well, but he should not be teaching.. he isnt even a professor!

Hes a wacky harmless guy.He likes people who make as much sense as he does-minimal.If you make the slightest effort to think outside the box youll do fine.Dont go into his class with a well defined idea of what you want to do...he will make you change it.
Very nice dude who really means well
I think Professor Swersey is a very good teacher.  He helps the learning process but does not do it for you.  I had a very good semester with him!

Changes his mind at least twice in the same coversation. never gives clear direction. he picks his favorite students at the beginning of the semester and exhibits favortism towards these students. one of the worst profs i've had.
worst Prof i ever had!  need to get his act together and not change his mind every 10 seconds.  should not be teaching senior capstone at all!
seemed like he always meant well, but unfortunately it didnt always come out that way, due to this everyone is expecting a grade lower than they think they really deserve
Wanted one thing on monday and something different on thursday, extremely unclear.
completely out of his mind.  Makes inane suggestions and changes what he wants from you on a daily basis.  Impossible to please.
No Comments
Swersey is awesome!  He rocks, and he only means well!!!
Those who can, do.  Those who can't, teach

Goes back on his word, senile, can't make a clear point, can't gather his thoughts, can't stick to a single idea for more than a minute, very unrealistic.  Claims he's searching for creativity when in reality he wants you to create what he's thinking.

never keeps on the same track. Always switches ideas from day to day. If you do somethign he suggests, he later comes back and says  no no not liek that ..keeps you working till the last minute redesigining and redesigning instead of sticking to one soln.
BS doesn't stand for Burt Swersey
This man is not living in the same reality as everyone else. Too Ecentric, and wtf is up with that hat??!
This guy is way out of the loop in terms of engineering and life in general

You have to keep up with the reading and videos or else you are screwed. Stuff that he goes over in lecture will most likely be on the test, so don't skip! He may seem like he doesn't care about you, but if you show interest and go to office hours he will care. Make sure he knows your name.
Very willing to help if you go see him for office hours but his tests are incredibly difficult. Lots of material to learn all at once but he makes it interesting. Just do not fall behind.

Dr. Plopper is an amazing professor. The only reason he gets a 45 for clarity is because he tried something new this semester. I literally learned so much from his class. His tests are very difficult, but he will help if you need it. Favorite class so far. Amazing lecturer. So inspired to continue my path as a biology major.

His class is hard but fair. He is an excellent professor, very willing to help students. BUT, the topic he teaches is a hard subject in and of itself, so work is mandatory. Lectures are great and very helpful as is the textbook.

Dr. Plopper wants you to pass his class and he cares that you learn the material, but you will have to work for it. His course is not easy, but if you truly work hard you should succeed. He gives you everything you need to pass, from past exams to real advice from former students on how to pass his exams.

I do think that Prof Plopper wants his students to do well, but he doesn't make that remotely easy. Not that it SHOULD be easy for students to do well, but it shouldn't feel impossible. If you work hard and put a lot of time in, you'll do well. But with other difficult courses and some personal issues, it was too hard to succeed in the class.

Plopper is the worst person ever existed on planet earth. He tricks you into thinking that he only want to help you learn, but really all he wants is slay you with no mercy.I went to all classes, took notes, studied the book, but the tests seemed like they're in a foreign language. SAVE YOU LIVES AND DO NOT TAKE HIS CLASSES!

Easy class if you take notes in lecture, read the textbook thoroughly and practice all the drawings. The only people who complain are the ones who don't put in the effort and are unprepared for exams. Dr. Plopper wants you to succeed and get an A.
Dr. Plopper is a great lecturer that cares more about sharing the material than doing busy work assignments. Hard class but very rewarding.

Dr. PloppG is the best. Down-to-earth but insanely smart, & incredibly helpful. I was intimidated upon registering for the course, hearing of its high demand; one of the top classes I've taken during the course of my academic career. Work IS demanding, & attendance is required as participation is valued highly by Dr. P.

This class was ridiculously difficult. No amount of studying from the back tests would prepare you for the exams. HOWEVER, the book was very informational, he was available everyday for office hours, and the UG mentors DO know their stuff. He is always willing to clarify, even set up a Facebook account to hold questions for students!
Very hard class. Very hard tests.
He was a good professor and taught well. But his tests are impossible and that made up 65% of the class grade (35% was lab).

Dr.Plopper is by far my favorite professor. I would love to TA for Cell Bio to relive the experience. Cell Bio is NOT hard. Everyone is studying hard,but is everyone studying the right way? By now,students should have set study techniques that they know work for them. If not,then such classes will seem difficult!

GO TO LECTURE, and office hours are helpful too. Tests are difficult but the amount of your grade they count for starts low and increases so if you aren't prepared for the first, it's not a huge deal. Everything stacks,info-wise. The final project takes up a huge amount of time, so be prepared.

This class is HARD. Keeping up with the lectures is a must, and reviewing the notes, especially the drawings, is very important. Plopper makes his multiple choice questions very, very difficult, so be wary of that. Lab also takes a lot of time out side of class (I came in every day for 2 hours, three weeks straight)

Between studying the material and keeping up with your lab, this class takes up a lot of time outside of class time. However, it's worth it because I did learn a TON about cell biology. Just keep with the reading, and for the love of god, DO NOT MISS LECTURE.
His tests are really hard and the class takes up a lot of time
Tests are super hard. He's good at teaching the material, but can be very pompous and somewhat inconsiderate at times.
Very good professor. He is able to explain everything in an explicit way.
He knows what concepts are difficult for students to learn and takes the time to explain the subtleties of the concepts
GREAT teacher. His testing style is a little funny, so BE WARE of answer A.

Best Professor I've ever had.  He truly cares about his students learning and doing well.  He uses novel approaches in teaching which work very well and make it easier to learn.  He writes challenging but fair exams.

Dr. Plopper is an excellent professor. The podcasts are awesome because sometimes the lectures are hard to keep up with. He does five office hours a week. . . no one else does that. If you can go to at least 1 or 2 a week it will help you tremendously. I got an A but it was not easy. Go to office hours!! He has that many for a reason.

Dr Plopper is a great professor. He really does care about cell biology and relates everything he can to real life applications. The tests are difficult but not impossible. I suggest you do what I do-- listen to the podcasts and take notes on EVERYTHING. It's impossible to get all the pertinent information in lectures. Keep calm and you'll do fine

Awesome teacher but the material and class is hard.  very helpful with office hours 5 times a week is unheard of.  He tells you what you need to do to get a good grade and that it will be hard.  Very upfront and to the point best prof thus far at rpi

One of the toughest classes I have ever taken.  Plopper really cares about the subject and tries to relate everything to real life circumstances such as cancer.  He is an excellent professor but your going to need to work in this class even for a B.  I loved this class and it really showed me what studying is all about
Tough class, but he seems to enjoy teaching and devotes a lot of time.  Questions require memorization and working knowledge of subject matter.

professor plopper is definitely one of the best teachers here at rpi. he explains everything thoroughly in class, if you dont understand anything at all, you can go to his office hrs which he holds almost every single day. he really truly cares for his students, the tests are very hard but they're completely based on lecture + modules we read.

He has the bad habit of oversimplifying his lectures and then overcomplicating his exams.  He is still excellent at explaining difficult principles in lecture, but he doesn't go in depth enough for you to go to lecture and do well on the test.

He'll always stop if people have questions, even if it makes the class go ridiculously slow, so thats a bit annoying.  But that makes him really helpful, and his tests have material straight from his lectures.  Often says specific things during lectures that you need to know for tests, so they are clear and fair. Don't just read the book though.

Took this class a year ago. Its hard and he DOES NOT post lectures. You need to take excellent notes. When he says to memorize a figure, do it, it'll probably be on the test. GO TO HIS OFFICE HOURS! He really does try to help the students and cares about how they do in his class and their overall academics. Don't be shy, ask him for help.

His class is hard and he definitely wants to keep it that way.He doesn't post his lectures online(even though he said he will;he always has some excuse)and he doesn't really say what's going to be on the test;so you just have to guess. Personally, I did not like his teaching style and the fact that he makes you read the section around the pictures.
Material was difficult but he is hands down the best prof. I have had so far and arguably the best at RPI
He is nice and knows his stuff well. He also readily accepts new ideas and comments.

I could have gotten away with taking BIOL 1010 instead of this course, but my academic adviser encouraged me to take cell bio. At times I hated her for it, but overall I believe the class left me better than I came in. The class is fast, complicated, and intense. Plopper is awesome though and he's there for you. He can really get you through it.

Professor Plopper has a very hands off teaching style that will take many people a few weeks to get used too. He jumps around in the text and covers TONS of material in just a few lectures. He leaves it up to you to figure out what will be on the tests. He's an awesome guy outside of class! Get to know him and he'll help you out a great deal.

I love Dr. Plopper and I loved this course. He's an awesome teacher and an excellent mentor. I know how to go about the rest of my academic career because of him.  This course is much more enjoyable than Bio-1010 (bio majors don't give up if you didn't get/like that class). Study a lot, care about the material, find the good in your accomplishments

Get ready to study like you've never studied before. There will be times when you'll question why you took the class, but in the end ITS WORTH IT. You will accomplish things you never dreamed you could. Yeah, I learned lots of cell bio, but really I learned I can do anything if I put my mind to it; those are lessons I'll keep with me my whole life.

This is the best class I have taken so far. But you have to work. Go to the lectures so you know what to study and because Plopper's lectures are good. Office hours help a lot even if you think you know the material. The tests are hard and you must study. The lab section is easy as long as you stay organized.

He's the nicest most caring and best professor I've ever heard of but he's absolutely terrifying. You will NOT get through his class unless you study EVERY SINGLE DAY. Go to his office hours. Theyll save your life. He'll do anything to make sure you understand the material, but you can't take this class lightly. Brace yourself. Isnt High school now

Easily the best professor I've had at RPI.  Intelligent, enthusiastic, always willing to help.  You can tell he loves to teach.  His tests are hard because he expects a lot but he will always do his best to make sure you understand.  Go to office hours, study, work to understand the concepts instead of memorizing.
great teacher. but course is easy, never read a page nor went to office hours nor asked any question and still got an A.

Everything everyone else has said is true.  Plopper is an AMAZING teacher.  If you do not understand something, TELL HIM and he will go to every end to make sure you DO.  He retaught an entire lecture because he felt no one got it.  Tests are hard, but that's the nature of the beast: YOU HAVE TO THINK ON THEM.  Just be ready to connect some dots.

amazing teacher. lectures are really detailed but interesting at the same time. his tests range in terms of difficulty, the 2nd being the most difficult. GO TO OFFICE HOURS!! and stay on top of your reading. all in all the best class i've taken so far here.

One of the best teachers I've ever had. Very articulate and engaging in the subject matter that helps you not only learn but also appreciate cell biology. The exams are tough but rigorous preparation is required. Professor is very helpful, so ask him questions.

Intro to Cell in his class is a hard class, but he teaches it REALLY WELL, I actually enjoyed his lectures to an extent, and the class was overall excellent.  He tells you his class and his tests are hard in the beginning, and he's right, but he works with you to help you get things right.

Really nice guy. Holds review sessions on Sunday afternoons just to clarify things before tests. The multiple choice questions have some ridiculous answers, but overall the tests are pretty fair.  Definitely the best professor I've had so far.
saf
Amazing teacher, though possibly unbalanced - cut his arm with his fingernails to demonstrate how intermediate fibers give cells strength. Go to office hours, they help a lot.
GO TO OFFICE HOURS! ASk QUESTIONS. IF he gets to know u he will be very elpful
Good teacher. HARD tests. Study a lot and don't fall behind. GO TO OFFICE HOURS!
Great Prof
HORRIBLE teacher
very thorough! and entertaining most of the time

Plopper is a good teacher, but get ready to work like a dog! Sell your soul to cell bio, quit drinking,and become close friends with the smartest biology geek that you know. You're going to need all the help you can get.Stay on top of things or else you're a goner. Don't take shortcuts...suck it up and read the material.

Plopper is awesome.  Concerned about the students understanding lecture material.  His analogies are amazing and help non-bio people to understand even the most complex biological processes. Ex - "Think of transcription and translation as a Xerox machine..."
Excellent Professor, very helpful and interesting / funny lecutres
Awesome lectures. Outlines everything and is interesting to listen to. I haven't fallen asleep once.
This guy is the best professor at RPI! As a mechanical engineer it was great to have a confident person behind a podium talking about something and making it sound interesting.

Bob Jones gets a bad rep. He's by far the best lecturer I have had so far. The tests are fairly difficult, but I hear he gives a curve. Really no homework, and you can do well in the class if you show up. I found that I started to enjoy showing up as his lectures are filled with real-world examples and past experiences of his.

Professor Jones is fantastic! He is an expert in economics and does a marvelous job teaching students and ensuring their understanding through iClicker questions. Attendance not mandatory, but his lectures are so interesting and valuable that I recommend attending anyway. Read the textbook, do the practice problems, and you will get an A.
Funny and makes lectures entertaining. Easy class.

Professor Jones is excellent. He is a thorough and engaging lecturer. However, grades are based entirely on exams. The exams don't reflect the material very well, and are difficult to study for. He provides a back exam, but that isn't usually enough. I wish he spent more time on practice problems and/or assigned homework for practice and grading.
Best prof on lecturing since I came to RPI. Exams and grades are tough. If you are here for easy HASS, not really what you want. But if you are passionate in economics, best prof.
Tests are hard and professor isn't very helpful / responsive to emails.
Very hilarious and great guy. You will learn from his lectures. And if you do the practice exams, you will get good grades on the real exams.
Not clear about everything. Don't provide the examples for questions.
No example for calculation. Difficult Exam.
No any notifications on exam dates.
He is a funny guy. The test is fairly constructed

He's a hilarious and great guy. Lectures are easy to follow, and he's great about only teaching you the stuff you need to know. This isn't a gimmie A, though. I didn't take it as seriously as I should have, so I struggled a bit early on. Tests are pretty difficult, but curve is usually pretty generous.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Lecture heavy

comment: Funny guy and good lecturer. Definitely knows his stuff. Tests are pretty hard but theres always a curve.
On the test, there is no partial credit
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Jones is an amazing lecturer! Knows how to make things relevant and memorable. Tests can be tough but there is a curve. Overall, would love to have another class taught by him.
Hilarious guy. Great lawyer intuitions. Since textbook is so clear, the only purpose to go to class is to have fun

He's a good lecture and makes the dry material less boring. He will call you out if you are seen on your phone btw. He gives a few HWs throughout the semester, lectures are based on textbook slides with iClicker questions. Has three tests and no final, test are challenging, but he curves at the end of the semester to make up for it.
Had him for Econ of Financial Markets and Institutions.  He's a hard ass in lower level econ class, but once you're in specialized classes he lightens up.  LMS tests with open book, open notes.

Jones is a great and genuinely funny guy - not your typical academic drone. He was able to deliver relatively dry material with some personality which made it more engaging and worthwhile to attend lecture. He was inconsistent with homeworks and tests (paper vs. Blackboard LMS), which is only complaint. His tests are HARD, but curves appropriately.

He has real interest teaching. Rare thing at RPI. Uses premade slides for lectures that can get clustered and hard to understand but he explains the material very well. Hw is on LMS, very do able if you read the book and slides. Tests are HARD and not allowed a crib sheet, etc. Grades are curved thankfully because tests count for 75%. I recommend.

One of my favorite professors. He uses pre-made slides for the lectures, but he uses them more as notes than anything else. Usually manages to keep the subject matter interesting (and often entertaining). Ties in current events to lecture material. Tests were open book, though I believe that's peculiar to this class.
This guy is an amazing professor. If you read the textbook, it is incredibly easy. This guy was my favorite professor that semester, and got me interested enough in economics to pursue a minor.

He's great at explaining materials, even though it's just an introductory class, he makes Econs easy for engineers. Test could be a little easier though. However, compared to the other introductory to econs professors, get him.
Great teacher makes the boring stuff interesting. Would try to try to have him for any Econ classes.

I don't totally like his method of lecturing. He just asks a bunch of questions. The tests were kind of hard, but the final was extremely easy and he replaces your whole grade if you do better on the final. Overall not bad

I heard that he was an easy professor, but this is no longer true. He grades the class in a way that the top 25% gets A and A-. The tests avg for the first test was a 50/66 and the second test was a 43/73, which make up 80% of your grade, so you can see what is the grade that most people will end up getting.

Ignore all comments prior to 2010, because they are not valid anymore. No open book tests, two test worth 40 percent your grade each on 10-12 chapters a pop. Stupid in class participation grade where missing one takes about 4 points off your letter grade. Not to mention you basically teach yourself as he no long lectures and just asks questions.

He changed his curriculum around a lot and it is no longer the easy A economics class. He gives out questions due for each class and uses them as participation points by calling on random students during class. His tests are long and all short answer with no back tests to study from
Professor Jones is a great professor in my mind.  His lectures are right out of the book and tests are predictable.  If you want an A you will have to work but it wont be hard!
