Dr. Kam is the real MVP. She's so funny and her lecture notes are very detailed and understandable. Her tests aren't surprising--if you do your homework and show up to lecture, you will do great.

Kam uses an example-based lecture style to drill in techniques for calc II. Quizzes are literally taken from the 5-6 examples done in lecture, and nothing on the exams are ever a surprise (plus bonus questions!). Super approachable, and she makes hilarious comments during class and then wonders why people laugh. 10/10 would take again
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Caring

comment: Had her for Calculus II, and she's nothing short of the ideal professor.  She's supremely qualified to teach the course (took BC Calc prior) and makes the course very manageable and student-friendly, but that's been said already.  She is a person of immense patience and she puts forth 100% every lecture to engage people in the material.  It works.

Professor Kam was one of the best professors that I had. She is very straightforward and I learned so much following along her lectures. Showing up to lectures, taking down notes, making sure you review the examples and optional homeworks will ensure an A. She made Calc II for me very enjoyable and easy.

Overall good professor however if you go to office hours and asked questions he'd be a little condescending and expect you to know everything. Go to the exam reviews because he'll tell you a lot of hints on the test. Lots of homework so definitely try to plan out your homework schedule ahead of time.

Fantastic Chemistry prof. Lectures are fun and very useful, but fast with a lot heavy material. If you pay attention and try to understand logically, will be a breeze. Attendance is very important. EXTREMELY helpful during OH explains material super well. Labs are super fun. Homework helps a lot Ask as many questions as you need he will answer.

Very knowledgeable in what he teaches, but lectures are incredibly fast paced. Will often begin the next lecture if he finishes early. Expects you to have a good understanding of chemistry prior to taking the class and will rarely answer questions during lecture. Exams are multiple choice but require deep genuine understanding of the material.

If you're taking Chem 1100, take it with Dr. Ma.  Ma writes exams and he is an extremely tough grader, so make sure to study harder than you think you need to.  All 3 Chem professors teach well, but try to get Ma or Korenowski.  Attendance matters a lot.

Although Chem 1 is an RPI course that has too much busywork quite often (especially with topics many students don't care about), Dr. Ma is the best professor to have access to for this intro class. He goes fast in lectures, but I admire how passionate he is in when reviewing content. Utilize the cybermentoring office hours as well, they're helpful!

Ma's Lectures are always extremely direct and to the point. It is extremely fast paced but he tends to not go off topic and his office hours are quite helpful. Chem is all round a very tough course so no matter who you pick it'll be hard but for me Ma was extremely helpful in learning the material. He makes the test so attend his review sessions
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: Chem 1100 is the classic weedout class, with tons of homework and tough exams. Given the choice between Korenowski, Tysoe, and Ma, I'd take Ma any day of the week (Tysoe > Korenowski though). If you can't stomach the 8 AM lectures, at least attend his review sessions. He writes the exams and drops hints like crazy. Good lecturer and cool guy!

Take Chem 1 with Ma! You're doing yourself a disservice if you don't. He does talk fast sometimes but is totally willing to answer questions or talk during office hours. HE WRITES THE EXAMS so sometimes he will directly tell you if something is on the test in class. Also, go to his exam review sessions, they cover everything you need to know.

It does not matter how well you can pay attention in lecture, you will have to learn everything on your own. Add that to the insane amount of homework for homework for lecture AND lab and you have a course that pretends like you don't have any other classes. It's absolutely criminal that it's only 4 credits. This is an 8 credit work load.
Knowledgeable bout what he is teaching

Dr Ma is a pretty good professor! He's good at explaining harder topics and is accessible outside of class if you have questions. I will say he is not the most tech-savvy person out there, however. He's the Chem 1 lecturer who mainly writes the exams, so if you go to his review sessions, he'll probably tell you the kind of questions to expect.

Dr. Ma is a good professor when it comes to teaching and conveying topics that can be difficult to understand. However the tests are made to be very difficult and he takes no responsibility for the averages (even if the exam average is an F). Office hours can be helpful but have to go from the get-go or else he gets upset and lets you know it.

Dr. Ma is a great professor for CHEM-1100!  His lectures are extremely fast-paced and engaging and he tries to make jokes about whether or not he will put something on an exam. If you take CHEM-1100 with him, be ready to take quick notes, read the textbook, and spend a good amount of time on homework. Definitely attend his exam reviews too!

If Ma is available for Chem I, take Ma. Writes the exams so knows what to teach. If you put in the effort, A is very easy to get because of the abundance of test review sessions and mentoring opportunities. Nice guy in office hours. Lectures are extremely fast, highly suggest pre-reading and taking light notes before lecture. Lectures required.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Accessible outside class

comment: I do not recommend taking Dr. Ma for chemistry 2. The best thing about his teaching is that he is clearly very knowledgeable no the content but he is unable to actually relay that to students. His lectures are incredibly fast paced and boring and do not prepare you for the tests.

Terrible professor, worst teacher Ive ever had. Calls students stupid. Will not give points back on exams despite having questions with more people getting it wrong than right. Some of the exams had a failing class average with no curve. Has no idea of student's understanding of material and seems to enjoy giving exams that people do very poorly on

A super nice guy. He lectures at a fast pace. All of the lecture slides where posted online. His reviews are key, he breaks down reviews to the topic of each question which helps focus on what to study. If you are a freshman I advise taking him for chemistry.

I strongly recommend Dr Ma's lectures, not because it's great, but it's the most helpful strategy for your exams since he made it. I don't like him personally since he always makes things way too difficult.

Dr. Ma is the chemistry professor who writes the tests, so I would suggest getting him if at all possible. Yes, his lectures are early, but you will get a much higher grade if you attend the lectures in person rather than over Webex. Pay attention, and don't be afraid to ask questions or go to his office hours.
Really hard tests
He covered all the material and his review lectures are super helpful, only negative is that he lectures very fast so taking notes can be difficult.

Ma is very knowledgeable in the field of Chemistry, which seems to be his biggest downfall. He lacks the empathy for the majority that struggle with chem. Lecture attendance isn't mandatory but he speeds through 90+ lecture slides expecting complete understanding from students instantly. He creates the tests and makes sure to make it very difficult

Took AP Chem senior year of high school with an A in the class and a 4 on the exam, and I hated and struggled with this class, getting poor grades while actually trying. Seemed like half the things we were supposed to know weren't in the textbook, and I learned more from google than the class. COVID isn't an excuse, this class was real garbage.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: This professor made me want to find whoever invented Chemistry and hurl them off the Golden State Bridge. This man gave us an 1hr 15 mins to finish an exam w/ an absurd amount of questions. No one was finishing on time, so much so that Dr. Ma had to increase the time on 2 separate occasions! 3 surveys were made about the difficulty of the exams.

Ma's really nice and helpful. You can get away with an A in the class if you do well on the labs & hw and get Bs on the tests. But, you do have to actually work for your grade. If you don't understand something, ask for help EARLY. Physically showing up isn't necessary. You don't REALLY need a textbook but for some people, it can a difference.

Dr. Ma is a good professor to have. He goes over a lot of content during lectures, but the pace never felt rushed. He streamed the lectures live online which was nice (i.e. staying in bed for an 8 AM). For Chem 1100, he is the preference. His review sessions are very helpful. He tries to make lecture fun and enteraining. A nice guy!
Quick lectures but they are extremely helpful especially while studying for exams. He also always holds test reviews that are vital to attend before taking the exams.

He's a good lecturer, although he tends to go through powerpoints at light speed. He also does his best to make lectures funny which is good. Tests are usually hard since he puts tricky questions (wording, hard question in general) and the tests were at 8am.

I had him for Chem 1 and Chem 2. He's a great guy. He loves to be tricky on exams, but he genuinely cares about his students and is a good lecturer. You gotta work for a high grade, especially in Chem 2.

From day 1 when he stood up and declared that in classical physics waves don't carry momentum I knew this guy didn't really know what he was talking about. He is a nice guy but not a rigorous explainer. People tend to think he's funny, I think he's just silly. He often just fails to teach material declaring it too hard. He's kind of a ridged grader

Going to lectures is a part of the grade, plus they really help. Dr. Ma really knows what he is teaching and explains everything very well. He's funny and makes lectures interesting. You do have to put in a good amount of work to get a good grade.

Dr. Ma is a great lecture-style professor. I had him for chem I and class was a breeze. He posts all of his lectures and review sessions online, and offers a tremendous amount of resources to study for tests.

I had Ma for chem I and chem II.  You do not have to read the textbook, but you HAVE to go to lecture and take notes.  His course is not that difficult, but you do have to do a lot of back tests to prepare and do well on his exams.  He is a great professor and I don't really have any complaints

He wore a Hawaiian shirt and brought inflated beach balls to lecture one time and let us throw them around the room. Enough said. Dr. Ma is great.  He presents the lecture material clearly and goes at a reasonable pace, though I'm not gonna lie, those lectures are long. Go to his review session before tests, they help a lot.
Dr. Ma is fantastic and hilarious. The class isn't too terribly difficult, but requires a lot of studying for exams.

Funny guy. Is very clear and explains material well. Lectures can be a bit long, but they're not too boring, and very helpful. Tests are 20 multiple choice questions, so a  few mistakes and your down to a B pretty quickly, but other than that, they're not that hard.

Dr. Ma is a funny guy. The curve is built into the letter grade criteria. Final MIGHT replace your lowest exam score. It happened in my year, but the previous students I've asked have said that he doesn't cut you any slack beside the aforementioned built-in curve. I was able to get an A with only Chem I experience in HS.

Ma is one of the nicest professors I've had so far. He is in charge of Chem 1 and has a deep understanding of the material. Also there's small experiments at the beginning of some classes. He encourages students to come to office hours where he occasionally gives out test hints. He doesn't curve and the tests can be tricky, but manageable.
Very clear and not boring at all. Best chem1 professor!
PRAISE MA!  An almighty god of chemistry and science, Ma fights the troubles students have with an Iron (Fe) fist.  Ma saves the day every time with his brilliance in Chem 1.
Very hard tests and final. Very nice teacher. Keep up with lab because that can help you grade a lot.
His lectures are not boring; he makes funny comments :) He's really nice, and he's tests are not impossible! Awesome Professor~~~

Dr.Ma is very helpful and patient. His encouragement throughout the year really helped guide me towards a successful end. He supplements the info learned during lecture with Korenowski very nicely. You just have to make sure to take the time to go meet him outside of class.
Charles :D
Excellent course and professor! A must take for CS people interesting in Vision and Deep Learning
A very good teacher. Clear and concise. Willing to help. He's not too serious. Other than the professor, the class was very well done.

Professor Stewart seems like a vey knowledgeable person, but when it comes to homework, he isn't fair in the slightest. He seems to enjoy accusing students of cheating off of each other, even when they didn't do anything.
His class is great.

Great professor for data structures! He did a good job explaining pointers and how to write classes such as vectors and maps in C++. Programming assignments and tests were relevant and fair (and also somewhat easy in my opinion).
Charles is the best professor I've had at RPI. His tests reflect the labs and homeworks. His explanations are clear. He's quick to respond to questions. It is a challenging course but fair.
Prof Stewart is the man. He was quick to respond to emails concerning homework/lab questions (within 12 hrs). Super nice and you will learn so much. Data structures ftw.
Very helpful and easy to understand.  Highly recommended.

Data Structures is a really hard class. He, however, is very helpful if you need help. His homeworks are very time consuming. This course becomes like a black hole consuming all your time even away from other courses so be warned of that.
Really good professor and always kind and helpful

Probably the best CSCI professor I've had at RPI. A really smart guy with a good sense of humor. His lectures were clear and fairly interesting, and he was very willing to provide extra help. The exams were fair and not too difficult.

Tests are moderately difficult, requiring strong on-the-spot problem solving ability. He provides a sample set of problems to review, some of which are modified or copied verbatim on the actual exam. Home-works are challenging, so start them early! TAs are semi-helpful, but very unorganized and harsh graders. Lecture notes are your best friend!
Professor Stewart taught the class clearly and concisely; however the difficulty level was quite high and the homework was quite time-consuming.

PROS: Clear in Lecture, Knows his Stuff, Attempts to be Funny, Curves Tests if Necessary, Gives Good Lecture Notes CONS: Huge jerk if you have to deal with him 1-on-1, doesn't listen if you try and explain something, doesn't communicate well with TA's, puts class "regulations" above common sense, sometimes docks massive points for unclear reasons.
I went to every lecture and understood EVERYTHING! Later when starting the homeworks, i was totally lost. Way to go prof!

He's a good teacher. Explains well but nothing extraordinary. I think he reads this too because he doesnt put the lecture notes online anymore for 2 weeks after the class ends. So you really do have to go to class. Lecture notes are key though, it IS the class, that's all he does.

Two Words: Lecture Notes...  you don't actually have to goto lecture because everything you need is in the notes.  If you actually DO goto lecture, you will most likely be bored out of your mind or driven crazy by his pathetic attempts at humor... baseball jokes get old very quickly...
Chuck Stewart is a really good professor. In class he is very clear and gives out printed notes, which are also posted on his website. The tests are kinda toughish...but he prepares you well enough.

A very good, very structured and caring professor. Probably the best comp sci teacher I had and I took cs2 with him twice. The first time I failed due to my own fault along with dear Motten Hotwick's bad class.

Really interesting guy and great teacher. He makes class interesting, and his tests arent *too* bad. He doesn't expect you to know C++ from the onset, so people like me who had no formal programming (lots of informal though) were fine. Homework gets a little tough... but not too bad. Good class.

This guy is awesome.  His lectures are pretty much just suplimentary and you don't have to go, so for the people that do go he jazzes them up with awesome tangents.  His Napoleon refrences are awesome.  He also brings his kids to class occasionally which is cool.  His projects are challenging andfun

He is pretty decent, but his lectures are pointless. I come in 20 minutes late, take the lecture notes (pile at the back of the room), and leave. Read them on my walk back and still get all A's, without trying too hard. The tests aren't too bad. You can expect an easy A if you keep up with the hw!

First few weeks are straight from CS I, but gets into some pretty complex stuff. He's a great code writer and give you lots of examples. Will show you a lot of cool tricks. Tests are medium difficulty, but he tells you what to expect. Funny, not a nerd. Sox fan. Only buy the Koenig & Moo book.

Starts out slow for those who skipped CS I but soon picks up the pace. The material is though but he covers it thoroughly and clearly. Hands out lecture notes and leaves the stack in the back of the room so you can grab one if you come in late. Amusing and fun to listen to as well.
me no like
Awesome teacher. Lecture notes are very helpful, and assignments are relevant and interesting.
Best. Prof. Ever. Stewart is interesting, intelligent, a truly nice guy, and most importantly, really gives a damn about his undergrad students.
wasn't the best prof i've ever had, but the TAs helped out a lot so I managed a decent grade
Fairly engaging professor. Lecture notes are helpful. Tests are hard.
Best CS professor at RPI by far.
No Comments
This guy is awesome.  He teaches you things and you don't even realize you're being taught.  Excellent coverage of material....and Napoleonic history.
He's an pretty good professor and I think I got alot out of his class. He seems to enjoy Napolean and telling us stories about bathing his children. Quite a strange bird, but I kinda like him.
what a jump from hs comp sci... decent prof, but exams are killers
knows his stuff, tries to be funny but really isn't.  HE LOVES bubble sort.
Very clear and knowledgeable. Not the most exciting teacher, but he tries to be.
He knows his stuff... but if you don't conform to his programming style, forget it.
No Comments
No Comments
Good compsci teacher, very knowledgable

Like others said, he's very ambitious in what he wants to accomplish with the class, specifically the semester long design project. Absolutely great mentor, but a terrible teacher. His tests aren't too bad, study lecture notes online. He allows 1 full page of equations - NO diagrams for the tests. Daily activities and about 15 HW's from the book.

A really ambitious and enthusiastic teacher. Be prepared for a design project. His tests are not that bad, pay attention in class and review his lectures that are posted online. He is a fair teacher, just hard to reach through emails sometimes.

Castillo was on point with his lectures and made sure everyone understood him at all times. He made the material simple to understand and was always encouraging the students to participate in class. If you had questions you could always catch him right after class or even at his office. Overall it was a great course with a great professor.

Prof Castillo is one of the nicest professors I have ever met in the department. He DOES care about students and their performance unlike what many people claim. Best recipe to get an A in the class: review lecture notes, ask questions and start the hw early not the day before!

Has difficulty explaining topics clearly. Frequently diverts to other topics. Has online "lecture notes" that are largely ignored. Gives HW due the day OF the exam, provides no help on how to solve problems like those on the exam. TAs were just as useless. Substitute lecturers were better than him. Doesn't follow/use book. Nice guy, but can't teach

The lectures range from decent to awful.  The Book is AWESOME. Buy it & read it.  This class is pretty straightforward, but he is a big fan of putting things on the exams that have not been discussed in class or in the book.  HIGHLY RECOMMEND TAKING ENGR 2250 (Thermals and Fluids) at the same time as Fun Flight. Makes undiscussed questions doable.

I hate to say this, but he doesn't explain concepts in details. He is unorganized and his lecutres are useless. You have to rely on your textbooks for studying; Although it didn't help me much anyway either.

Class is utterly disorganized. last month of class seemed to be a waste other than to give him a soap box to talk about his research. never really received any grades back and therefor couldn't challenge final grades.  his heart and enthusiasm is in the right place but he shouldn't allowed to teach at the 4000 level.

I agree with the previous comments. He has good intentions but has a definite inability to present topics in a logical, encompassing, and concise manner. Confusion has accompanied every test, with him having to interrupt often with notes he should have mentioned on the exam itself. I purposely tried to avoid taking this class with him.

As a person, he is pleasant. However, as a professor, he is awful. He is highly unorganized and has difficulty explaining himself well. He will give you homework on certain topics that were not discussed in class. Exams are highly unpredictable...do not only prepare for what he tells you will be on them.. and can either be very easy or very hard.

Castillo sums up his teaching style best with this quote: "I wont go out of my way to make sure everyone understands the material."  He makes up random stuff in class, only cares about his research, and doesn't comprehend how much his students know or don't know.  If you can avoid this professor, do so at all costs.
he literally just makes things up and then when you make something up on a test you are wrong

I actually liked him. I thought he was funny and I thought he seemed to care about what he was teaching. I don't really pay attention in classes anyway so him being, or trying to be funny, at least kept me somewhat interested. Class was not that hard, but it looks like he may have changed his tests from years past.
awful prof. ended up giving A's to everyone but the class was bull. I never knew what was due and he gave us an impossible project.

Very difficult class but he mustve been told how bad he was teaching in the past since he made things very clear and the TA said his first test was easier than usual. Hes helpful in office hours but you have to go to class and pay good attention

Worst professor i've ever had in my life. Did not clairify the things he taught. Would accuse you of not paying attention when you went to office hours. Didnt clairfy anything in office hours by responding "i did that in class". His exams a haphazardly put together. Expects you to know everything he did not teach. Cares too much about his research.

Castillo is the worst professor ever.  He shows up only when he feels like it, seems not to care about students needs or thoughts at all.  Tests are absurd.  Required regrade and extra questions.  I was originally interested in thermal as a field, but castillo has made me HATE IT!
Never update his website. Take a long time to respond to students. Won't be in office hours at all. He sucks.
keep sighing in class....keep saying he is tired...he is such a lazy pig........
No Comments
ok, but doesn't anyone else think he's hot? yummy!
worst proffesor ever

This guy will go out of his way to avoid you.  Seriously, don't bother making an appointment with him because he won't show up.  Door to his office is ALWAYS closed.  He went out of town every week we had a test so we couldn't get help.  It's pretty obvious that his research is all he cares about.
unorganized in general... very unclear in lectures and is not helpful when approached with questions
The things he explained in class, and the things we did on the homework weren't even close to being related.  The class was redicusly unorganized.
gives lots of homework

Caffeine addict.  Likes to talk about his ex-wife, his son, and his hot girlfriend.  He talks trash about Shirley Ann sometimes, but says we have to be careful, 'cause her office is right above our classroom.  Overall, a pretty crumby teacher.
boring n really sucks
bad professor, his class had the worst exam average out of all the classes. he doesn't teach well at all
Kicked a lot of ass.  Probably my favorite teacher in two years.
was easily sidetracked. didnt fully explain concepts. difficult to get help from. his one plus was his emthusiasm towards the course
wicked hard
This guy was hilarious.  Accents not a problem, it sounds awesome.  Great teacher too.
I had taken a few physics classes before I took his IEA class.  I realized he knew little to nothing and wound up explaining most of the course to the other students.
He gives too much homework and doesn't explain anything.
This guy is the real man.  He likes to talk about his ex-wife.  He is very fun although a little unorganized
enthusisatic but unorganized
No Comments
he was cool..the energy was very exciting...buuuut very  very unorganized. my only gripe

He is the most energetic professor that I've ever had. It was nice to be in a class that professor wanted to teach and wanted us to learn, he was not just standing up in front of students and talking. But. . . he did talk REALLY fast in a carribean accent

Stevenson is very chill. The class has two exams (one Multi-var, one Matrix Alg) and one optional final. He also gave our class a massive formula sheet, though I don't think too many people actually needed it. The one bad part was 8am quizzes in recitations. Quizzes are basically copies of practice he uploads; tests are similar.

He was a good lecturer and a very lenient graders. Exams were straightforward and equation sheets were provided, making this class easier to understand. We were graded on 2 tests, weekly quizzes and an optional final (I did not take), ensuring we learned the content throughout the semester. He's a great option if you want a good grade!
Extremely awful

Stevenson's courses tend to be more proof-based (even 2000s) so he may be hard to understand if you are not strong with mathematical concepts. His lecture style is laid back. Homework sets tend to be challenging but office hours are amazing. He will basically explain the solution in detail to you if you ask for help. Extremely forgiving grader.
He's a good teacher who knows the material and it shows. Lots of knowledge, so office hours are very helpful if they're ever needed.
A gooooood professor that gives great lectures
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: lecture notes are very nice IMO. easy to self-teach, but lectures are worth attending. Notes follow the format of theorems + definition --> maybe a visual demo --> example problems. . Exams have 75% in-person portion --> based off of lecture qs, recitation qs, and quiz qs (pretty easy). No hw, but the Recitation wrksht basically serves as it.
Awesome professor. He truly wants his students to succeed. If I could take him for every math class I would.
Good notes, decent lectures, very accommodating. Homework's and exams fairly assess knowledge and understanding of the material. Would recommend.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Prof Stevenson is dad core without the trauma. He has good lectures, notes, and tests. He is very good at answering student's questions. If you are having trouble, his office hours are very accessible and when I went for homework help, he practically did the question for me. He does focus on theories though but is fair by not testing on them.
He is very nice and passionate about math. Check the homeworks with some friends and study for the tests. The tests follow what he teaches in class very well.

Stevenson is a very nice guy that definitely understands the material of the course, however, his style of teaching was not something I liked very much. He tended to focus more on theoretical material than on practical applications, though this may just be a Diff Eq issue. His tests were more than fair, and Homework was graded nicely even when hard

Stevenson knows the material he teaches and is great at teaching it. His handwriting is clear and his lecture notes are so organized that many don't come to class and do fine. He is generous with deadlines and extensions and many of his tests are styled similarly to practice or homework questions.

As someone who enjoys math, I found Dr. Stevenson's lectures to be inaccessible. His teaching style seems to be designed for math majors or those who took prior courses with him and this did not pique my interest in the subject. Homework is weighted heavily, but he often gave tedious computational problems or obscure proof problems.

Dr. Stevenson has good lectures that explain concepts well, and has fair tests with no surprises if you paid attention. There were no quizzes but instead there was weekly homework of 5-8 questions, only 3 of which were graded. He is probably the best choice for MVC compared to what I have heard about other professors.

I honestly have no idea why these ratings are good. Professor Stevenson is the worst professor I've had. Lectures were boring, always went past the allotted time, making me late to classes. Homeworks were long but few questions were graded, making half of my work obsolete. DON'T take him. I don't have enough characters to describe how bad he was.

Professor Stevenson is a very fair professor, he is likely to give extensions if you ask in advance and will never hesitate to help you if you need it. He is a very good lecturer and will always answer your questions either in person or over email.
Good

Weekly HW, not difficult if you go to recitation. Unlimited page crib sheet that is not collected on exams. I have seen students bring in literal booklets with a table of contents. Exams are straightforward if you study class examples and hw problems. The questions are almost identical. Easy grader. Not the best at explaining conceptual stuff.

Dr. Stevenson is a friendly professor who cares about his students and gives fair assignments and tests. His lectures, however, focus too much on mathematical theory and proofs rather than applications. He does give good examples, but the content can be hard to follow if you don't understand his definitions, theorems, and proofs.
Dr. Stevenson is a caring and friendly professor. He is very passionate about his field and clearly loves to teach. Lectures can be a bit repetitive, but homeworks and exams are graded fairly.

Prof. Stevenson was an excellent teacher. He was able to convey the material well in his lectures, and his lecture notes are very useful when studying. He doesn't give much homework. Do not miss recitation, and don't forget to do the gradescope portion of his test, and you should do well.

Great lecture notes, easy weekly quizzes, no homework, optional final, and exams that are exactly the back exams. It might seem daunting that the entire grade is just quizzes and exams, but the quizzes are a free 10/10, and 25% of every exam is online. While his lectures can draw on an his voice is a tad monotonous, this class is an easy A.

Stevenson is easy A. Good lecture notes. Class test averages are 20+ points above other classes. Easy tests with an in-person and open notes online portion (you have the weekend to do it). TAs go over quiz content for 30-45 min. before quiz during recitation (quizzes are in the last 15 minutes of recitation and are 2 questions). Opt. HW. No Achieve

Dr. Stevenson is a really nice and chill guy. He usually gives out very smart solutions to simplify problems. His lecture style is a theorem followed by an example question.
Homework is basically plugging in different numbers. Exams are medium difficulty, definitely not hard.
Do your hw and backtests, you will be fine

Professor Stevenson is one of the best math professors that RPI has to offer. For his multivariable calculus and linear algebra course, the tests were really easy but the homework was slightly difficult. However, I felt that this balanced out the overall difficulty of the course. Stevenson is very kind, considerate, and an exceptional teacher.
He is very reasonable and cares about students actually learning.
Professor Stevenson is a great lecturer for Calc II. The only big thing to note is he does not assign homework, you are only graded on quizzes and tests. Take that as you will.
He is a great professor, but his notes are not neat.

I had Dan before he was at RPI, but the man is a great teacher who made me love math. Explanations are clear and direct without a lot of fluff, very easy to understand. Tests are definitely hard but not in an unfair way and occasionally have some fun/rewarding questions.

Took him after seeing the reviews here and thought he would be good... I was used to my calc 1/2 teacher whom made me absolutely adore calc, but Stevenson made me stop liking math. Class was not mandatory, but I always went as it helped follow his notes, but that still didn't help much. No quizzes during recitation, so grade is only based exams/hw

Stevenson is one of the best math instructors I've had. He lectures well and maintains a good balance when it comes to what problems you'll see on homeworks and tests, which usually have 1-2 problems per concept and are a very fair assessment.

Took him for diffeq last semester for Multivar this semester. First time teaching the material at RPI for both semesters btw. Seriously, one of the best professors at RPI. He tends to delve into theory a lot but follows it up with examples that are almost word-for-word similar to HW problems and Tests. You can't go wrong taking his classes. Easy A.
Nice grader.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria

comment: Had him for both Calc 2 and Diffeq and he's an incredible teacher. His lectures are a good mix of theory and then a few examples to make the content clear. Posts notes and homework/problem set solutions online so you can check your work. Really accessible and understanding. Probably one of the best math teachers I've ever had.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Amazing lectures

comment: Does not provide enough examples for material.
Easy class. Tests are short and just like lecture. Quiz in recitation is easy. Homeworks are optional as is attendance to class. Learned calc 2, got easy A.

He is a good professor does a lot of theory, but also does examples and steps for a lot of the problems. he is also really nice and you can tell he cares about his students because he is always available in office hours. even though class is not mandatory I would still go because he tends to not write everything he says down in his notes.

Dan is seriously awesome. He makes Diffeq extremely comfortable and easy no matter what your math background is. As long as you know how to do the HW's and in class examples, the tests will be a lightwork. He is also accessible during office hours and is willing to help you understand the content. Overall, great professor and very straightforward.

Dr. Stevenson is a great professor. He takes his time to make sure that every student is able to understand the content properly and is ready for exams. He is great during office hours and is generally pretty laid back.

He is a nice guy and a decent teacher. He is great in office hours and if you need help on the homework he is always there. He also tries to get to know his students if you put in the effort. His tests are mixes sometimes they are easy sometimes they are hard. I had him for calc II, now for differential equations, next semester I will have him.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: Teaching is good but texts are so freaking hard.
He's a laid back professor but is still a great lecturer
other reviews arent huge fans of him, but i thought wetzel was a pretty fun prof. he doesnt remarkably standout but hes helpful when you need help and makes jokes from time to time

Anyone rating this professor higher than a 1 aren't in their right mind, he literally (as the rating below me states) reads off the slides which the physics department does NOT make any easier.. the structure of the course is sloppy and the professor does not make everything any better. Please pick West instead or Kim.
He doesn't go over any problems in class and he just points and reads off the board all of class.
not good at all, avoid at all costs

This professor simply can not teach the material well. Everyone who I know who received a good grade in his class learned the entire material through the textbook. I ended up retaking the class with professor Kim, who was a far better at explaining the knowledge (my new grade reflecting that). This is not a hard class if you have the right teacher

This professor wasn't great at all, I truly dont recommend taking a class with him if you can. He didn't explain the material well and was occasionally rude. For this class I think that its best to take it with professor Kim.

Professor Wetzel is a fine person, though the PHYS-1100 course is structured terribly. He was very kind and understanding when working with me regarding missed assignments, and many of his lectures were only tolerable thanks to his sense of humor, as the slides the department provides are far from useful.

My main critique is less Professor Wetzel himself, and more the poor structure of the course itself. That being said, choose another professor. Wetzel often does not explain concepts well, and can sometimes be very rude and not understanding. Relying on outside resources or prior knowledge for this class is more helpful than the lecture slides.
Lectures are boring, but practice exams given before tests are very helpful and similar to the actual test.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework--Test heavy

comment: I really liked Professor Wetzel this semester. He does try to help you even if sometimes he doesn't explain everything well, but his lecture slides were always pretty easy to understand. And he is very lenient and understanding with extensions if you have a good reason. He checked in on me personally multiple times to make sure I was caught up.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: I hated Physics 1, not because of Dr. Wetzel, but due to the way the class is structured. Every period, you go in, do an activity, while relying on an extremely short lecture video that all Physics 1 classes share. These activities did not help, and you have to learn most of it yourself.

All of the physics professors use the same slides, so it really doesn't matter who you get. Wetzel was a decent lecturer, usually got through the lectures pretty quickly so that students could work on the lab activities. Very accessible and reasonable; easy to talk to about grades or missing papers.

The way I didn't learn a single thing in this class <<< You couldn't pay me to take this class again. This man was so hard to understand, not because of his accent just because he makes everything more complicated than it needs to be. If you don't understand anything within the first few weeks, drop the class. Switch to Kim instead.

Tough curriculum, although this appears to be the fault of the department and not the professor. He occasionally jumps through topics without talking about them much and assumes everyone understands it. Doesn't explain some things very well.

His lectures are dry even though he tries to make jokes, so I want to sleep in every class. His expectant tone of voice makes it hard to ask for clarifications because he expects us to just know physics and makes you sound stupid. And if you make a mistake, you can tell he disguises his annoyance and is passive aggressive.

Wetzel attempts to make jokes in class which generally fail. He teaches as if we all understand physics at his level, and make fun of students in front of the whole class who do not understand. Does not attempt to show how an answer is obtained. Spends much of class texting while the TAs are overloaded with questions.
A fun teacher, who is very easy to listen too.  However, he does not go over material as well as I would like.

Wetzel is generally a nice person, though I've witnessed harsh comments towards his TAs, probably out of frustration that the class is quite lost. The tests for all Physics sections were made by Ciolek this semester. Wetzel's section fared badly, with average scores ranging from 55-70 on each test.

If you don't have a solid background in physics, I don't recommend taking his course.  He is very smart and doesn't realize that physics is not as easy to everyone as it is to him.  He often calls the entire class lazy if we don't know how to solve a problem rather than realize that he probably didn't explain things so well.

He might be best physics teacher as he speaks english and examples well. But he is a hard grader. you will learn if you pay attention and go to class. but physics is all about tests, so take him and pay attention. no slacking
No Comments
I certainyl enjoyed his class a lot. I felt like he was pretty good at explaining the material. Plus the grad TA that I had was excellent, so I learned a lot from my TA as well.

A smart guy who has trouble understanding why physics is difficult. Also, his accent is a little less than "charming," native German speakers may have difficulty understanding him when he tries to say words like "Tangential." Or "Joules."
No Comments

He is such a helpful professor. His lecture is very interesting, so I never fell asleep in his class. He explains everything very clearly;making sure that we understand the concept visually helped me a lot. Plus, his German accent is so charming.
avoid him!
No Comments
He tried to get us to use our own knowledge of physics, which was tough in the beginning.

As long as you're not entirely incompetent and pay attention while he lectures (read: don't stare at your laptop all class), he's very helpful and very explanatory.  Compared to what I hear about a lot of the other phys 1 professors (aside from Bedrosian and some others), he's certainly one of the better ones. Plus, he actually has a sense of humor

Wetzel was okay in lectures and activities. He tries to help students out, especially if you make an appointment and go see him he gives you advice and some comments on your work. (Its good to go see him) He was a nice guy
lectures are helpful, keeps them interesting
No Comments
All he does is talk to himself in front of the classroom, instead of teaching!!!!!!!!!!!!
Not great, but not horrible. Nice.
I thought he was a good professor?!  He's very friendly and willing to help.  I think that he is clear and his examples are helpful.

Agree w/ rating @ bottom of pg. Bring your laptop to class! Boring + Confusing. U're better off ignoring him + learn on own. Ask for help on a hw prob, and he'll spend 10min on it, realize he'd messed up and just move on. TAs helpful. Don't skimp at the beginning. Not same as highschool phys.

the guy truly is 100% terrible.   subs were SO VERY much better than wetzel.   and i told the subs that....specially prof cummings.   he was great and i told him i wished he was teaching our class.   wetzel just didn't want to help or answer questions or be of any sort of use to the class.

He's awful. He was absent twice in my class and the subs were so much better. One of the subs was Cunnings. He, along with Bedrosian are awesome. They don't tell you which professor you have (it says Bedrosian for all). If you do get Wetzel, try to switch. Really, anyone is better than Wetzel.

Freshmen need to stop whining and realize what exactly a bad professor is. Compared to others at RPI, Wetzel is a decent professor. The class is set up badly in general (especially the useless lecture slides) and that is not Wetzel's fault. A decent guy and much better than many other RPI professors
worst prof ever

He gets the homework problems wrong in class if you ask him. Then when the TA corrects him, he gets flustered and trys to explain why his way is still correct, even though it isn't. In summation, he's a big ****. He doesn't prepare you for the tests at all.

Zeghal lectures painfully slow, even for simple things like manipulating basic vectors. This can be painful, but he teaches you everything you need to know and finishes the lectures, so I can't ding him for that. Besides that, he's a fine professor, and I would argue he's just as good as any other IEA profs.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I thought Dr. Zeghal was an excellent instructor for IEA! He provided back exams with problems very similar to the exams. IEA is a difficult course but he explained the content in a more understandable way! I would definitely recommend

I thought he was great. Teaches very well. He occasionally emphasizes a thing unnecessarily, but not often. I got a B in the class but I understand and remember all the material better than any other class. He has review sessions and back exams that are super helpful. Only complaint is he didn't answer my email one time. My favorite class so far.

He teaches, and that's about the best thing I have to say about him. He responds to emails once in a blue moon, even talking to him about it after class doesn't help that issue. He's typically extremely late with uploading lecture slides and is often difficult to understand because of his mumbly speech.

Oftentimes doesn't upload lecture slides until over 3 weeks have passed, making studying examples absurdly challenging. Almost never responds to emails. Emphasizes information on slides that don't matter and/or are obvious and understood to everyone in class while briefly skimming over the most important things that will be on tests.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: Lectures are slow, repetitive, and often lack information that will be present on homework or tests. Problems practiced in class are generally helpful for understanding a new concept, but fail to prepare you for the large difficulty spike of exam problems. I tried many times to reach out to the professor when sick but would receive no response.

This is a good professor for a difficult course. Everything that is needed to know for tests is taught well and thoroughly. Yes, he teaches on the slower side, but for me, it was a nice change of pace compared to most courses at RPI. HW is harder than tests, but doesn't take too long to complete. Overall, a good professor
His lectures were sometimes unclear, but if you ask him questions, he is very knowledgeable and will help you through the problem.

Professor Zeghal was a very solid teacher for IEA. If you put in the work, his lectures will be more than enough to prepare you for the exams. He's not very enthusiastic but I didn't find that to be a bad thing. I actually liked it, almost like an organic chemistry tutor vibe. Would rec for IEA.

Your experience with Dr. Zeghal is proportional to the effort you put into the class. Ask questions during lectures and reach out to him during office hours, and you'll find him to be very knowledgeable and eager to help. His lectures help to prepare for the exams, but they can be very slow. Homeworks are much more difficult than the exams.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Accessible outside class

comment: Zeghal is a great lecturer and prepares for exams well.  IEA is a tough course, but he explains the material in a comprehensive way.

IEA itself is a bit of a learning curve but this professor does not make it easy to get over the curve. In class he mostly mumbles and keeps skipping things "for the sake of time". When asked a question, he will go off on a tangent and leave your question mostly unanswered. I ended up going to the TAs or upperclassmen for help.
I found IEA to be a hard class but Professor Zeghal is a good lecturer and is helpful during office hours.

IEA is a tough class, but he cares enough to provide examples to work in class for credit. For these problems, he does not just assume the TA's have got everything and will go out of his way to explain problems crystal clear. He gets a bad rap on this site I'm assuming from people who didn't do well. Just go to class and don't be afraid to ask.

Professor Zeghal did give slow lectures at times, but he always got through all the necessary content on time regardless. Everything was clearly laid out and plenty of examples where given to help us students prepare for tests. He also would regularly schedule extra office hours if students where having a hard time with concepts.

Dr. Zeghal effectively teaches IEA, however, his lectures are extremely slow and boring. There isn't too much homework, but be sure to check your answers! There were frequent grading errors on exams, and the rubrics were completely incomprehensible, even to the TAs. Don't expect your exam to be graded promptly either!

IEA is a tough class, but professor Zeghal did a great job to make it interesting. This became one of my favorite classes of my freshman year, despite it being the hardest. Professor Zeghal was so helpful in and out of lecture, and he had tons of office hours. Just make sure to pay attention in lecture, it is very important if you want to pass.
Honestly not a fan, I'll put it this way, I'm retaking the class with a different professor

Crystal clear lecturer with solid powerpoints. The content is relatively difficult for a first year course, but the in-class assignments and the 1 hr long homeworks usually help keep you attentive. Back exams are also readily available and help a lot.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Great, comprehensive lectures. For the difficulty of the material, he did a great job teaching it. In-class assignments were a great help in understanding the concepts, and the homework was abundant but not busy work. It really helped. No more than 1.5 hours of HW between classes and that was rare. Use the back exams. They're life-savers.

Dr. Zeghal's lectures were very clear and incredibly helpful. A lot of people were not fond of his lecture style, but I found it to be very comprehensive. The online homework was helpful in practicing, and therefore learning, the material. The class itself was not an easy A, but with a hard work that grade can be achieved. Use back exams to study!
Repeats simple concepts and solutions rather than explaining harder ones that will be on homework and exams
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Clear grading criteria--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Not an easy A but cared about his students. If you went to him for help he was more than willing to figure things out with you. I wish he'd sent the power points out before or after class so that we'd had access to them to study from. His lecture style was fast paced, he sort of expected you
He cared about all his students and made sure that everyone was doing fine. His lectures were great and his review sessions before tests were super beneficial.

Not an easy A for sure but if you're willing to study a bit and pay attention in class, you should have no problems. Go to every class: Zeghal is a great lecturer and genuinely wants to help students that don't understand. For every problem on the test, we covered similar examples in class. Just bring a blanket to class, he keeps the room ice cold.
Very good professor, the online homework can be difficult, but he does a good job with tests and reviews questions very closely related to the exam q's. Would recommend
Very helpful during lectures and test were easy.

Good professor; knows the material well and is very good at communicating it. The material itself was hard for me to grasp, but I feel his teaching helped make it a lot easier. Plus his accent is cool.
His notes for lecture are very straightforward and make sense. Ask questions; he happily answers. Both of his sections had the highest averages for the tests this year. Overall, he's wonderful!

Helpful and Interesting, lays out all the material in the easiest way to understand. People complains about him going to fast, if you ask him to slow down he is more than willing too. However, on review days he sometimes goes to slow! His accent is easy to understand and amusing.Great experience for my first collegiate engineering course.

He is a good teacher, can be boring at times sitting for 2 hours in a lecture. Has an accent but i got used to it after about one lecture and had no trouble understanding him. Wants you to succeed. Post his lectures online and everything else about this course is constant between all professors. Shows lots of example problems during lecture.
Overall pretty good professor for this class. Only downside is all the homework he gives :-( 10 homework problems can take you 6 hours. Still I would reccomend this class with him
He is a pretty good teacher. He went too slow for me though, and teaches stuff you do not actually need
Class was more unorganized than anything else.  His lectures were less than helpful.  As an IEA professor he is great.

I was stuck with Professor Zeghal for IEA, which was a bit unfortunate for everybody involved since, from what I understand, he's not really a first-year studies kind of professor.  It was very intense at the beginning of the semester, but as the semester progressed everything began to get easier, and I credit Professor Zeghal.

Prof. Zeghal is an overall excellent professor for this class. His examples cover the most important material and his review sessions are a great guide for studying for the tests. In class though, he can tend to get too caught up in derivations. However, he can usually help settle any difficulties that you have in his office hours.
Boring class, but he is helpful at office hours.  Lectures are clear and easy to follow.  He also tells you what's on the tests, and has review sessions before.  Take strengths with him.

His voice puts you to sleep, doesnt try to make the subject more exciting, but he tries to be helpful, keeps repeating to us his office hours, and looks you square in the eye when ur answering one of his questions... did i mention he kinda looks like zoolander?

Good IEA professor. Willing to help students and actually cares about making them understand what's going on. TA's suck at grading...every test I had to get points back, but regrading sessions were held (long lines).
It was a pleassure to be in his class. Very helpfull! Gives great, long reviews before every exam! Has nice acentt.
Boring boring class.  He doesn't make it any more interesting but at least he's a pretty easy teacher.  Do your homework and tests and you can pretty much sleep through class.

His lectures are not very helpful in learning the material for the second half of the course. The homework's do not align with the course material. You have to do the hws and activities to get an A. The tests are easy if you do the provided back exams. Overall if you do the classwork, it is very possible to get an A

The lectures were math-heavy. If you're good with calculus, you'll have no issues, although the thermodynamics section felt rushed. Attendance is mandatory for both lectures and labs. There are two in-person exams with questions similar to previous years, and one take-home online final. It's an easy A if you attend lectures and practice past exams.

Homeworks often don't align well with lecture material, need to attend class to get lecture activities, the back exams he provides are basically the exam with different numbers, you get a front/back crib sheet for exams too.

Overall there is way too much emphasis on the math portion of the course and not enough on the actual intuition behind the concepts. The first half of the course if manageable if you've done Physics I in high school, however the second half is a train wreck, doing thermodynamics in 3 days and rushing through all of it. Korniss is a nice guy though

Had him for classical dynamics. Have to go to class to get activity worksheets which are due 2x/week. Nice TAs and mentors. If you do all HW and labs perfectly, you roughly need an average minimum of an 80 on very exam. +10 point extra credit on exams. Lectures are just doing multi.. I don't know multi. Have an A so far but subject to change.

His lectures are literally just calculus. No concept.

If you are able to grasp material by merely looking at an equation: your solid.
If not: have fun buddy, I know I sure didn't!

And some real talk: All he does in lecture is go through each step of the math as though it's not sitting there in front of you. Not helpful.

He is very nice though.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Korniss is the most caring and understanding professor I've ever had and it's nearly impossible to fail his class. There's a lot of multivar/diffeq, but he explains its connection to the formulas very clearly and conscisely. He even went out of his way to make the material extra accessible when I was out sick. Cannot recommend him enough!

Normal Physics 1 looks like middle-school content to me. His Honors Physics 1 was a complete nightmare. He taught so many concepts, such as general relativity and thermodyn. What made things really hard was the level of Mathematics involved. Diffeq and Multivar were used heavily in his lecture notes. Anyway, generous grader. Exams weren't hard.

Lectures can be very dense(lots of calculus), tbh I don't understand why calc-1 is a co-requisite, partial derivatives and line integrals are used often, students must be able to understand calc-3 if they haven't studied it yet. Far more in depth than a standard AP class, definitely don't skip as a physics major.

Learned everything from the textbook. His lectures were actually useless, but I still had to go because he handed out assignments during the lecture breaks. On the bright side, he is very willing to help.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: This man is a god. Physics major or not, take his intro physics class. Back exams are posted on his website and very much resemble the real thing. There are often a large number of conceptual questions that are directly from the back exams. Study the back exams, and you'll have no trouble in this class. HW is from book, can be downloaded online.

Lectures are upper level math heavy with triple intervals and partial derivatives but you usually won't need to use them on the homework or tests. Tests don't have any surprises, they're very similar to the backtests and the problems gone over in class. Korniss seems to care about his students and can offer a lot of help if you need it.

He throws line integrals and partial derivatives at you in the first month. He is a very personable guy. He is okay with you turning in activities late with a semi-valid excuse. His TAs grade labs and that is toss up whether they are reasonable or not. My friends would make sure every persons labs were close to failing, while mine was okay.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Lectures are very math heavy and he uses Diff EQs and Multi Var so if you haven't taken calc before be warned.

Professor Korniss is a great teacher if you're interested in physics. He doesn't spare you on the mathematical side of it, and therefore when you understand things that he teaches or the problems that he assigns you can feel extremely accomplished. He is caring and willing to help if you ask.
Really nice guy, the class is challenging as are the tests but if you use the notes and the provided back tests it isn't so bad.

Very interesting material, and Korniss covered it very well. Tests are essentially the questions covered in lecture/in-class problems with the occasional problem that is similar to a homework question. Oh and once you get used to him you'll find that he's hilarious.

Lectures almost always consist of long, complex derivations that will make your head explode. Homework is much less challenging than the lectures and the tests are a downright joke. Korniss is a bit quiet but is always willing to help 1-on-1 if you're confused. It's easy to get a good grade but the material itself is very deep.

The class was ridiculously difficult for absolutely no reason at all. Lecture was useless. Everything I learned was from reading the textbook. Lecture barely matched what the homework did, and the tests railed everyone every single time.

Brilliant man. However, we are young and therefore not so brilliant. Expects a level of intellect that as freshman we haven't obtained yet. Extremely difficult material, combined with accent and speed of speech makes a bad combination. Made me sad =(

Korniss' brain is lightyears ahead of everyone's, but he has the humility to walk you through material you don't understand. Oh, and he's Hungarian, so he has an awesome accent. He probably killed a man once.

The hw was easy, however the tests are pretty difficult so pay attention in class, also he is not super forgiving on tests.  He teaches mostly from the book and is pretty clear.  Lectures were a little dry but that has more to do with the material than the teacher.  Overall he is a nice guy and I would take another course with him.
I'm sorry but he was horrible. I still learned everything I had to learn because I completely relied on the textbook.

? second that he is the man! easy tests, but sometime the homework is challenging. his lecture covers a lot about physics and he showed the process of how physicists derive the formulas brightly. Thought his accent could be a pain and sometime he talks too fast?
Gyorgy is THE MAN! Attend his lectures, you'll fall behind fast if you skip.
cool dude, good teacher
Excellent professor.  Very helpful and approachable inside and outside of class.  The class notes and homework were challenging.  The exams were straight forward and the grading was easy.
Great guy, good teacher.  He practically gave us the answers to the tests the class before, and they were open notes/open book.  He's pretty easy to understand if you get past the accent.
Korniss is smart and thoughtful.  He cares whether you get it.

He would read the notes he handed you. He knows what he is doing, but it is still a rough class that requires a lot of time to understand. His homeworks are hard, but the exams were very reasonable, especially the grading
He is an understading guy, helpful if u ask questions, and keeps stuff brief, very knowledgable, phys I is pretty easy

One of the smartest profs I've had, but hard as nails; doesn't suffer fools gladly. Make sure you have a good overall understanding before you ask him any detail related questions. Expect homeworks to take a very significant amount of time - find/organize a group. Very possible to get an A, but you must put the time in.
difficult class, but he's extremely helpful if you go to him for help. HW is really hard, but exams were very reasonable.
Good teacher, very helpful if you ask questions.  Nice guy.  Lectures are read from powerpoint, but are very short.  I get out early every class.

Tough class, but he can be very helpful. Make sure you take down ALL notes in class, as he'll usually slip in a solution to one of the hw problems. Go to office hours, hw will kill you if you don't keep up. Tests arent too bad, as long is you make it the the class prior (he gives you the answers).

8am in Carnegie with a chalkboard. Does a few very long problems in class. Boring, but more helpful that the book. Very helpful after class. Does "sample" problems in class that are almost exactly what's on the test and lets you use notes/book on test. Good soccer player.
Boring class....equation after equation that took up the entire front wall.  Handwriting a little hard to read, but he reviews for his tests - and usually uses the questions he does in class.
class was at 8am... boring as hell to listen to him lecture.  Very helpful, sends email to students who do badly on the first exam.

Lvov is a nice person and knows the material, but we were months behind other professors. Did not cover laplace transforms, fourier series, or PDEs. His lectures can be confusing, but the tests are extremely easy if you study from the website. Some homeworks are very difficult or were not covered in lecture, saved by the TA, but most are not hard.

Yuri is an interesting professor, he is a very kind man but he also is not a good teacher. His lectures are boring/unhelpful so I never went and still learned all of the course meterial. I was able to do this becasue my TA was great so I learned a lot through the reciataitions and by doing the homeworks. Exams are predictable with lots extra credit

He's a good person and knows the material he's teaching, but unfortunately it's hard to understand because of his russian accent and his handwriting (some letters are written really similarly). He's also pretty helpful if you email him questions about anything (be specific though). Just study for the tests using his website and you'll be fine.

Impressively bad.

Edit: F24's course with Dr. Lvov ended up like an entire month behind *every other professor*. I'm sorry but students deserve at minimum to have access to materials explicitly stated to be taught in the curriculum.

I had this professor for MATH4400 and he was one of the worst professors I have had. His lectures have you confused and he does not explain what he is doing. His note are handwritten and barely legible. He always says to visit his "website" for all information, yet it is poorly made and has nothing he claims. Zero back exams. Horrible experience.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Worst professor at RPI. Notes are in sharpie and uploaded into a 300+ page pdf with no organization. His handwriting is impossible to read. He grades super hard on exams and refuses to rescore, even if he made a mistake while grading. He's condescending and rude in office hours and never responds to emails. AVOID HIM AT ALL COSTS!

Professor Lvov falls into a specific type: he is clearly brilliant and has a deep understanding of advanced mathematics, but is ineffective at conveying it to non-experts. His lectures often moved quickly through tough material, focusing on derivations over examples. Can be a great resource when supplemented with recitation and textbook reading.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Yuri isn't the worst professor you could have. That being said, he's nowhere close to the best. I learned 90% of the course from my TA and the textbook. During my semester with him, the tests were average but he was SUCH an easy grader. My understanding of the material is probably a C, but I got an A from trying every problem on the test. No HW.

Don't take this professor. If you can take Prof. Kam as a lecturer do so. His lectures are super unprofessional and disorganized... You will mainly have to teach yourself from the textbook. There is no homework, only quizzes, and exams. He messes up multiple times when problem-solving and doesn't explain the process.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: No graded assignments. The grade is an average of exams, cumulative recitation quiz grade, and the final. The lectures, however, are terribly explained, disorganized, and not at all informative. You will end up teaching yourself from the textbook. He is also very unreasonable, and hard to work/communicate with over email.

Hard homeworks/exams but easy grader (does not curve at all so don't try to convince him). Did not like the way he taught the class (curses time to time). About 3/4 of the class dropped about a week in, only stuck through it cause of credit.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: I would not recommend this professor. He does not clearly explain material and goes so slow you are lucky if you make it to the second half of the course. We started the linear algebra half of the class with 2 weeks left in the semester. There is so much material we didn't cover. The tests are either super easy or hard but scaled ridiculously high

Prof. Lvov is a gem - he makes oftentimes difficult material more accessible and easier to understand with his lectures, & the structure of the course/the path followed through the course material made digesting everything straightforward. Of all the math courses I took at RPI, I found his among the easiest to attend, understand, & learn from.

Lvov is not as bad as a lot of people says he is. He does a decent job teaching, and he will answer pretty much any question no matter how dumb it may be. He tells jokes during lectures, some are funny, and some don't make any sense, and most are offensive, but he kept me awake. There's a lot of extra credit available if you're willing to do it.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: If you aim to pass the course and get a not bad grade, he might be the best choice ever in RPI for this course! Because his way of calculation of the final grades are kind to everyone. However, if you are in Math department or you really needs those knowledge, please avoid him. He skips a lot of course material and wastes time during lectures.

Lvov knows the material, but he can't teach it. The only way I learn how to do the homework is by reading the textbook. I study a lot and I still can't understand the type of responses he wants on the exams. Not easy to do well. No matlab experience? goodluck. I DO NOT recommend.

Pretty good. Clear lectures, likes questions, but slow so misses important material (diffeq is EVERYWHERE@rpi). Encourages questions. Homework sets optional and very comprehensive/gr8 review. Tests and quizzes pretty easy, forgiving grading system. Jokes vary wildly in quality. VERY knowledgeable, though. If interested you can get a lot out of him.

Despite being a very nice man, he is not that great when it comes to teaching. Sometimes his writing is hard to understand or he skips some steps... etc I would advice going to his class from time to time but you will be just fine by doing the optional homework problems. It's an easy A if you know how yo use the formulas..

Horrible at giving lectures, he has no organization at all in teaching. Handwriting is hard to tell, and usually, he is not available outside of class. You may want to buy him a microphone because his voice is so low that you often can't hear what he says.

It isn't too hard to get a decent grade in his class, you can do a final project for 10% extra credit. But the professor has a pretty heavy accent and his notes are so hard to understand. Which require you to spend extra time to figure things out yourself. He also provides very few resources for you to study and review.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: I took differential equations with Lvov last semester.  As many have said, he's very Russian.  He has a slight accent, but he's easy to understand.  He tells a lot of dumb jokes and gives a lot of extra credit.  I didn't have any mandatory homework in the class I took.  Attendance was mostly optional, but for a few days he tried to take attendance.

Worst c;ass I've taken thus far at RPI. It's hard to do well in a class where the prof. verbally informs me he doesn't enjoy teaching it. As an aeronautical engineer, I got absolutely nothing out of this class except useless math theory which I won't use again. Homework takes forever and he doesn't teach the Matlab portion, the most important part.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: He's actually a really good professor, he answers any questions in class and explains things well. His homework answers online are wrong but other than that I can't complain. He's really funny and very Russian but not hard to understand. If you do the online homework and go to lecture the exams are really easy.

Lectures are confusing, not very helpful, very russian. He has a course website with everything you need for the class. Do the problem on that site and you will get an A. Get the book, do the problems, follow the proofs and put them on your crib sheet.
For spring 2015, gave 26 free points on exams. However, the exams were kind of tough. He is a not a good lecturer, but you can find all the information online and do fine
He's pretty funny, easy tests and quizzes, will do well if you take notes and then supplement with the textbook for exams

Professor Lvov isn't the best instructor for Diff Eq. He tries to be funny and makes jokes very often, but his lectures aren't very clear. He often makes mistakes and is ambiguous as towards what he's trying to show. To his defense, he does encourage students to ask questions and attend his office hours. Exams and quizzes are easy as well.

Don't listen to people who tell you to avoid him. He's a great professor, his accent isn't bad, and he loves jokes.  His exams are four 25 point questions and one 20 point question that is extra credit. He wants you to ask questions, and he wants you to get an A.  And honestly it's worth it just for the jokes. Take him if you can.
the exam is very easy.

Lvov is bad news. Hardly does anything to help his students. (No lecture notes, hw solutions, practice tests, or test solutions posted) Makes mistakes constantly. Horrible at operating Matlab. Loses focus or gets confused and harasses his students to fix the issue for him. Test ?'s are not like the homework ?'s at all. I'd recommend any1 b4 Lvov.

He is terrible during lectures. Spends most lecture talking to the board. Some jokes once in  a while. Constantly makes mistakes when doing examples, which are literally copied from his notes. Learned the class's material from the TA, who also wasn't notified of exam material, some of which were stuff he spoke softly to the board. Self-Study+GoToTA

Lvov knows math, that's for sure, but he has a poor way of communicating the ideas to students.  Diffeq is tough if you don't have a math mind, and although he covers the "what" in lecture, he doesn't even begin to address the "why".  He's also difficult to deal with (told the TA nothing about the final, making it harder to study)

He is funny, knowledgeable and supportive. He's been teaching NC for roughly 10 yrs. His English's surely improved to a good level. It's harsh in the syllabus and the grade of the first homework. But after that he is very generous on grading(2 of 4 questions already told before exam). He likes proofing.  He is the best professors I've ever met.

Don't know what the other raters here are talking about. Just finished his class and I intend to take his other courses too. He gives you several textbooks to read, tells you where to find the current material. Gives great EC. He wants students to ask questions because he wants them to know the material. HW was rough but you learn so much from it.

The only prof worth taking NC from.  He actually cares that you learn the material.  The HW are hard and time consuming, but worthwhile.  Definitely not busy work.  Tests are just right, not easy, not impossible, but require a great deal of though.  There are enough bonus points to keep you afloat though.

This is the absolute worte professor.  He complains if you don't ask enough questions.  His selection in textbooks is terrible as it shows no example that are worthwhile.  He teaches nothing about matlab which every homework is based on, its ridic that if you have no background in matlab you are screwed.

This professor subbed for two days of the Numerical Computing section taught by Kapila. Me and my friend found him very interesting and motivating. He was very interested that people understood everything he went over and strongly encouraged asking questions. Slightly wishing I had been in his section.

Homework amounts to plug'n'chug.  Tests amount to Monte-Carlo regurgitation of notes.   He states he's "too lazy" to put course notes online -- instead you must refer to those from previous years which are in a 200 page, unindexed, PDF of his horrid writing.  The course material itself is interesting to me, but this professor does a half-arsed jo
Terrible teacher...I would rather take it with Giladi in the spring

Tough grader, boring lecturer.  His syllabus states that if you fail any homework, exam or quiz you will fail the course.  This is simply him showing his inability to use the English well.  He's trying to say that if you're consistantly failing your homeworks, you'll probably fail the course.

This professor taught the absolute worst class that I ever took. His policy was simply that if you failed anything, ranging from a homework to an exam, you automatically failed the course. He was harsh in his grading as well.

His lectures would be 20 minutes at most since he knew we wouldn't pay attention if it was longer. His lectures never matched up with tests but tests were easy enough that this wasn't an issue. Course became online and asynchronous about halfway through the semester so it became even easier. Want a GPA booster, take with Larry Reid.
Goes on tangents, and doesn't really teach, but it's an easy psych class.

I'm sure Dr. Reid was great once, but I can't give him a good rating. He's very old, can't hear 90% of what students say, and you won't hear/understand like 50% of what he says. Class "discussions" are embarrassing as he goes on tangents then blames students for not talking. Content is interesting and if you put in any effort at all you'll get an A
If youre upset about InfoWars being removed from social media, you can attend this professors lectures instead.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: It is literally impossible to receive anything less than a 100 in his Abnormal Psych class. The first half of the semester are hour long lectures and the second half is retaking tests and researching . You retake the exact same test until you get everything right. He won't let you turn it in otherwise. You do a final presentation on any disorder.
rating_tags: TEST HEAVY--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: My favorite professor I've ever had.  I would jump at any chance to take a course he teaches.  Not only is he extremely intelligent and knowledgeable, but he is also very wise and pretty funny too.  He demands respect of his students, which I highly admire.
