Anyone who is on their phone during his lectures is really missing out.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational--Amazing lectures

comment: Thoroughly entertaining lecturer and easy enough tests. Go to class, you'll learn something and its worth his antics alone.

Professor Reid is a very knowledgeable man and a great professor. He makes learning the subject of psychopharmacology really interesting. He's also a really nice guy as long as you're never late to his class!
Extremely intelligent.  Learned tons in his classes.  Be respectful; on time, come to class, don't text, or else he'll call you out.

Will supposedly randomly take attendance and drop everyone's grade a letter who's not there, but never did so all semester.  All tests are cumulative and contain some questions that were on previous tests, so its easy to redeem your grade after a poor start.  Lectures don't correlate to tests, but they are sometimes interesting.

He gives interesting lectures and his tests aren't particularly hard, but the curve is brutal. He's very reasonable with fixing grading errors on the tests as well. Don't fool around or be late to class or you will regret it.

This class was easy and very interesting. Is an easy A if you read the text, come to class and study the back test. Just don't fall asleep in class, for he will make fun of you. Also don't get caught doing other things in class....he can throw you out with no questions asked. He can come off as a little creepy at times but is easy going and funny.

I took his class in Spring 00. He gives A's easily and is easy going. For engineering students, you learn to be responsible adults when dealing with drugs. For psychology students, you are missing out! Other schools require their students to work much harder than Reid does which puts you at a disadvantage because you do not learn much.
Clear and knowledgeable but slightly pompous.
The best psychology professor in this school! Very interesitng lectures, attend them, do the reading and you will deffinetlly get an A.

keep to his rules and you will be fine. he occasionally takes attendence and might lower ur grade a full letter for one miss. the scalin is also diff than most classes an A starts at 92, and 69 and below is an F, believe offhand that a B starts at 85. also saw him throw a kid out of class for sleepin and he told him to drop the class.
Easy A... and one word: Obedient. :P
Borderline crazy, but an interesting class regardless, or maybe because of.  Don't disagree with him, he'll chew your head off for the entertainment of others.  Really easy A.
Interesting lectures.  Funny guy who knows alot.  Alot of reading is required for tests, but they aren't so hard as he gives you back tests.

the guy is incredibly interesting, class isn't a drag to go to.  not hard to get an A, but don't get caught sleeping or doing other stuff while in his class.  he threw a kid out of the course for doing other homework in his class.  but if you sit there and listen, the class is very interesting.

Back tests make things easy. Lectures are interesting and he knows when to cut it short. He can come off as an **** sometimes but he wears sweater vests so he can't be a real hardass. Overall the class is fairly easy and very worthwhile.

Good Class.  Interesting Stories.  The room is in Sage and it's a 6pm class.  Get's as hot as balls so it's really easy to fall asleep in.  So take the class get an easy A or B and catch up on your sleep.
EXCELLENT entertaining speaker, very clear, nothing is tricky in this class but tests do take studying.
One of the more entertaining lecturers on campus.  If you learn the basics you can very easily get a B from him.  One of the best profs at RPI.
He is one of the most interesting lecturors out there, loved the class.  Knows a lot and teaches it well
I don't know where you draw the line between strong-willed educator and hard-ass traditional academic goat is... but larry seems to tread this well. Boring, memorization, wierdo... whatever.
Lecture tends to get boring, but tests are predictable from a series of questions he gives you ahead of time.
Class is easy, but the guy is very condescending toward the students, always trying to push his code of morality on you which gets annoying.  Not hard to get an A though.
Very nice man.
Definitely one of the best profs. I have had in this school.

this guy is THE MAN. he is the best prof i have had yet. 80% of the tests are the practice questions and the rest are from the reading, so if you do practice tests you can get a B without a lot of work.  the class was fun too.

lectures were a waste-his tests were a scattershot collection of prior tests and practice questions he gives out. and a lot of the questions were based on the 4th ed of the book(we had the 5th!!!!!). nice guy, but class could use more integrity

Good guy and all... but make sure you NEVER look up during one of his tests or he'll say you were cheating and threten to throw you out of his class... happed to me... wasn't very happy at all with him from that point on.
No Comments

Prof. Reid is an excellent teacher, probably one of the best at RPI.  He certainly had a huge impact on me, in fact taking this class almost single handedly made me change my lifelong career goals.  Yeah, I really liked the class that much.

What a great class and a stand up professor. Do not cross him and go to class. He is old school and will embarrass you every chance you give him. Speak your mind and ask questions. One of the best classes I have ever taken. Great Professor, do the work.
good sense of humor

He is well educated on the topic he is teaching, but he doesn't care much about students success. It's important you pay attention in class and take good notes. I would recommend taking the class with friends who you can rely on. The class average was with a 50%

You could tell this class is probably not where he wants to be.  If you're stuck on any concepts, it's better to find a friend to help than pursue him.  If the material is easy for you, he's fine, but his way of explaining things can leave you in the dark more often than not.
Worst Professor I have EVER come in contact with. Refused to go any deeper than "study harder" for advice on how to do better.

The math portion of tests very closely matched the homework given.  Some multiple choice word questions were ambiguous.  He is very uncompromising with regards to his way of thinking and becomes verbally nasty when asked questions about test material.  I got an A, but I still wanted to punch him in the face.

He doesnt care about students, or teaching. You can email him a million times and even if its about how he gave you the wrong final grade (an F) which caused you to be on probation he will not answer.

He is a smart guy but he can't teach and doesn't try to explain the material. Lectures didn't fit with the book whatsoever and homeworks made nothing clear.  The book was terrible and didn't match the material we were expected to know at all. His tests are not complex, though he will murder you with the grading. I did well in his class despite him.

tons of office hours visits ended in anger, with no progress made on the subject matter. notes were handwritten, but at such a low contrast, that they were often illegible, along with his handwriting. Although he appears to know what hes talking about on the subject matter, it seems like he has no ability to convey that knowledge to his students

His exams are designed to match his lectures, where as the homework was from the text. He never really went over the text in class, as a result things were very disjointed. He does post lectures online, but they are difficult to follow.

This is the first bad teacher I've had at RPI. He does not even understand his own labs. He does not care about his students. Occasionally, he just walks out of the class during labs.. He teaches lectures via powerpoint & has VERY quick slide changes. If you want to read the slide, expect to take your laptop to class (lectures off LMS). Horrible.
His lectures were a borefest.  90% of the time I had no clue what he was talking about.  I asked for advice for taking the final and he told me to switch to management.
Doesn't seem to care much about his students.  Labs were somewhat ambiguous and he was very unclear about what he wanted initially.  Lots of problems with the execution of the labs.

Personally, he is not a bad professor, but he is not quite that helpful when I ask him questions during class. Still, he selects great TAs that can explain things well, so I thought it was a pretty good class. But by the pace of the class, he could only skim through most of the concepts, so I suggest you to read the textbook.

Adams' voice is a lullaby.  Expect to sleep through his lectures (you will not be missing much).  If you want help, ask your TA or someone else.  I feel like Adams was not really prepared to teach physics I, seeing as his name was only added to the course the week before classes started.
Not very helpful. Rate of teaching is too fast to comprehend.
Adams is a horrible writer. The lab book used is very vague and the information in it is not well organized.

Didn't explain things well, didn't make it clear what exactly was supposed to go in lab reports. We didn't have to set up the labs, and it was a game to figure out how to use the equipment, then later what the point of the lab was in order to write the report. I didn't learn anything useful.

I wouldn't say that the course was absolutely atrocious, but the fact that Adams' lab manual was not thorough and his lectures also did not help, the course proved difficult. Additionally, I don't want to harshly label Professor Adams as an idiot, but his competency level was not what I expected from a seasoned physicist like him.
engage students more!

I really liked the class, and Dr. Adams was very helpful.  Also, the TA's were amazing, particularly Brian Moziak, who also helped me tremendously.  This also reflects well on Dr. Adams, showing that he knows how to pick good TA's.

Professor Adams was not helpful at all. When I would ask him a question he would just make me feel dumb instead of trying to answer it, responding with things like "didn't you read the book?". Lab instructions were poorly written and usually very unclear. A little more effort on the professor's part would have saved all us students a big headache.

For Ex-Phys, you don't interact with the professor that much.  He's pretty reasonable, my only problem is that he isn't direct in answering questions and wasn't too clear with explaining error analysis.  Other than that, I have no qualms with him whatsoever.  The course itself is a lot of work, but that doesn't have much ofanything to do with Adams
Professor Adams is knowledgable, but his teaching abilities seem marginal at best.  In particular, he did a poor job explaining error analysis in the lecture sessions in the beginning of the year.
Since it's Ex Phys, there wasn't much interaction with the professor. When there was, it was brief.
adams is ok. his voice will put you to sleep during lecture as he reads from the powerpoint. he doesnt seem to be too competent in physics. he's not a bad teacher, but by no means good.
Didn't really seem into it.  Lectures were boring and what's worse: uninformative.

For X-Phys you don't really need to use the professor that much. I just use the TA's since I know them. From what I understand he tends to over explain things a tad. The point of this class is to figure things out on your own anyway.

BAD. The first few weeks of the semester we just lectures, which consisted of him rambling on for an hour. I kept taking out my notebook to take notes but he never made any points. Then we had labs, which were impossible. He did try to help but had no clue what he was doing.

Bring a strong cup of coffee to stay awake.  He reads directly off the powerpoints, which makes me doubt how much he knows about the subject.  He reeks of incompetence.  The class was easy, but not at all enjoyable.  Avoid if you can.
Nice guy nice teacher at least hespokeenglish well
borin, kinda goofy, but hey he is a physics guy...
Easy to listen to during lecture. Explains problems well.
Neutral, doesn't explain things very well.
gary adams is the WORST professor i have ever had.....he's also a big JERK

This guy sucks.  He sucks at giving lectures and physics 1 is just terrible because the tests are so messed up (curves of 20+ points).  Tell the idiots that got a 5 on the ap physics not to take this class and ruin everyone else.
Clarifies Bedrosian's lecture notes.
No Comments
i got a lower score on the evaluation test given at the end of the semester, then the one at  begining of the semester.

Took him for "intro to logic based AI." This professor teaches you brain rot for 2 hours every time you see him and makes you pay for the worst software known to man for a $140. Only take his class if you really need it for your minor/major.

Don't take him for an easy A. Lectures can be very interesting but hard to follow. Bringsjord goes on rants during class about ChatGPT, AI, and other things, so you may have to teach yourself and read the textbook. The class HWs and tests are on HyperSlate, which was co-created by Bringsjord. Funnily enough, he doesn't go in-depth on how to use it.

The lectures can be interesting and thought-provoking. However, the class is graded through the Hyperslate program, which he does not spend time to guide through during lectures. Tests are graded generously; however, prepare to self-learn if you want to do well in that class. Best to avoid this class if you're taking it as a laid-back elective.

Probably a great class if you're already familiar with logic, but your out of luck if not. He's bad at explaining how logic transfers to his HyperSlate program ($130-ish btw), the book for the program is incredibly dry and doesn't explain much either. Coming from a skilled programmer, I felt like I wasted my time with this course.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: very good

Whole class is based on his self-developed online software which he does not take the time to teach about. All homework on said software is required- you will fail the class if you don't finish them. Tests are given the same format, grading is pretty generous. Can be a good class with some background in logic, but don't take for an easy grade.
He is a great lecturer, and is very lenient with deadlines, a lot of the homework assignment deadlines were extended.
Intro to Logic with him is pretty easy. He uses a weird program but other than that its pretty easy. The lectures are entertaining but not always that helpful, but overall a pretty solid class.

Selmer really is a caring professor, let alone possibly one of the most intelligent people on campus. He is willing to help a lot on homework problems (which are all on his $100 online software, similar to mastering). Homework problems aren't too difficult, and all the answers are on reddit. Tests are randomized per person but problems are not hard

Good guy generally but if you are looking for an easy A in a HASS course I would not recommend this. Unless you are a CS and are familiar with computational logic, this class is an unnecessary headache. His lectures are unrelated to all the homework and tests he assigns. You pay $100 for his software that he does not explain and expects you to know
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes--Tough grader

comment: Selmer is a great professor. "Are Humans Rational?" is an easy A while being non-traditional. The course itself is easy, but if you take the material and give it thought, it is challenging and engaging. Selmer, like the course, is different, interesting, and ultimately a softie. He truly cares about students and spreading logic and rationality.

Actually I took both this course &the other one based on the Stanford software that Bringsjord is competing against. All I can say is that from the AI point of view HyperGrader and HyperSlate are cool. They get sluggish when hit hard, but the AI in them is really something. This isn't really an intro to logic. It's an intro to logic & AI.

This is an easy-A professor. He grades all the course materials very generously or even not mindfully. For example, at the beginning of the exam 3. He said everyone will get an A FOR THIS EXAM (only this exam, not the whole course). You must finish all the homework questions in hypergrader, or you will get a F in the homework part .

This class introduced me to something I'd never heard about despite stuyding a lot of comp sci before getting to RPI -- logic programming. Bringsjord has unique knowledge of the connection between formal logic and programming, and that was really helpful. Really knows his stuff when it comes to comp sci and logic intersecting.

Intro to Logic is a great class to take with a difficult courseload. It's very easy to get an A while not trying at all (although you will be very confused the whole way through). However I would still recommend trying your best, since Bringsjord is world famous in this field and is a really interesting professor (albeit strange at times).
Great prof, famous but humble.

It's kinda cool taking a class with a famous AI guru, but his views on AI & logic are kinda tough on stat-based AI.  Lots of students get by without knowing what they're doing, but Bringsjord knows they're faking it, cause of his AI grading technology.
Homework is pretty hard. Good on the dude for coming up with mandatory $85 software. $85 * 400 is quite a bit for every semester he teaches the course. $$$ yo.
Great professor.  Extremely knowledgeable and helpful.

About the only thing I think is missing in Bringsjord's platform for teaching intro logic (and its really intro to *mathematical* logic, which he's pretty clear about, actually) is an automatic grading technology.  That would allow students to get instant analysis of their graphical proofs.  But basically I think this is a world-class course.

Personally, I think Bringsjord makes some of the material super hard so that he can find students with the potential to do research, while in the end he's pretty easy grade-wise.  So, if you just stick it out, your grade should be great, but it's really, really hard to nail all the problems.
Easiest class I've taken in my life

Do the practice exams and homework and you magically pass. Lectures are not mandatory. He makes you buy his textbook and program on a CD from the bookstore, not optional if you want a grade for the course.

I found some of the problems to be ridiculously hard. I'm not sure how some of my classmates got some of these problems, which are very mathematical in nature.  But I learned a lot, including that I probably shouldn't try to be a logician.  But Bringsjord is a great guy, and you can get a high grade even if like me you can't figure it all out.

The material Bringsjord teaches, at the level he teaches it at, can be downright impossible for mere mortals (students who don't plan to be logicians) to understand.  But if you seek him out and ask for help, he gives it with cheerfulness, and you can grasp a lot of it.  And then in the end he really doesn't grade that tough.

Before I got to my Analysis class as a math major I really didn't see the value of Bringsjord does, because it's really an intro to mathematical logic.  But what I'd learned about proofs  in his class saved my butt.

Bringsjord is a dynamite logic teacher, and his logics are cool, but the bottom line is that it's all very computational, and even specifically AI based.  If you want just old school paper and pencil stuff, stay away from this class.  But if you want to know how the heck he and his lab @ RPI built smart gadgets, this course unlocks the secrets.

If you want to study logic taught by a teacher just using someone else's logic book and courseware, don't go with Bringsjord.  He has his own novel approach to teaching mathematical logic, which is based on graphs, rather than linear sequences of symbols.  It's kind of cool taking the course from a prof famous in AI, & he uses logic for AI.

Some of the extra credit logic problems are so darn difficult that I'd estimate about 2% of the class understand them.  Despite some  ridiculously difficult proofs (which Bringsjord openly says only make sense at a place where students are technical), he's more than fair as a grader.
Well, Beingsjord is probably a genius, but he's very opinionated.  He basically condemns all current math education, and claims that his approachsoftware will revolutionize learning logic & math.
Selmer is as Selmer does. But the class is easy and if you do the work he promises an A.
Intro to Logic is very easy but a bit dry. He is very responsive to emails and a really smart guy. The entire class is just a few homeworks.
if you wanna learn something about logic, don?t take his illogical class.
class is too advanced to be called an introductory course
Very knowledgeable in his field, but seems to find it hard to teach those who are new to philosophy and logic. Great reference is you are already into logic, but not as helpful for beginners.
VERY conservative. Makes students feel uncomfortable if they do not agree with him. Will go as far as making fun of liberal students.

Bringsjord is very fun.  His stories are great, and he teaches in a way that makes the time pass quickly.  His courses are easy enough to get A's, yet you learn everything you are supposed to and have fun doing it.

Probably one of my absolute favorite professors at rpi. He is nice and open to all sorts of ideas and input. Unlike most professors he is willing to iterate and design his class in order for students to succeed. There was a lot of discussions in his class but he made students feel welcome to state their opinion.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Caring

comment: This course was writing intensive. There was a large project worth most of the class grade that included investigating something related to the environment (that was as specific as he got). There were also weekly "journals" due to reflect on the things you learned in the course. Overall boring lectures, but an easy course.
He is a truly passionate teacher, and always a ton of fun to listen to.  I just wish I was more interested / better at what he teaches.

A good professor if you are at college to learn. The course was work intensive, but definitely inspired thought and creativity. Required text was Lessig's Code 2.0, which is cheap for the hard copy and better yet, free online.

Lectures are absolutely terrible; it's as though he does not know when to stop talking and when to allow discussion to continue in class. Possibly one of the most boring classes I've ever taken and it had the chance to be something wonderful.

Good prof, provided you actually care about the subject matter (or like to read, or write, or learn, or do much of anything). If deep/convoluted thoughts aren't your thing, though, you might want to find a different professor. If you like going "Huh?/Whoa..." then Social Dimensions of Engineering is the class for you.
P&E sucks.. it's a lot of work, especially if you get stuck in a crappy group.  Atsushi is ok, but the lectures are pretty boring.

Social Dimensions of Engineering -- very interesting course.  Though it was my humanities, I probably learned more about engineering in this course than any of my other first year courses.  Atsushi, (he encouraged us to call him by his first name), always involved everyone in the conversations.
No Comments
Great Prof. Knows his stuff. Tons of work, but you learn alot too. He is opened to all kinds of diffrent opinions too!

Watch out he assigns a lot of work and just when you think your done he assigns some more. Ask questions about project descriptions they were filled with useless background information, figuring out what he actually wanted was a challenge. Keep up with the massive amount of reading and participate.

A good guy at heart, but way too much reading.  I'm still not sure what he was looking for on a lot of the papers I handed in.  I got good grades on what I thought was some of my worst work, and bad grades on what I thought was well written...

I thought this prof was very good. Though he tends to take very left-wing stances and I am very conservative I found this lead to great debates in class. He was very open to people who didn't share his view and welcomed disent.
Dude SUCKS!!!!  Horrible prof.  Grading system is screwed up.
He has the most awful speaking skills I have ever encountered.  I counted 256 "right"s in a 50 minute period.
Intro to Science & Tech Studies ok. It is a lot of reading & papers every week.
AWFUL FROM.. IM DEM AND HIS VIEWS WICH ARE PUSHED HARD ARE WAY TO CRAZY FOR ME.... HIS GRADING IS OFF THE WALL YOU NEED A PHD TO UNDERSTAND IT... AVOID HIM
The mullet needs to go.  His grading style was somewhat unclear and unfair but he would tell you he wsa fair.  Never taking another class with him again.

He's extremely helpful, but in this class the point of most of the material was unclear.  How it fit into the course, the curriculum.  The readings were supposed to be comparritive to the weekly essays, but were not.

he is japanese and has a mullet! he is that screwed up, his views are completely utopian and the grading is retarded. a kid in my section failed a paper because he used the term "man-hours", as in hours of labor. The professor said it was gender

Grading in this class makes very little sense.  The professor has built in so much personal leeway into the grading scheme that ultimatly it is irrelevant how you did in the class.  Nice guy but sadly not very consistent.
Although odd and at times boring, very understanding and knows material well.
I thought he was one of the best teachers I had at RPI

The grading system for this class is definitely messed up: a) Effort definitely DOES NOT translate into good grades, and c) I got an A in the course even though I got a B or a C on pretty much everything I did.
Horrible class no matter which u take of his, if possible stay out, classes are completly left wing, lack relisticness, and are always too much work.
A great section leader.  The only good professor of social science that I have had at this technical instituion
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments

A nice enough guy, but skewed to the left. In fact the whole class is skewed that way: if you write  him  instead of  they  you will fail the paper until you correct it. The other TA's are outright hippie.
Too much work. The class is full of over-acheiving freshmen and it seems no matter how hard I try I can't figure out what him and his colleagues are looking for when it comes to grading criteria.

I had Akera for and I can tell you that while his outward appearance might be left-wing, you have to have him as your section leader to learn his true colors.  He's a really bad lecturer, however in a smaller group he's more accepting of right-wing views.
I hated his class.  Way too much work.  The whole course was a way for him to talk about his left-wing political views, and I learned nothing.  Way too much work for a freshman level IT class.

He was a great teacher, and enthusiastic, glad i had Jill Fisher as a section leader though, she was even better.  Atsushi was very organized in lecture, and this was one of my favorite classes at RPI

This is by far the most one-sided teacher I have ever had.  He is a complete hippy that has no respect for normal people's comments.  If you are going to try and engage students in discussion you must respect both sides of an argument.
intro to sts, lot of reading articles and writing involved, prof is kind of out there, but he's very nice. enthusiastic and knowledgeable about his field.  really emphasizes participation

He is not the best lecturer. There is just too much content to cover and not enough time. I found his previously recorded lectures to be more helpful than in person lecture. He is a slow speaker and it is hard to be engaged in his lecture. Exams are difficult but Physics 2 at RPI is not as impossible as everyone says! Go to someone's office hours.

Dr. Ciolek was a good professor. Often went over the designated lecture time, but was helpful and taught the content well. Lots of labs and homework that take up a lot of time. Exams aren't easy but plenty of resources are given to help study.

His lectures were pretty boring, he mostly just read from the slides, but the slides themselves are pretty helpful. A LOT of assignments outside of class on top of lab assignments, etc. but there's no other option if you have to take physics II. The tests weren't too bad if you study and use the dozens of back exams they give to you.

Very knowledgeable in course topics and very helpful in answering questions. If you arent used to waking up early, maybe dont take him at 8am as he talks in a very monotone, sleep-inducing voice. Apart from that, he is very good.
Consistently and ruthlessly went over class time, but knew the material enough to give good explanations. Be prepared for superhero jokes.

Most people would find him very boring as you sit there and watch him read the slides, as all the professors do. But, he is actually very nice and puts a lot of effort into the slides to make them less boring. Very knowledgeable, good personality, and explains topics in more detail during lab whenever he shows up. Be ready for superhero references.

The lectures are slow and usually go past the class time but he is pretty good for lab and office hours. He gives out a ton of extra credit. Making a good crib sheet will save your life. This class will be tough if you struggled in Phys 1. Ciolek is great but curriculum is not. 
Save your mental health and grades by taking this class elsewhere.

Ciolek has decent lectures and the labs aren't too bad. I didn't think the class took too much time either. The crib sheet on the tests are super important and doing the back exams, but the tests were fair and not too difficult. Everything besides the tests are pretty much guaranteed to be 100 so the tests pretty much determine your grade.

Very good in office hours, always willing to explain a topic as thoroughly as you ask for. Can be blunt, but rarely ever hostile. Lectures can get a little meandering, and often go past the stated end time. Extremely generous extra credit makes it very difficult to get less than a 100 in all non-exam categories. Crib sheets are critical on exams.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Physics 2 is a terribly formatted class at RPI, and Ciolek didn't do much to make it better. The amount of work given (2 labs, 2 quizzes, 2 homework's per week) is ridiculous and time consuming, and Ciolek is condescending and rude to students that do anything to offend him (which is not difficult to do). Tests were not that bad though.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Awful lectures, do your best to avoid this guy. A lot of what is covered in class isn't applicable to the exam and the depth of the exams goes beyond what we discuss in labs, hw, and lecture to a stupid degree

I had him for lab, and he was genuinely so helpful. He's kind of hard to approach at first, but he does really care about your understanding and will explain things as many times as you need him to. He makes himself super accessible outside of class, and even offers extra credit whenever he can. I wish I could've had him for lecture too

Lectures are short to make time for lab, so they feel very rushed, but his explanations are good. Highly reccomend taking 10-15 minutes before lecture to watch a video on the topic of each class to help understanding. Homework and quizzes are due before each class, they don't take long but there is a lot of them.

Lectures are good, kinda boring, but he gives quiz answers at the end. I learned mostly from HW and lecture slides, professor didn't make a huge difference for me.
HW+quizes are out of 133% so you can easily hit 100% on them. Labs are graded kinda easy+extra credit, should get 100% again. 3 exams + final are 60%, kinda tough, but lowest is dropped.

There's so much extra credit that you can have a 100 in all categories that are not test related. He drops the lowest exam, and there's a decent amount of extra credit on tests.

The actual lectures are pretty good, but are not required to do well. The only thing that matters on tests is how good your crib sheet is.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment:
Overall, this professor is accommodating and a good dude, but he clearly does not like slackers or people who don't seriously want to learn. If you show interest in the course, he will be a great resource to learn. So my experience went from meh to good with him. 
Still hate Physics II as a course though :/

Professor Ciolek radiates passion for physics. Lab attendance is mandatory, lecture attendance is not. If you skip the lectures, the labs are terrible, because you understand nothing. If you go to lectures, the labs are fun. FUN. Also, ask the guy questions during lab, he is very, very, very, very, very, very, good at explaining physics concepts.

The classes are basically all labs. Theres supplemental lectures that youre supposed to watch on your own time which is not how I learn. Prof Ciolek does give a short lecture before each lab but it rarely helped me understand the lab material. To be fair, Im a bio major so this isnt my area but this class was hard af.

Taught myself almost everything for this course. Very little help offered in class. Because of this, The time commitment was disproportional to the difficulty of the subject material. Not entirely Ciolek's fault due to the course design. If possible I recommend you take this course elsewhere and transfer credits.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Ciolek is sometimes awkward, but very kind and gives good help during class. Lectures are whatever and don't really help. Every single exam, I study hard WITH a crib sheet and still get dumpstered despite my confidence going in and out of it. The class isn't not impossible for sure, because I didn't give it my all, but its definitely difficult.

During this class, I was pretty burnt out but for the most part, he was always very insightful and easy to go to when help was needed. I would definitely recommend taking an Astrophysics course with him as you will learn a lot. Especially if you want to go into astrophysics and astronomy.

I really appreciated the in-class experiments and the opportunity to learn physics. It was powerpoint-based for the most part, I believe, which sometimes made it hard to follow the integrals right away, but he helped me understand the material.
Not the greatest lecturer, but provides solid powerpoints online to learn from. There are a couple opportunities for extra credit in lecture (extra clicker problems) and labs (reviews before tests).

Professor Ciolek has been the only professor I have ever to learn every student's name in all of his lectures, it was nice to come into lab and be greeted. He is a nice guy, but his lectures are incredibly dry and contain lots of information not related to exams. This made it difficult to succeed in this class. Take physics 2 with another prof.

Physics 1200 with Ciolek was miserable. He repeatedly demands to be "the only source of acoustic radiation in the room" as he mumbles through text heavy lecture slides. Once he asked if I would lay a baby on its face upon returning an oscilloscope. When I attempted to turn in missed work after a trip abroad, I was denied and told "how unfortunate."
Yes Professor Ciolek, I understand.

He mumbles and isn't easy to hear unless you sit in the very front of the class. Doesn't check to make sure the projector actually works all the time, and spends too much time talking about things that don't matter to the exam. Rushes the last 10 slides because he misallocates his time.
I transferred colleges because of this class.

Don't do it. He mumbles in his lectures and reads off slides. He fails to provide students with a better understanding of the lecture material. He examples the easiest problems that everyone already knows and purposely evade from talking about any questions that might be similar to the ones on tests. Avoid this guy.

Not recommended for physics 2. His voice is low in lectures while the lecture room is large. He spends so much time explaining inconsequential or even trifling materials, and he often fails to manage his time properly. Quizzes are before each lecture, arrive on time and don't skip them.
rating_tags: Participation matters--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He's absolutely terrible. He fails to engage the students in his class whatsoever with him reading off a dense slideshow, in which a good portion of the material is useless in understanding. Hard to have respect for a professor when on the first day of class in DCC308 he's quoted saying, "I'm the laziest, most unorganized slob in this entire room."

He is a terrible lecturer. His lecture slides are primarily text and he spends to whole class reading off of the slides and doesn't look up or interact with the class for questions. His lectures and labs are riddled with typos. He is arrogant when answering questions. He is a terrible professor. I love physics, and he made me hate the class. Bummer
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Unless you enjoy going to class and not learning anything then being forced to teach yourself, dont take this mans class. I actually couldnt tell you one thing this guy has taught me.
Often is difficult to understand in class. He's an absolute babe
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Very knowledgeable about most areas of this extremely diverse course. He has a general idea as to how research in most every area of stellar physics is done. His homeworks/activities are often designed to teach you something. Sometimes it's crazy hard but he's very reasonable about needing more time. Get a friend in the class. Nice guy. Great notes

Professor Ciolek is cute and dorky and very knowledgeable.  The best way to do well in the class is to read the sections in the textbook before you go to class, and try to do the homework ahead of time because you can go to the TAs or your mentor for help.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Awesome teacher. Knows his stuff, and is willing to help those that seek it out. Decent amount of extra credit. Wish he taught more classes.

Prof. Ciolek was an enjoyable teacher. Taking his class in tandem with IEA sometimes led to a bit of overkill in static physics, nothing too unbearable though, just funny. He really tries his best to show visual examples in his lectures so that students can understand better. My favorites were always when he broke out his bike tire and the turn tab

He teaches pretty easy. The lectures are comprehensive, and the activities pretty much makes you do "real physics" not just learn theories. He is really good at helping his students. This class should be an EASY A even if you blow 1 of the 3 tests of the semester.  The final is optional.

Circuits with Prof. Sawyer is far from the easiest class I've had in terms of grading, but the workload's not too unreasonable. HW is 2% of course grade and the labs aren't difficult as long as you choose the Alpha option (I pity you if you go for Omega). Lectures are hard to follow, but study material is posted online, including practice exams.
This class needs some better organization. Assignment guidelines are inconsistent and confusing. However her classes are fun and she does a great job at allowing creativity.

Great professor! Very knowledgeable and good at teaching, but: HW is 2%, so it's only worth doing that to study for exams. Labs are a huge time sink, 80% of the effort in the class, but only worth 15%, but getting 80s makes the final optional! The communication and assignments on the website+webex+gradescope makes everything chaotic and confusing..

A charismatic, engaging teacher, but infuriatingly disorganized. Uses a difficult to read website to 'organize' course information. Due dates change regularly and grading is done at the last minute. TONS of group work, so don't get stuck with freeloaders or your semester will be miserable. Stresses communication skills despite her lack thereof.

Sawyer's one of the few professors at RPI who grades hw for completion, which really allows her students to  practice problems instead of fitting a grading criteria. You really feel that she's trying to get you to learn things; She provides plentiful resources, is extremely responsive and reasonable, and brings great energy to every lecture.
This class is very difficult so ample study time is needed. Professor Sawyer is a great lecturer, and teaches the course better than the average professor could.

I really appreciated how Professor Sawyer helped me with my group projects throughout the semester. She was always willing to help and gave good advice. This is a new class structure so this was the beta testing semester and I think it went well. Show up to class and participate and the tests should be quite easy.
rating_tags: Group projects--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: At the beginning of this course, everything is good, and I could understand almost everything in the class. However, after the second test, the time is not adequate, and she did not teach everything in the class. Instead, she just let us do the examples .. Especially for the last section, she just use 1 week to teach everything....
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Too many tests. She taught nothing on her class, so you should figure out everything by yourself. All her resources are even not written by herself. ECSE made a bad decision on letting her to teach this important class.

It's a tough class, be prepared to put in time with a lab group. You learn a lot if you pay attention, and you definitely should if you want to stay on top of this class. Definitely don't slack off and start your labs early, they're pretty long-winded. Great professor, keeps things interesting during class!
Sawyer is the goat. The class is tough, but you really learn a lot from her.

Professor Sawyer is by far one of the best professors at RPI! I was a student struggling in her class and she was more than helpful in helping me catch up with the material and understand the concepts behind what we were learning. She makes learning circuits really fun and gives lots of opportunities to improve in the course. For exams do backtests

Expect a heavy courseload, but great professor. She really cares about her students and bases things off each individual class that semester (based on lecture questions/discussions, concepts most students are struggling with, etc.) She gives chances to get some points back on tests and offers other extra credit assignments! Overall, LOVE HER
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: A respectful professor but with lots of work.

Professor Sawyer was uncaring, condescending, and assigned more work than all my other courses combined. Her lectures were not particularly insightful and she expected students to come to class having taken notes on 20-30 minutes of videos which were subpar at best. I would avoid Sawyer as best as humanly possible.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Test heavy

comment: Seems cheery until you realize she is completely unsympathetic to your troubles in the class. Says things aren't mandatory, then they are. Obtuse test grading; bi-weekly labs take 20-30 man-hours each and are barely worth anything. Believes in reversed classroom model despite significant negative feedback. This class is SO MUCH WORK! Never again.
Extremely unprofessional and unfair. Tests are written poorly. Rude to students.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Beware of pop quizzes--Tough grader

comment: She expects us to know every little movement she does
Terrible lecture notes.
Exam is hard, also no time to work on exam. The lectures are bad, she has ppt but never use it. Only few class problem.

I learned a lot in this class. I put in the work during labs and homework to understand the material and it really showed on the tests. The tests are straight forward and very similar to the homework. There is "class problems" which is mostly what I learned with and are a great resource for studying.

Dr. Sawyer is really nice. She is always willing to help us in many ways to improve our performance. The lectures may not be super-helpful but the supplemental videos can still be of great significance of understanding materials. Tests are not very difficult, try to study hard to push for a good grade!
rating_tags: Participation matters--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: The average is really high this semester. Dr. Sawyer gave us cutoffs mid-semester and the cutoffs were a 98 for an A and a 68 to pass. Everyone got anxious, particularly alpha lab students because we have less extra credit opportunities. Seeing the anxiety, she then moved the cutoffs again to reasonable ones. I don't know how I feel about this.
I appreciate how Dr. Sawyer is receptive to student input and actively tries to make ECSE Enrichment Seminar engaging. Plus, her seminar about her own career was wonderful! Would listen to again.
Professor Sawyer grades very fairly. The option between Alpha Labs and Beta Labs was a huge plus.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Clear grading criteria--TEST HEAVY

comment: Electronic Instrumentation was painful for me. I found the experiments/projects conceptually easy, but tediously long and vague. Since there were no in-class lectures, Sawyer was basically a TA. What really made me respect her was when we filled out mid-semester surveys and she took time in class to go over the responses. She actually cares.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: One of the best professors Ive ever had. Homework can be challenging but the team assignments and optional class problems prepare you for them. Cares about her students and wants them to succeed.

If you miss class, it's not the worst thing because of the videos she provides. However, if you fall behind on the material, catch up fast. The homeworks can range from easy to challenging, and may take a good amount of time. Overall, just put effort into the class and you should be fine

Tests are not hard, but homework is quite difficult. You need to watch the video before class to have a good understanding of what she talks about. In class problems are pretty helpful in understanding the complicated concepts. Generally a good teacher.
Not specific about course material. Didn't even explain the main concept of calculation

Good professor. The additional video lectures were incredibly helpful, there was a ton of extra credit, and her explanations during lecture were pretty solid. Make sure you try for a regrade on each test, she's very generous with points and the TA's usually grade them pretty harshly.

She spends a lot of time on the little math and stuff, including in the video lectures (and I mean spending a lot of time to write out the problem... I would prefer not waiting for a problem to be written out and to have more examples that I can go back on as to why something happens). It makes it easier to let your mind wander and then get lost.

Pros:  She's generous with regrading for tests.   Cons: Lot's of formatting errors and typos in assignments and tests. Often will not do a problem all the way out. Review sessions before exams are a waste of time. She doesn't get into detail with the difficult topics because she tries to touch on everything.
She is really nice, talking about her child a lot. Videos are helpful. I don't like the Team Assignment part, kinda hard to do. Be sure to be prepared for class.

I do not know what he is talking about even after I have read the book in advance. Awful writing and messy ideas. But the exam is not very hard, if you learned  the topic he talked about from reading the text by yourself, and know what the methods are to solve all the review problems. And TA is more helpful and clearer than professor.

Personally, he is not a good professor. Also, he gives a lot of quizzes and iClicker questions. He is really confusing. Just don't choose his courses, please. That would be my every advice for people who's gonna to take multi-var.
Exams are really easy, just do the practice exam. Quizzes are hard. They are usually four questions and there is no partial credit.
I'm sure he does a lot of really cool research.............
bad lecturer

This is the worst professor I've ever taken with at RPI. He's one of those professors that think that can teach but really can't. He has a very messy handwriting. Half of the students don't go to his class because he's teaching style is so poor. Exams are mediocre if you somehow manage to understand his poor lectures. Why is he even a professor?

Professor Herron is frankly a genius and his expectations correspond. He expects you to do outside reading - essential to following lectures and you will teach yourself. Homework is graded and quite challenging, tests are very easy - the two effectively balance one another out. Hope for a good TA because they make your life infinitely better.

By far the worst professor I've had at RPI. His lectures are boring and he doesn't explain anything he's doing, he just expects you to understand it as well as he does. His homeworks are also very long and challenging. Had teach myself differential equations through recitation and the textbook. Avoid him if at all possible.
Avoid at all costs. Very difficult professor. Can't read his handwriting. Wish I took it with another teacher.
Does not make any sense. Worst handwriting possible... Makes a lot of mistakes.. I have to rely on reading the textbook & going to recitation to understand anything at all.
He is the absolute worst professor I have had at RPI so far.
homework is ridiculously  hard. idk how people can give him 4 out of 5 on easiness. he cant teach. alotta mistakes during lectures.
He was a terrible teacher.  I stopped going to lectures entirely once I realized I wasn't learning anything during them.  I had to learn entirely from the book and recitation.
Long, Monotonous lectures consisting of only going over examples of the book. A genius, but cannot teach/explain

His handwriting is horrible and his speech is hard to follow (not due to an accent, but his thoughts are scattered). If you take one of his classes, make sure to use your book and hope you have a good TA.
We learned about meat cleavers. And that's about it.
The nicest professor one could ever have. Very clear in class and never boring. Alwayas available for extra help.

Horrible Multiv. Prof. If you are a geek, have fun in this class or else hit the books and study very hard to get a good grade.  His final is very difficult and his HW's are very very long and challenging.

Don't expect Herron to teach you anything.  Read the book and go to TA sessions.  Herron is useless, can't even read what he writes.  And he goes way too fast through the material.  The tests are pretty easy though.  Unfortunately the homework is incredibly hard.
Worst writing and teaching skills ever.  Would only assign the hardest homework problems possible.  Tests are easy though.
The worst professor i have ever had. Never have i had a professor who cannot teach or write
he makes positively no sense and no effort to make sense.  his exams are east tho.
He trys to act like he wants to help you, but doesn't seem to get that the students don't already understand.

Horrible, horrible, horrible.  He obviously enjoys and knows the material but he thinks we do too.  Didn't even bother going to lecture, as I learned more by just studying the book for the three hours a week.  At least you can use crib sheets.
This man does differential equations for fun and thinks you like to too.  He flies through material at blazing fast speed.  If it wasn't for my TA I would have never passed.
Had him my first semester at college.  Almost made me reconsider being a math major.  Learned everything from the TA.  Herron is a useless man, who experiences occasional fits of uncontrolled anger.

Horrible professor! All he does is derive general equations and never shows how they're used. I learned everything in diff eq through my TA and through reading the book. I really like the topic but Herron ruined the course.

HORRIBLE Prof, I only learned anything in the class because of the TA and also he picked some of the hardest course material.  My TA said he didn't see some of the stuff we are doing in diff eq right now until he was in grad school.
The one redeeming factor in this class was our ability to use crib sheets, and the major portion of our grade that was comprised of homework, which also happened to be very difficult.
I have never failed a class in my life... but I will now thanks to prof Herron... the ****.
Apparently the hardest Diff. Equ. teacher, we hit chapters other teachers wouldnt touch...
He was horrible when I had him
Worst professor I've had at RPI.  Hard to understand, and disliked the fact that I went to office hours as often as I did to try to learn the material.

He is a very funny guy and overall a really good professor. He focuses a lot more on his research than his class, but the class was still very good despite that. Definitely be prepared to study a lot for the exams and you will do well.
His test is insanely difficult, trust me do not take his strength.

Compared to other professors in this course, HE IS THE WORST PROFESSOR. I took his class this summer. He tries to make students feel embarrassed and uncomfortable in his class. His notes are an absolute disaster, and the lecture slides are not human-readable. Opt for classes taught by Kristin Mills or Omar El-Shafee instead of him.

FANTASTIC lecturer, the best I've ever had. He makes you care about and gain intuition for the material. Very funny and personable. Incredibly tough grader. Unless you study, expect to feel lost. Test averages very low but he curves everything. His slides are a bit confusing and don't always have all info.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Amazing lectures--Tough grader

comment: He failed to explain the content of the course thoroughly due to his weak math and physics background, which makes this course unnecessarily difficult.
He is the man. Strengths isn't my favorite subject but he keeps the lectures interesting and teaches it well. He knows his stuff

Wasted a lot of time on joking instead of really focusing on the materials. Go to class without preparation. Never able to solve the problem in the textbook. Extremely weak in basic math, physics and chemistry.

Strongly recommend he go back to high school and learn some basic physics chemistry and engineering stuff. Guess he bought his PhD degree. He pretends he is good but God he has no idea what he is teaching. His lecture is no help at all for his own exams. How does he manage to keep his job?
Very though class
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Rahmi is a pleasure to be taught by. He is quite fair and honest. Also, he is completely willing to help if you're willing to ask for it. His accent is super dope too which is a nice touch. Reading the textbook really helps on the quizzes.

Rahmi was a great professor. He explains course material very well. He is very helpful during office hours. Thermodynamics itself is a tough subject and the low averages in the class are reflections of thermodynamics subject's ambiguity itself. I would take this class with Rahmi again!
My favorite professor at RPI so far. Made everything easy to understand and is always willing to help if you're willing to put in the effort.
A good introduction to polymers. I took the course years ago and ended up in polymer research. I learned a lot from this course.

I took Rahmi for Strength of Materials and he is clearly the best teacher for that class. All of the sections are hard for this class and the average for our class was 15+ points higher than the other sections. He's great in his office hours and will go out of his way to help you learn if you seek him out. Amazing person and professor.

Rahmi is a really great guy who genuinely cares for his students. He goes above and beyond for his students and wants them to do well. He explains topics much better if you see him one-on-one by making an appointment to see him in his office. Not to mention, his jokes are great, you will be very entertained.

Great guy, really humorous, would like to see his student success. Really helpful outside the class. However, sometimes, his lectures are not clear.  And he is really a poor organizer. Change his syllabus over and over again.
Rahmi will make sure you know the information if you put in the effort. He takes the time to understand students' problems and truly wants to see his students succeed.
He is the top dog. A really nice and amusing professor that helps cut the tedium of thermodynamics with his brand of Turkish swagger.
Greatest professor i have ever had. Truly he deserves praise akin to the praise received by ghandi or MLK.

He was a nice guy and everything, but this class sucked.  The test averages were like 50/100 and even though he curved them, it was very frustrating.  Expected us to do all of the already-worked out book examples on top of the assigned homework 2+ hours of homework a week.
his exams do not test material covered in course
Tried to make this course work, but in the end it was a horrible failure resulting in test averages below 50 and a lot of unhappy students. He is a decent guy, but he should not be teaching.
No Comments

Was his first time teaching the course. He dealt with issues in class in a fairly mature matter but his organization of the course was not so bright (Double-length homework due BEFORE Thanksgiving and test immediately AFTER?)
No Comments
A victim of bad course organization. Knew his stuff, but didn't always teach what ended up being on the tests written by the course coordinator. If you talk a lot in class he will like you.

A good guy who really wants to see his students do well.  His lectures can get boring and sometimes he doesn't seem to know what he's talking about, though.  Hard grader overall.  Unpredictable with some of the questions on the quizzes.

He is one of the best professors I had at RPI. He went over everything that is in the book and warned us that we need to read and understand the book. Was very helpful out of class. I think the course could be changed a little but overall it was a good start to polymers.

Very boring class - prof. is one of the more boring lecturers I've had. However, he's nice when asking questions face to face and will give points back on tests. MUST read the book to do well on the tests. Test questions tend to be ambiguous and random, so write as much as possible. Not much HW.
The worst class I've taken.  Don't expect to learn anything, but be expected to get tested on information that is random and not in the book/notes. Simply put a waste of time.
All he said was read the book, but when you wrote what was in the book to answer his test questions, you didn't get the right answer.

Rhami is a terrible professor. His test questions are vague, and rarely pertain directly to what he lectures on. Even though there are multiple answers to each question, he only accepts one, and thus most people get bad grades.

besides the fact that broken english and little dances fail to describe what polymers are, he doesn't write test questions that ask for anything in particular and then looks for one specific answer and fails you on it, even if it pertains.

one of RPIs best CS professors. Smart and communicates with students well.

exam heavy. exams were pretty hard. brought my grade down a lot.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Good lecturer. Adds clarifications or corrections to assignments if need be. Exams can be difficult, but fair, and provides prep material beforehand.
Best Prof, get in every course hes teaching!!!!!

Goldschmidt is one of the best profs I have had at RPI. His lectures are clear and concise. He is always understanding and will help any student work through an issue. He is also a great advisor who truly only wants the best for his students. His study guides prepare you for what the exam will be like and you will never be blindsided.
Nice
Reasonable amounts of work. A really nice professor, very approachable. The exam is relatively easy if you spent enough time studying. And do takes student's performance into considerations.
Goldschmidt was the one of the best professor in CS department, he have good arrangement for each lecture. Exams are not so hard if you are willing to spend time review it.
fair and accommodating when it matters.

An absolute wizard in Windows Notepad. Lectures are mostly code examples, which aren't super helpful in the moment, but are useful when doing homeworks. Exams are the downfall of Goldie; Operating Systems is centered around coding, but the exams are mc+write the output of a program. The exams feel like they're testing a different class...

Prof. Goldschmidt cares about his students, and he is very accessible outside class. Unfortunately, I never found his lectures to be clear or very helpful. He did not explain examples well, and many in-class problems actually contained mistakes. This made CSCI 2200 very difficult for me, and I still don't feel I understand some concepts.

Is very clear and concise during lectures, and manages to keep things interesting and funny. Is very understanding of students and doesn't try to make tests and homework overly difficult. One of the best professors I've had.
Perfect Professor I've seen ever

This class is hard, and you should read the textbook and start the homework early. However, from what I heard about the CompOrg professors Goldshmidt is easier. He is a nice professor and extends homework deadlines often, and when a lot of students do poorly in a lab, he allows them to get checked off during office hours.

I like Dr G but his OpSys class could be way more useful.

Won't learn things like how the linux file system works, mounting, devices, POSIX file API. Instead covers decades-deprecated kernel functions in depth.

Tested on trivia, e.g. "trace the output of this 20 line code block which forks and reassigns stdio file descriptors multiple times".

A great professor! I met a weird problem and I posted it on the online discussion board. He responded really fast and he ran the test on his computer, and found maybe somethhing wrong with the online grading, so that he just corrected my score in a very fast speed. Good professor!

Goldie is a chaotic good character. He's a bit disorganized but in an "oh I didn't get the autograder working, here's three extra days on your hw" or "this question on the exam was bad so I gave you all credit" kind of way. Very effective at lectures and the homework and exams are fair and not designed to punish you at all.
This guy really knows his stuff

PROS: Great lecturer, always gives good examples for coding, teaches everything you need to know, clearly outlines the homework and often gives starting points/code to help out, pretty balanced grading, accessible CONS: "90-minute" tests take the entire 3 hour block, amount of lecture content in a week ranges from none to 6 hours

Pretty solid lecturer, does a lot to help out students. That being said only teaches in notepad/vim (i.e. no slides or anything) which can make it kind of hard to study if you don't take good notes at lecture.

Dr. Goldschmidt is a top notch guy. Expect to be graded on your coding ability, and expect to do a lot of coding. Quizzes are extremely difficult but may curve. Dr. Goldschmidt has a lot of office hours, unfortunately everyone and their brother needs to see him so expect to wait (like an hour).
Makes workload heavier than the class reasonably requires, takes over a month to give quiz feedback, doesn't give us timely responses, crams significant amount of work in small timeframe.
Good guy, good class, good job

Highly unprofessional -- pushed back several assignments multiple weeks, and often changed expected program output directly in the test cases but not the problem description. Exam questions were near-exclusively multithreaded programs with no semantic meaning that you had to diagram possible outputs for. Did not assess op sys knowledge at all.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--TEST HEAVY

comment: A ez professor

One of the best classes I've taken. What I've noticed is that it's a very example-driven class and so you'll find most of your learning comes from doing the homework and consulting with example code he writes during class. The tests by comparison are very easy.

A nightmare, this class was. The HWs, projects were super-vague. Little to no sample output provided.  The discussion forum for students, the piazza site, were filled with student questions, but the professor or the TAs responded infrequently & often too late. We had more than a month of no HW then 1 HW & 1 project announced just before the final.

AWESOME Professor. Try to get him for every class. Took FOCs, algorithms, and Net Prog with him. Good assignments and felt like I learned a lot. Took FOCs with Drineas as well and learned the material better with Goldschmidt and did way better in the class. Also felt like I learned a lot in algorithms.

An ok professor, overhyped. Helpful if you approach him but can take a long time to reply. Grading takes ages. Is one of few professors who can compile & run code in class without making a fool of himself. Homeworks are all programming but class is mostly not programming, so homeworks are only marginally helpful.
Great professor with appropriately difficult assignments and projects. Understanding but not a push over.
Useless

The professor seems very intersted in the topic, but is sometimes scattered in class. He's very willing to answer questions in class and gives good feedback on exams, although plan on waiting to get your grade. Other than that, I would definitely recommend him, mainly because you don't get very many good-looking, young profs. at an engineering scho
Very interested in teaching
Not a professor, but an instructor. Makes things interesting. Very helpful. Recommended for SD&D.

He's very test-heavy and textbook-heavy, but most tests don't have material from the textbook. He rambles during lecture and doesn't actually explain anything but expects that everyone do well on his exams. Most of the class ended retaking the whole class next semester.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Worst proffesor I had in college. Talks too much but does not focus in the actual topic. The tests are very heavy. He said is about something and it result it's about something completely different. The grades are very very bad. He does not give u extra credit on test questions so be prepared. Office hours are very useless, he does not help AT ALL.

Out of all of my professors, Rutledge is the one who seems to care most about student's success. His passion for the subject material is evident and he wants all his students to care as much as he does. If you participate in class and attend his exam reviews he'll love you and give help on tests. It's a lot of material, some only from the textbook.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Accessible outside class

comment: 70% of the grade is 3 exams that he expects the average to be around 60%, he won't tell you what to study or whats on the exams and the lecture slides are worthless. I'd say just study the textbook but he had the class get newest version which was twice as expensive but only used material from the 5th edition for exam and lecture material.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Great professor, very understanding and helpful during office hours. He's amazing.

Dr. Rutledge is a great guy. He will go above and beyond to help students understand. It is obvious that he is very passionate about biology, and he really cares about his students. Make sure you find some study buddies for this class because having a review with them before the exams is very helpful. The exams progressively get more difficult.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr Rutledge is one of the toughest professors I've had so far at RPI, but he's a really good guy who wants you to succeed. His exams are pretty difficult and in-depth, and he doesn't really curve or offer much extra credit, but he's very accessible outside of class and encourages asking questions. I learned quite a lot in every lecture.

Terrible at communication, never answered emails in a timely manner. Exams had a lot of content and were mainly based on the textbook. Before every exam, he would send out a list of topics less than a week prior and revise it multiple times just days before the exam took place. He did give a good amount of extra credit though.

i think dr rutledge does a great job in this class. there is definitely A LOT of information covered (an entire textbook in a semester), but he isn't ignorant to this. he was super accessible outside of lecture periods, and was more than willing to meet to help review for exams. it's a lot of work, but he is absolutely one of the best profs at rpi
rating_tags: Tough grader--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Really liked his class - Truly goes out of his way to ensure his student's success. He tries to give a strong biological foundation for his students. If you put in the work for the class, it should work well for you. BIGGEST TIP:  Don't wait till the last few days before a test to study - study 20-30 min everyday!

Just skip the lecture it doesn't matter. The material on the test is straight out of the textbook and none of the lecture material. Memorize the textbook. Hard tests because of all the information the textbook provides. Only good thing is he allowed test corrections otherwise the majority of the class would be below a C.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Nothing related to the lecture and exam. You have to read through the whole book. Never repeat the answers that he gives in class. Horrible class experiences.

His cell bio is very hard but worth taking it. I thought I would end up with a B+ but there was a curve at the end of the semester, so I got an A-. First test is always the easiest one so try to get as pts if possible.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Does not Properly lecture in his classes and does not go into detail what is on the test you rely on yourself to memorize the whole textbook to succeed in the course. The only way you can get an excellent grade his class is to either eat and breathe cell biology or go to all of his office hours. don't take if it is not mandatory for your major
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Also took BIOL2120 w/ him. Overall, he is a good professor but great guy. He is always willing to help students and explains things very well; he is very smart. However, he is a tough grader, has fairly tough exams, and can be very disorganized in lecture/teaching. However, talk to him about everything and follow his guidance and you'll succeed! :)

Overall, great professor especially for office hours. Tests can be difficult so DEFINITELY READ THE TEXTBOOK. Lectures may be a bit unorganized/not actually cover the material for the test but definitely very helpful to answer questions related to exam preparation. Very supportive of students and helpful in lab as well.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--TEST HEAVY

comment: He's the worst lecturer I've had the displeasure of having at RPI. He wants to feel important and like he's preparing us well, when in actuality he goes on and on about concepts not on the test and only mentions actual test material briefly. Incredibly frustrating, boring lecture.

Not very good at grading, waited to put any grades online until finals. This made it very hard to gauge where you are in the class, I didn't appreciate it. Other than that, he knows what he is talking about and is very interested in the subject.

Dr. Rutledge simply loves teaching. this is one of the things we have in common, however,  if he grades you wrongly and you bring it up he will think you're just grovelling for points and completely dismiss any arguments you have, no matter how logical they are. He's right and you are wrong and that's the jist of every argument I have had with him.

Dr. Rutledge gives very tough exams, but he really takes time to prepare you for them. He is extremely generous with his time and even comes in on weekends for study groups. I recommend reading every chapter of the textbook and swinging by his office regularly. He's a very nice guy and I enjoyed his class.
I liked the lab part of the class but Prof. Rutledge wasn't a good lecturer. He didn't seem interested in what he was presenting and his slides weren't that clear either. Tests were fair overall.
Prof. Rutledge is an amazing lab professor. Very helpful, but ask a lot questions to get the most out of the class. He really wants you to succeed.

He didn't know what he was doing, and it was really evident. The averages for the tests went downhill over the semester, even though he said he was trying to make the tests more straightforward. Thankfully though, he came to his senses by the final and let us replace our lowest two test grades with it. Also he handed out A- like candy at the end.

He says that everything is important to know for the test.  He also says that the test will not be specific, but the questions are very specific.  Also, if he emphasizes that something will be on the test, chances are that it won't.  Boring lecturer.  All his slides are pictures, so it is hard to go back through them.  Overall would not recommend.

His lab class was a lot of work but he was great.  He even came in all day on a couple Sunday's to help students learn lab techniques that we didn't have time for in class if they were interested.  He's very approachable and I enjoyed talking to him outside of class.  He really respects people who put in extra time and will give extra credit.
Great teacher. Some TAs grade papers harshly but you can bring yours to Eric for a regrade.

Dr. Rutledge was a great professor! This class was a lot of work (4 papers ranging from 12-25 pages each) but Rutledge was very helpful. He has high expectations and expects you to know every little detail about the lab but if you pay attention when he talks it's not a difficult class. You have to put in some effort but it's not hard to get an A.

Dr. Rutledge actually cares about his students, both their grades and what they get out of his course. He is approachable and kind. Be warned that his papers are highly demanding and the way he words things on rubrics and handouts tends to be unclear. He makes more sense in person so ask for clarification when necessary.

This guy cares about students. Different from other students in the class, I had 0 molecular biology background when I took his lab, and was worried at the beginning. Thanks to Eric who helped me a lot. He made me feel as long as I worked hard, I could do a really good job. This class had a lot of fun, just love it
If you are looking for the best bio 1 teacher at rpi,  this is your man hands down.  Kind, smart, and excited to teach, this guy will go to the end of earth and back for you and your grade

He's extremely friendly and a great guy.  The only problem I had with him is that he taught us what he wanted to teach us, which often involved whatever worm functions he was currently studying.  Because of this, he made his own tests for his section that were often harder than the tests the other sections took.
You will not find another class or teacher where learning is actually easier or more enjoyable. Highly suggested.

Awesome prof. Clearly tells you what is expected and is very helpful! Is more interested in making sure students actually LEARN something than anything else. He is also passionate about the material, which is refreshing. Very straightforward, if he does not know the answer to your question he will tell you.

Amazing professor! He was very clear in class, willing to help is students, and was just a nice guy to talk to.  His Biology lab was easy because he explained everything very well and gave detailed guidlines for his papers which made it easy to write well, and write what he wanted.  DEFINATELY take his Class!!

Do not take programming with Kruger. Take it with Lee in the spring. The exam content is way more difficult than what's covered in class. Kruger is hard to understand, mumbling and rambling, making this class 10x harder. The homework is confusing, requiring hours of work. Office hours with the TA was the only thing that helped.

Tbh the worst class with the worst professors you could take. Before the final I was doing fine and had a good B. The final had material that he said would not be on it, and created difficult problems way out of our scope. Dropped my grade to a D+.
Professor showed an astounding lack of understanding, both empathetic and academic. If you have the misfortune of registering for this course with this professor: reconsider.

MAU is tough to begin with and Prof Kruger's lectures are kinda confusing. Homework is optional but I recommend doing it if you want to do well. He's always making jokes though and they make going through the content a little easier.

Programming for BME with Kruger wasn't so good. Exams were fair enough, but the grading was quite harsh. Homeworks took minimum 4.5 hours and were composed of coding various matrix operations (pretty boring).
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Avoid his class. Despite his expertise, lectures are written in cursive w/excessive proofs. He restricted any past reference for exams/quizzes, leaving only lecture notes. With only 2 HWs & no textbook, practice is scarce. His condescending attitude in OH & strict grading w/no partial cred created an off-putting & discouraging learning environment.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy

comment:
1: unilaterally lengthened class by 30 minutes (8:00-10:05 instead of 8:30-10:05)
2: claims you can buy his textbook for online quizzes, then makes them in-person anyway
3: VERY heavy German accent; doesn't understand grammar
4: lacks self-awareness regarding #3, refuses to clarify exam questions
5: no pacing; rushed through 60% content in a month

He doesn't post lecture notes or any related resources, buying his textbook is the only help you can get outside of class/office hours. He sends messages on Webex but then absolutely refuses to elaborate in person, stating that "hes already clearly explained it in writing." Over half the class failed exam 2 so he made exam 3 worth 50% of our grade.
No comments
