I'm retaking ECSE2500. The exam was utterly terrible, extremely unfair, and exceedingly difficult! I genuinely advise everyone not to choose this professor.
Absolutely terrible professor in and out of class. Told me to drop out of my major when I went to office hours with a question.
His lecture skills are lacking. For one of the exams the class average was 64% and he does not curve. Homework is not graded, but necessary to pass.

One of the worst teachers I've had, avoid taking if you can. This class is pre-recorded, outdated, and hard to follow. The recordings haven't changed in three semesters. Exams are 90% of grade (final 50%) and he doesn't do review sessions. When I took this class all finals got canceled, the grade you had before was the grade you got, no curve
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: One of my favorite classes I've taken as an undergrad
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Amazing lectures

comment: He's not hard and he's not rude, like the other guy said he's just very old-fashioned (by the way he dresses, talks, etc.). But he lectures are amazing and clear and at a good pace - you HAVE to go to class and take notes. And you'll actually understand it and do it well. Exams are very similar to back exams. Just don't be behind and you'll be set.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: He's not a rude man - he's actually pretty nice although he tries to be funny at times. He's just very old-fashioned. Modeling isn't hard just number-heavy, but you HAVE to go to class and take decent notes. The exams are based solely off of that and back exams. If it doesn't make sense go to the TA or him and he'll definitely help you out no prob.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: He doesn't want students to know the average score because it is too low!

His class is tough, but he gives plenty of back exams. It's a little annoying that you don't know when the tests are until a little over a week before, but as long as you listen in class and do the homework the class is fine.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things

comment: His lectures are fine and he makes an effort to engage the students (my class was 20 students). He will not answer questions about exams regarding the content (including format and length) but posts back-tests on piazza that should suffice. Annoyingly at the beginning of each exam he insists everybody waits for him to read every question on it..
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: He explains topics clearly, but makes you feel like your questions are stupid if you ask them. 80% of your grade is based on exams (best 2 out of 3 count). 10% on homework and 10% on class participation. He won't answer any questions about exams or during the exam. If you don't participate on piazza, goodbye 10%. This course is Matlab heavy.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: Generally strick with students' manners( sometimes not very responsive to me due to my questions...) and not very accessible. But he makes the structure quite clear so students don't need books and the homework and exams are easy than other professor's sessions in which students are required to do so many projects.

inaccessible, very irresponsible in homework and exam grading, some times unreasonablely getting angry with students' posts on piazza. Only one good thing his teaching pace is not very fast to keep up with and homework is more concentrated on problem solving rather than conducting many reports ,which is more accepatable and productive for sophomor
Don't do it. He is one of the worst professors I've had at this college. Extremely tough grader later on. Does not care about students. Avoid this professor if you care for your GPA.

This professor for this class refused to post notes, would ofyen not answer questions, and did not adjust the grading for the class nearly enough to make up for the amount of Fs in the class. His teaching style was dry and hard to follow, and he often moved too slow fast at different points. I highly recommend avoiding this professor if one can.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Type of professor who thinks his class is the only class. Test one is very easy whereas later tests become much more difficult. He doesn't offer many resources to help study the material, students often have to just redo homework problems to prepare for exams.
IEA wasnt that hard of a class, but Kruger is an extremely dry lecturer. Basically reads the powerpoint word for word. Also MasteringEngineering homework sucks

Good professor for IEA. Our section was the highest scoring in each exam (F'17). All IEA exams, grading criteria, and lecture material is the same for all sections. Is very clear and takes his time when going through example problems in class. He is also helpful during the in-class assignments.

He isn't the worst professor in the world: he explains concepts quite well and paces the class appropriately. I just personally find some of his comments and mannerisms rude. He constantly puts down dual majors, pre-med BME students, Biomaterials and Biomechanics students for not choosing Imaging/Instrumentation, and students with a low GPA.
rating_tags: TEST HEAVY--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: weird grading rules, hard to understand

Don't want to say too much about this professor. It's the first time for him to teach this course this semester, so I'm not sure about what does it feels like in the past. The knowledge in the class is not too difficult but this professor makes you feel worse than it should be. Also with horrible handwriting, which is beautiful but hard for reading

He is very strict in class - no cell phones, no talking, etc (we are going back to middle school). Additionally, he constantly deletes student input regarding the exams from Piazza. Gives us a one-week notice before exams and is unwilling to tell us what will be on them. No back-work. No reviews. By the way, tests are 40% each. Lowest is dropped.

Grade distribution (Fall 2017): - 80% is your 2 best out of 3 exams. He does not answer questions during exams. He does not tell you exam averages - 10% is Piazza Participation - 10% is from 10 HW assignments. 5 are incredibly easy, 5 are difficult without a TA or backwork No crib sheets on exams even though the other section get one.
He has no idea about what is gonna have in test. Also mean. Class is extremely boring.
Very neat hand writing. nic man

This was his first time teaching the course and he seemed out of touch with the class. He used another teacher's powerpoints and tended to simply click through them during lecture rather than explain and do problems out himself. Much better if you ask him questions directly.

Unlike other profs at RPI I've had thus far, Kruger actually cares about whether you understand the material and gives time to students who need it despite  having hundreds of students. Taking his IEA class, which is a tough course, but it's totally manageable if you get this professor. He's a great guy.

He was my least favorite professor last semester. He is definitely very knowledgable, but he is one of those professors who does not care about his students. His exams are not impossible, but the multiple choice are intended to be difficult. A lot of people would get full points on the open response, but do terribly on the multiple choice.

I did not take AP Bio in HS, but I barely learned anything from him. His voice is very unclear and it was hard to understand him. He posted his lecture powerpoints online but it was very hard to understand just by reading them. Overall, tests were ridiculously hard with the dumbest questions asking for very specific things from the lectures.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--TEST HEAVY

comment: He's a good teacher and the class is really easy

BIOL 1010 is like AP biology all over again.  With that being said you're not going to learn much from this class because its almost a repeat of junior year high school.  His ppts are useful, almost more useful than the book that you're required to buy. His exams however are tricky. Studying from back exams will help a little.

Intro to Bio is not an exciting class to begin with, but it's also not a hard class. Roy is extremely boring during lectures, he puts the lectures online and just goes through the slides.  He'll put you to sleep, but you can still get an A if you just go over the slides on your own.  Avoid him if you can but it won't kill you as bio isn't that hard
Bad with technology. Bad at getting point across. Lectures are difficult to pay attention to and difficult to gleam any information from.

Umm he is one of the worst teachers i have ever had...he can't work his own computer and once at had a video go for almost 10 minutes without realizing he forgot to put the projector on.  Do not take bio with him.

Intro to Bio is boring, regardless of who is teaching it. I was constantly amused by Dr. Roy's ineptness at working his computer. He tries to spruce up the class with relevant news stories and videos, but only partially succeeds. Daily quizzes require attendance, but they're a breeze. Switch attending class with a friend and take the quiz online.
His lectures can put anyone to sleep. Doesn't clarify his answers when students ask questions. Terrible.
Roy was such a bad teacher that I dropped his class, and now I'm taking bio at a community college this summer.
complete joke, cannot believe he teaches at rpi

Gets a bad rap as his lectures are pretty useless, but (as he warns you from the beginning) so long as you follow the text and keep up on the hw, you're sure to do well. That said, while he does have some communication problems, he's not a bad guy by any stretch. Fellow archies: drop the studio work for a few hours a week and you'll have an easy A.

This guy really doesn't understand the materials he teaches, and is very unavailable.  Avoid at all costs.  I really wish I had taken this at community college.  The clickers are annoying and don't create any positive learning whatsoever.  I could go on and on about why not to take this course.

This guy has a bad reputation here.  I only took Intro to Biology with him, but if you actually listen to what he is trying to lecture, you will learn alot.  I think most people just ignore him from the start and become bored quickly.  Still, make sure to read the material-very little of the powerpoint content is tested.

His teaching is AWFUL. He doesn't know how to present his lectures and has long pauses in between every three words which makes paying attention to him very hard. He's a very boring guy and has a really creepy smile...
Bored me to tears.

He is a very nice teacher who shows a general interest in the subject. The pre and post quizzes helped alot when studying for the exams because the questions were very similar and sometimes exactly the same.
He is so boring. He knows his stuff, but he could careless about teaching it.

This class is an absolute waste of you time, avoid it at all costs. he doesn't lecture, he expects you to know everyting before you show up for the first class. when you ask him a question he wiggles his eyebrows and turns the question back on you. If you like to feel stupid this is the class for you!
WORST. CLASS. I'VEEVERHADTOTAKE. ewwwww

Biggest waste of time.  He does not know one thing.  He is a little baby.  Terribly dull and painfully boring.  You will learn nothing in this class, but you will be frustrated to no end by it.  Stupid pre and post class quizes.  Stupid journals.  ALL BUSY WORK.  worhtless.  without worth.
Awful Awful Awful class and professor...avoid like the plague.  Your GPA and your sanity will suffer after taking this course.

DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE UNLESS YOU HAVE TO! The subject matter is painfully dull; genetics is taught as an applied statistics course. Roy's bland lecturing style doesn't help make the class any more exciting.
Deifnitely time to sleep and AIM.  When you ask him a question, he likes to talk from his ass; he never ends up answering the question either.
I learned nothing.
Roy sucks he doesnt lecture or cover the material... take this class if you like independant study.
You will fall asleep as the camel drones on, face contorting into strange shapes that baffle the mind.  WHAT IS HE SAYING?! STOP TALKING PLEASE ... you make me want to kill myself.
the worst teacher ever. He spends too much time trying to use technology and not enough time teaching. if you dont need to take the class dont, it's a huge waste of time.
Worst teacher I've ever had in my educational career...it hurts knowing that I'm paying for this guy's salary.
This may be the worst class offered at RPI, which really is an accomplishment because most classes suck.
Possibly the worst professor on the face of the planet.  Thank god he doesn't teach physics.
No Comments

Belmiro does a nice job engaging students. He makes lectures fun by adding in jokes and personal stories while also doing a thorough job explaining content. Exams are on the tougher side but he makes it clear what will be included. He has a slight accent but I find that it actually helps me focus. Grades are based on only quizzes and exams.

I would take all my math classes with him if possible. His lectures are amazing, genuinely funny and kind professor. Completely understanding of students' circumstances, and wants to see everyone succeed. Exams are a little tough and can vary massively in difficulty depending on topic, no final exam.

Belmiro Galo is all in all a pretty good professor, I had him for Calc 2 and was pretty lost at first, it seemed like he reviewed some things quicker if he thought people already knew it, but just talk to the guy about any problems you have and he will try to help you. Very supportive in office hours, and don't be scared to grade challenge on exams

I had Professor Galo for my first semester at RPI and he is definitely one of the most difficult ones I've had. He is a great lecturer and the homework was  fair but his tests were significantly harder than other Calc 1 professor's exams.
Great guy who really tries to make the class fun and engaging. Always accessible during office hours and very helpful. The class average for tests was usually about 70 and they are difficult.

I went into Calc 2 my first semester not knowing what to expect and all I can say is he does live up to the hype. He has well organized lectures and tests + recitations that reflect back exams/achieve questions. My only minor problem with the course is that only 1 back exam was given and that was for the first exam

Took him for Calc 2. I was nervous at first because he's known for hard exams, but many questions (at least 70%) were straight from Achieve, so it wasn't too challenging. I got a good grade and could focus on learning without stressing about grades. Keeping up with the homework made this class very manageable.

Took him for Calc 2. Exams are HORRIBLE in this class. To the point where the averages where Ds and Fs. Also, he was not very good at explaining certain topics. Spent hours studying to barely pass with the skin of my teeth... Do yourself a favor and don't take him unless you have to since other Calc 2 professors have much easier exams.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: Took calc 1 with him he was great, favorite thing was he provided tailored exam practices that were set up similarly to exam he gave (just different numbers), wanted to take calc 2 with him but didn't align with schedule. This semester I saw he teaches Multivar and immediately signed up for it its going great. He explains well. Bonus he's funny.

The content is quite tough, Belmiro is passionate about math and has solid lectures. Recitation had group quizzes. He has a bit of an accent, but is totally understandable.
Tests were difficult but never tedious or annoying with the values given.

Belmiro is a lively lecturer, sometimes goes really fast but you can always ask him to explain things after class. He is good at breaking down concepts. He posts clear notes and always willing to help students. He has 4 midterms, no final and always post practice exams. He's known for giving hard tests in calc1&2 but his exams in multi are easy.

Great professor for MATH4300! Belmiro is clear, organized, and genuinely cares about student success. He literally explains "complex" topics well, makes the material interesting, and is always available for extra help. Highly recommend! The hardest B+ I've gotten and learned a ton!

Belmiro is not a bad professor, just inexperienced. His notes aren't great and the few example problems he does are trivial compared to the hw problems. exams and the point distribution is tough. Since he's new to this class there was only 1 back exam but when asked for more exam prep he said he couldn't do anything about it. He's nice though.

Notes are ok for the homework's but don't prepare you well for the exams. Exams can be challenging and tedious, point distribution between questions is ridiculous, and grading is also incredibly harsh in return. He needs to show more examples in the notes that are closely aligned to what's on the exams, especially for computational problems.

Professor Galo did an amazing job teaching this course. His lectures were engaging and enjoyable and he incorporated a diversity of interesting and useful topics into the material. The homework, quizzes, and tests were well-designed and he consistently demonstrated his desire to improve the quality of his instruction and the course for everyone.
Good professor, flexible, easy going.

He's my favorite professor. He's a very young approachable guy and his lectures are solid. He's always talking about sports or making jokes. Would've given a 5 however he makes his exams pretty tough in comparison to some of the other Calc 1 and 2 professors. His exams are copies of old ones with different functions.
He got through the content easy to understand ways. He's known for writing hard tests but I've had worse. There was no final exam too which was really nice!

I've had him for both MATH-1010 and MATH-1020 and he's been pretty great for both. He provides everything you need in order to succeed such as practice exams and a layout of the exams. He really wants everyone to succeed and even gave extra credit after one of the first exams. He's pretty understanding and is always willing to help if you ask.

Professor Galo is an awesome guy, he's a big sports person and is very friendly, and is very approachable if you need help with anything. Tests can be very difficult, especially the first one of the semester. However, he is a very good lecturer and explains things well.

Professor Galo is a fantastic professor for Calc 2, he is one one of the funniest teachers I have personally had before, and always made lectures entertaining. He is also extremely kind and cares about his students, and is more than willing to help you understand anything you are having trouble with.

Nice dude great lectures and you learn a lot however his tests can be extemely hard for no reason. It can also depend upon which version you get with the different versions for the same exam being two different skill levels

He really cares about students and likes to joke around in lectures. He is also willing to work with you if you don't understand something and when our class average is lower than expected he seemed genuinely disappointed/sad and also offered extra credit.

I really enjoyed this class and thought the professor made lectures both enjoyable and informative. The tests were sometimes more difficult due to harder questions than we had gone over in class, but I did feel that doing homework and practice assignments prepared me well for them.
Professor Galo gives great feedback and is great in lectures. His notes may be hard to read at some times, but he is hilarious and fully attempts to help his students understand the materials

A little bit prone to distraction and side tangents, and sometimes it's difficult to read his notes, but overall, he's a great teacher who knows how to teach material while also keeping the class light-hearted and relaxed.

Belmiro is great. He cares a lot about his students, he strives to form connections, and his lectures are pretty easy to follow. The exams for Calc II were on the harder side, but unlike some professors, he curved his exams or gave us the opportunity to do an extra credit project to get some points back. One of the better Calc II lecturers at RPI.
I love him but I wish he gave me a D- at least, still a very fun and easy teacher.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Test heavy

comment: It was a fun class. Get to know the professor and the class will be more enjoyable.

almost failed the class, he believed in me and i was able to pull myself back up and pass the class. he was very upset i wasnt in calc 2 with him but unfortunately my major classes interfered. i will definitely try and take him again

Prof. Galo is the best prof at RPI. I currently am taking LA & CV with him. I previously took LA with a different professor, but Galo has taught me more in the past few weeks than in that entire semester. Not to mention, he is engaging, hilarious, and a very kind person. He values our feedback as much as we value his.

With great lectures and an empathetic character, Belmiro is engaging and fun to be around. His lectures do a good job of explaining material and are interesting, but don't always correspond well to the content on homework and texts. He tries to strike a balance between theory and application, but his class would be more cohesive if he just chose 1.

Textbooks were recommended, but not required. 

His lectures were very engaging and chill. He made sure that the material was understandable for both Math and Computer Science majors. Homeworks and quizzes were relevant for the exams. Exams were difficult but fair. Time in his office hours were well-spent. Best linear algebra professor at RPI.
Really cool guy. Often adjusts the difficulty of test based on the performance of previous tests. Posts all lecture notes online but it's easier to understand in person.

Belmiro is an amazing professor. Although at times he can make his tests very heavy to the point where the average grade is very low he provides extra credit to make up for this. He wants all of his students to pass no matter what. If you are looking for a math professor I heavily recommend Belmiro.

Professor Belmiro is truly one of the best lecturers at RPI. He cares for all of his students and their success, while making his lectures fun and engaging despite them being just notes. The problems that he puts on his exams can be very difficult, however they are nothing unlike the examples we go over in class.

Belmiro is a great professor, he's very hard on himself but is still fantastic. His exams are very hard but makes sure his students understand the material before. Go to his office hours, they're helpful and he's very nice to talk to. I was going to take him for Calc 2, but I had a class for my major which overlapped. Recommended to all my friends

Really engaging professor and makes calc topics very easy to understand. He makes lectures very lively and interesting. Balmiro is a pretty young professor too so he understands what we're going through and really wants to help students out. Honestly can't think of anything bad about teaching style or hw/exams. By far my favorite professor at RPI.

Really nice guy, a bit hard to understand and doesn't explain things well but I took intro to open source so he wasn't lecturing most of the time. The class suits him well, definitely recommend. Genuinely cares about students and inspiring open source creation

Moorthy is a very passionate professor. If you can get past his accent (Which is a problem for some people) then he is a great professor. He knows the material and is always ready to help. He is invested into his students.
Professor Moorthy, overall, was pretty good. He is a very entertaining lecturer and presents the material well. Sometimes the tests could be quite difficult, but that comes with the territory.

I had him twice: once for Algorithms and once for ModComp. In Algorithms, the TAs ruined that class as some TAs didn't give partial credit so a lot of is TA-dependent. Moorthy is helpful, he has a facebook you can even use to ask him questions. However, his lectures are fast-moving and hard to understand.

Moorthy is the best professor at RPI, aside from R. Grice.  His lectures are hilarious, but only if you pay attention.  He is ALWAYS willing to help and loves to teach.  His accent isn't too difficult to understand.  I think he is a bot though, he responds to all E-mails in roughly 29.7 seconds flat....

He's knowledgeable and has a good sense of humor, but I really had a lot of trouble understanding him because of his accent. I skipped most of the lectures but luckily you can learn most of the material from the textbook.

Professor Moorthy's Models of Computation class was very enjoyable. I've heard very mixed opinions about him coming into this class, but there really is nothing to complain about. He does have an accent, but he's very understandable.
Moorthy's a great teacher.  He knows his stuff, but the accent does provide some trouble at times.  He's very helpful if you seek him out, pay attention and go to his office hours if you need help.

Good teacher.  His accent was a bit tough to understand at times, but he was good at explaining, and cracked an occasional joke, in his own kinda way.  Very helpful too.  He went out of his way at one point to meet me for extra help late evening because I had such a busy schedule.

Projects were difficult, and he spent lectures teaching us "magic tricks" (which was really just math).If you had questions he recommended you use google. He did curve tests though, but the projects were very time consuming and frustrating
Very intelligent.  Provides interesting examples in class.  Almost always in office.  Has a thick accent, though.

The course material is difficult and demanding. The projects are very difficult and should be started on immediately. He's very helpful if you seek him for help. Class is only semi-useful. He can be difficult to understand, especially when he gets excited about a topic.

Can't understand a word he says in lecture and he has poor organization and teaching skills. He makes things more complicated than it seems.  I was really looking foward to taking this course, but he made this course hell for me
Can't understand what he says.  He jumps from point 1 to point 5 without explaining how he got there.  Hws are graded pretty tough but the projects are ok.

Lectures are tough, but if you go see him to get help he will basically walk you through anything you have trouble with.  Gives projects which are involve little more than cutting and pasting code together.
Accent was a bit tough, but once you get past that the material was not hard at all except for the last 2 weeks.

Good teacher.  In his class you can learn as much or as little as you want to really.  He makes the tests and projects pretty easy.  Tries to get the class involved in discussions.  His accent isn't bad at all compared to many other TA's and professors.
Yes, he has a thick accent, but it's not that hard to undstand.  He's always happy in class and he smiles a lot and will always answer questions.  A nice teacher.
Excellent teacher.  Easy class.
Fantastic teacher.  Very funny.  Made computer science fun again...
Good overall.  At his best when improvising demonstrations of the material rather than summarizes the textbook.  But I had to buy a book on network programming to do one of the assignments.
No Comments
Funny guy, really bright.  Ask him to juggle and recite Pi, as this is one of his many talents.  Hard to understand but his final was incredibly simple.  RTFM!

The man is funny to watch, but thats about the only amu****t you will get from him. He is totally and utterly incomprehensible. The homeworks started off easy enough but out of no where they became totally impossible to understand.
He is very hard to understand, has a thick accent and just reads off of powerpoint lecture notes another professor made.

Wow, if you ever have any trouble with homework or projects, go to his office hours (not the TAs). He sat with my partner and I and helped us fully complete the project.  He is funny and a great person to talk to.  The Pi man!
Great teacher, lots of extra credit, took about 2 weeks of sitting up front to get used to his accent.
No Comments
He's not really a bad guy, but he's not really a good professor.
Nice Guy,  Indian  (I think) accent, but not too hard to understand. Funny, and interesting too.
No Comments
Incredibly precise when solving questions in class, and makes sure to show all work necessary. Hands down one of the most knowledgeable and caring professors I have had here at RPI.

Very tough class, but Taylor is absolutely your best choice for IEA, his lectures are clear and he's very enthusiastic, he really wants his students to do well. The class is hard (and the homework is harder!) but if you pay attention, do the back exams, and get help when you need it, you should do well
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Very good lectures, very clear, very passionate. Great professor!
Great teacher, great office hours

Aerodynamics with Professor Taylor was easily the best class I have taken at RPI. Lectures are more of a discussion rather than a lecture, making it easy to get in depth in to complex topics. He does a great job of making sure you understand the most important concepts that you will need in the industry. He's also hilarious.

Absolutely love Keith Taylor. Probably my fav lecturer I've had at RPI so far. He really cares and you can tell. His lectures are incredibly engaging and thorough and you actually feel like you've learned something important by the end of his class. Show up to lecture, do all the homework and study for the tests and you'll pass, not an easy class.
Taylor is fantastic for IEA and is so understanding and intelligent! He calls things as they are and is one of the few professors who actually remembers what it was like to be a college freshman.
I loved this class, he presented the material in a way that just made sense to me. He genuinely cared and made sure everyone passed, AS LONG AS YOU GO TO HIM IF YOU'RE STRUGGLING.

He truly cares about his students and wants everyone who deserves it to succeed. The course content is was pretty challenging for me as I felt like it was all mostly theoretical. I went to his office hours and he took the time to explain each and every step in a way I understood. Very accommodating, patient, and one of the best professors at RPI.

He definitely cares about his students and is very helpful at office hours. However it is hard to get help at office hours with how many people go. I do not like his lecture slides and find his process of solving questions overcomplicated. However he emphasizes on using his method which is why I did so poorly.

Professor Taylor is genuinely one of the best professors I have ever had. He went out of his way to help me in IEA and took the time to work with me when I was struggling. His lectures explained the content well. He will go out of his way to make sure his students pass.

Professor Taylor is legitimately one of the best teachers I've ever had. He is very accommodating for all students, and his office hours are incredibly useful. If you can handle some corny jokes, some mild sarcasm, and some VERY emphatic repetition of important concepts, his class is the place to be in for IEA.

He is extremely clear with what he needs student to learn, as well as very attentive to students when doing in class assignments. He repeats the important stuff over and over until it gets in your head.

While prof Taylor was one of the hardest profs I have had, he is also the best teacher of any course he is a part of. He grades hard but it is clear that he just wants you to succeed. If you do the work, ask questions, and show up to office hours with problems he will ensure that you pass.

Professor Taylor often uses his paranoia to award students points, and he will deduct points from students for adding attachments to their emails. His ppt was very chaotic, and his teaching method was too. I could hardly learn anything in the two-hour class. He even needs chegg to explain some topics, but he does not allow students to use chegg.

Professor Taylor's Engineering Dynamics is - in all honesty - much more difficult than other professors' classes you could take, but it was definitely worth it. He teaches you notation strategies and methods of problem solving that make classes requiring 3D problem solving and multiple reference frames way easier. 100% recommend prof. Taylor.
JUST AVOID. Can't say too much details.

Do not take this class with him. He is a fine professor for other classes but in this one he is incredibly confusing and insists on using this terrible notation that is unlike anything in the textbook so you're solely dependent on his notes which are rarely helpful. He makes the class much more difficult than it needs to be. Take a different prof.

I would not take the course again, and he needlessly punishes honest students for what cheaters do. He spends way too much time caught up on chegg use instead of teaching. Graded by few tests and grading criteria is never clear.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: At first, he seems really funny and nice, and he is, he answers questions in lecture just fine. However, the number of mistakes in lecture notes is really problematic. His tests are either NOTHING like the back exams or have errors in them. And don't expect him to be helpful in an exam either if you ask for help. He is nice and approachable in gen

Professor Taylor is a great professor. He is funny, intelligent. He often makes jokes during class. He constantly improve the way he teach the concept. His pacing of the lecture is good. He would often stay a little late to help the student with in-class activities.
He makes everything very easy to understand, often tells jokes during class and is very understanding.
Really great professor who cares about his students and knows a lot about the subject. Very fair grader and reasonable with excuses/absences.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Very helpful. Loved his class. Always seems to care about the students and the materials; very helpful when asking questions. Good, well-paced lectures and easy-to-follow in-class assignments. Definitely come to class or you will quickly get behind.
Talking to my friends that were taking IEA with other professors made me feel lucky to have Taylor. He is very nice and helpful during office hours and his lectures were great.

Don't get me wrong, he's a very clear lecturer in terms of concepts- it's just his exam/class answer keys are constantly riddled with mistakes, and it's hard to keep up with his numerical errors. His exam q's are HARD and points get taken off easily with significant figures, ect. but he's caring and knows his physics stuff. NOT an easy A, but hey.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Taylor is a very good lecturer and his office hours are very helpful.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: Prof. Taylor is definitely the best lecturer for IEA. He is clear and concise, and is able to ask any question asked of him. He wants to make sure everyone does well, so he is constantly asking the class if they understand what he's gone over. He is also very accessible in office hours, or if you want to make an appointment with him.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Caring

comment: Prof. Taylor was excellent as an IEA lecturer. He structured the class so in-class assignments were integral; he didn't just turn his back on us when we did them either- he would work through any issue we had and would lift us up when we got down on ourselves. The man is definitely your best bet for IEA in my view.
Had Keith for IEA and Dynamics. Guy looks like a goon but hes a good professor. Study his back exams and in class example problems and the exams arent too bad.
Keith Taylor is the man. IEA was a tough class but he was as clear and understandable as possible. He is also very helpful during office hours and he's so funny. You won't use your book much.

I had professor Taylor for IEA. This class is my favorite class so far because of him. His lecture is clear and easy to understand. He is also a pretty funny lecturer to keep you awake. You pretty much get full credit for the in-class-assignment grade as long as you attend ever lecture. He is super caring and his office hour is supper helpful

I had professor Taylor for thermals and fluids. he is a good teacher. his tests are kind of difficult because he doesnt let you use crib sheets but he makes them pretty straightforward. As long as you study the lectures you should be ok.  He seems to care about the students and is a nice person.
rating_tags: BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Caring

comment: Although as some students pointed out. He focuses on supercomputer history and so forth and the assignments might be a bit different but I found everything super interesting. I loved working with MPI/CUDA too and it did get a bit heavy in the end but overall learned a lot and it was worth it.

- Gives generous grades
- Talks a lot about different supercomputers (kinda like history) instead of focusing more on CUDA/MPI stuff
- Doesn't respond to discussion threads/emails
It's 2023 and this man still never responds to email or discussion forum

- 5 homeworks, 4 of which are done alone, and 1 which can be done in a group.
- 1 group project worth 30%
- 26 lecture summaries * 350 words
Only would take again because I can PNC.
Don't work with lazy people for group project. 
He doesn't respond to emails or discussion forum.
Homeworks generally easy, don't start late.
No late days.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--So many papers

comment: Writeups are a significant portion of the course grade; they tend to be all-or-nothing with vague requirements and little feedback until far along in the course. Lectures suck horribly, but you sorta have to go to get access to the supercomps/have all the info you need for the writeups. Homeworks were mediocre. Only CS class I've ever dropped.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--SO MANY PAPERS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Slides in comic sans, perpetually late, never answers email

While the homework can be difficult and the lectures can be a bit dry, it is wonderful to have a professor teaching about something they are genuinely passionate about. Not easy by any means, but he is a very helpful person should you ever need it.
Terrible professor. Frustrating assignments, and very little indication of what students are expected to know for quizzes.

I've never experienced true rage until I entered this course. After taking it, I realized it wasn't a course on computer science but rather a course on perspective. I always felt that the current topic/homework was the hardest/most unfair thing ever until I experienced the next one. By the end of the course, I was at my wit's end. Don't take it.
Very smart, very knowledgeable about the material, very passionate, and a pretty bad professor. Assignments are ambiguous and quizzes are pretty bad. That said, you could do a lot worse.

The professor might as well have not tried to teach the course. His lectures are copied straight from another university's computer science website, and he does a terrible job of even trying to explain that. If you enjoy computer science at all, spare yourself and don't take computer science with Chris Carothers.

Terrible professor! His class is extremely difficult and he literally reads off of his powerpoint which includes some of the worst written things ever. He also never responds to emails, literally none of my three emails to him were answered. Don't take comp org with him.
Not the easiest of instructors but he knows his stuff and teaches well. Looking for an easy A, go elsewhere. Want to learn, he's the guy.
very hard, very boring, do not take comp org with him!

Do not take this professor for 6:00pm-8:00pm class. I could not focus on his lectures which were powerpoint slides loaded with typos. You would be much better off just studying the book instead of going to the lecture. I found the two exams very difficult and failed both of them. The other half of the grade was homework which I got 100% on with sup
Comp Org with him not an easy class but you come out of there learning something.  If you just want the grade take it with someone else. If you want to learn, he's the guy.

Terrible professor, lectures straight off of horribly typed slides. The homeworks do reinforce the material that SHOULD BE taught, but they're hard as hell. He rarely responds to his email, is very unresponsive to the class, and you have to pin him down at office hours to really get him to explain things sometimes.
No Comments

Terrible professor.  Doesn't really teach, only reads from the text.  Has typos in everything, annoying as hell to read anything he types up.  Quite frankly, with him as your professor, save yourself the time of going to class, just read the text, you won't miss anything
VERY UNHELPFUL, ANY TIME I ASKED FOR HELP HE BLEW ME OFF, VERY RUDE PERSON
When I had Chris C as a professor for Comp Org I thought he was the hardest professor EVER.  However, I've come to learn that he was one of the best.
Clearly one of the most attractive professors at the school.  Classes are good with lots of options to learn more about topics you enjoy.
Clear explainations and VERY helpful outside of class... But course work is HARD compare to other prof for the same course.
Good teacher and enthusiastic, but the class was hard as hell.
No Comments

Class notes not all that useful, but if you READ THE TEXT.  He picked a REALLY good book for this course and if it seems like he's just reading stuff straight from it, it's the best way it can be explained.  Liberal with extensions.

His PhD should be revoked.  While it may be easy for him to simply copy his assignments from everywhere else, when he forgets to friggin' change the email address from cmu.edu to rpi.edu, he gets his PhD taken away.  That anecdote says a lot, trust me.

If lumberjacks could read then he might be a good professor.  He completely reads from powerpoint slides (which he got online from the publisher).  He had no idea how to explain concepts, he is just all around a bad teacher.
No Comments
Hard course!!  good teacher, sometimes rambles on and on but tries to keep it interesting
Really good prof, you get an email from him nearly every other day.  Explains material well and cares about students.

Had this Professor in 1972-76 for Organic Chem. He was tough as nails; didn't want you to memorize actually wanted you to think an use your brain to figure things out. He had a MAJOR impact on my life that goes far beyond a grade ( philosophy that "C" is a good grade). Today I am a Professor of Medicine and teach my residents to think. Thank you.

Very brilliant, if you read ahead there was no way to learn material better. He pushed you to the max and expected you to know your stuff. He is a firm believer in not babying people like the current education system does, lots of people don't get it many should fail simple as that. Not all are meant to be good at everything it is simply life
Very intimidating but knows his material well. His examples are sometimes funny and unexpected.

i agree with the previous post. Exams had nothing to do with lectures. the test format varied wildly. I never had any idea what to study. The class averages hit new all time lows. I don't see how anyone succeeded in the course, but succeeding meant having a 40 average. It was a waste of time and effort.

The course is impossible and unfair. Tests are random in terms of content coming from text or lectures. Every test is a new horrific experience. RPI should be embarrassed as a fine institution to have this professor instruct such an essential course impacting the educational careers of their students. Dreams die and GPA's plummet under the instruct

I have him for Ochem I and II lab and honestly he HATES teaching.  I'm doing well in the lab only because of extensive research on the internet.  I went to Moore once for a question and man he really thinks he's something...I'm SO GLAD I don't have him in Ochem Lecture, that class must have really sucked.
Terriable made me want to stop learning!

Very tough teacher.  He answers your questions with an impatient/frustrated tone of voice.  Hardest exams I've ever taken.  Prepare to study hours on end just to get a 30 on the exam.  Lectures lack structure and are overall unhelpful.
hate him. makes tests that are incomprehensible and then is surprised when the average is in the 30s. unhelpful.

My first impression of him was that he was a jerk, but if you go to him after class or during office hours he is a nice guy. Notes are from the text and you must study a lot in order to do good on exams. He expects you to know a lot about organic chem and the tests can be very hard. Good luck passing this class, organic chem at RPI really sucks!!!!
If you guys think Moore is tough I only wish you could have experienced Herbrandson. Rock on Jim, gjm '74

Moore isn't a bad person, he seems extremely smart, and he's friendly enough when you come to office hours.  The thing is that he seems to make it his goal to cause as many people as possible to drop the class.  Don't be suprised by exam averages in the 30s.  Also don't be suprised by unhelpful lectures and wildly varying exam styles.  have fun.

Rarely in life do u come across suck a horrible teacher.  I go to class, read and still have no idea what the hell he is talking about.  He is condescending, and is way to smart to teach us regular folk.  If he is teaching the class wait until next year to take!!!!!

In typical smart-guy-who-has-no-business-teaching fashion, he did not explain anything in detail, nor did he define variables he used in his formulas, and when I asked him to explain, he'd make a comment about how I should have read the chapter.  Problem was I DID read the chapter, but the book was almost as horrible as Jimmy Boy.  Sorry, Mr. Moore, you get an F.  Go work in a lab somewhere where you won't be bothered by humans.

Had him for lab, he made the TA's cry on occasion...not a very nice guy, glad I didn't have him for lecture.  He would give us lab quizzes and then leave, so he wasn't helpful at all.  One girl asked how she could do better on the quizzes and he said, "You can't."

Though Moore seems to come off as condescending and very old-fashioned, he is under the influence that RPI students are supposed to be smart, or at least willing to learn. When no one in class asks questions he indicates that we will not do well on the exam, which is 100% true.
No Comments
What an a**.
This guy is a ****......a real ****, but if u pay attention and arent afraid to ask questions then hes a descent teacher.....I also dont think hes gettin any quality time from Ms.Moore.

The most evil professor. Tends to make exams impossible, scaling difficulty of the next test on the scores of the previous exam. Condescending as hell, students are too scared to ask questions about the exam.
Makes tests impossible.  Can be intimidating but go to office hours anyway
Horrible teacher
he has an attitude problem, bad teacher if u dont know the material inside out

He is terrible, he is very condescending and old-school, he tells you if you don't ask questions you are going to  fail the test.  Also he explains thing that have nothing to do with the course and kind of assumes you know everything in the course already
This guy is a jerk and should be locked in a cage. He sends threatening emails and if any prof is going to hell.. it will be him

Dr. Moore would benifit from a class that focused on interpersonal skills.  while yes his class is difficult, he adds to that by making us not want to ask him questions for fear of being called stupid and dumb.  he does not really care about how we do.
he sucks, i hated him.
very demanding, but a good professor.  very difficult final exam, even harder than the semester tests.  somewhat of a bad attitude, but i definately learned a hell of alot.
No Comments
can be mean if you ask him a question, but decent teacher overall
People sure whine about his class alot, but if you do your work and prepare yourself for the worst, you should be okay.  Does not tolerate cheating.

I went into this class with a basic level of understanding of Quantum physics, which he quickly removed through his incompetence. His lectures were sloppy, riddled with mistakes, and failed to cover incredibly important material for future courses. Avoid him at all costs
He doesn't teach, just writes equations
He often did mathematical calculations that were unnecessary for the tests, very hard to understand. Choose a different professor.

Get angry when students don't pay attention to him. Forgetful, not lenient with grades, annoyingly incompetent with teaching physics ii. Cannot understand why some students aren't interested in physics.

A really interesting guy who knows a lot about his subject, but the lectures were often hard to understand. The lectures and homework were not very good preparation for the exams, and it was hard to know what to study. But he's nice and helpful and has a good sense of humor.
It is somewhat difficult to guess the test content from the material taught in lecture.

He is a cool guy, but the course is difficult. The slides and textbook do a decent job of covering the material, but the homework and exams are somewhat out there. Exams are unclear. The exam are 90% of the course so beware. Write everything, EVERYTHING from slides on your crib sheet. Make sure you go to office hours for homework. Class is semi worth
Professor Stoler's classes are often confusing and borderline boring.  He is a very smart guy, but teaching physics 1 is not his forte.  Seems like a nice guy, though.
The worse professor I have had. I asked him to clarify some slides for me and all he did was read them VERBATIM to me...twice! Avoid his classes.
Confusing... did covered material that was on tests.

Absolutely the worst professor I've ever had.  Avoid if at all possible.  He is extremely incompetent, makes errors both in speech and on his slides with alarming frequency, and does not administer fair examinations.
lecture slides are filled with "typos" (some of which change the problems entirely), the homeworks have nothing to do with the lectures, the exams have nothing to do with either.

I'd also recommend taking multivar before if you can (many can't, but stoler doesn't seem to care).  As a teacher, he's actually not that bad, hes enthusiastic but he sets the bar high. He definitely knows his stuff; hes a researcher.. His slides can be intimidating, with lots of diverse and difficult material : but overall the tests were fair.
He's very incompetent at what he does and makes numerous mistakes when teaching in class, so much that it detracts for learning quite a bit.  Overall, never take a class from him.

Apparently he sucks at every other class he teaches, but he didn't do badly in physics 2.  He taught with the course heads powerpoint slides, which was good and bad cuz he questioned them at times.  My TA was very nice though so maybe he's not as good as I thought.
He tends to get the information across but very slowly, which might not be so bad if we did not need every minute to complete the activity on time.

Stoler knows physics, but is not good at explaining it.  He doesn't over complicate things like others have said, he uses different methods.  I agree that he expects a lot of knowledge, but I believe that has more to do with the order in which classes are supposed to be taken.  I reccomend having MultiVar done with, it'll help a lot.

He's kind of arrogant, but he knows his stuff cold.  Doesn't teach directly from the slides like many other Physics professors do; skips some of the unimportant ones and goes into depth on the ones that really matter.  The class itself is kind of rough.  Make sure you do the HW that's not due in addition to the handed-in HW to do well on the tests.
He is a smart guy, but he doesn't seem to be very involved in teaching.

Can't explain anything properly, lectures are full of mistakes, tests are unclear, teaching method is horrendous, expects you to know alot before taking the class, makes the simplests things hard.  Cuz of him, I've had to change majors, its not that the material is hard, its that the professor is just plain horrible.  Nice guy though.
This guy's a joke.  I don't know who he thinks he is teaching classes.  He should be sitting in a corner by himself pretending to do his "research" that no one seems to care about.
No Comments
Stoler is not the person to introduce one to theoretical physics.  Doesn't explain concepts well, if at all.

This man is so adorable.  All he talks about are quarks.  And I had him for physics 2, which had nothing to do with quarks.  Haha.  As far as a class I had no desire to take, he did a pretty good job teaching it.
I don't know about other classes, but he was a great Phys 2 prof. Knew the subj well. Gave relavent antedotes and comments. Powerpoints weren't his, and he didn't make the tests, or assign HW.

Many errors in notes which cost too much class time for him to fix - perhaps future classes won't have to contend with this problem. Tests were...erratic in difficulty level - though if you've had DiffEq and MultiVar they should be do-able. HW load is not bad. Not a great prof but a nice guy.

This is by far the worst professor i have ever had. His lectures are riddled with typos and his tests are far fetched and not based on what he taught in class. When people study from his online lecture notes outside of class, no one can follow what hes typed out. I dont think he should be teaching.

I liked physics until this course. He does very little to make sure you actually understand the material, because he assumes you already knew it or can pick it up easily from the nearly worthless and error-filled notes. He's great, though, if you can easily triple integrate in spherical coordinates.

Terrible teacher. His lecture notes are riddled with errors which we then spend our class time tring to correct. I suggested he have a TA edit his notes before class and he replied "I simply don't do them early enough for that to be plausible." He also expects us to know more than we do from phys 2.
stoler is a horrible teacher.  he goes over the same thing 80 times, making it unclear to students what is going on.  easy to fall asleep in his class, gets excited in a creepy way over simple topics
Really a terrible lecturer in entry-level courses like this one, he's so far above the course material he can't explain it, confused a lot of students.

Everyone in class loved Merrill. It was one of the best classes I took in RPI. Merrill is exceptional at teaching. I learned a lot from the class and I will always remember this wonderful experience. I felt sad when the class ended (so was my undergrad at the same time).

This class was definitely one of the most helpful I have ever taken. Prof. Whitburn gives excellent feedback for improvement and is very generous for grading, as long as you put in a sincere effort. I thoroughly enjoyed the class to provide feedback for my peers and saw strong improvement in my public speaking skills. Excellent class overall.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Great class

Great course and an outstanding professor! Merrill cares about the success of his students and really pushes them to succeed. His course was the most useful I've taken thus far, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to all RPI students.

Merrill is the best professor at Rensselaer!  I had to put many extra hours into this course and I was stressed at many points in time about giving speeches but he structured the class so that it made it easy to succeed. 100% would recommend!  I feel confident about public speaking and it is a great tool to have for the future.
One of the best classes and professors at RPI
The class is hard, and if you have problems speaking publicly it will be extra hard. But you will learn more in this class for your career than many other classes.
I learned so much about public speaking. I really got to know the professor and my classmates. Fun, interesting, easy, and you'll never get critics like in this class!

Greatest professor at RPI. He expects a lot, so you'll need to work hard but you will learn a ton. Very friendly and comical class environment. Textbook reading not too important, practice and improvement determine your grade. Painful at first but you will see yourself gain confidence and become a much better public speaker. Take this class.

I took public speaking from this guy. He has a commanding presence, and knows a lot about the subject, but he doesn't know nearly as much as he thinks he does. Attendance is mandatory and his grading is brutal. If you don't eat up every bit of his dogma like the religion he thinks it is, he will hang you for it. I did A level work, it got me a C+.

Easily the most useful class I've taken to date, and his advice has helped me in every single presentation that I've given since then.  Merrill keeps the class fun and interesting, and I hated all public speaking coming in.  Grading is not too bad as long as you put in the effort, he judges you on your improvement over the semester.
Came into speech communication with zero public speaking ability now i feel much more confident and prepared to make a public speech.  great professor

Merrill is awesome! Take speech communication and you will ace any and every single speech, oral presentation and interview you encounter for the rest of your life. Oh, don't buy the textbook for this class, its a waste of money. Just go to the library or borrow a friend's to do what little reading he assigns at the beginning.
Merrill is the man! Best professor at RPI!

This is one professor you definitely want to have.  His class starts out hard; you will have to practice a lot to meet his high expectations.  However, he is very knowledgeable, and will help you however he can. Your class will come together and you will feel like you have all been lifelong friends.  I will definitely take more of his classes.

Amazing prof. who deeply cares about students. Hard if you haven't spoken in front of people before but well worth the effort.  He's scary the first day but don't worry he really does care, and it's not as much reading as he says.  as long as you try your best and dont just blow it off you will not just get a good grade  but learn great life skills

Merril was by far the best professor I've had at RPI. He's so awesome that my class made a Facebook group for him.  "You just got Whitburned!"  One of the only classes where the whole class actually felt like a group and learned something.  Odd, I know, learning something from a class, but Merrill manages it perfectly.

As I'm going into my last semester of RPI, I can honestly say that Merrill has been my favorite and best professor I've had.  He's a bit scary at first but he truly cares about you succeeding and is incredibly supportive.  You can truly take what you've learned and use it for the rest of your life. Wish he taught more classes! Amazing person.

I took his class in my freshman year at RPI, and now--even as a second-semester Junior--I can safely say that Merrill is the best professor I have had at the Institute to date.  I felt like I grew as a person by taking his class.  He may seem tough at first, but if you put in the time to excel, his class will be an amazing experience.
Great Professor! Down to earth and hilarious. Grades extra hard in the beginning, but if you progressively work hard you should get an A in the class. But working hard is the key.

Simply the best professor at RPI.  Merrill challenges students to perform and makes class extremely enjoyable.  Though the class seems intimidating at first, hard work and determination pay off in the end.  Speech Communication with Merrill is the rare course that helps you develop as a person and not just gain experience in a particular subject.

Merrill is one of the best professors at RPI. Lessons you learn from him will help you immensely in the future. Don't be intimidated by him in the first few classes, he really is one of the most genuinely kind and caring professors on campus. He is also hilarious, but makes you work, he wants you to grow into a great communicator.
Merrill for President... Loved him... Loved the class

TAKE THIS COURSE! Merrill is the best prof I've had at RPI. Everyone in the class works to help ppl recognize areas that need work to make you a good speaker. Don't let his speech the 1st day scare you off.

The best professor at RPI hands down. The only class where I have actually developed as a person and not as a studying machine. You would be wasting four years at RPI if you did not take this class. This man is the type of professor your dream about. I definitely will miss this class :'(.

By far the best professor I have ever had, his charisma and humor creates an amazing atmosphere for students to interact in.  Learned wonderful life skills from his class.  I reccomend this class to anyone who enjoys learning and having fun while doing it.  Thanks Merrill!
He's hilarious! Made a class that could have been nerve-wracking really fun.
The Novel was one of the most enjoyable classes that I have ever taken!  Merrill is an incredible teacher, and you can learn a lot from him.  More of the professors at RPI should learn from him!

After having so much fun and learning so much in Speech Comm. I decided to take The Novel as well.  Without a doubt, the best teacher I have ever had.  He keeps the class engaged and has an incredible wit and sense of humor.  Take a class with him before you graduate!  Keep up the good work, Merrill
I learned so much from this man in the subject.  He made you work hard for your grade.  Kept the class always excited in what was happening.  Take his class if possible.

Merrill is one awesome teacher.  He's really organized and does a great job at understanding each and every person's problems with their speeches.  He's also very helpful, and has a great sense of humor.
Best lecturer I've ever had in the CS department. I would absolutely recommend taking any class with him if spots are opened.
Nice guy, great at explaining and breaking down concepts.  Go to class and do any quizzes or practice problems he puts on the board.  Listening in lecture will help you immensely on the exams

Best CS professor I've ever had. He is an amazing lecturer, take him if you have the chance, you won't regret it. However, exams were 100% of the final grade, which is quite scary if you are not good at exams, so be cautious if that is you.

Dr. Anshelevich is a phenomenal lecturer. His ability to break down concepts like dynamic programming in an understandable way (and reinforce these concepts on homework) has made this course one of the more valuable ones I've taken. Despite this, I feel that his tests were unfairly weighted, as even a few mistakes could cost you your entire grade.

Great lecturer, you can literally feel his enthusiasm for the subject in every lecture he gives, and is super willing to answer questions or confusions. Personally not a fan of the grading criteria (35% midterm, 45% final, 20% HW), but I cant deny that the exams were very straightforward and reasonable. All in all, he'll make you appreciate algo.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Best CS professor at RPI. Explains very important material as simply as possible, and provides students with the exact amount of resources needed to succeed - not too little, not too much. His grading and tests are very straightforward, and actually verify that you learned stuff (he doesn't focus on the nitty gritty).

A fantastic lecturer, mostly thanks to his visual style of teaching and his knack for walking through example problems. There's a reason Anshie packed the house for every single one of his lectures (very rare for CS). If I could have him for all of my CS classes, I would.

Lectures were awful. I feel bad for the guy: he obviously is deeply passionate but he frequently went on long, irrelevant tangents. It was easier to read the textbook and skip the lectures. Additionally, our grade was determined by 20 questions: 6 questions on test 1, 6 on test 2, and 8 questions on the final. Homework grade did not factor. Brutal.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment:
Fantastic lecturer. Explains concepts clearly and concisely. Always gives problem examples. Straightforward homeworks that don't break the bank. Exams can have some questionable problems, but are mostly fair.
Feels like I learn a lot from him, and am assessed based off of what I've learned.
Amazing professor. Very clear in lecture and you can tell he really loves the material. He's classes are tough but very rewarding.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Anshie is a great professor, and an amazing lecturer. His courses aren't easy, but if you go to lecture and pay attention he's amazing. He has ample office hours, and is always willing to spend extra time to help a student understand. He has different approaches to areas the textbook doesn't explain well to help people learn in different ways.

Anshie was the best lecturer I've taken at RPI. His lectures were incredibly effective and taught me all the material effectively. He's also a genuinely good guy. The class was not easy, but Anshie prepares you well to succeed.

An amazing professor for Algorithms at RPI. Explains tough concepts in an easy way to understand. His office hours are very helpful. One of the best lecturers I've met. Tests were as difficult as the homework given to us, and are fair. Grading is brutal. Would especially recommend to visual learners. Am excited to take his other algorithms course.

Professor Anshelevich is amazing. He is great at explaining difficult and often abstract concepts in easy to grok ways. He is extremely knowledgeable about the course domain and he imparts numerous insights into every lecture. In CSCI 4020, the class was graded heavily on tests with weekly "partner" homeworks from the textbook problems.

Amazing professor. You'll absolutely learn a lot if you follow him closely during class. Be aware that the tests he gave are very hard(at least for me, lol). The average for the first test i took was like 60.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: I took Elliot's class for Intro Algo and he was the best lecturer that I've had. It would be a lie to say that his class is easy, but tests are similar to homework and by no means unfair. They test the how well you can apply the algorithms rather than your ability to regurgitate lines of code, which can be hard if you don't understand concepts.

While Elliot is not the worst professor I've ever had, he is certainly among the worst. He does not give back tests, cannot explain concepts for his life, and when you don't get something, he practically makes fun of you. He curved the class heavily, but still, I feel robbed of my education. I could've learned so much more.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: It was an absolute pleasure to attend Anshelevich's lectures. Algorithms is a tough concept to understand and he explained it amazingly. His tests were extremely difficult and I had to work hard for a B-, but the knowledge I attained from this class is priceless. I wish the 5 point rule did not exist, but still I have the utmost respect for Elliot.
There is no partial credit challenging on exams, and the rule that homework where most of the time is spent can not help you by more than 5 points is frustrating.

He is a fantastic lecturer, and really knows his stuff about algorithms. He's one of the few Algo professors I've had who really did a fantastic job explaining new concepts. His homeworks are short, but tests mean a lot. Really prepare for those and you'll do fine.
Does not have Office Hours so any questions must be answered by TAs during lab with 40 others. Also makes tests significantly harder than what is done in class and in homework.
rating_tags: Respected--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Be aware that his tests are much harder than back tests.

Amazing Professor. So inspiring and knowledgable. Tests are hard, and if you f-up 1 test you are pretty screwed since it weights so much, but you'll absolutely learn a lot from his lecture. Hope all professors from RPI cs department could learn from this professor about how to actually give a lecture instead of just reading lecture notes.
rating_tags: Respected--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: The best teacher I met in RPI. Really smart, knowledgable and well prepared for the classes. He explained difficult concepts and algorithms in a way that's very easy to understand.

I always wondered how this guy had such a high rating on RMP despite teaching a non-trivial course. Now I know.  He makes you engage with the material. He won't teach you Algorithms, he will teach you how to think about Algorithms.  Complaints: The grading TA wrote nonsense in his grading comments. The solutions provided for HWs are terrible.

He is a great lecturer and is very clear and easy to understand. I would highly recommend Prof. Anshelevich for any course. He makes conceptually difficult concepts easy to understand ie dynamic programming.

This is literally the best CS course  I have taken. 4020/6210  are the same. The professor is very knowledgeable and well-prepared. The tests and homeworks are very well-designed and not easy. But the effort is worth it.
Great teacher. He's really enthusiastic about the material. He definitely talks fast, so you have to be awake in order to follow what's going on, but that usually isn't a problem.
Wonderful lecturer.
he is a great teacher!
He's a nice person. I took all the courses he taught and get A in every course. If u can get used to learn everything by yourself, he's a great Prof for u. BTW, he's the only Prof who teaches CHD.
Smart man, still a terrible class and so disorganized. Avoid.
Terrible Prof!!

I had him for both Computer Hardware Design and Advanced Computer hardware design. His course is very out of date so his lectures are useless but I liked the course. He rambles through lectures and there is almost nothing worth writing down.

He knows his stuff. The course itself requires many skills to be successful. You need to think beyond what he writes down or says. It is not suppose to be an easy course. It should require you to ponder in deep thought. He is fair.

Definitely agree with all other raters...AVOID HIM AT ALL COST... but in fact he's the only one who teaches the computer hardware design and advanced computer hardware design. He will NOT hand out notes and he will just go through a little bit of things you will need in class. The other stuffs you will have to look it up online.
Extra hard grading policy, no help where it was really needed.

Besides the fact that he is old, mumbles a lot, scribbles at times, and chuckles to himself all the time... his notes start nowehere and go nowehere, his homeworks make no sense, and I'm in week 14 out of 15 and we're having our first test.  Washed up.

Abysmal.  4 weeks into class and we've only learned some equations which were learned in prerequisite classes.  Misses class regularly for research, leaving the TA to do software tutorials.  No class notes provided, no website, no course schedule, no direction to the class.  He takes material you've already learned and makes it seem impossible.

TERRIBLE PROFESSOR.  AVOID HIM AT ALL COSTS, HE IS EXTREMELY CONCEITED AND LOVES TO HEAR HIMSELF TALK.  YOU WON'T LEARN ANYTHING.  HE SHOULD BE FIRED BUT IS STILL AROUND BECAUSE HE GOT HIS TENURE YEARS AGO.

He is not very helpful when I went to him numerous times about the course work. The were only a couple of homework assignments, a midterm, and 2 projects. The homework was straight forward from the class notes. The projects took a huge amount of time but mainly due to the learning curve of the software package. Plan to spend many hours in the lab.

Prof. McDonald's lecutres are torture...it's the worst punishment ever. This man has NO communication skills..absolute worst class you could ever take...I have not learned one thing from this man...i'd rather have my eyelide hairs pulled out ONE BY ONE than sit thru another one of his lectures.
most egoistic a prf can get

CHD is definitely one of my favorite classes here.. McDonald seems to get negative ratings, but he is one of my favorite professors here.  CHD was not difficult, especially with no tests and class material only being an add-on to the labs.  Labs are time consuming but so is the average class here...
I thought he was great.  Oh well.

This guy is the absolute worst professor i've had in my undergrad studies. All he talks about is how he his research is doing this and that and blah blah but never teaches about the course. A rock could teach better then him. Visit him during office hrs.

He gets a bad rap unfortunately because he's conservative and old-fashioned.  His knowledge and teaching is spot on, and mixes hands on projects with classroom lecture.  A++++ if you get a chance take CHD and ACHD with him.
Warning: Beware of McDonald
Ruin my senior year!
Computer Illiterate
Ruined my entire senior year and my capstone.  AVOID AVOID AVOID!!!
No Comments
No Comments
rambles all the time about stupid side stories more than he actually teaches (which he does pretty poorly)
No Comments
does not answer email
totally incoherent, clueless
No Comments
Doesn't teach, unorganized, may as well not be there. AVOID HIM.
Took Data structures under him at UNCC. Assignments, quiz, homeworks and projects were challenging. Definitely recommend to take his course to learn in depth.
very well taught, as is every other class I have ever taken from him, (about 4-5 now)  interesting course, hard if you dont have the background for it
He always pronounces the letter "h" as "hedge."
Very helpful and open to questions.
Covers material well.  He's boring, but its DSA.  Good prof overall.
He's a horrible teacher. He skips over important material and has the worst course organization ever.
decent guy
Very nice prof!
Can be tought at times, but he really knows his material very well.  This is the second course I've taken with him and might take another if I could
Excellent Professor
DSA is a crazy hard course, but he is a great prof.
Somewhat hard class, but good teacher.
He's the man
Doesn't understand that the overhead he is showing is actually striaght so he moves it EVERY 20 secs.  Good guy
Just keep in mind that "hedge" is "H" and you'll be fine. He seems a little off at first, but he really is a fantastic teacher who cares about his students.
Doesn't know anything
Lectures waver between boring and somewhat interesting. Good professor, though, easy to learn from.
All I have to say is that I managed to get a B ... just barely. So he must have done something right.
No Comments
Really nice guy that knows how to teach.  Explains difficult concepts such as sorting algorithms very clearly.  Tests hard, though curves generous.  Overall, a great DSA prof.
This guy is a great prof.  Though, he pronounces the letter  H  a bit funny  =D
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
excellent prof.
Roger is a real nice guy but I didn't get a whole lot of out of this class. May be the easiest college course I have ever taken
I like Roger

Roger is the kind of professor who really cares about the well-being and progress of his students.  While his assignments, even in the HCI capstone, were pretty straightforward, the course was a decent amount of work and well organized.  Talk with him outside of class and he'll become a good friend and mentor.
Awesome dude.  very easy no matter what class you take with him.
Great professor. Very laid back will allow excuses not to have class. Not heavy work intensive, just keep up with work and you'll get a good grade. Try to get him as a professor.
Take whatever you can with him. Most laidback professor, comes up with excuses to not have class (its too hot, the hockey team won, etc.) Do the 5 projects (that aren't difficult) and the A is yours.
good sense of humor, very easy on grading. do the assignments and u'll be more than fine
very easy grader... cool/fun teacher.. understands students
His lectures bored me to death, but he allowed AIM in class so it wasnt so bad. You didnt need to pay attention to do well, just keep up with the assignments.

I had Grice for Writing to the WWW, but I knew who he was before I took the course.  He's a great guy with good sense of humor.  His classes are always fun and that makes them a lot easier.  Great professor and an asset to the school.

Great teacher.  Funny, energetic, creative and a good teacher.  He may be easier than some teachers, but who cares?  As long as you learn the material, you're getting what you paid for.  And with this guy, you have fun in the process.
Very Approachable outside of class, made a subject I thought was dull very interesting and fun
No Comments
Its a grice class

This is a good interductory class into the area of Human Computer Interaction.  The teachers is also very easy.  I recieve a 100% in the class.  The only problem with the class is that is has a lot of animations that do not stream well over the Internet to the distance students.
Roger is the best professor ever.  Bring him a Diet Pepsi and win an A.
Roger is as easy as he is friendly.  He is a great guy, and although his classes are not the most extensive at RPI, you do learn something.
Roger is the best professor at this school by far.  He also loves hockey and coming up to his fraternity house to hang out afterwards.
ROGER is the man!
This professor is one of the elite at RPI.  Other professors should be honored to hold his coffee cup (just to sip from it once)!    ROGER IS THE BEST!!!!!!

roger's class is certainly easy; almost impossible _not_ to get an A.  however, the material he presents is not exceptional if you're truly interested in human-computer interaction.  that you're supposed to read norman's 'design of everyday things' is it.
a distance class that you could 'attend' anywhere I went to as many of Roger's Lectures as I could.
Simply the best professor at the school hands down.  Not only helped me in school, but helped me get the job I have today.
