Took his Ethics course to fulfill my obligation to humanities.  He rewards cohesive arguments and well-discussed material EVEN IF you disagree with him.  He's interested in training your thought processes, your logical presentation and firm bases for discussion.  For the STEM heavy population of RPI, this is a paradigm shifting class.

Class material is interesting and will make you think, but the grading scheme is awful. As others said, he admits upfront that he grades on length because "it's the only real way he can tell you're trying." Very much the opposite of the way I was taught to write. Not very responsive with grades and how to improve papers either.

Had him for Moral Development. Class was all over the place, and the grade in the class is determined on two 20 page essays, in which your grade is really subjectively defined. The lecture was tedious because of its sporadic nature, and his gimmicks to appear "different" are obtrusive to learning. Take a 4000 Psych instead, it'll be easier.

Prof. Puka is a thoughtful man who really cares about what he teaches. I have taken classes by him for two years, and he certainly provides interesting ideas. His classes will change your viewpoints and life, if you let them. I would HIGHLY suggest taking his Ethics or Anarchy classes. (Note: There is a lot of reading.)
One of the best professor I have ever met. He makes the subject crystal clear with a lot of humorous stories. And he's a very nice person.

Think 'personal growth'. His classes aren't to 'teach' and the grades are a necessary annoyance. I rarely read or took notes (though I wish I had), and sometimes I daydreamed during class; yet I consider them the most important I have taken. The papers weren't fluff, but opportunities to debate my own morality. In no small way, they changed my life

Only take his courses if you know how to fluff a paper. His grades are mainly based on participation in class and how long of a paper you can write. So basically his grades are based on quantity, not quality (took this course w/ a friend and turned in the same paper, except one was fluffed a few pages, longer got the higher grade)

Along with Zenzen, the best professor that I've had at RPI.  Extremely intelligent and passionate about what he is teaching.  You'll learn alot, not only about philosophy, but about life in general.  The only reason you wouldn't want to take his classes is if you're easily offended or hold unreasonable beliefs.
He is one of the most brilliant professors Ive ever had the privilege to learn from. He is a truly good person, and a very good teacher.

He is definitely one of my favorite professors.  He will explain something from 3 different perspectives.  I second a previous reviewer's comments on his compassion.  If you take a Psych class, make it one of his.  Let me rephrase:  take Bill's Psych class!

Great class. The class periods are very entertaining and often he drops nuggets of information useful in interacting with the world (not just the field).  Often people confuse his examples with pushing an opinion. They then argue the point as wrong and get frustrated - if you can't understand metaphorical and hypothetical speaking, you'll struggle.
Puka is the man! By far the best class I have ever taken!
He has a lot of ideas however he refuses to listen to the classes points of view, interesting lectures if you don't happen to dissagree for the moment.
He is the best teacher at RPI, and made my 4 years bearable.
One of the best professors at RPI. This was one of the few courses I enjoyed at RPI.  Highly recommended.  The man is awesome!

A great philosophy professor.  He has an excellent rapport with the class and his lectures are entertaining and funny.  You have a lot of freedom in the class (we were free to make any syllabus we wanted).
Very good, funny, and entertaining. He doesn't assign much work but attendence is mandatory--the lectures are good enough to go anyway.
Take any class Puka teaches. He'll work with you, he's entertaining, and by far one of the smartest men on campus.

Awesome! Best professor I've had at RPI. He assigns a reasonable number of papers of reasonable length and lets you have a lot of freedom. His lectures are more like a cool talk show than lectures! Lots of reading assigned but if you miss some you're ok.
Really interesting professor.  Also one of the most compssionate people I've met.
Awesome professor, illustrates every concept eloquently and extremely clearly.  I recommend his Ethics class to anyone.
No Comments
Puka roxorz

You would ask him a question on webex and he either wouldn't answer or answer in the most convoluted way possible. He also has a habit of randomly calling on students with a varying range of questions, he would ask questions that was like "what is the density of water" to "explain why pumps matter." also the harshest grader I have ever had

Dr. Letchford is kind, but the way class was taught wasn't the best. Our final grades revealed for this semester were lower than we expected as he never told us how we did on our final exams. He also made all HW and exams, but used no textbook. I do feel that his lectures with asking us questions on the spot made me more confident in the material.

His class is tough but if you put in the work, you'll understand the material. After the final, grades were posted without exam scores, and our grades were much lower than expected, straying from the syllabus. Extra credit seemed ineffective and his explanations were snarky and left the class confused about how are grades were actually calculated.

It's been about 4 days, and he still hasn't released the grades for the final test, despite having posted the final grades for the class as a whole. The homework and tests were written solely by him, which means that sometimes there will be no definitive answer. He is very accommodating during office hours, but outside of that, he's not the best.

Last minute removed a policy written in the syllabus that drops our lowest homework grade because, in his opinion, it probably would not make any difference for anyone. Unfair. Why have the policy in the first place if this were true? Refused to post our final exam grades final grades. He is the dean of CEE and seems to be abusing that power.

Prof. Letchford's entire class and coursework were very disorganized, and at many points he contradicted himself in regards to homework's, labs, and grading. The instructions for the labs were very unclear, and therefore nearly impossible to do well on. He also refused to publish our final exam grades, even after many students requested him to.

Dr. Letchford sets you up to fail. Lectures are okay, but he offers almost no study materials for exams, and he grades too harshly without any helpful feedback. Easy to reach out to on Webex but won't answer simple questions, and is quite snarky. Refusal to release Final Exam grades is completely unacceptable. Completely unprofessional.

Letchford's teaching is a failure. He has incomprehensible lecture notes and exam material that doesn't match the content covered in class; his grading is excessively harsh, making success nearly impossible, and his refusal to release our final exam grades shows a lack of accountability. He should be removed from his position.
This class was the reason I changed to business

Unreasonably harsh,unfair. Tests= understand physics in the scope of fluids so if u aren't strong physics, math be prepared to get screwed. thought he was nice but a harsh professor tilhe refused to accept my revision bcusI mistakenly submitted the template first. dissapointed bcus I had liked him. Doesnt care for students. Don't take if possible.

As a person, he is very nice and caring. As a professor, he is very tough and leaves you confused. Do not miss lecture! The only way to "study" for exams are the very difficult homework questions that are tough enough on their own. Active Webex, yet is sometimes helpful. Generous office hours. Lab reports will take you several hours. Good luck!

You think you know what you're doing, until you get to the exam. Exam review and homework do not prepare you at all for the exam. I went to office hours every week and somehow almost failed the first exam. The average was a 54 and there was no curve. Be prepared to be confused. Picks favorites and is not helpful. Doesn't care about your grades.

Used back exams to get thru the class. bad lectures and there are A LOT of reports (labs or group projects). Expect to not have a social life this semester as 3-4 assignments are due Sundays and Tuesdays.
do not use textbooks and grade tough, but fun classes and you can learn stuff
Teaching style doesnt work at all.
exam are 65% worth of the class. dident use the book at all
he mentions the textbook in the syllabus but never used really, nice guy but tougher grader
goes up note which very hard to follow, TA for the class dont help at all
very hard tests
Letchford is a beast super nice guy his class is just super hard
tough grader, nice guy but class is too hard

Nice person, but one of the worst professors I have had. He was an insanely tough grader and I did not learn well from his teaching style. He has a bad habit of calling people out and putting them on the spot every 5 seconds.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Personally, his teaching style doesn't work for me. He doesn't post notes online so you have to write down everything in class, but it might not make sense by the time you have time to actually go over it. Also, he mentions a textbook in the syllabus, but it doesn't really makes sense with the way he teaches. REALLY TOUGH GRADER
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: Had him for Intro to Structures, great guy and good professor.  He moves very quickly and he's tough, you need to work very hard in order to get an A.  If you need help, he's there.
great professor

Had him for both Intro to Structural and the Hydraulics portion of Hydrology/Hydraulics. Excellent Professor! I rate him one of the best at RPI. Super hard tests. Hard grader on HW too. Class moves quickly so pay attention.

Letchford's a good professor and all, but he randomly calls on people for answers in lecture. That probably doesn't bother most people, but it scares the daylights out of me. The tests are hard too, by the way.

Great lecturer, very clear to understand.  Likes to randomly ask people questions during lecture, and tries to get to know everyone individually.  Tests are incredibly difficult, the average for ours was 60%.  Not very helpful at office hours, and the lack of textbook makes figuring out problems difficult.
Awesome professor.  Makes you pay attention by asking random students questions during class, so you actually learn stuff.  Hard tests, but only one of them. He also has a cool accent.

The grades are never curved. He rarely uses the textbook. And he is not the best at explaining concepts. He also has some aversion to using numbers. How do you possibly give examples of problems based solely in math and not give numbers? Oh, and he grades up, not down, so test scores will be way lower than expected.

Very good at going through examples and showing how the math is done. My only complaint is with the course, as it is very theory and definition heavy (as to be expected in a higher level math course). I advise doing the homework (even though it is optional) to get a better hang on recognizing what the problems ask for.

She seems like a very experienced lecturer/teacher, but she isn't very good at providing a conceptual understanding of what certain concepts actually mean.

She's also a strict grader and gives no opportunity for extra credit. A good class should not be based entirely off tests and quizzes, but that's what she did. Her tests are also way too long.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Her exams are kind of unexpectedly difficult, but her lectures are super clear and concise, and have super readable notes. She kinda grades super hard and doesn't make any exceptions for anyone, so I wouldn't recommend taking her classes if you have a lot of stuff going on.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: She gives little time for long exams and only grades on that and quizzes. She drops 2 quizzes which is nice, and no final, but 4 exams total. No homework. Use the TA's during recitation to ask questions. They answer better.

Brown is a decent lecturer, her examples and explanations make sense in class, but she goes a bit fast. The grading is a little tough, her tests are extremely hard, was lectures 1-7 but almost 60-65% was only on lecture 7 topics. The exam was ~10 T/F, 1 select all, and 5 written questions with multiple parts, and she only gave 1 hr and 10 min
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: lectures are helpful but you need to take a decent amount time outside of the class to really understand the topics. The final is optional, there were weekly quizzes during recitation and mandatory two exams, one covering all of multivariable calc and the other matrix algebra.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: I thought the lecture slides were really helpful along with examples although sometimes she went through big concepts very quickly. You definitely need to take some time on your own to understand the concepts. If you go to class actually pay attention because Brown will call you out if you aren't.

This class was pretty easy if you understand Calc I concepts. The lectures were a bit boring as she went through a lot of examples slowly, but in the long run that was helpful in understanding the material. I thought the tests were challenging but nothing unexpected.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Great lecturer and recitation quizzes are fine but for exams she uploads a practice sheet but doesn't post the answer key nor makes it a complete list of what is on exam, I don't like how deceiving that is. Heard from others that she can also be passive-aggressive though I haven't seen that.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Good lectures, and I genuinely feel like I'm coming away understanding the material. Homework says optional in the syllabus. It is not. DO THE HOMEWORK!! The one exam I skipped a few of the homeworks I did poorly on. Grades are all exams/quizzes, which can be rough, but she's fair/generous with partial credit.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Extremely clear in the expectations of the course. Exams are very fair and taken straight from the homework. Lectures are to the point and she manages to make very difficult topics understandable. I wish all the professors were as good of lecturers as her.

Dr. Brown is amazing!! No idea why she has low ratings. She's very caring, her explanations are thorough and she provides great examples. She prepares you well for tests/quizzes. Hw wasn't mandatory, but I would recommend doing it because it's good practice + she takes quiz problems from it. Highly recommend Dr. Brown

I highly recommend going to lecture and taking notes (at least filling in her notes sheet), the way she explains things is helpful. The exams are easy as long as you did all the homework since the test questions are the same/sometimes easier hw questions. There weren't any study guides/back exams , however redoing the hw problems is sufficient.

She has the best lectures I've ever taken -- so much so that I'm willing to overlook how unfair the tests feel. If you can get excited for the material and truly want to learn: take the class. If you're just in it for the grade or for the grad requirement: it might be worth it to you to find an easier professor for the class.
Great professor. Uses clear notes and language to teach topics.
this teacher takes horrible notes, you basically need to go in-person .
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: I think she is a very good professor. The content taught in class is easy to understand. The test results will be curved.(Generally, if you get 4 out of 6 multiple choice or "true or false" questions correct, you will get a perfect score) If you study hard before the test, you will get a good grade.

Good lecturer overall, very clear and concise. Assigns lots of "optional" homework that you are quizzed on during recitation. Exams were very similar to homework, but the time given to complete them makes them challenging (i.e. 20+ problems in 70 minutes). Willing to give partial credit.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Took Calculus II with Professor Brown. Would not recommend to people who are not proficient in calc. The grading system is different than the other calculus 2 teachers, such as quizzes being worth more, and just a lot more stricter in certain aspects. It's also very rare that students finish their exams, which are worth a lot of your grade

The notes are really clear and helpful, but the course is too test heavy. 70% is based on exams, and the 30% is based on quizzes. TA sometimes only gives 10 minutes to complete 2 very work extensive problems for the quizzes.

Took for Calc 2 but couldn't put it under that category. Her exams are ridiculously long and tough. Half the people don't even finish the exam. Class is very exam heavy, about 75% of your entire grade, wouldn't take her unless you understand calc very well and can do it really fast
Lectures are extremely slow and boring, but necessary to understand content. Would be better served if recorded and watched at x2 speed.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: I took multivar and I dropped. Test is difficult only because no crib sheet is allowed (Other professors might allow crib sheet). I can't memorize all formulas so I dropped. But she definitely have the best lecture notes and she post all lecture notes

Horrible teacher. Avoid if possible. She does not know her stuff. At the end of the semester, she said to our class that we most likely know more about strengths than she does by the time we finish the class. W/o her solutions manual she might fail the class herself!!!

In all honesty, professor Schadler is the worst teacher I have had at RPI. The only difference between herself and her students is that she has the solutions manual. She can't help with hw problems without the solutions manual and she often gets stuck and class and says "I don't understand what the solutions manual did here." Avoid this teacher.
One of the worst teachers I have ever had. Can't do anything without her notes and useless about answer a question. Usually talks to you like you're an idiot.
Helpless with out her notes, and still not very helpful with them.  Left out key concepts for the common final and some of her own tests.  barely taught singularity functions
The class average on tests was consitantly 15 to 20 points lower than the other sections.  The final curve was more than a letter grade because of it.

Class can best be summed up by her quote, "You won't learn it, but it's on the final." Consistently didn't know material. Couldn't solve questions in class without her notes. Tests were on information she couldn't cover in class. Great TA, but you'd have to have one to make it through such a mess. Probably one of the worst classes I've ever had.
Mediocre at best, never clear on what would be on the exams, and frequently would have questions we'd never even covered - sort of helpful, but too scary to be approachable.

Totally reminded me of Chewbacca, and definitely the worst teacher I've encounted yet (but at least she spoke english). Totally intimidating, unclear about what was expected and/or on quizzes, and totally unhelpful when trying to get extra help. Avoid!
Easily the best Materials Science professor. Very clear lectures, and extremely helpful. Some quizzes can be fairly difficult.
Very helpful, clear, and is also an effective speaker. Take her if you can!
I don't see why she has such good ratings...she isn't that great.  Frequently confused about material and if it's not in her notes she doesn't know it.  She's not bad, but she's certainly not good.
Okay Teacher

She is one of the best teachers that I've had. Her notes are very helpful, she gives practical and useful examples.  Her tests are fair but tough she teaches you everything on them but she makes you earn your grade.
very friendly one of the few teacher that actaully care about their sudents, A+++++
awesome teacher. she's the best materials teacher you can get. her quizzes are hard, but it means you'll do better on the final
Shows an interest in students and comes prepared to class.  Always has a very organized and straight forward lecture ready.
She's a really good teacher and tries to make this subject easy to understand.   She really understands her stuff.
Knows what she's doing.  Fully understand the lectures she gives.  Prepares you well for cumulative exams (which she does not make).
Dedicated to reaching out to students
Great professor
Excellent professor.
Straightfoward prof, pretty easy compared to others... you learn what you need to know and thats it.  definitely decent

He seems like a great man throughout the semester just with the fact that he was not care about my project. In the end he gave bad grades which I never get from any other professors. Worst is that he never tells why :(

I first interacted with him in IDS. I wasn't the best in his studio, but I genuinely appreciate the way he teaches. His Tai-Chi desk crits are so effective that all I learned became unforgettable. His own works are infused with the air of avant-garde, and he's way more open-minded than most faculty members in this school. He deserves a lot of love.

Indeed, ‘overly confident in his own knowledge and intelligence’, but then again, he is an architect. Ted tends to use his experience to teach his us. Very helpful…will stay as late as possible to help you during desk crits. Gives freedom and insightful feedback, only if you work hard and seriously towards developing your idea.

He seemed overly confident in his own knowledge and intelligence to the point of a limiting cynicism that precluded other valuable pov and led to critical errors in assessment. Brilliant people remain open minded and curious, enjoy seeing things from different perspectives. Ted lacked any of that. Also plays unnecessary games that were concerning.

Ted is best for intrinsically motivated students. Pursue what you're interested in, and he'll be intrigued by your interest. He lets lazy and/or unsure students fall by the wayside. He would be great to talk about architecture with over a cup of coffee, but as his student I was often left frustrated and wanting actual guidance.

Cool guy, awful professor. Not present for about 1/4 of classes. Very unclear. Like the Cheshire cat. Seems to speak in riddles. Very good trait for, like, the equivocating narrator of some Shakespearean play. NOT for a professor.

Be clear about one thing: Ted will not issue any clear formula for "good design." He will offer insight/criticism (and some tangential anecdotes) to help you find yourself as a designer.  Don't aim to please him - first pursue what interests you. If he senses you're wrestling with issues and engaged, you'll be fine. Great guy - take his seminar!

Ted is a genius, he really is...the bad comments left on this board a probably from incompetent design students who expect professors to hold their hands and baby them through everything. For many of you that do not know, Ted has taught all over the world including some very now famous architects.
Ted doesn't lie or pretend -- that makes him worthwhile in my book.  His perennial question "why is that a good idea" is an honest one. Helps you get over your bad self, if you take it seriously.
he is an extremely knowledgeable professor. There are few like him at rpi. however he may not be the best for 1st - 2nd year studios. Really great guy if u get to know him.

Not helpful in a Studio Environment!!! Never once got a straight answer from him. Great guy to talk to but not a professor. I can deal with criticism and even pushing myself to produce better work but "you need to start over if you can't make this work" after a month of developing as the second desk-crit that i got from him just made me furious.

Seems like a great guy when he's your teacher... then it comes time for your grade.  He'll sneeak up on you and nail you with your grade out of nowhere.  It's not too pleasant.  Also not a very clear guy in what he's looking for; kind of indifferent towards whatever you're doing, and then he'll just agree with whatever your critics say in review.

Ted was one my best teachers.  He always finds a way of understanding your research and giving you a world of possibilities.  It's too bad that arch undergrads are not ready for criticism and give him such bad reviews.  They're not ready for the real world.
Good criticisim if it interests him.  It your idea isn't his cup of tea you get pretty much nothing. Not much help to those who are unsure.  Great juror.  Not so good teacher. Good guy though.
completly unhelpful, very arrogant
sarcastic; disinterested (often absent from studio); unapproachable; antagonistic at reviews.  bitter that he has to teach at all and can't just follow his research whims.

Ted is wasted on the undergrads. He can come across as being snooty but is approachable. His book "Mosquitoes" is a refreshing satire on architecture and I reccomend everyone to read it if they are to learn more about Ted. As for his behaviour at reviews, I do think some students need their feathers ruffeled as the school is a little too polite.
so inappropriate, he is surely headed for a lawsuit or dismissal.

Clearly, Ted has contributed to this website (see last comment) since I can't think of any student who would actually say that. Definitely a victim of the "failed architect lashing out on students for fun". Doesn't understand the concept of constructive criticism. Really, he should be ashamed of himself.
No Comments

laid back easy going prof. casual teaching style. Be careful the "open end" project could be a trap. He won't push you. If you are self-motivated person, take his class to broaden your idea about architecture and design.
Ted is God...

Prof Shahsavari was pretty accessible during the MSL in-class lab but whenever my team asked a question, he often responded pretty vaguely and didn't really help identify the problem. However, he kept the class timely and we always finished on time.
He never responded to any of my emails and when I went to ask for help he had me rewatch all the lecture videos and didn't even answer my question.
Great teacher, The Mechanics 1-2 Pilot course is great. While attendance isn't mandatory you should show up to learn properly.

I had him as a professor for Strengths, EMD, &IFE. He really cares about teaching the material and puts a lot of effort into the notes he makes. They are color-coded and wonderfully organized so you have great material outside of class to review. He makes an effort to thoroughly answer questions that students ask in class and outside. Recommend.

One of the best engineering professors at RPI.  Very professional and does not waste time.  He's very clearly aware of the average student's understanding, so he doesn't make the content any harder that it has to be.  Lectures are very well-prepared.  Everything he shows in class is posted on LMS, so you don't really have to take notes in class.
Exams were open textbook so a physical copy of the textbook is necessary. Lectures were great and informative.
Shahsavari does really care about students. The course is difficult though, no matter who teaches. I'd recommend both Shahsavari and the course.

IEA is hard. Youtube helps but the prof really matters. So much better than Korolov he actually goes through each step and makes sure you know how to do a problem before throwing an ICA at you. Attendance is mandatory for ICAs but you can find them all online. Lots of homework but its the same for everyone. He actually cares.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Shahsivari is a caring professor. If needed, he will give you extra time on assignments, but is still strict when it comes to deadlines: late work is always a zero. The homework can some times be heavy, but it does prepare you for exams, with many exam questions coming from homework. It's easy to do well on exams but mess up homework grades.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Lecture heavy

comment: Uses the full lecture time. Every single minute. Strengths is a pretty hard class he did his best to make the material understandable. A lot of opportunities to save your grade if you do poorly on the exams. He always tries to answer questions.

This was the third class I've had with Shahsavari. He is a good teacher for the mechanical engineering courses but should stay away from the Aero courses. This course was quite difficult and I don't think he personally knew what was going on because the whole course followed Professor Rusak's structure from the previous year. Computer projects hard
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Tests are tough

comment: Will go out of his way to help you understand the topics and help you with the projects. Great professor, albeit dry. Make sure to study for the tests and use backtests and you'll be fine if you take him

Great professor, had him for Strengths then Aerospace Structures, and now Aeroelasticity. Get ready to do LOTS of MATLAB coding in HWs and two computational projects that had extra credit if you didn't do well on the exams. Exams are open laptop/book/notes. Really helpful in office hrs! Try to start work early, office gets packed near deadlines.

If you're not following the class I strongly recommend dropping the class early because the professor does not help failing students. I was sick for weeks and tried to catch up but the professor had a severe attitude problem. All he could say was "I covered this in class". Also, I was in his office hour and he consistently asked me if I was done.

Very boring lectures. This professor was not good at conveying material, only went to class because of in-class assignments. I learned everything better by watching videos online on my own. He also never ended early, but would instead spend the entire two hours going over two example problems that could have  been done in 30 mins. Do not recommend.

His lectures take FOREVER, but it's worth it. He goes through everything step by step, and while it is tedious, you will learn. He puts in extra hours if he thinks it's necessary and is available for office hours.

The tests are curved generously. Say the avg. is a 65% with a std of 15, then a score of 80% will get you an A. He does problems in lecture, there's no textbook, and the homework is procedural most of the time. Sometimes a specific homework problem can be challenging, but he's approachable for help.

Second time having Prof. Shahsavari. Lecture notes are useful but it is boring to watch him write everything out in class. Tests are difficult but everything was given a generous curve. He is concerned with student performance and encourages people to come to office hours, which I have found more useful than class itself.

Not particularly exciting, but he describes the material well if you can focus. He gives online homework you have to pay for, but it's helpful and you have unlimited attempts. The tests are difficult but not unexpected. He definitely cares about everyone. He's probably one of the better/best strengths prof. I'll take more classes with him if I can.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: I took Shahsavari for engineering dynamics.  The lectures are not mandatory, however the tests pull from the in class examples along with the optional homework.  If you do the examples in class along with the homework as well, you will get A's on the tests.  If you go to office hours and get to know him, he is helpful in more ways than one.

Strength of Materials is a tough class. Examples he presents are helpful studying for tests and doing hw. Has slight accent but doesn't adversely affect presentation. Very willing to help during office hours and is concerned with each student's performance. Would recommend.

Intro to Engineering is an easy class if you show up to lecture and pay even somewhat attention. He is pretty clear in explaining things, though FYI he does have an accent. Do the back tests and you'll be fine.

Hear me out- if he literally only lectured then his class would be great. He's just really not good at responding to emails and grading in a timely manner. For context, I took an exam mid-October and just got grades back 4 days ago. He's super frustrating at times but he really does know course material and if you can catch him in OH, he's great
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Worst professor at RPI. Had 4 tests, test 1 took 3 MONTHS to grade!! By the end of the semester had only gotten 2 out of 4 test grades back. Ridiculously slow grading and would be extremely snarky to students asking questions. Maybe he needs some more energy drinks in the morning.

Although he definitely knows the content, he is not a good person. He was very rude and arrogant towards the students and if someone was asking a question he would often just cut them off. Some of the exams did not reflect what we were learning in class at all. He doesn't respond to emails. He takes forever to grade exams... like 3 months.
Took 9 weeks during arch to grade our Exam 1. Completely unavailable outside classes. Doesn't respond to emails.

He's always so behind on his work and the pressure reflects on us especially when he forgets (consistently!) to post homework for the class for a week. Additionally, he did not grade our exams for over 9 weeks in a 12 week semester. Overall, avoid him as much as possible.

He's a terrible professor shows no respect to students nor other professors. He's always shows that he cares about us but at the same time it takes him 3 exams out of 4 to finally grad our 1st exam. If only there's another professor for this class, I would never want to take his class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: If he has a whiteboard and a classroom full of not mouthy students, he's pretty good. He is awful with emails and webex messages, so finding him somewhere in person is usually the way to go. GO TO OFFICE HOURS and talk in class as much as you can, even if you think you understand all the material. He had homework groups for us this sem, so beware.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Show up for attendance, there were a few lectures where he gave an optional question you could answer related to the lecture, and if you did it, then you got points back for an exam, one of my top 3 favorite professors at RPI
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Hilarious--Graded by few things

comment: Great professor and person. If you show interest or participate, he brightens up and is much more willing to help. He really helps and tries to answer questions when they come up and will use interesting analogies and applications to explain the concepts. Also great person to get to know outside of class as an advisor and mentor.

Prof. Woodcock is a very good lecturer, I would recommend attending as many of his lectures as possible. He is both entertaining and knowledgeable. He isn't consistent with assigning homework, so some weeks will have a lot more work required than other. He has also has been known to get annoyed at students and over-assign HW, so don't annoy him.

Woodcock is very generous & explaining professor to have for TP1, especially with him making it mandatory for us to do HWs in groups, which makes me less likely to struggle and understand more of the class. However, there will be times where he forgets to upload lectures, grade hws and exams (he curves exams) until the end of the semester.

Dr. Woodcock's course was unpredictable and difficult to follow. He would give out assignments and grades seemingly randomly and often seemed disinterested in lecture. Outside of lecture, he is helpful in person.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: All exams were take-home and curved and overall a great guy. Outside of class would teach you whatever you wanted to learn. Helped with Capstone projects after finished his class also.

He seemed to care about students but had a weird way of showing it. He would tear groups apart when they presented for it seemed like an unusually long time. His remarks were a little beyond constructive criticism. Nice guy to talk to outside of class. Terrified to present to him.

Despite Fluid Mechanics being cut down to 3 credits, Professor Woodcock tries to pad out his online lectures to make it feel like you're in a 4 credit. I always end up doing all my learning out of the textbook, which, for the first time, manages to teach the material MORE concisely than the professor.
great guy!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: Corey is a chill guy, but he seems like he doesn't care a lot of the time, and on occasion even makes students feel kind of dumb for asking questions. I think he just gives out grades based on what he feels like the student should get, because I assure you I did not do well enough on tests to earn a B+, but I guess he went easy on us due to COVID
Cares little about students and their work. Randomly gives out grade.

Solid professor. Very charismatic. Definitely seems like he wants the students to understand everything and do well. That said, he does try to make the tests somewhat on the harder side so that he can determine a proper scale so that you get a normal bell curve with an average around a 75 - 80
literally my favorite professor ever
Corey is nice and always available, but yet another test heavy class. The curves he gives are very generous but this is a class that you either get it or you don't. Good luck.

Dr. Woodcock is relatively new to teaching, but he received his bachelor's and PhD degrees at RPI, so he understands the student experience. He has an "open door policy". His lectures can be boring and seem very theoretical, but his examples are helpful. His grading is fair and exams are generally curved. Make a solid effort and you'll do well.

The best design teacher at RPI. I am so sorry that he is retiring. I took all his classes and I actually get real experiences from the industry and learn a lot from him. He provides me a good sense of how to prepare my portfolio and apply to graduate school.
The higher level classes Paul teaches are definitely more helpful. He also puts a lot of his field experience into his teaching. Really fun personality when he opens up.

Doesn't know his students at all, but that's not horrible. Doesn't know how to use a Mac.. but he's all into graphic design..? demonstrates the software ok, but is somewhat esoteric. Really helpful if you ask for help, though. He's fine, but I wouldn't have taken the class if I didn't have to. BUY THE BOOK: open book/note exams!
He does a good job teaching students how to use the Adobe Design suite and provides good feedback on projects. All around he is very cordial and will do his best to any student in need.

Paul is a super nice guy. He really cares about the students. Just put in effort into the class and you'll do well. Fun course. Sometimes it feels like theres lots of busywork but it is all really easy.
He shouldn't be teaching this class.
Miyamoto is the TRUTH!! He is so GANGSTA! Nah, for real, mad easy and light. All you really have to do is show that you tried.
Paul is not a bad professor.  His methods may be a little unusual, but they work.  If I put more effort into this class I could have easily gotten an A.

He is not a good professor, unless you are forced to take this class dont, i thought i was going to get useful knowledge. He doesn't know how to teach and changes his mind constantly and will not clarify anything. DO NOT take this class unless EMAC and forced too.

Paul is a really nice guy. He's very approachable, and takes great interest in the progress of his students. Although a lot of time and money are required for his Intro to Viz Comm course, it will prepare you for the more rigorous projects to come.  Just make sure you actually demonstrate your commitment to the class. Approach him, you know?

Miyamoto is a good guy.  He is helpful IF you approach him with well-thought-out questions.  Some bash him for being a bit "old school" but he runs a well-organized course and it goes at a nice pace, so you never feel rushed to churn out graphic design projects.
meh. not a wonderful class, but it could have been much much worse... and it is a little sad that the man can't use the programs...
i got sick of this class really fast. its such a ****.

He is an alright teacher however he requires almost $100 in supplys to be purchased for the class and changes his mind overnight about what is due for the next class. His late night emails are very confusing. He is helpful but if your work isnt hyper minimalist designs he will hate it.
He owns this class, but i believe he's getting sick of it.  But you really don't have a choice if you're an EMAC.
awesome class and great teacher... if you think he picks favorites then you must suck beyond belief
He is overall a very good teacher for those that want to learn about graphic arts
How a computer art teacher doesn't know how to use photoshop is well beyond me.
No Comments
No Comments
even though the class was really easy, he helped me learn a lot
Has Favorites
Very sweet professor, but can waste a lot of time in class, tend to be slow. Otherwise she is nice and sweet and very caring about you.

I have a mixed feeling with the way Professor Ruiz teaches GD game design. She is very nice
and cares about her students and their projects. However, the course is not about game design but about game culture (interesting though). We never get any grades and at the of the semester everyone, good or bad, gets an A. It's not motivating.
Best professor I'v ever had

I love Prof. Ruiz not only because she guides us to draw a "better view" of our games but also as she tries to help us on finding our real selves. What do I really enjoy making? What do I want to change? What will my ultimate goal be? She lets us think about all these things. Her strong and free spirit light me up during my darkest time at RPI.

Professor Ruiz is a studied and engaging professor with a unique worldview and philosophy regarding game design and media that pushes students to approach their art from creative and groundbreaking standpoints. She has also served as a great mentor, giving me feedback and guidance within the industry even post-graduation.

Kathleen is a great professor. Her class is one of those cases where you get out what you put in. I have taken several classes with her and the way she teaches allows you to do a lot of personal exploration. She gives a lot of great feedback and if you put work into the class she will take notice. Wish I could rate her higher than a 5.

She is one of the worest professor at RPI. She is nice person, but her lecture is a joke. You waste every 4 hours studio time to study everything yourself. Every student in her class will literally fall asleep. She doesn't know how to use tools professionally. She is also poor time management.

I have worked with Professor Ruiz twice on ambitious game projects. Each time, she has gone above and beyond to support us in our work. Programmers from Game Dev II need to realize that the shoe is on the other foot now- you are in the artists' world - but it can be a powerful learning experience to prepare you for professional game development.

Excellent course & professor.  Rate it highly!  No text - readings great as were assignments. Learned alternative game genres,and designed award-winning prototype for class.  I attended as a grad student.  Definitely worthwhile if you are interested in game studies.

She is a very personable professor and takes a deep interest in her students. I had her for exp. game design, and her views on game design differ from those of some of the other professors in the department. She tends care more about a game's story and intended cultural impact than its mechanics and gameplay. Overall, she is a good professor.

Professor Ruiz served on my dissertation committee. She didn't have to. She was extremely busy. But she believed in my project, and she added me to her already full plate. Her comments were clear, thoughtful, and incredibly helpful. Her encouragement never wavered. Professor Ruiz is amazing.

Professor Ruiz is a wonderful instructor. Her background in experimental game design is extensive and she offers real-world insights that are really useful. She is also really supportive of students' work and provides excellent guidance during the design process. I found her class to be both challenging and exciting - I highly recommend!

this is supposed to be a class in which we learn how to use photoshop and dreamweaver, yet Ruiz does not teach a damn thing about either. lectures are just a bunch of really loud youtube videos. the class requires you to teach every aspect of the course material to yourself. easy A if you can figure out how to use photoshop by yourself

Over the years Ruiz has seen teams in Experimental Game Design succeed or flop, and now tries to improve the odds that teams succeed. If you dismiss her as an outsider with no experience with game dev (wrong), you can expect to have a negative experience. Drop your ego trip and take the professor seriously, and you'll do well. And rightfully so.

She's a horrible teacher.  The two hour lecture is spent watching her click on links and play movies painfully loud.  It's painful when she starts to talk about science, since she has no idea what half the words mean, let alone  understand any of the concepts. Easy class but she's a flake and it drives you crazy

She lets a lot of guests teach class and is super flighty about class policies. She's very easily impressed if you can make complicated-sounding explanations of your work. Easy class, but her flighty-ness can make it unbearable.
Professor Ruiz has some great ideas, though they may be hard at first for students to grasp. Open your mind and honestly do your best, and you'll do well in her classes.

does not teach a thing. urges students who actually know something teach the class. has a very loose concept of what interesting art actually is. don't expect much. take an art class with her only if you are not interested in art.

When you see her art, you realize this is a textbook example of the skilled not being able to teach their skill.  Her comments were ambiguous.  "I think you should print that on the archival printer because that would make it much more exquisite.&quo

I am somewhat disappointed in Ruiz for not really understanding some of the graphical and coding work that goes into game design. I have seen so many of her students get her to believe they did more work than they actually did.
She seems to know what she's doing, so I trust her opinion. I took Experimental Game Design, and in that class she really expects a lot out of you.
Intelligent, helpful, enthusiastic
Amazing professor. Kind and always willing to help. Lecture heavy, but if you try hard, getting a A is not hard. 100% the best professor in RPI.

Amazing teacher, passionate about the subject. Lots of content so going to class and paying attention helps. If you do so you will succeed. Homework is easy, you get two tries and best grade is taken. 100% would take the class again.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Dr. Crone is great and so far my favorite professor at RPI! I took both 4620 and 4630 with her, got an A in both. It's lecture heavy, but homework in both classes are easy and interesting. 4620 is basic homework and exams, but in 4630 there is a fun group project and paper; exams also have take home components. Crone is super caring and friendly!

Worst class I've ever taken, and I've taken Data Structures. None of the questions on her homework or take home tests can be found on google, in the textbook, or in her lecture slides. The class consists of Crone's understanding of useless current events in Molec Bio. The necessary information can be found nowhere except in Crone's brain.

Homework is EASY. 10 mindless multiple choice after every lecture, and you get two attempts if you didn't get a 100 the first time. The tests should be no problem if you do your reading. The final is a joke. 100 multiple choice from old homework and tests, and it replaces your lowest test grade.

Covers a lot of topics very quickly without any particular order. The class could be restructured to flow better and focus on the big picture rather than memorizing protein names and specific bits of information.

Cell and Dev lab is a straight forward class, but if you do not put in the hours or pay attention to what she says, you will be lost in the class. She clarifies anything you have a problem with and ALWAYS willing to help students. She's helped me immensely in the course, giving me a B was more than generous. Very understanding and nice to talk to!

Dr. Crone is a lovely person!  Although she does recite off the ppts, the exams are mostly based off the slides.  She may become angry sometimes but only when justified.  She dislikes it when people ask unnecessary difficult questions.  She also strongly dislikes it when people with grades already in the A range try to get points back on exams.

Crone is a horrible teacher. She basically recites her powerpoints in class and if you ask her any questions she yells at you. Don't bother going to office hours, she only complains about how much other work she has and does not do her job as a professor.

Donna Crone is a lovely person and a great teacher. She teaches through PowerPoints, which constitute most of the exam material. Course is 80% tests and 20% homework. Many of the homework answers come directly from the book, so it is beneficial to read it. She is willing to answer any questions and is great if you go to office hours.

Dr. Crone knows who is trying and it matters to her. She is also great one on one. I failed the first exam, went and talked to her. We worked out a better time for me to take the next exam and my grade pulled a 180. She is not the easiest woman to follow in lecture but she's very approachable and will help you if you ask.

Dr. Crone is an excellent professor. Some students didn't like her because she often had to yell at the class for talking over her at the beginning of class which shouldn't be happening anyways. I always found her to be very pleasant and helpful. The homework is relatively easy and the exams are even easier if you look at back tests. Great class.

Dr. Crone is an excellent professor. The homework was relatively easy and the exams were even easier if you look at back tests. Some people didn't like her personality because she often had to yell at the rude students who thought it was acceptable to talk over her at the beginning of class, but I always found her to be very pleasant and helpful.

Not a good teacher;she stutters all the time while lecturing.Her office hours are okay,but if you ask a question that's on the test,she won't answer your q's.She yells at us like we're children and keeps saying how she's stressed out and has many things to do.Her tests are okay,just memorization no understanding.

Class is interesting. Gave only one test, which is not much of the grade but easy, and gives lots of help. The rest of the class is readings with short responses and a few short papers and presentations. She is hyper but passionate about subjects covered.
Very easy. Tests are usually 70% back test. Online homework is straight forward. Her exams are based one what she teaches in lecture. So know her lecture notes and the back test..and you're golden.
Class was fun to take. Homeworks are from the text and test are mostly the same as the back test. The class can get boring at times but it is an easy A.
I have had the pleasure of taking Donna's classes and serving as her TA twice.  There is no one more helpful at all of RPI.

Dr. Crone is one of the most enthusiastic, helpful teachers I"ve ever had!  The work we did in her lab during the last summer of my grad work there was thrilling! As a teacher, I appreciate all her hard work, her thorough knowledge and her kindness!
Boring ... talks like a research paper.
She taught great last year, knows her stuff and loves to teach. Doing lots of great research, she's the hardest working part-time member at RPI

Really kind professor who cares about his students and truly enjoys his material. His projects can be a little confusing but he's great about answering questions and making sure students understand the material before the tests.
Great teacher. highly recommend
Great at teaching Project Management! I really enjoyed the course and found it useful for other IME classes, too.
Very difficult class. Personally, my learning style didn't match with his teaching style but he is liked by many. Super nice guy!

He is a great professor because he loves what he is doing and you can see it. Stands in sharp contrast to many of the professors at the school because he takes the time to break down the material in a way that can be understood.
Hands down, best IEA professor. He makes everything very clear and is very knowledgeable. He  presented all info in an organized way. Good teacher for visual learners.

This professor gives classwork at the last minute, and some of us were forced to choose between losing points or being late for our next class. The grading on at least one exam was also very harsh - think 16% deduction on a problem for a tiny arithmetic error. Overall, he was okay, but I would choose a different section if I could go back.
Probably the best IEA teacher at RPI. He is really down to earth and usually does a good job teaching. If you're confused, don't be afraid to ask.
Best IEA teacher at RPI. Lectures cover everything you need to know. Goes over back tests with the class before the test. Class was pretty easy with him.

Don't know about u folks but this is how engineering courses r meant to be taught. U must be able to derive formulas and know how stuff works. If u think u r into "Learning by doing it" or "Learning by memorizing problems" u shouldn't have become a engineering major in the first place
Great guy.
great prof

His class is an easy A if you put in the work, and his lectures covered everything you needed to know. He seems to have a poor understanding of matlab, which is probably why it's barely touched on in lecture, but the matlab assignments were graded very leniently. His accent was a non-issue.

Fantastic professor. I would recommend him to anyone interested in taking IEA. I was worried before i attended class that he would be difficult to understand, however that is not the case, he speaks very well and is very easily understood. Encourages students to think about problems as opposed to just blindly doing what the slides tell them to!

After the first few weeks, I only came to class to turn in classwork and homework. He requires four MatLab assignments but never teaches you how to use MatLab. His TA graded the exams pretty harshly, but he offers grade-challenging sessions, in that he's pretty helpful. otherwise he just reads off slides and argues with students with questions.

Honestly the guy is very chill. But he's useless. He teaches right off slides that someone else made. I went to class, put in my headphones, read the lecture off of LMS, cranked out the classwork and homework, then left. Go to upperclassman for help because he just confuses people. When I tried to pay attention I nodded off.
Professor Abdoul Seoud is THE BEST IEA professor. His sections always do better on the tests, and he is very clear in his explanations. I even got up for my 8 AM lectures with him.

Very good prof. Of all the foreign instructors i've had he's the easiest to understand. Quite through and makes sure you know the material. you will do well in his class unless you bs the hw (like me). It was pretty funny how he had to leave for egypt in the middle of my class and couldn't get his visa re-upped

He's the best IEA teacher in RPI. He's a genius in that he always THINKS not MEMORIZES the materials. For fact retention type people, yeah people would hate him for being slow. However, for people like me, he's the best teacher available in RPI. THINK people! THINK!
He was great!  Really good at explaining problems, and before long weekends he would play youtube videos for us.

He's not a bad professor really, but he teaches VERY slowly and repeats himself often. It can be tough to stay interested in his class because he goes over complicated things very quickly and confuses people, but covers simple things over and over again.
Just do what he says and show up to class and you'll get an A.  He teaches you how to write pretty dry papers, but I suppose that's what most of the professional world expects.

Just. Agree. With. Him. Seriously, that's all you need to do to pass. He's very liberal, he was at one time a 60's war protester. Play off that, I did, I got A's without doing anything. Just write what he tells you, he has very strict rules on how to write, it's easy to conform to. Easy A, Writing req. Good intro class.
He is a really funny guy. Sometimes the class can get dry, but none of us are really here to take writing classes. One of my favorite teachers. Teaches you new ways to think about writing.

I took one class with him, and hopefully will never have to again.  A bit of advice, to get an A choose very very liberal topics to write about and always agree with him during class no matter how ludicrous his comments may be.
I could barely stay awake in his class.

Ken was overall a nice guy, but very opinionated.  His "lectures" consists of him talking about whatever comes to his mind.  I am not convinced he knows what he is talking about when it comes to writing and the English language.  He does not know the difference between "effect" and "affect".  He decides grades based on whether he likes you or not.

Funny guy. His class is pretty easy. Write a few papers and make a powerpoint presentation. Gave me extra credit because I told him he was funny. Just make sure you do all the work according to his requirements and it should be an easy A

I took 2 of his classes.  After i took classroom and Careers i loved having him as a professor so much i took his intro to lit course.  Great Teacher, fair grader, and has very intereting things to say.  Definatly take his classes!

4 papers and one oral presentation for the semester.  Gives everyone a 100 on the oral presentation.  A Guaranteed B if you put in some effort.  Just bug him about your grade, and he'll give in and give you an A
Great guy! Very funny. Do each paper with what he wants you to put in it, and you should be ok.  He likes it when you laugh at his jokes.
He changed my perspective on writing. I recomend every person who has not taken a writing course to take it from him it will be a great experience.

I took two of his classes!  He is fun, interesting and an easy grader!  DEFINATLY take one of his classes.  The only reason you won't like his class is if your a complete moron at writing papers.  He practically tells you every detail of what he expects...put in a bit of effot and get an A.
Prof. Denberg worships himself and expects his students to do the same.  Whatever you do, NEVER EVER disagree with him!
he does know his stuff, but he's also very biased in his opinions. also, don't take the class if you like writing decent papers, he likes you to use phrases such as "This paper will discuss..."
Very good teacher, knows his stuff very well, very informative and organized.  Writing for Classroom and Career a very helpful class.

Denberg genuinely knows his stuff and does take an interest in not only his students' opinions, but their learning as well.  (God forbid at RPI, but) If you like reading and writing (or want to learn), this is a good course to take.  (And yes, I realize t

Since we do go to RPI, I'm going to let the two useless comments above go (and the useless people who wrote them).  Denberg does grade rather tough, but realize that this is a half-way decent ENGLISH course that isn't toned down for ENGINEERS.  Continues-

I liked his class.  It was tough, but he made you think and work.  He was genuinely interested in the students and what they had to say.  He is a really tough grader, and you shouldn't take the class if you're expecting to BS it - only if you're serious.
AWFUL TEACHER DO NOT EVER TAKE THIS CLASS EVER THIS TEACHER IS AWFUL NO ONE HAS EVER SAID ANYTHING ELSE ABOUT HIM.  DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS, FAIL OUT OF SCHOOL FIRST!
No Comments

Had him for Fluid Mechanics. Overall, I think he was a pretty solid professor. He tends to drag on and is very soft-spoken and class ended later than usual. His handwriting was questionable too. However, he is really passionate about the material and you can tell. HW's were doable with the TA's help and tests were open note and laptop, easy A.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Test heavy

comment: Cares a lot about students who make an effort, but his lectures are not great. In Fluid Mechanics, he derives everything without explaining beforehand what you are doing. Does examples in class, which are helpful and similar to test problems, but starts deriving more instead of solving them. Class is very difficult if not taken Diff-EQ or Calc 3.

Rusak was awful for Flight Mechanics. He brings no energy to teaching the class and the class always ends 10 minutes late. The notes are useful for the tests, but his handwriting is terrible so I sometimes would write a wrong variable. Tests are not super difficult but are very long. Homeworks are very long but the TA basically does it for you.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Very insightful and knowledgeable professor. Homework and test problems can be challenging, but he is a fairly lenient grader.

Going to office hours helped immensely. He was always willing to take time to help you with the homework or to understand a concept, and, if needed, start from the beginning of a concept to make sure you really get it. He was a lenient grader, but make sure to do the homework because the two tests were worth 35% and 40% of the total class grade.

Fluid mechanics--Lectures were often terrible. Terrible handwriting combined with him obstructing the projector made it difficult to take notes. Often charged into tedious derivations without first explaining what he was deriving or why it was important. Thankfully tests were fair reflections of the homework and notes, and were graded generously.
Amazing professor, nice man, anyone who says otherwise hasn't taken the time to get to know him.

Zvi Rusak enjoys teaching, you can tell that my just sitting in one of his many MANE courses. While this class is not easy, prof rusak made it as clear as possible and was always available for office hours.
I enjoyed the lecture and gained much knowledge from learning the topic. Professor is ighly recommended.
An excellent professor. shared with the class his experiences with real airplanes. highly recommended.
great teacher. you have to pay attention, study the lectures, and read the books. he's so nice and very helpful. i was afraid of failing and he helped me out a lot!

Great Professor. The material was difficult to grasp, but if you put time and effort into understanding it you could get a lot out of the course. He was very passionate about the subject and tried to get students interested in the material through the use of personal experiences working on the F-16.
Horrible.  Mean, doesnt speak clearly, not helpful at office hours.
He is very passionate about the subject. I took the course as an undergrad, so did not appreciate the mathematical details that he focussed on.

I was also shocked at these ratings, and comments.  He IS a very personable guy and vry friendly and wants everyone to do well.  If you hate him, you are probably unwilling to do any work.  He was however, a poor lecturer.  Often had mistakes in notes that had to be fixed.  Good guy, not such a great prof, but not worthy of all the horrible reviews
I was surprised when I saw the other ratings. This guy's really a nice guy, you just have to try a little in the class. He's very willing to help you out if you screw up something.
If you pay attention, you will get an A in IEA summer class.

A bit on the stubborn and intimidating side.  Knows his stuff but has trouble communicating it. Just do the project (it's a capstone course) and you'll get a good grade.  No tests, only 2 or 3 HW assignments.

We would have been better off with a handout of equations the first day of class and then just showing up for the final.  He showed no interest in helping students, thick accent, bad handwriting, didn't explain anything.  Hated him.

Does not have a grasp of the english language.  Decided to shorten a hard summer class that was a condensed 6 wks to 5 wks without getting approval from the Eng. Dept.  Very angry and hostile individual.
Dude does not know how to use technology and I'd rather watch paint dry than hear him lecture. He is that boring.

This class was good overall. You have to fully understand the pre-print he has for the course, the lecture slides, and the homework. Exam questions are always related to what he talked about in class/lecture/pre-print. But he is a tough grader. I once lost 10/100 points for units typo despite my solution being correct and carrying correct units.

A very kind and intelligent professor. He doesn't give partial credit, but his exams are straightforward if you pay attention. Sometimes he'll go on cool tangents about materials, which raised my interest in the subject greatly. Sit as close to the front as possible, though, to absorb his wisdom.
His lower level classes are often very similar to previous years in regards to tests/quizzes/homework. Can be hard to understand and has poorly structured lectures.

Get backwork!!! Quizzes are exactly the same as previous years. Even the numbers are the same. Far superior teacher compared to other MatSci professors. HW is on Wiley and there are no prelabs. Easy A.

he's ok.  Hard to understand sometimes. Uses the ready-notes and is all over the place with them.  The partial credit thing people keep referring too depends on the TA for your class, they do all the grading, I get a fair amount of partial credit.  He gives you a list of the material that will be covered on every quiz/test the class before.
No partial credit ever.

Awesome professor! He is fun and really seems to care for his students. He wants you to understand and goes out of his way to make sure you get it. Quizzes were difficult with little partial credit, but overall the cumulative averages were higher. definitely get him if you can.
He always talks about his research, which is glass.  He writes on his overhead slides over and over again, with the same thing.  He is alright, but his quizzes are really hard.

I agree with what many people have already said. No partial credit. And a lot of it is luck. I don't really know what I'm doing in this class, but I beat the average on the first exam, by making some educated guesses and being lucky. Unfortunately, he's the only guy who teaches this course, otherwise I'd suggest getting someone else.

Overall I liked this prof. Very intelligent, has somewhat humorous anecdotes. Accent can be hard to understand. Class is a bore, but tests are VERY straight forward. Yes, he doesn't give partial credit, but if you know your stuff you shouldn't need any. One caveat: I'm probably in the minority, as most of the people in class  weren't fond of him.
interesting guy, tests difficult and a bit unclear, but he seems reasonable about adjusting grades accordingly.  Will spend 1/2 a class explaining techniques for forging a sword

He offers no partial credit and is a little bit hard to understand because of his accent. However, if you go into office hours he is extremly helpful and tries to think of new ways to explain things to you. Also for this class he understand that its really hard and that hes a strict grader so he curves it very nicely.
Excellent professor, extremely intelligent but very had.  Gives little to no partial credit on exams, but his cum. quiz grades are much higher than that of other professors.  Highly recommended.
the tests are so unfair and he is not a good teacher and no partial credit
No Comments
my quiz grades were all over the board, but he's decent guy.
no partial credit at all for tests. if you want a better grade, switch to another professor!

If you don't make a mistake on the exams you are golden (basically no partial credit).  The exams are extremely straight forward however. Other than this, he is an excellent professor who you will learn from as long as you tune in.
AWESOME teacher

wrote aggressive emails to the entire class. used the projecting device to project her notes to class. it was hard to read. did not like explaining things again. got upset for minuscule things. rebukes students who are even a minute late. refused to provide solutions to exams or even for past homework. avoid.

We dont have anonymous midterm evaluations so we cant voice our concerns during the semester. I honestly regret taking this class with her as my free elective. She needs to take a class on passive-aggressive behavior (its no longer microaggression). Save your happiness and choose another elective.

One of the most disrespectful professors I have ever encountered at RPI. I'm really upset with how she treats students (extremely unprofessional over email). Sending her an email only results in an out-front aggressive response back to you. She does not create a welcoming learning environment in the Risk Analytics class. Do not take as elective!

Gupta is the absolute worst. She is someone who shouldn't teach. No slides, just scratchy notes written on chalkboard/projector. No examples ever gone over in class but expects you to be able to do everything. Class is weeks behind because she is extremely disorganized. Does not explain a single thing. If you don't need to take a class w her DON'T.

I am a BA student and I need to take financial modeling for fnce requirement. However, this prof talked in class that those BA students who dropped the class 'do a good thing' because it is better for QFRA students. I will never give her any respect.
Exams were hard, with no review material provided. Class was confusing and mess

Gupta is a good professor. She does not come from a business background so there are few practical examples. She is very organized and seems to have every minute of every lecture planned. The RM exams are difficult. She applied a curve to the final which pushed me to an A. The two projects are a bit vague, but going to her office helped.
Talks constantly throughout slides, does not respond well to questions.  Inconsistent grading methods.  Takes attendance by using busy work sheets every class.

Don't be fooled by the "bad" icon.  I took MAU in Sp2007 with her, and it wasn't nearly as bad as these comments claim. MAU, will be a hard and annoying class, but she made it less of this than my friends w/ Malaviya experienced.  Gupta has much better organization and made sure you knew how to use the Minitab software. If she is a choice, take it.
sHE IS VERY BRILLIANT

It's true she doesn't always clarify stuff in class very well, but this class is so easy that you can figure it out yourself or with friends. Tests, homework, and quizzes are all reasonable if you pay a minor amount of attention. She was very accommodating when I had to miss class and a test because of sickness.

Worst professor that I've dealt with at RPI.  She gave awful lectures that made no sense, and when someone asked her to clarfiy examples, she pretty much yelled at them and told them to read the text and understand it for themself.  Work load and exams much harder than in other MAU sections. Don't expect an A with this woman.
Horrible.  She is unclear and just talks during the slides and assumes that you understand what is going on.  She doesn't explain any of the topics and her examples are terrible.

What he said.  This woman has no concept of teaching to the students.  She just speaks through all the slideshows she manages to come up with and thinks the material makes sense since it makes sense to her.  Her in class examples are worthless and she gives you a pretty needless attitude most of the time. Just read the book during class and smile.
She has a way of making the simplest thing look like the hardest problem of your life, when you take MAU stay clear if you want to pass.
horrible intructor, you best bet is to not go to class and read the book.  All she does is confuse you

Too much theory, and not enough hands on work. Never wanted to give, or work through examples. Piled on the course work, projects leading right into an exam. Too much overlapping of assignments. Handouts were terrible, could not read. Felt that I could have learned better without going to class.
No Comments
Extremely difficult to learn from.  Hw was ridiculous and the online program hw was given on was very buggy.
She is extremly difficult and just cannot teach.  She gives huge amounts of hw, more than any other professor in the course and relys on a faulty computer system to grade them.

Her lectures are theory-heavy. Getting help was at times difficult, mostly due to busy office hours. I ended up needing a tutor, which helped a lot. She was also nice and was willing to give me guidance on assignments even after office hours were completed. I would recommend taking Programming Languages with her.
Very nice and accommodating professor. Class is tough but she is there to help along with the other TAs.

Professor Milanova is truly one of the most infuriating professors I've had in recent years, her teaching style for a coding-based class is nearly entirely theoretical. Problems in the homeworks and exams are sometimes obscure or haven't even been taught yet. She refuses to take any responsibility for the performance of the class.

Idk if it's a problem with the contents she teaches or just her lecture is bad, but overall, progLang with her is the worst class I've ever taken. She releases hws even before enough materials are covered in the lectures and she easily gets stressed when students attempt to argue over her ridiculous hw policy. I wouldn't recommend her.
I took her for MBE. She was super helpful and really wanted you to learn the material. She will help any student at any time and had great lectures
She is soooo amazing. She will go above and beyond to help you understand the material. Make sure to show up to class because she goes over a lot of the material that helps you in the class.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Most of the time, profs are just lecturers and dont focus on their making sure their students are actually learning. Ive taken 3 courses with Milanova during my time at RPI. She is this rare breed who actually cares. If you go to talk with her and ask questions, she will do everything in her power help you succeed. Every prof should strive to be.

Milanova teaches fairly advanced courses dealing with language theory/compilers/etc. The topics tend to be pretty dense and tough, but she knows the subject area incredibly well and is very helpful overall. If you care at all about the subject area, it's pretty hard to not do well in her class(es), although she doesn't offer courses often.

Explanations are usually unclear and not helpful. Lectures were stiff and super boring. Read straight from lengthy PowerPoint presentations. She used LMS Discussion Board instead of Piazza. So of course rarely did people actually use it for questions. Therefore she constantly complained of people sending her emails instead. Find a different prof.

Not helpful. The lectures are boring, slides are unclear, and the worst thing is she never gives us clear solutions to any tests, quizzes, or homework. And if you email her questions she won't reply. Uhhh.
I thought she was a great professor. It's a hard class but if you make the effort, she will help you in any way she can.

Milanova's ok. I usually didn't go to lecture and the lectures didn't seem very helpful (just reading from slides) but the curriculum was pretty straight-forward and well-managed. The course pretty much sticks to the book. Projects are helpful and interesting. Exams are pretty easy but homeworks can be tough.
Very difficult subject matter made more difficult by a professor who teaches off of poorly written, unhelpful powerpoints.

She tries her best, but gets overwhelmed and loses track of what she's doing really easily.  Grading and difficulty varies wildly.  On the bright side, she has a hilarious/adorable accent.  Bring a hip flask to class and take a swig every time she tries to say "push" and it comes out as "poosh".

Not a terribly good teacher.  Tends to teach off of slides, doesn't really stray much from them.  Not really any point in going to class (assuming you can read).  Also, not terribly helpful.  Posts replies such as "Sorry, I don't have time to write all of these down."  in response to requests for answers to the review questions for the final.
Pretty difficult subject matter, with very little clarification from either the text or the professor. I would look for someone else.
Hard to understand.  Tests and assignments can be hard.  Although she makes up for all of that by being a very easy grader.
No Comments

Milanova is new to teaching and it still shows unfortunately. She's not a bad person, but she's very shy and it shows when she's giving lectures. Plus she uses PowerPoint presentations which are upwards of 70 slides. So attention drifts off quickly. Not a horrendous class, but not a good one either.
She is very unclear and difficult to follow during lecture.  Her exams are difficult.  It would be better to take a section of this class that Milanova does not teach.

Lectures are always amazing, so you should attend. Exams are homework heavy, don't cheat and go to office hours for homework questions and you will be good. Very reasonable grading policy and very understanding professor.

Great guy, very knowledgeable about the source material but always humble. Actively works with students to line up office hours with their schedules and arrange review sessions. Always willing to answer any questions about source material. Can sometimes get sidetracked during lecture, but never fails to cover all of the material in depth.
