comment: Took mechatronics as a lab elective. As an EE, the course needs your background in physical modeling and analysis, so I struggled sometimes, but he is really willing to help. Exams are hard and long but curved a lot, labs and projects are not that difficult to complete (as a hybrid course)
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Great guy I had a lot of fun in the course but I'm invested in the course material. Mechatronics is a tough course and he says as much. He really wants you to succeed and is available out of class. He did very well adapting the course to an online format.

Dr. Hurst is always eager to help if you run into any difficulties, and he really cares about his students learning. He responds to student feedback and is constantly trying to improve his teaching. He is also very good at teaching only what you need to know rather than wasting time on complicated derivations or theory.

Joshua Hurst is a great professor who is very knowledgeable about Controls. He always aims to improve his course through mid-semester evaluations (so write what you want to change). Hurst reviews important content and is good at answering and understanding questions or concerns. Take Hurst if you want to learn! - Average for my year was low 80s.

Hurst is the only way to go for MODCON. Had him for two classes now and highly recommend. He will go out of his way to ensure that you understand. Hurst genuinely wants you to do well and will do his best to ensure that. Just watch out, he sometimes makes tests way harder than they should be, but he generally curves it if the grades are bad.

Homeworks can be tough but he is very helpful during office hours. You may struggle in class with examples but everything will make sense once he goes over them. He does plenty of prep for tests. With the homeworks and reviews you will be prepared for the tests. Would absolutely reccomend this class and proffesor.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Caring

comment: MODCON is a tough class but Hurst is the way to go. I didn't really enjoy the class as it doesn't apply to my major but he is a good professor. Homeworks are very long but are great preparation for the tests. He has a strict attendance policy so be sure to be at every class. He is very helpful outside of class if you are struggling with a topic.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Excellent job relating class to real life.    The labs were long and don't tie in to the tests , but if you know Matlab they are a lot of lines of code, but not hard.  Tests could be confusing if you don't have full command of the concepts, beyond the wrote homework assignments.  That being said the homework is mandatory for mastery.

In both of the classes I took with him (Design Opt, and Mechatronics) he didn't post lecture notes, and urged you to take your own. It works. If you go to class, pay attention, and ask questions when you're confused, there's nothing you wont understand. He explains everything well, and adjusts the class pace if needed.Best teacher I've had at RPI.
Really helpful professor, passion for lecture and kind. Always smile to you.

Joshua Hurst actually listens to what the students say in their midterm survey and changes his teaching methods accordingly. He is the most helpful professor I've ever had, and he makes concepts extremely comprehensible.
Passionate teacher
MODCON wasn't my favorite class, but Prof. Hurst was very helpful and passionate about the subject, making it tolerable and relevant.

cui is kinda all over the place. when i took the class, we had in class lectures, now i hear that theyre all online. shes a new teacher still learning how she wants to run the class. she does care about students performance, and the exams are online, but she also is very inaccessible out of hours and is sometimes late to class lol

Dr. Cui is new to RPI. She is a very caring person and wants everyone to learn, but her teaching styles are so hard to keep track of and it makes it very confusing when you are trying to figure out what you actually need to do to pass the class. She makes the lectures, quizzes, and exams online, and class time is spent doing activities.

I didn't take the intro to psych. I took Research Methods and Statistics with her and I thought she was a really nice professor. The class was fun and chill, as it should have been since it's a HASS course. Overall, a great experience!

Dr. Cui is unresponsive and shows blatant disregard for her students. She would go as far as leaving reviews on her own page trying to defend her teaching instead of actually addressing their concerns lol

This might be the worst professor I have had. There is absolutely zero clarity with the grades. Her class page is an absolute mess. She also feels the need to get into her personal life with the class almost like she wants the class to pity her. She will not respond to emails and really does not care about you, just wants you to care about her.

Intro psychology is not a hard subject to learn with any professor and the textbook Professor Cui uses is quite good. However, the level of communication and clarity is very low. Her assignments can be confusing, there are a lot platforms to keep track of, quizzes are not announced, and the late policy is ruthless so live by the syllabus.

Lucy is new, so understandably her style of teaching will improve with time. As it is now, she can be a bit disorganized; But most professors are subject to this. She is fun and exciting to be around, so if you actually care about participating in class and actually care about psychology she is the right fit. Else, her PSYCH-1200 is not for you.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Intro to Psych is the most pointless class I've taken at RPI. Dr. Cui's application of the material is disorganized and ineffective. She limits her availability and wrote in the syllabus "If you email me, I will not respond." She is unforgiving with students but expects constant sympathy from them. All lectures are poorly narrated videos, too.
One of the worst professors ever.

Don't be fooled by claims that this class is difficult, because this is one of the easiest classes you could take by far. Homework/exams are online and open note with questions directly referencing what is written in the textbook, so unless you take really bad notes or cannot read the textbook, you'll do just fine here.

This is one of the most difficult classes I have ever taken, not because the class/material is hard but because of how difficult she is. She plays the victim a lot and complains about her life. She has no mercy for students having issues or turning in late work. She uses several different applications that are hard to keep track of. Simply terrible

The lectures were horrible and inconsistent with the things tested in the exams. The professor is selfish and does things at her convenience. She told us to use another platform rather than school email and LMS she didn't check quite often. The grading build-up is extremely weird!

Everything about this class is the worst, except at least you don't have to write essays & the tests are open note. She makes you message her on a separate platform that she doesn't even check daily, & takes points if you email her. Also she has a no-mercy approach to late/missed assignments, which I think is ridiculous.

Although it was her first semester teaching, I felt as though her lectures were unengaging and that there were no clear grading criteria as they were kind of made up as she went. The tests were quite confusing even though they were online. She always wanted student feedback though which I appreciated.

Her biggest issue is her experimentation with how she wants to communicate material. For a while it was normal lectures with a powerpoint and occasional iclicker questions. And then at another point were doing arts and crafts with pipe cleaners and having to instead watch online recorded lectures. Sidenote: Her online lectures were boring as sin.

I think her grading criteria is a bit complicated. There is also the name of the assignment. Although I heard about this assignment in class, when I checked the assignment after class, I didn't realize that "Deliberate Rest" was the name of the assignment.

Lectures were not extremely engaging but could have been significantly worse. For the most part, the issues in the course were due to it being her first semester combined with constant experimentation, sometimes feeling like a different class every other week. I think Dr. Cui will be a good to great professor as she gets more used to the role.

She's pretty new so still figuring things out. Tests were all open note/open internet taken outside of class, so you don't have to pay attention to lectures. She offers lots of extra credit opportunities throughout the year.

This professor didn't seem like she knew anything about psych. She was always late to class by at least 5 minutes, but usually around 10-15. Her exams do not make sense. The questions are either overly wordy so that they do not make sense or they contain no relevant info. There were questions that were never discussed in class. Grades were uneven.

Mary Anne is difficult to rate. She is very knowledgeable, and is always willing to talk and give feedback. She cares about her field and wants others to feel the same. She can, however, be very disorganized and distractable. I wish I could grade her higher. She is, however, very lenient with grades, especially if you submit decent work.

Grades based off 3 papers and attendance, as of now (last days of finals) she still hasn't graded anything. Rushed assigning us papers at the end of the semester because she didn't plan out due dates. Lectures are awful with everyone sitting on their phone behind their computers. So many easier inquiry classes don't take it.
rating_tags: So many papers--Graded by few things

comment: This professor is a mass. Hard to communicate.
do not take this class
There may be merit in reconsidering taking this course. I did it to get the communication and Inqr criteria for HASS ticked off. But would not have otherwise have chosen this course.
No

This prof was so disorganized. She ran over class time every class, would take 40 minutes to take attendance, 30 minutes to explain one thing, etc, then give so many papers and take off points for the most asinine reasons. 0/10 would not take again.

Prof. is such a sweetheart, I loved taking this course and it really changed how I consume media for good, there is a lot of news analysis during class and it is mostly based around current events. She will work with you if you come across problems during your time in the course. Work is mainly the 3 research papers you have to write. 10/10 amazing
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: She was a fun character and lectures always flew by. Written assignments were graded pretty fair, especially citation, but she was more than willing to help you out. She was super sweet and definitely wanted to get more connected with her students.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--Caring

comment: If you love professors who are a completely disorganized mess, you will like her

Loved her! She may be difficult at times, however as long as you talk and voice your opinion in class she's a very lenient grader. She did require us to memorize some key facts about culture & history, however I liked the fact that she allowed us to be creative/open-minded and pick our own topics to present.
She is a very thoughtful professor and cares about students. Although her exams are hard, you should be fine if you put emphasis on her syllabus. She grades everybody kindly.

Prof.Staniszewski is a really nice person! I like her. I don't think her lectures are boring, but when she explains stuff, it's really confusing. Her exams are not hard (lots of memorization -dates/paintings- for this course). She's always energetic and active! overall i like this course and the professor.

Professor Staniszewski was the best teacher I had at RPI. Her concepts are really interesting and she knows art theory/history inside and out. She literally wrote the book(s) on it! The classes I took with her were eye-opening and just so wonderful. She requires a lot of memorization but there's a lot of discussion and analysis too. She's fabulous!

I gave this class countless opportunities to shine, and it passed up each one. The course material is actually interesting, but is not presented well. At all. Professor S. is a good professor- she professes and all that- but as a teacher I find her to be IMPOSSIBLE.

If you wished you went to a liberal arts school, you'll enjoy her, but she's too tied up in the pretentious "Art" ideals to actually teach stuff that will be useful in real life (unless you plan on being a fine artist or a teacher).
Rarely starts class earlier than 20 min in. Enjoyable personality especially outside of the class period. Do take notes. A lot of memorization. Essentially an art history course

controversial and partisan, some people think shes a b*tch, but i love her, even though I dont agree with her social-political beleifs nor her aesthetics. She has written, researched and added plenty to her feild and she gives out mutual respect when it is deserved. only treats adults like adults.

Course totally not anything like described. Turned into a boring tedious art history course centered around a horrible book that was written by her (of course). SHe is 1 of 2 reasons why I changed my major.
amazing professor
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: She is very nice and understanding. If you like creative writing, you'll really enjoy the class. She talks a lot, but the class is interactive. If you hate writing, probably don't take this class.

Had Dr. Walf for INQR 1175, not PSYC 1200. Very kind professor, enjoyed participating in her class discussions and the classwork was very doable. This class was a nice break between my morning Chem 1 lectures and afternoon Calc 1 lectures on T/F, and I'd recommend this HASS class as it's both Communcation Intensive and an Inquiry.
Had for inquiry CCWB, not psych. Professor Walf was very kind and caring, and genuinely wants students to succeed. Gives good feedback on essays, and workload was very manageable.

Dr. Walf is an amazing Psych. professor and made what otherwise would've been a boring class into a very interesting one. There is a lot of homework and late submissions result in a zero, however, she posts all homework and notes on the first day, and grading is generous. I hope to have her in another class!
Had for a hass inquiry class, workload was easy, professor is very caring and approachable. Gives good feedback on assignments.

Literally went to class the first day, finished all the homework's the first week, took the exams throughout the sem and got an a in the class. It is all common sense and knowing who Sigmund Freud is. Otherwise I can't speak much on Dr. Walf, she seemed like a lovely professor. This class is definitely the way to go if you need a GPA boost.

Only if every professor was like Walf, RPI, well wouldn't be RPI. Think of the worst imaginable professor, grading wise and overall demeanor and professor Walf is the direct opposite of that! This class was very easy and amazing because of it. You learned at your own pace really which makes Walf great. 10/10 would recommend!

I really enjoyed her lectures. She speaks slowly which makes it easier to take notes without feeling like my hand is on fire. She's wonderful to converse with after class, and she's incredibly kind and personable of a professor. Would recommend any of her classes.

This class is a great and easy introduction to psychology. There is a textbook associated with the course, which I read, but if you have already taken a psychology course, it may not be necessary for you to read every chapter of the textbook. Tests are easy but have a lot of questions.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: Best prof I have ever had
I absolutely loved Professor Walf. If you can, I would definitely recommend taking one of her classes.

Dr. Walf would always stay after the class for students with questions. Her class is inspirational but also critical for research skills training. Not an easy A class but you can definitely get A if you do everything as the syllabus indicated.
Favorite Professor
She's one of my favorite professor in RPI in terms of both classwork and personality.
Very informative and knowledgable on subject matter

intro to cog neur -- awesome instructor, passionate about the subject/her research, straightforward assignments/exams, quiz every lecture based on prev lecture, patient and thorough answering questions. would recommend this professor.

One of the best professors I've had at RPI. Excellent at teaching the content, enjoyable lectures, tough but fair homeworks and exams. Truly understands what students go through and will do anything he can to try and help, including responding to emails at off-hours. His end-of-lecture memes were always great.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Shafee is a charming guy I like his foam block demonstrations and memes but his lectures can be hard to follow. He goes through example problems at Mach 10 and loses most of the class halfway through each lecture. The weekly homework assignments take forever and exams are extremely difficult. Prepare to put a lot of time and effort into his class.

Dr. El-Shafee is a very knowledgeable and kind professor! I'm grateful I had him for Strength of Materials. This class can be very grueling, but Dr. El-Shafee was very helpful during office hours and cared about how you were doing if you reached out. I'm a fan of his memes at the end of class as well. Studying in advance for exams helped me a ton!
He's the goat.
good professor for strength of materials, very helpful during office hours
really knowledgeable, kinda hard class
Omar is probably the best professor you will have at RPI. He is engaging and at times hilarious. Class is by no means easy, but it is my favorite class have taken so far.

Omar is genuinely the best lecturer I ever had. He expertly and clearly explains concepts using his foam beams, both in terms of real-world as well as academically. He will purposefully go on useful or hilarious tangents if people need more time to take notes. If you have a question, he will go back in the slides and explain it in a different way.

For IEA, he was a great teacher. He would explain all concepts thoroughly and efficiently and would pause for questions. If a student still did not understand he would explain in a different way until they did. He would even go back in the slideshow if someone asked. Amazing professor and had fun memes in the slides.

There were many incongruence between expectations and what was evaluated when it came time for exams. His lectures are chaotic and obnoxious especially if its your first class during the day. The classes and homework did not adequately prepare anyone for the tests; I am confident that the only reason I passed this class was because of COVID-19.

Overall, a solid professor for Strengths of Materials, though I don't think I would rate him as highly as some of the other reviews. He definitely does a good job, but, if you prefer a more laid-back lecture style, I would recommend Shahsavari instead.

I love his memes. He's got engineering memes in his lecture slides. He's a good lecturer who can project his voice and is able explain and elaborate well. He's available outside of class often and is very willing to help. There's a problem you'll have to do in class each day to take attendance. Tests and homework are long but you get partial credit

Dr. Omar is the best recommendation for IED. He is very nice and kind, always grade your project, presentation and report with mercy. Also he gives good feedback telling you how to do better next time. He really wants every student to succeed!

This professor is the GOAT! He genuinely cares about his students and wants you to succeed. The exam averages are typically higher in his sections of strengths of materials even though all sections take the same exam. He tries his best to keep lectures interesting by showing real world application, and he prepares his own memes for class.

El-Shafe is an awesome professor- he is funny and loves memes, but he also is the absolute best Strengths teacher you could ever have. He knows his stuff (He is the course head) he is understanding of student difficulties and he is very receptive to questions. He has the soul of a millenial and the experience of a 90yr old. P.S hes got all da memes
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Amazing lectures

comment: Strengths was tough, but it could have been tougher if I had another professor. El-Shafee explained things well and prepared us for the tests. He also cares about his students. Would highly recommend.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--TEST HEAVY

comment: One of the best professors I have had at RPI. He is very approachable and loves helping out to address questions and concerns. The class is not easy, but if you put in the effort, you can do well.
Dr. Omar is a ball of fun. Greatest lecturer to set foot at RPI.

The man the myth the legend.... We are talking about the wonderful man named Omar. He brightens my 8ams with his use of dank memes. He definitely teaches the material well and tries his best to answer all questions. I love this man.

James Li is a BAMF. May he get well soon, but this man is awesome. He had surgery and when the substitute professor was driving students away, he came back and saved some of us from failing the final. His jokes are classic too. He reminded me why americans are "special." RIP
Excellent professor, and I'm glad I was able to take his course before he passed away.
Amazing professor, one of the best I've had at RPI. He can relate to the students and keeps the material interesting.
Excellent professor for modeling and control. Very sentimental and down to earth personality and presents the material with good examples. I hardly have opened the book, except to do the homework.

James Li is an excellent professor. I haven't opened the textbook since his notes tell me everything I need to know. I'm surprised at all of the negative reviews. I never took dynamics with him, but I sure wish I had. People who don't understand him are people who don't know how to listen. Overall clear, (very) entertaining, and fair professor.
No Comments
He is a good person in class, covers all the material you need, but is not very personable. Overall he made the class decent and exams were fair.

He is a great teacher. He makes jokes in class and keeps it lively. to those who think that taking attendance is a drag, you are probably failing the class because you dont show up. so **** all of you who this he is not a good professor

The RPI dynamics program is perhaps the most wretched of any. The tests are extremely unfairly graded, the TA's are retarded, and there is NO consistency between sections, tests, etc... while this class has a common test for all sections. Having a professor who knows almost nothing about dynamics (Li), makes it even more difficult.
great class!

The commodore, as we call him, is absolutely worthless. He devotes class time to going over the problems that are already done out entirely in the book. He also arbitrarily changes the syllibus throughout the year.  He grades you on your class notes and takes attendence.  He is worthless. Avoid him.

A funny guy, but shouldn't be teaching a class which he has had no experience with since his sophmore year of college (he admitted to this). I've had to learn everything from Craig's or Tichy's review sessions a couple days before the tests.

aaaaarpha.  this man does not have 'L' in his alphabet.  also he does not teach the asy method for anything.  i end up learning all the material 2 days before the test in craigs review.  however he is funny
Very boring in lecture, just reads slides.  Tries to teach, but is hard to understand accent his accent.  Take the class with Craig.
pretty good teacher, hard class to teach to MANE students.  homeworks hard, but similar content as tests.  keeps you awake with pointless but funny stories about his life
funny and nice taiwanese instuctor
Great teacher, real funny, his accent is easy to get used to.  Homeworks and tests are tough but definitely doable with a few hours of studying prior to the tests.

Interesting 1 Credit Course. Only required to go to class once a week and listen to him, other students or guest speakers for Pass/No Credit. Do a presentation or poster to get a grade for the course.
Wicked easy, not that boring.  Nice guy.  Tests are really easy.  Required 15 minutes of studying to get a 95 on  both tests so far.

TSS for 1 credit is an easy A, but not for 2.  The tests have the most random jeopardy questions-like the names of the satelittes that were sent in orbit in 1992.  I liked him though, and I thought the class was interesting and fun.
I loved this class. It had many interesting facts about the solar system that I never knew before. The test are straight from the lecture and the class is an easy A. I recommend this class highly!!!!
The tests have THEE most random questions at points. But he's VERY interested in the teaching and what he does and it emminates to the students...or at least to me.

I'm not sure if it was him or the subject matter, but I found it very hard to stay focused on his lectures.  Also, the class includes lots of looking at the sky, which is hard with all the street lights on campus.  Otherwise, you will learn things.
No Comments

Tour of the Solar System is an excellent course. The topics are fascinating and Professor Whittet presents the material well. The lectures are fairly straight-forward and you feel like you are listening to a recording more than a person at times, but that doesn't make it boring. Take this course!

For this class, he had strict requirements about visiting the observatory. We had to go 5 times in the semester, and the reports are total worth half of your final grade. I went 11 times total, and it was only open 3 times of those 11 due to weather. He wouldn't give me a break, and I got a D.

took two classes from Whittet, great professor!  Very helpful, and can teach material in a way that makes it accessible to non-physics majors.  Very easy to approach with questions on course material. Seems to genuinely like teaching, Imagine that!
Good teacher.  Shows the most AWESOME videos on the planets that will blow your mind.
TSS is awesome and easy. Whittet is the hottest old guy ever.

Awesome class. Very nice prof.  He really appreciates people who take an interest in the subject matter, especially in a class where you don't really have to be interested to get a good grade.  Take a class with him.
Fair and pleasant mannered English-type professor.  Much of the material is dense, but he makes an honest effort to teach the material.
whatever you want  take this class easy a and cute old man
Tour of the solar system is an awesome class.  Learned a lot of cool stuff.  Tests are easy if you spend about an hour reviewing the lecture notes prior.  Really fun course.
Tour of the Solar System is ****ing awesome, and WICKED EASY

I'm glad I had Professor Swalla for 1600 too.  She always made sure we were on top of what we needed to do well on exams, we did lots of in class problems, and she was always available when I had questions.

Professor knows alot about design.  Our team was able to get help on every aspect of our project.  She gave good feedback on reports.  Everyone's project worked this semester.  I give her alot of credit for that.

I took Material Selection with her and feel I learned a great deal and will do well in Capstone.  The final project was awesome.  I heard she busted a couple of people for cheating.  I am glad to have a professor who is tough about that.
She is very knowledgeable in her field. Some people dislike her, i found her very helpful. She also gives you a lot of industry application of course material.
Worst professor I've ever had

Her style is different. Now that I'm doing a co-op, I can see why she teaches this way and glad I took her.  She doesn't make you participate in class, but in class work is worth alot.  She showed us a plot linking in class grades and test grades.

Her lectures are good if you do the reading assignments.  If you dont you will have a hard time. Her methods are different from other professors but i think that comes from knowing what employers want.

Prof. Swalla is extremely knowledgeable, but that doesn't necessarily translate to being a good professor.  Her Thermals class is pretty tough, but that's normal for the subject.  She tries to make people participate in class, with limited success.  She's also a pretty quiet speaker.  Her tests are open-book and of appropriate difficulty.
In the capstone class Dr Swalla really helped us stay focused and helped us complete a project that our customer was very happy with , she is a great capstone professor.

She not only teaches in a way that makes the problems understandable but brings real work experiences to the class. I have gone to her office many times and she Dr. Swalla makes it clear that this is no longer high school and that she is here to teach us advanced skills that will help us to be great engineers. She expects the best from us.
Extremely boring class, legitimately reads straight from the textbook at times. A nice curve from the start though, get a 50 and you pass

I cannot stand her! I wasn't able to understand the material well at all, and it took about 6-8 hours to do the homework due each week. A's and B's were also not to be expected in her class, because although some of us might be used to it, this is because of "grade inflation". Probably not the worst professor I'll ever have, but still, I'd switch.

Dr. Swalla was my favorite teacher this semester!  She takes students out of the high school 'plug and chug' and gives them skills they will need when they graduate.  She's tough but fair. That is how it is supposed to be. I'm looking forward to taking her TF1 class.

Dr. Swalla sometimes has difficulty organizing a lecture. She has alot of experience from industry that makes the material interesting. She cares alot about students, always answers emails, and is willing to spend extra time when needed.
Has good intentions, but is a terrible teacher. Doesn't explain things well, and kept changing the homework system every week. Overall, not a good experience.

This professor describs Strength of Materials as her "bread and butter". While copying derivations out of the text she still manages to mess up. I would recommend taking this class with someone else. You can end up with a test average above 90, and a final exam grade of 94  and still manage a B+ with her grading system. Puts herself on a pedestal.

Terribly annoying teacher. She really understands the material but isn't too great at conveying it to a room of students.  As a Mech E major who really enjoyed statics, I dread having to go to Swalla's class. I highly advise you to take the class with someone else

A great guy. Really helpful in the office hours. But the assignments are quite difficult. So are the tests. Grading is very tough. A very difficult course indeed. One needs to spend a lot of time to properly handle the different aspects of the course.

He knows the material well. I personally wouldn't recommend taking this course with him if there is an option. In my experience he is not fair & consistent in grading at all. This course requires a lot of work which is fine, there are lots of techniques to be covered. I personally learnt mostly from the textbook. Good book, some typos though.

I'm doing well in his course, but it's not his doing at all. The textbook is excellent. His weekly quizzes contain material he never did in class, and when a student in our section commented on how we were only to be quizzed on material taught in class, the student was told his point was not valid. Smart, but not personable, doesn't care about you.
Very mean, does not care about questions from the class or explaining the material because he thinks it is easy. i do not recommend

Very good lecturer.  I don't know why others don't like him. I think he was a pretty good professor.  His teaching style is good.  He doesn't linger on stupid questions if no one is going to answer.  He gets all the material done, mostly on time, so you don't get too behind.   Also, the Mat Sci book is a good read, so read it.
obviuosly nothings changed since he got tenureship. He's still a bully.
Very unclear and not interested in students as people.
No Comments
he doesnt like to share his wireless with others in the MRC
I was in the hospital and he refused to let me make up the work
good but tough

Knows his stuff and also teaches it well. But he also expects you to know it well (nothing wrong with that). You walk out as a different person from his course. Gives a deep insight. But be prepared to work hard or else drop the course.

He was my IED professor, and he did less than the minimum asked of him.  He provided no help when we were designing our project, and did nothing but criticize us on our work, even though we worked very very hard on the entire course.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
Knows his stuff.  Helpful, but boring and heavy accent

Untrustworthy and unprofessional. If you have the unfortunate experience of having him as your academic advisor, he will do nothing for you. In fact, he will go out of his way to sabotage you and sit by ideally while you figure things out on your own.
Excellent Professor! He actually cares about his students.
ever since he got ten-yr he's stopped showering and brushing his teeth.  It was hard to take him seriously before but now it's just impossible

eh. if he doesn't like you then good friggin' luck trying to do well. he has these team meetings though that are really helpful. he's an amazing artist and very inspiring but sometimes loses sight of the fact that we have 4 other classes to worry about too.

Seems like hes lacks communication skills. When he crits my work it seems like he lives in a different world. Does not understand that drawing is not the only class that students take and requires too much (quite pointless at times) work.
gotta love the Oat-man
I hate this class!! Im an engineer and no artist! I hate to draw, this guy and his assignments are a PDI nightmare, 26 drawings of styrafoam anyone??
His popularity is unwarranted.  Anyone who studied art before will not be impressed.  Dumb assignments with no point and no development.
What a cool dude, never a dull moment with him, gotta love his jokes!  Bit then again, his drawing assignments are ridiculously long and usually pointless and he normally doesnt even collect them.
Awesome Oatman. Absolutely Awesome.
Oatman. Gotta love him. Love to hate him.
Bring ear plugs - the man cant stop talking!
he is really cool, has great ideas and a great sense of humor.  sometimes talks too much but if you listen youll always learn or open your mind
No Comments
No Comments
Oatman is pretty cool.  He's a typical art teacher.. kinda out there.  He gives some weird assignments but he's always willing to help out or just chill with you in studio
Wack job, he is a cool guy with crazy ideas, but he needs ot be a little more down to earth, nad be a little less flighty/unrealistic
Cool guy.  Slides have a lot of extra information, which is good sometimes but can cloud the important points.  Tests weren't particularly hard.  The class wasn't much work overall.  Fun class.

It's hard to know what to study and what's important because his lectures are collections of tons of slides with random pictures of Tiger Woods thrown in.  The textbook is never used.  The class isn't a lot of work but if you make a small mistake on a test it can cost you bigtime.
good teacher but curved our class grades down because we did too well
No Comments

alot of his questions on tests seemed to be totally random...but he does give alot of opportunities to make up for doing badly on one test. i didnt like how every single topic we covered related back to dental implants. he would spend at least 30 minutes of every class talking about dental implants. get another example!

I agree with the ambiguous question thing. However, he always tells you exactly what is on the tests, and he gives tons of extra credit and makeup (take-home) exams if people do poorly the first time around.

Homework and test questions are ambiguous, and I am often left wondering what the question is actually asking. Dr. Brunski is a great lecturer, but the problems we work in class are either ridiculously simple or impossibly hard.

Although Brunski can be misinterpreted as uninterested, the man is a good teacher who learns  from his students.  As a matter of fact, most of his examples come from students.  I found out five years after I graduated that Dr. Brunski still uses a Jaw Model I constructed (out of cherry wood, mind you) to demonstrate loading conditions of dental implants to students in IEA.  I believe a good professor learns from their students.  Dr. Brunski is proud of what his students learn and show to him.
This class was a waste of time.  Brunski is useless.
he was great for IEA, but didn't give any direction whatsoever in BME design
one of the best professors for IEA. Explains material clearly and is always willing to help.
will help you if you ask for it. you'll definitely learn in his class
Awesome teacher.  Learned a lot.  One of the best you can get for IEA
lectures are a bit boring but informative.  Easy if you just sit there and look like your paying attention.  VERY helpful as an advisior.  Knows his stuff and is always willing to help.
Had him twice (for same class) and he's def the best you can get for IEA
not bad as an advisor, kinda knows what's going on
No Comments

His lectures barely cover any solid materials, often he would just make us perform "activities" for his personal entertainment (that included singing and dancing). Having spent a long time in the tech industry, I can tell you that he doesn't know anything about Information Systems, Business or Technology. An extremely racist and egotistical person.
So full of himself.  Projects were good in building soft skills but taught you zero hard skills or quantitative methods for solving business problems.
rating_tags: Participation matters--SO MANY PAPERS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Would take any and all criticism incredibly personal and would argue with students in class to make his point.  Never lectured, but assigned unclear group projects throughout the semester.  His tests were incredibly easy because of this lack of actual instruction.  Learned nothing but did boost my GPA.
rating_tags: Participation matters--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: One of the better management professors at RPI. He really knows his stuff and challenges you to better yourself. I'd recommend taking any class with him. Plus he assigned a project that was a HUGE resume booster.

Many students did not like for the reasons I liked him, actually. He brought us down to Downtown Troy and had us consult with local business owners utilizing the quantitative models we learned in class. He did not lecture that much which was fine with me. He is a practitioner and brings his experience to the classroom. One of my favorite at RPI.

Taking his MSA 640 at Central Michigan University - He must be different guy than these previous comments - found his examples in class as good practical personal experiences that gelled with lessons for practical learning.  I think previous raters on here were a little less apt for learning the real lessons he is teaching.  Very good professor.
DO NOT TAKE HIM
Dedicated to his work, make learning so much fun!!Respects everyone in the class. THE BEST OF THE BEST!!!! A true Professional

This professor is very easy but completely full of himself. His homework assignments are all about his previous experiences and how he single handedly saved the military millions of dollars or his uncle's business etc... Also unless you are a woman, he won't usualy give you much attention.

A wonderful professor who thinks outside the normal curriculum box.  Focuses on challenging projects, tests are easy.  Turns boring math into real life scenarios which are both practical and interesting.  Take a course with this professor if you like to think outside the box!
real life application of concepts taught
No Comments
No Comments

One of the coolest and most practical teachers I've had here at RPI. More time outside of class is required to do better on tests, but it's not impossible. Will go the extra mile for you. You'll actually find out what IT is about in this class. ;)

Spends most of class time talking about himself, and when he was in the army. Doesn't really teach any of the course material, which makes it hard to study for tests. Has a way of making you feel stupid if you don't know the answer to his questions.
No Comments

Very Interesting, gives great real life applications and example of classroom material, harder to study for tests (since he was not course coordinator). Great if you're looking to get more out of a class than just an A or B.
Feels like you're drowning all the time
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: Very high amount of work and a lot of studying required for tests only for him to throw curve balls randomly. Test was a completely different format than all the previous year tests that he provided and had several different subjects added that weren't gone over in homework. Avoid class if at all possible.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: Very poor instruction and very harsh grading. Unless you already knew the topic you're in trouble.

This class is likely fine for MATP majors. However, there are cases you can be forced to take this class even if you are in another major. If you're in this situation like I currently am, the course is near impossible as he assumes you have significant background information and you're probably going to be spending >20 hours per weekly hw.

He is one of the best professors I had. The class material is not hard, but you need to work on it for exams. hws are very helpful in exams, he will have one question from hws in each exam. He is also very helpful, and he is very patient as well. There is a programming project involves, great in simulation practice.
Best classes at RPI.

Extraordinarily smart man, but he wouldn't let you say that about him. Taking his NLP course was one of the most challenging experiences in my academic career, but well worth it in the end. The homework is difficult, but enlightening if you see it through. John's extremely accommodating and his door's always open if you need help - super nice guy.

I found Professor Mitchell's Models of OR class to be less interesting than his Discrete Structures class (which was awesome), but it is probably a worthwhile course nonetheless. I haven't personally conversed with him outside of class, but from what I heard he is very approachable and really wants you to do well.
He sounds like a teacher straight out of Charlie Brown's world, but if you can manage to pay attention, he does actually seem to be a sart man.
Brilliant man. Not very socialable. Dull lectures. Great guy. Teachs a lot of material. Do not take if you are look for easy A. Only take if you want to know the material.
Prof. Mitchell teaches the class Intro to Discrete Structures very well. Take his class.

He does enjoy teaching, but his style is a bit bland.  Proving things out is essential for understanding things like Discrete Mathematics, which means it's hard to follow at times, but he provides enough examples that it's easy to see what he's looking for.  This was his first year teaching Discrete, and I think he did pretty well.
Prof. Mitchell loves teaching and it shows. He cares about his students and he makes himself available for help.

You don't even go to class with this guy. Everything is DIRECTLY from the book. He doesnt even make his own review sheets. He uses Prof. Schmidt's. Come on guy, get motivated and show some interest in what you're doing or no one else will.
Very boring professor, was not motivated to go to class.  I wouldn't recommend him unless you want a class that is straight out of the book.

Mitchell's good, but nothing to write home about.  He teaches the Multivariable Calculus portion of the course really well, but since he actively researches in applied programming, he tends to go off on confusing tangents wrt Matrix Algebra.
His lectures are interesting and his policies are very fair. He makes his tests difficult, but he's nice and more than willing to help. He's one of the best professors I've had so far.

I didn't have him as a teacher for very long. Unfortunately, he died before the midterms in 2021. From what I gathered being in his class, he was caring but he was a hard-ass. A was a great math teacher and an even better person. Talked a lot about his family. He was very understanding. A good teacher that was unfortunately taken from us too soon.

Prof. Drew is a very nice guy. He enjoys teaching however he sometimes cant be helpful, specially in office hours. The material he taught was more his than Holmes' but the homework assignments were from Holmes' book. Overall he is good.

Professor was a clear but slow lecturer - I spent most my time pulling my hair out because I knew where he was going. Ocassionally makes mistakes and gets confused making bits of lecture confusing. Exams are pretty easy and very evidently based on material from recitation/lecture.

The materials covered on his tests are easy. The only problem is that he and his TAs are hard graders, and you might end up losing a lot of points because of small careless mistakes. Overall, he is quite funny, he tends to prove things, and his test focuses on lecture material, so pay attention and try to understand the concepts.

He's funny as hell during lectures!  He kind of stinks at arithmetic, but he does a pretty good job of explaining the concepts he wants you to know.  The tests are easy if you do the (non-required) practice homework, but I didn't realize that until the last third of the semester :(
He doesn't know how to explain anything.

Not exactly a bad guy, but STAY AWAY FROM HIS CLASS.  You have to write essays on every test with him in calc II, and his tests are pretty tricky.  If you're stuck with him, do all of the HW probs (even though they're optional) because the test questions are similar.  I would've bombed if it wasn't for our grad TA.
I went to two classes, drew is a nice guy and real smart, but not good at teaching, i dropped is class took kiehls class and got an A no prob, DREW is the WRONG choice
Only does proofs, the only reason i passed was because of our TA that had terrets.... ps Grades like a Swanz (that means not good)
He's an okay guy and makes the material relatively clear.
He's cute and always smiling..i like him!!
If I hadn't already taken Calc in high school I would have failed.  Don't take Drew.

He taught the material well and made sure to tell you what was going to be on his tests. The graders however were very harsh, although by the 3rd test they loosened up a bit. The class seemed to be harder than all the other calc sections, but those that earned there grades got them.

I'm sure he cares about his classes deep down inside, but it doesn't really seem like he's able to get across exactly what he's trying to do. BEWARE: He has this really hard grader FOR SPRING 2005. AVOID CALC II WHILE THIS GRADER IS STILL EMPLOYED... he is infamous. I got a B in the class.
By far the worst teacher iv ever had.  Basically he sucks.  He teaches us nothing and expects us to know everything
He just goes over problems and doesnt really bother to teach any thing.  and the tas are no help

I found this class very complicated, and although I thought Prof. Drew was friendly and all that, I just didn't understand what was going on. Our first exam was failed by most and took several weeks to grade. Aaagh!

Did little to make the dry stuff(statistics, evolution) interesting, but a great guy for the entertaining parts, i.e. the discussion of sex. Hilarious anecdotes, discussions in class can be entertaining. Knows his stuff & tries to focus on the more entertaining & relevant parts of the class. Projects are open-ended but painfully vague.

"Abnormal Psychology" - Sometimes, his lectures become a little dry and make you sleepy. But other times, they're really interesting. He's a great lecturer. Grade based on exams, pop quizzes, and case studies. Watch out, sometimes, there are consecutive pop quizzes! But still interesting class!
Had him for both Ab Psych and Human Sexuality.  While the lectures are powerpoints mimicking the text, he does his best to make them interesting.  Classes are definitely worth taking.
Great guy
good teacher...present class in an interestin way...
Amazing professor
I had him for both Abnormal and Human Sexuality.  While sometimes his lectures can be a boring repeat of the text, he is a very friendly and helpful guy!
Explained materials clearly, tried to make the course interesting to the students, been very helpful...
His lectures are pretty interesting and his tests aren't too bad.

You can tell from day 1 that he actually cares about the material.  He is kind, approachable, and knowledgable.  He's always willing to talk after class and very patient with students.  What else can you expect from a man who works at the health center&#6
He's a reasonably good teacher, but I didn't like the way he turned a human sexuality class into more of a biology class.
I love his sexy mustache!!
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
He's cool.  Not so clear on the specifics of class projects though.

Honestly, probably the best Strengths professor. Students from other sections would frequently visit his office hours! He is VERY determined to make sure you understand and visualize what you're doing instead of plugging and chugging. He has a fantastic way of explaining concepts and makes the content much easier. You can learn a lot from him!!
This guy knows his stuff. He really gets into the subject because he this is his life. The project in class is awesome. If you pay attention and get help from him, this class is easy.

Very caring and intelligent professor. You actually learn in his class and he's very approachable. The class is tough if you do not use the help resources and actually do the homework. Definitely the best Strength's Professor at RPI
Awesome guy!! Very nice!! and clear, takes time to explain and uses demonstrations..one of the best professors at RPI
great guy, extremely clear teaching!!!

Great professor! I had him for strengths, and he solves problems out for you step by step, and uses colors to make things clearer. I loved the class, and his tests are easier than other Strengths professors' tests. He's a good man, very approachable, and has a heart

Great professor! I had him for strengths, and he solves problems out for you step by step, and uses colors to make things clearer. I loved the class, and his tests are easier than other Strengths professors' tests. He's a good man, very approachable, and has a heart

great professor!  very helpful at office hours.  clear explaination.  actually cares, even though he has research stuff on the side.  his kids come out of the class KNOWING the material.  explains the overall progress/reasons of the course material as u go along.
Strengths can be a hard course, but Tarek put a lot into teaching the course. Great Professor!
AWESOME
AWESOME PROFESSOR!
He went way out of his way to help me make up late work, and he was a fairly clear lecturer, although he followed his syllabus very rigidly.

Abdoun is the Man! Probably the greatest teacher at RPI and believe me, I had alll the bad ones. The work was fun, made learning easy, learnt a lot thru examples, exams weren't difficult because you knew the material even if you didn't study. cheat sheet kicks arse!
Abdoun will help you anytime, even if he has to work around his schedule.  Very good lecturer, and he cares about his students.  A+ Prof.

Abdoun is the best professor i've had so far at RPI. he is truly interested in what he does, wants to be there, and is incredibly helpful outside of the classroom. his lectures are neat and organized, and he is very prepared. amazing teacher. take any and every class you can with him.

Abdoun is the best professor I've had at RPI so far. I highly recomend him in any class he teaches. He's clear, consise, and super fair. Also the most helpful prof I've had with regards to help outside of class hours.

Didn't explain the slides well AT ALL. Made me redo labs for "finishing too fast". Gave horrible advice on how to do better on exams. She told our class to focus on deep breathing. Oftentimes wasn't helpful at all. Also the test had VERY FEW back questions unlike in previous years where the entire exam were back questions.

Professor Wilke is a poor lecturer, hard to understand, and unsympathetic to students' knowledge levels. She's a harsh grader, expecting expert-level understanding. Exams were far tougher than past years, with averages in the 50s, yet no curve, support, or extra credit was offered. Overall, a frustrating and demotivating experience.

Good professor: doesn't rush through lecture slides, understanding, and very friendly. Personally, the lab activities didn't help me with understanding the content but that's a problem with the course itself. I relied heavily on the online textbook and back exams to get a thorough understanding of the content.
Reasonable amount of homework. Okay lecturer. Tests are standardized so it's the same for everyone, just do the back tests.

Aggressively competent in what she teaches. Very on top of things. Fair and accommodating if you are struggling on something or need a little more time. I enjoyed going to her class, which is saying a lot considering it was at 8 am.

I had Wilke for Honors Physics II Spring 2016.  She's underrated.  Very nice, straightforward person. She helped me a lot outside of class.  Very tough grader and expects a lot from her students.  Do the work, and do well.

Wilke really does try her best.  She communicates clearly despite her heavy German accent, and she'll help you if you ask for it. Physics I is a tough class, and you're gonna have some trouble.  Don't blame it on her though; she's doing all she can.  Also, she writes her "m"s weird and has some strange pronunciations, but they're easy to deal with.
8 in the morning makes it tough to stay awake, along with the style of the class.  Long derivations done out in class don't relate much to the homework or exams.

Last year was her first year teaching I-Mech, so I anticipate that in future years, her methods will improve. She taught straight from the textbook, and she writes the letter 'm' and 'n' with one extra hump, but other than that, the class was very easy(with no prior mechanics save physics I) and the hwk can be looked up online if you get stuck.

Don't know how this professor ended up teaching when she can't even solve simple physics problems. She spends too much time on unimportant parts of the lecture and then rushes over the important part. She loves to force people to attend the class for the whole 2 hrs even if you are done with all observations. She's not one to look forward to.
I'm not sure whether it's her or the subject that makes this course so dry.  Taking it at 8:00 AM at Carnegie may have added to the suffering.  She knows what she's talking about though.

So it seems like she's better at Graduate classes.  The class she taught was right out of the book.  You can basically get the same information from reading the book and some outside research.  Homework can be tedious at times, but isn't too hard conceptually.  Same with exams.  The examples are organized, and she does explain them.  Not horrible.

Expect to use your textbook a lot with Wilke's class. Almost everything she puts on the board is out of the book, along with hw and exam problems. She spends most of the time with examples instead of the core material. Read the book before class or else you won't learn much.
She did an excellent job covering the derivation from Jackson. Her final was a little rough, but other than that, she was a great teacher

boring class, but very organized and good notes given. sometimes she does a whole class where you break into groups to solve problems, which is a nice change. exams were hard, but reasonable. homework is reasonable considering its a grad level class.
You have to know German she tends to slip into her mother tongue...
really nice, and tries to help you as much as she can, but she is really really boring.  there is probably a better teacher out there for this class.
good class, very methodical in her teaching. good note-giver. difficult midterm exam. homework is semi-reasonable to difficult.

Aside from the fact that the class is difficult, Margarita is a queen. She's so sweet and responds to emails fast. I would often complete other work during orgo lectures but when I did pay attention, she was very detail-oriented. The exams and quizzes are hard but manageable, same with the homework. Chapter 6 is when it's time to lock in.

Dr. Snover is a wonderful, caring professor who truly wants the best for her students. She gives an absurd amount of extra credit on exams and quizzes, provides assistance with lab reports, and always allows students to make up exams without asking any questions. She is the antithesis of Dr. Ma, which made Orgo much more enjoyable than Gen Chem.

Dr. Snover and the way she formats the course is the only reason why organic chemistry is even tolerable and passable at RPI. Such a kind and sweet soul, and I loved both semesters I had her for organic 1 and 2.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: She is the most caring professor I've met. She will reschedule tests and quizzes when needed, and will straight up give you answers and processes when you ask during a test or quiz. She just cares that you're learning something and understand the material, not if you test well. Orgo with her made it fun, and entirely less stressful than chem 1
Excellent professor in every possible way. Very accessible inside and outside of class, motivating and encouraging students to succeed. Very detailed-oriented, easy to understand lectures.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: She is a wonderful lady. The lectures can be pretty dry and most students stop going as the course is so easy through achieve. She will also legit just tell you the answers on quizzes and tests sometimes. 10/10 would recommend, she's so accommodating and nice.

Amazing prof who gives wonderful feedback if you go to her with questions. She makes sure that you understand whats happening and really wants you to succeed. She gives a ton of crib sheets for tests and quizzes to you basically dont have to memorize anything. In her class, organic chemistry felt more fun rather than stressful.
Love this professor. So kind and helpful.

Dr. Snover is one of the nicest professors I've ever meet. I took her class during my freshman year. She was willing to listen to your concerns and more than ready to answer your questions regarding the lecture or the lab during office hours(might be pack with people).
Dr. Snover is very kind and is very helpful during office hours.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Test heavy

comment: Snover is an excellent professor. Her lectures are clear and very helpful in understanding the material. Tests can be challenging, but if you understand the back exams and hw it should be no problem. Would take again.
She gives out a lot of extra credit on quizzes and tests.

She is a very sweet and caring professor. Orgo itself is a lot of work but she makes it doable with always being there to answer questions and her office hours are very helpful. The online homework gets annoying so just get Chegg. Overall, much better compared to previous teachers of Orgo.
She is very sweet, the type of lady who probably bakes amazing chocolate chip cookies. Definitely available to ask questions, but the lectures are boring.

I took both Orgo I and II with Dr. Snover.  Orgo II was much more challenging than Orgo I. You have to study hard and not fall behind. Her exams were hard and long, especially the mechanism problems.  Her lectures are organized and thorough, with many examples. She made me want to go to class and as a result I love organic chemistry.

Took Orgo 2  with a different professor prior year and dropped because they were so awful. So glad they switched her to be the professor for this class. Solid professor, through and through. Always nice and approachable. Tests/quizzes were fair and often had bonus questions. Orgo is hard and annoying, but it was bearable with Dr. Snover.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Not a very good lecturer, but a nice woman. She has a slight accent, but is usually comprehendible. Orgo. I and II with her were both challenging.

She is friendly, professional, clear, easy to talk to/ask questions of. Orgo Lab I & II were my favorite subjects. She explains chemistry quite well and makes it easy and the labs fun. Extremely helpful. Will help you with experiments and give you hints for the homework problems and guide you through mechanisms from Professor Moore's class.
Tone of voice and inflection like a mad scientist. He doesn't like sophomores taking micro pchem; he thinks that they're incompetent. Get an A out of spite.
No Comments
his tests just suck...memorize EVERYTHING!!!!! or you will fail... im not joking

Avoide this professor if possible.  He’s a fairly nice guy, but a horrible professor.  If you’re an unfortunate CHME who has to deal with PCHEM II, and he is the only guy teaching it, take it at another school over the summer and transfer the credits if possible.
Talks slowly. Forgets what he's saying during lectures and has to refer to slides. Paces like a madman.
Worst Professor I've ever had. The only way to get a decent grade is to go to office hours. Hope he likes you.
Boring professor, class consisted of ten minutes of rambling, forty minutes of problems that we didn't know how to do and that we never went over, and an hour lab.

He talks SOOOOO SLOOOOWWWWLLLLYYYYY. And, when I said they I needed to get an 82 on the final to get an A. He said "You probably won't do it"!! It was awful. I think he was kidding and all... but sheesh. He's a fun guy to talk to after class. Oh and I got an A. So THERE!

Horrific teacher.  He does not understand that the point of teaching is to impart knowledge.  He was unable to clearly explain concepts in class, and then refused to explain them after class.  We would be referred to the TA.  Class focused almost totally on quantum physics.

Grades are based on whether you come to class or not!!!! His son admitted to this while ****!! He should be banned from teaching.  He presents material to be much more difficult than it is, won't give out lecture material, and the material he covers is different than in the book.  Warden's grade=F
Hasn't taught me much, and he truly does speak his own language... but it keeps recitation interesting. So what if he doesn't prepare us for the exams...
No Comments
Exams are meant to screw everyone over, not to determine understanding.   He can't explain the topics in a way normal people can understand.   Pretty much the bane of my existence this semester.
Lectures are unclear, won't give out lecture slides. Tests are difficult and topics covered in class differ from those in the book.
Speaks in a different language than everyone else! makes up his own terms!
Commonly unclear in his explanations.

If you pay attention in class and like to raise your hand, you will have a great time in his class. If not, you'll probably still have a good time. He is very understanding and remembers all his students' faces. I sometimes zone out in class but he uploads all the lectures so I could still understand most of the material.
Just an awesome guy. I would recommend any class taught by him.

Ben is def the best professor I've had here. The course content is pretty interesting, and the activities and videos are really engaging. He is really nice and there are few assignments but they are very doable. He grades pretty leniently and really cares about his students. Def recommend taking a class with him at some point while you're at RPI

I've taken both linguistics and cog sci with him in the past, easily best rpi prof (which tbf doesnt say much or really anything at all but he's still pretty good), he mogs everyone else, now if he's teaching a class w/ something else it might not be a 5/5 experience but he himself is a 5/5 prof, pretty lenient, good teacher, mostly light on work
Very engaging

Professor Ben, as he likes to be called, gave interesting lectures that often included videos and class participation to make it interesting. Biweekly quizzes reflect the lecture material. Gave us essentially free rein for final project topic. Easily approachable and understanding about DSS accommodations and in general.
Very kind, understanding, in-touch, and passionate. Very interesting lectures, assignments and tests were not very difficult but still engaging and interesting.
Super nice prof, very lenient with grading, only things you have to do are a few essay-like assignments and 2 quizzes every week

Very caring and easy-going.  Very well-prepared, fun lectures.  Doesn't waste your time.  You only have to write a couple very short papers throughout the semester and take open-note quizzes based on the lectures.  As long as you show up to class and pay attention, you'll have no problem getting an A.

weissman is my GUY. he is a great professor and i recommend everyone tries to take at least one of his classes. he cares about the content and about his students a great deal. he is extremely accessible out of class if you ever need help understanding a concept that he talked about. overall 11/10, great guy, great prof
This class is pretty easy, its a few essays and short homework quizzes

He’s a wonderful professor who really cares about his students. I did take his class when it was online due to covid but I have to imagine he’s the same way in person. Lecture slides are posted online and you can review the slides if you miss class and get pretty much the same info you would’ve gotten if you went in person.
Great prof. Very kind and fun. Personally, I definitely could have done better in this course.
Great professor, clearly loves linguistics, and is a great guy.

Dr. Weissmann is honestly one of the best professors I've met. He is hilarious and he made the class fun for all majors. I also loved how he discussed real life applications based on what we were learning. The class does require some work though, yet if you actually put effort in, you'll get an A.

Ben is great. Tests are online on open-book, made available at midnight on test day, you can start it whenever you want, but once you start you have 2 hours to complete. I always looked forward to class because the material was interesting and Ben is a fun guy, you should definitely take his class.

He writes everything on the overhead with varying degrees of explanation. He can clarify what he's teaching but can't answer in-depth questions. Quizzes & tests were straightforward, almost everything on them was in lecture-"required" readings were optional. Lectures went to the end of the period, labs often got out early, nothing ever ran long.
he talks quitly, fast, does not know how to teach. lecture usually has nothing to do with quiz or test.
unfair quizzes, prof cannot admit when wrong, never at office hours

Teaches the material well.  Quizzes can be a little tricky sometimes but they are usually fair. Labs are easy if you can figure out the main goal of the procedure.  Good guy.  Says "iron" kind of funny though and randomly stresses like, a single letter of a word.
Very interesting class. Come to class (on time) and pay attention. Very fair on quizzes.
Competent guy, knows his stuff.  Can be a bit dramatic at times, but if you don't let it phase you, it won't detract from the class.  Take notes, ask questions and you'll learn a lot.
very very very boring...class isn't too hard, if you can stay awake...has a tendency to run out of time and section falls behind on quizzes
Lectures well, class material is relatively straightforward, you need to pay attention in class to do well, and its hard not to sleep. back tests can guarantee you an A in the class.
teaches the easy material too in depth and has to skip the hard chapters because he runs out of time
Awful
Material was very clear and very straightforward; I didn't notice much of an accent.  Was helpful when needed, if gruff.  Just pay attention in class and do the work and you'll be fine.
beautifully structured classes. very knowledgeable.  still excited if you show interest.
Not an easy class but the professor explained things relatively well.  Somewhat heavy accent but understandable.  Cared about students' needs but made material sound more complicated.
No Comments
Nice guy, willing to help if you ask.  Seems harsh at first glance but if you take the time to talk with him you will find that looks can be deceiving
Good.  Funny.
100% test based, 25% for each, closed book only. Charlie was a great guy who made MAU a great class. Clearly lays out what will be on each test and doesnt recquire you to use excel or minitab.

25% homework, 25% test 1, 25% test 2, 25% final. Tells you exactly what will be on the tests. Homework is absolutely mandatory but he goes over almost all the assigned Q's in class as examples. Really nice guy. Lectures are boring but it's honestly the subject matter rather than the professor's fault.

He is brilliant but expects you to know too much..I have taking other statistic courses elsewhere and he makes it more difficult than necessary. You have to learn on your own. He is not great at teaching you the stuff, more of forcing you to keep up with him and all the accompanying statistics lingo. You then fall behind.
He is too quiet and makes paying attention hard even for good students. The tests were miserable and horrid. I worked extremely hard and dropped the class because he was so bad.
Took System Modeling, Great!

Malmborg is a good teacher. He puts up the lectures online so you can refer back to them later, and he goes over a bunch of example and homework problems in class which is helpful. Not a hard class, just pay attention in class and take notes.

Dr. Malmborg is one of the nicest people at RPI and also a very good teacher. If you take the time to care about the subject he will give you fantastic insight into not only the methodology but also real life applications of the topic being discussed.
Very helpful.   Really wants his student to understand the material

His curving method is unclear-the average *MIGHT* be pegged to a B-, he's not sure, good luck calculating your grade if you're well above/below that, he doesn't know either. The final was insane-it was supposed to take an hour, which was all we got, maybe 5 of about 100 students finished on time. Breezes through slides which explain very little.

Malmborg is one of the best professors at RPI. He provides many examples and he encourages questions. His tests are pretty hard, though. If you don't know the material cold, you won't have enough time to finish. Overall, he's a great professor.

Also had him for OR Methods. To put it simply, Malmborg is the man. He's always willing to help you out and he does a lot of examples to show you how things are applied. I think probabilities are a bit abstract, so examples are key for understanding how they're translated. Great Professor.

Easy class.  He explained things clearly and concisely and gladly answered any student questions.  Homework was graded very leniently, but tests were graded more strictly.  Class always ended early.  Would love to take another course from this professor.

Teaching method is sub-par.  Grading scale is unclear so you're left wonder the whole semester to find out how you make out.  Tests are timed to only 75 minutes.  Could actually use 2 hours to take the test.  Take home problems were the only highlight because you get unlimited time.
Grading system is a joke; teaching methodologies are unclear and vague.
Grading system is bad! Its based on Standard deviation.  Fact is you can get a 90% in the class and if everyone else gets 100% you FAIL!
Facilities and Design was a very good class. Malmborg was always willing to meet to further help a person understand.
He gives quizzes that have multiple answers and his course is a jumbled mass of content.

Lister is a great guy- you can tell he is clearly passionate about what he does. Lectures are interesting, tests and quizzes aren't too awful, plus homework is relatively light. Group presentation that is an easy high test grade. Grading scale is generous.

Professor Lister is a great guy. He can be bit scatter-brained, but that does not come across too much in class. I had Principles of Ecology with him and his passion for the environment is what made me want to conduct research with him for over three semesters. He uses a lot of pictures and videos in his lectures to make them more interesting, too.
Great lecturer, clearly loves what he does

Lister is very nice and accommodating. He knows the material well, but the subject it self is easy to get lost in. I liked the book, it was comical and realistic. It is not a text for those who seriously want to learn statistics and the theories behind it.  As a bio major it was a hoop worth jumping through and it could have been much worse.

Pros: gives study guides to students prior to exam, rarely used textbook so it saves students money, quick to respond in email if you have any questions, and lets class out early. Cons: Not clear in class, STELLA exercises are hard to follow, makes fun of students who ask questions during class.

Really great teacher.  Speaks english, actually cares about his students doing well and enjoying the material.  It's a super easy A if you just show up to class and do the homework which takes five minutes.  Before each test/quiz he posts an outline and if you fill it out with google you can do great.  If the average is bad he curves it.
Knows what he is talking about, very enthusiastic with the subject a bit space brained but overall a great guy and really cares about his students.
Professor Lister never curves the exam and quiz scores. However, it is not his fault that the course is badly designed. I would not recommend it overall.
Not his fault that intro to bio is a badly designed course, but he knows the material and can lecture pretty well. However, this particular class was extremely easy for his section.
Knows what he's talking about. The tests come from the homework, not the lecture. He gives an interesting lecture if you like biology. If you don't, invest in headphones, attendance is mandatory.
He doesn't lecture on what the tests are on. Architecture majors who have him struggle a lot. He uses a lot of pictures and videos in his lectures.

He doesn't lecture on what the tests are on. Architecture majors who have him struggle a lot. He uses a lot of pictures and videos in his lectures. There are in-class exercises so attendance is mandatory.
Super easy course to get an A. He's a well groomed ecologist, but not so great a lecturer. Class labs were fun. Boring lectures, but worth going to class.

He is a nice guy, but not a good professor.  He doesn't see that lectures might be confusing to a student.  The book could have been better, such as a real statistics book.  We didn't receive our first homework back until after the first test.  Overall the course was very easy even if you didn't fully understand the material.

Brad is a good guy. I had him for Intro to Bio with Gilbert too. Tag team teaching was never my thing, but he did a great job. Kept students interested with lots of pictures, videos and interactive things. Real nice guy. Easy tests, harder quizzes. Tons of points just for trying.

She is one of the best professors I have ever had. I had her for two semesters ( biocomp and tissue engineering), I wish she offered more classes. She is very smart and her resume is impressive ! She puts so much enthusiasm into teaching. Her classes are NOT easy. You have to work very hard for your grade and ATTEND to class.

Dr. Bizios was my advisor.  This woman was so passionate about how her students acheived, she yelled at me (yes, yelled at me) for not attending Grad School.  For whatever reason, I think she was right.  And even though I've learned through the school of experience about the medical device industry, I could have benefited more from an MS or PhD.
She isn't the most approachable professor (putting it nicely)...and she tends to be very defensive if you question her.  The class is really interesting to sit through, but her exams are REALLY HARD.

Test questions tend to be broad and ambiguous; in addition, there is no pre-defined rubric and points seem to be assigned randomly. MUST attend lecture to do well on the exams. Professor does care about the student but views most questions as personal attacks, and can come off as slightly arrogant. Grades are based on standard deviations.
Expects alot from students.  Tests are very hard, but class is entertaining.  Don't miss class, as everything is based off of lectures.
Terrible! Never shows up, just reads overheads.  If it's not on the overhead, she can't help you.  Tests very hard, with very low averages.  Don't take a class with Rena!!
She teaches only the stuff you'll need to know for the test.  She can be harsh sometimes, but I think she teaches well.  She expects a lot, especially in TBI.

She just copies quations from the book.  She doesn't seems to know anything except what's on her overheads.  Takes off points for no writing all cancellations in equations.  Seems satisfied with very low averages on tests.  Only showed up to teach for about 60% of the class times.  Not recommended.
She was only in class 60% of the time, replaced by some old guy.  Her notes were simply copied straight from the book.  Tests were ridiculously hard.

Her notes are just copies that she uses over every year.  It was very difficult for me to follow what she was talking about relative to the notes.  I thought it was a waste of my time to even go to class.
Fun
Great professor.  Very nice and helpful.  Liked the many example problems that were done in class.  Fair tests.
