I also took Professor Turiel for Calc 1 during the Fall 06 term.  I think this was his first semester at RPI, so I gave him some slack.  Even taking that into consideration, it was painful to try and focus on the lecture.  Fortunately, I took both Calc 1 and 2 in high school so it was all just a review.  Some topics weren't covered before exams.
Had this guy in Fall 06 for Calc  1.  He was pretty bad and hard to follow in lecture.  I had taken Calc in high so I knew everything he did.  He was pretty bad too.  Painful to listen to.

Lectures are geared to math majors more than a general class. Sometimes didn't cover something before quizzing students on it (the TA would cover it in recitation before the quiz) Do the homework and you'll do fine. Didn't understand students' questions in class without being walked through the students' problems, which took like 5 minutes each.

Dude was useless...  He used "lemmas" which are kinda like theorums...  but not...  and everything he said made no sense...  i was extremely lucky that i had taken calc in h.s.  I leanred more in Schmidt's review of calc I in calc II than anything from this guy...

I found Schwendeman to be a great prof, his lectures were always very clear, and he always made sure to do many examples, which helped my understanding of the material. His tests were difficult, however partial credit was somewhat on the generous side. The only part I didn't like was how 3 multiple choice problems on each hw could tank your grade

Extremely knowledgeable on the topic and accommodating with his office hours. However, his class is very lecture heavy and the tests and homework are graded very harshly with little or no comments on where you lost points. In spite of the challenges he actually wants you to succeed and will do his best to convey the knowledge to everybody.
Prof Schwendeman is a great guy. He will go out of his way to meet with you if you jut ask for help. The material itself is what makes the class so difficult.

He is a nice person however his lectures are droning and hard to follow especially since the material is difficult. The only grades in the course are hw and tests which is nice per week but can really affects your grade if one category is low. He claimed to be understandably lenient towards the hw deadline, but from experience he is definitely not
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Absolutely awful lecturer. His lectures are so boring, I have had to leave them prematurely multiple times because my brain was overloaded and I couldn't sit there listening to him drone on anymore. I wish he would spice up the lectures because I have just read the textbook instead of attending sometimes and enjoyed that comparatively.
Really good at teaching really knows what he's talking about. speaks really clearly and makes really good notes in lecture
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Amazing professor, and was a very good lecturer
Awesome professor  best I've had at RPI so far. Super charismatic and charming and really helps students understand the material.

Had him for diff eq. Definitely has the toughest tests for  that class, but he's the best teacher for it. He's explains things really well, and his notes in class make sense. His lectures, along with a bit of the textbook made the class a breeze. Hands down the best professor I've had at RPI!
I enjoyed his class. Homework was relevant to the tests and wasn't too much to handle.
Sometimes homework may annoying, but overall is good

If you take Diff Eq with this professor, be prepared to put in a lot of work. He focuses more on theory and doesn't do a lot of examples, so when you sit down to do the homework it can be frustrating trying to turn that theory into working knowledge you can solve problems with. Still, he's a very nice and approachable guy, and a decent lecturer.

Clear lecturer, engaging.  Spends too much time on theory and not enough doing examples.  Homework with problems out of left field that he didn't go over at all in lecture.  Textbook not very helpful.  Also throws in test questions that you were given no related problems on homework.  Not recommended.

Really nice guy, tries to test you one what he teaches you, incredibly helpful in office hours, good notes in lecture. He's really boring but thats more the fault of the subject than the professor. Worst thing he'll ever do is not accept your homework late.

I have taken two classes with Professor Kupferschmid and they have more than exceeded my expectations. He puts 100% of his effort into making his classes effective, fun, and fair. He is probably the most organized professor I've ever had, cares about his students, and constantly improves his classes based off student feedback. Amazing professor!
Great Professor. Enjoyed taking his class.
Professor Kupferschmid is the most organized person I've seen.
An excellent teacher. Helpful professor. The course was very well structured. He is just perfect in all.

Although the course material was complex, Professor Kupferschmid showed a strong understanding of the material and presented it in lecture in a manner that made learning fun, easy and engaging. He was always happy to help with any kind of question and made doing well in this class very achievable for any student willing to participate.

Mike (he prefers to be called Mike) is the best professor I've had on his campus. His attention to detail in his lectures is impeccable. Ample opportunities for extra credit and he makes going to class enjoyable. I definitely recommend taking any class with him if you can!
He is the best Professor I have had at RPI so far. He is extremely caring and puts a lot into his lesson plans. If you can take a course with him!

I love Mike! He makes operations research a lot of fun and engaging. His grading policies are extremely fair. Extra credit is given by handing in assignments early, and the further along you are in the class, the more credit you get! One of my favorite classes and professors to date.
Wonderful teacher! Explained everything clearly, was super organized, and made sure you understood the material. Available at office hours. Overall, one of the best teacher's i've ever had.

This is a quite easy class, even for students who are not math major. The professor will illustrate all the things slowly and clearly in class, all you have to do is to spend no more than half an hour a week to finish the homework. He gives a lot of extra credits, it is really easy for you to get an A if you attend class.
Yes

This professor is excellent. He explains everything in class just about as clearly as could possibly be. He makes a point of calling on specific people in class to make sure everyone is keeping up. The grading is very merciful, with extra credit being given for work turned in early. He's most interested in you actually learning the material.

The best professor I have ever had. He gives crystal clear notes, and explains things until every student understands. He wants you to do well and understand the material at the same time. No exams - just homework and quizzes that you are allowed to retake if you bomb one. TAKE THIS PROFESSOR!

Absolutely one of the best professors I've seen at RPI yet, right up there with Prof. Schmidt and Holmes.  His syllabus and lecture notes are very organized and easy to follow.  His grading system is very lenient and he is more than willing to help students in and out of class.  Lastly, you actually learn the material and get something out of class

Very clear and concise professor. Lectures were pre-recorded and not hard to follow, however he had a makeshift syllabus and took most info from a professor at another college. Nevertheless, his "live lecture" was used primarily for office hours (no mandatory attendance) and the class was only homework based (no exams) which made it a breeze.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things

comment: Incredibly difficult class. Isaacson helps you through it, though. The material is very thick but very beautiful. His lectures are solid and he is very willing to help you in his office hours -- do him the courtesy of solidly knowing the math vocabulary you need to ask your questions.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: He's pretty good. added a lot of interesting background to stuff. His stories are excellent. But we did not make it nearly as far as one would hope.

Worst teacher thus far. He gives you 5 multiple choice question tests and has no room for partial credit. His lectures were hard to understand, he assigned a ton of homework, and to top it all off, the TA was the worst thing I have even seen. Do not take him for Intro to Diff Eq.

multiple choice tests are awful... 5 questions with no opportunity for partial credit so one small mistake will cost you 20% on a test.  He is not clear while lecturing, giving you all the complicated theory but does not work out or solve any problems like what is on the homework or tests.  Do not take him for Diff Eq!
Multiple choice tests, no partial credit, drop a negative and you are down it an 80 no complaints. Ridiculous amount of homework

does only theoretical examples, never actually plugs in numbers to the equations. skips many steps, does integration in his head rather than write it out on the board. tests are 5 multiple choice questions, no partial credit.

This guy is horrible diff eq teacher, he uses ridiculous theoretical and unclear examples which dont help you understand the material. He assumes everyone in the room is as smart as he is so everyone ends up completely lost.
nice guy, interesting lectures, but the worst prof for intro to differential equations ever. strongly suggest NOT taking this course with him.

Favorite Quotes: "10 greats" : includes Euler, Newton, Maxwell, Gauss, Fourier (borderline), Bernoulli (full family)...; Class is more interactive than other professors; has his own syllabus.. dont bother asking
Excellent teacher. Clear, well put together lectures and reasonable tests. Very helpful both in and out of class. Amusing sense of humor and interesting stories.

Everything went real well...got an "A" in the course...he even asked me if he could photocopy my notes from the course!  Then, he gave me a very medocre letter of rec. for graduate school...seems as though he did not even bother to see what grade I got in the class!!!
really good class. excellent lecturer. he involves students in the lecture. gives good notes. makes it interesting.
wicked nice guy!!

Outstanding instructor and lecturer, extremely knowledgeable and caring for her students. She will get to know almost everyone's name in the class, especially those who participate in lecture. Tests are very fair, but there is an unbelievable amount of fairly difficult homework. Overall worth the difficulty and time, I learned a lot in this class.

Overall Prof. Borca isn't a terrible lecturer, but she's not great either. For a three credit class, expect about four homework assignments and two quizzes per week. You will be doing heat transfer homework of some kind almost every night. Most of the homework is done on Wiley Plus as well, so TAs/Prof don't grade the HW. (so no partial credit)

Prof. Borca taught this class using a more involved approach than most classes and, as a result, the material was more thoroughly explained. Lectures were clear and informative, and contained both lecture material and worked examples, which were both helpful. Class was very time intensive, but if you put the work in, you will get an A
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Group projects--Clear grading criteria

comment: Heat Transfer is difficult, but the prof makes it infinitely better. The most important thing I can say is that it's obvious she cares about her students and their ability to learn the material. Easily accessible outside of class as well- answers emails super quickly!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Group projects

comment: As far as lecture goes, she's pretty average. Not very helpful in office hours. Projects are frustrating since she doesn't clearly define the deliverables.

Heat transfer is HARD and Professor Diana is a hard professor too. However, she is very knowledgeable about the material and really cares for all of her students. Homeworks and projects are very rigorous but they are designed as if you were in the industry. You will be frustrated but if you can crank out the work and work with TA's, you'll be fine.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Group projects

comment: She is the best professor I have had at RPI. She actually cares about her students and actually want them to succeed. She sent two students home one class to go rest after they pullled an allnighter.

Most of your grade is the project. The project is a great experience and requires intuition, assumptions and decision making skills in the field of heat transfer. It is supposed to simulate industry. It also requires a lot of communication, creativity, and initial assumptions that you may not be comfortable making. Great experience overall.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Fantastic professor and fantastic course. Hard work, but nothing will prepare you for industry better. Take any opportunity you can get to be taught by Prof. Borca-Tasciuc; she is simply the best of the best.

Awesome, would recommend her to anyone. She is a ton of work but genuinely cares about her students' success and is a great teacher. So far, she's the only professor I've had that's made an effort to learn her students' names.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: It was definitely lecture heavy with lots of expected prior knowledge. Aside from the difficulty of material we were learning, the project required at least 4 hours a week and sometimes required 20+ hours for milestones. The take-home exam was the hardest test I ever took. Overall, though, she is incredibly helpful and teaches thoroughly.
Very good at explaining material. If you put in the effort you will succeed.

GREAT! Tests are open-book, notes, laptop + are easy! She gives out extra credit every class! Clear communicator, organized + receptive to feedback! That said, be prepared for a quiz + challenging homework EVERY class (drops lowest of each) + that the final was hard, but honestly she's one of the best teachers at RPI! In fact, I'm taking her again!
She is awesome! Tests are easy, final was a bit harder than the rest of the exams, but she does everything she can to help you succeed. I absolutely recommend her.
Great, easy going professor, easy for A. May be hard to actually get learning about certain things, but ask if you are really interested.

He is very enthusiastic, helpful, entertaining and easy going, he gives great feedback and make sure everybody feels good about what they've made. To be honest, I wish this class is harder, more group projects and homework would be way more helpful. The content of this class feels disappointingly shallow, the history part is interesting tho.
Igor is very enthusiastic, helpful, entertaining, and easy going. The cares passionately about the subject and it shows. Great class overall, would highly recommend.

Took Hacktivism with him in Fall 2015.  He's a unique teacher with a lot of enthusiasm, not to mention a lot of connections with others who are doing very interesting things.  His class can tend toward being overly unstructured but there's a potential to get a lot out of it, especially if you're not accustomed to taking disussion-based classes.

Here's what you do for the entire semester: make a short film. Like 5 minutes. You don't HAVE to go to class, but Igor is awesome so you'll want to go to class. Go to some classes, help people with their videos, and make an okay video and you'll get an A.
I love his video class, and he's awesome.
Great Professor, interesting ideas and keeps class entertained.
extremely interesting chap
cool guy take the course

Igor is the best teacher I had at RPI.  I would venture to say every student, regardless of major, should take a class with him.  I found every othe teacher in the EMAC department to be useless except for Igor.  Keep up the good work, buddy!
Cool teacher, cool guy, great class
No Comments
Igor is one of the coolest professors at RPI!
No Comments

I came from CSCI4390; this is the second course with him and my last course at RPI. The materials and homework are tough, but he tried his best to explain them step by step. He is being real helpful after class. Highly recommended.
participation gives extra credit but was not mandatory; simple class but unfair grading scheme with taking the minimum of hw and test grades; not much hw, takes a lot of studying to do well
Pretty standard CS course. Open book tests. Good lecturer

I had Zaki for both Data Mining and Intro to Algorithms. I only took DM because he was such a good professor. His lectures are well organized and easy to follow. He's very understandable and the examples he goes through are helpful. The exams are somewhat difficult but on par with most classes at RPI. One of the best professors I've had here.

Lectures are often aimed at people interested in the topic, so they go beyond required material. The required textbook is posted online (with lec. notes). Tests are directly from the text examples. Difficult material but a very fair grader. I got nearly full credit for answers I mess up a little. Very responsive to online questions too.

Good professor. His exams and homeworks are lengthy. The bad part is exams are more number crunching type than real problem solving (well but the limited time of exams also makes it difficult to give good problems to be solved in limited time). I enjoyed the course overall though.

A perfect example of the horrible teaching at RPI.  Clearly unprepared for his own lectures, unable to assign clear homework or projects, could not answer student question, and even broke the school rules by giving a pop quiz when the possibility was not listed on the course syllabus. Truly horrible
very clear in class, explains concepts very very
Zaki was a horrible DB Sys professor.  Did not explain concepts clearly at all, and grading took forever.

The lectures were pretty boring and Zaki was not good at clarifying some of the difficult concepts.  The book used for this course was also poor since it had overeasy examples which did not help with the difficult homework exercises.  Grading took forever

Great teacher. Prepares for his class. Very reasonable in terms of projects and makes sure everyone learns the material. Always open to ideas and encourages research. Not for the weak student who whines.. For serious students he is the man.

Worst.  Professor.  Ever.  Was unable to explain the requirements of the term project, changed the requirements 4 or 5 times, was incredibly slow to respond to requests for clarification and assistance, dismissed all criticisms by saying "the student

Zaki was terrible for Database Systems, his lectures were dry, didn't consider how long or difficult projects would be, and didn't listen to the class even when they created a petition against him.  I would advise against taking a class with him

Wacky Zaki is awesome!  The best teacher I have had at RPI.  I took Data Mining with him and he actually prepared lessons and taught them - a rare thing at RPI.  Take a class with him, you won't regret it.

Morris taught one of my favorite, and most practical courses at RPI -- optoelectrionics. He comes from decades of industry research and is an expert's expert in practical and applied optics, which shows through in his lectures. I found him soft spoken, but fun to listen to and very knowledgeable. His course was tough due to the challenging content.

Great guy. The lecture is structured very well. Constantly checks to make sure everyone understands the content and happily goes over it if someone doesn't quite understand it. The class itself has a lot of work outside of class, but if you do the readings and homework you should be fine (Go through back exams before test).
Worst professor ever. He gives horrible explanations and argues students about their grade making it always lower than it should be!
Prof. Washington is a very clear and concise professor.
Terrible. Doesn't really know what he is talking about. Can't answer questions that well.

Good professor for physics 1. The course is really determined by the coordinator, but Washington teaches the material clearly. Other students complained about their grades, but if you look around half the class is on AIM on their laptops. Speaks clearly, which you would think would be a requirement for a professor, but sadly is not.

He was one of the best professor I ever had.  He always tried to make sure everyone understood what was going on, and encouraged people to visit his office hours.  Very easy to understand.  Definately Recommend him.
really nice guy, best course i have ever taken
I like him... but not the class or the way it's taught
Explained the material pretty well.

For upper level classes, he is pretty good.  He knows what he is talking about from industry experience, and is very helpful.  Gives reasonable, though long HW.  His grading during the semester is weird, especially tests, and he then curves all the grades at the end to make some sense out of them.
No Comments
A 20 min lecture each 2 hr class full of unclear concepts + a terrible activity = no learning.
No Comments

I thought she was a great presenter of class material and made it entertaining and interesting. She was not reachable when I needed assistance or questions regarding homework assignments. (She would give her email and number but never responded when trying to contact her)

Could not apply class information to real life situations outside of her own examples, did not actually read through papers, smiles and laughs while she says unflattering things about other professors and your classmates, will succeed in her class if you seek her help, generally gives  broad, useless advice (for instance, "differentiate yourself").
I would not take this class with her again. I enjoyed data-basing before taking her class, but she made it seem tedious and annoying.
speaks to fast goes off topic, air-head, conceited, flaky

I had class with Lael in 2004 and in 2005. one of the most influential professors i had in my shaping my career. She is tough, and mad examples of me numerous times in class but i deeply appreciated her thorughness. She knows what she is talking about and is passionate about teaching, overall excellent professor, not an Easy A, but you will learn.

very excited about the material she teaches but doesn't always do a great job of explaining things. very willing to help outside of class, though and if you utilize that, you'll do great. otherwise, the tests are a lot of memorization and the project is just showing up to class & struggling with it.

An average professor and I think she takes this class for granted.  She seems to prefer to teach CIS than DRM.  She doesn't teach that good. Her teaching syllabus and materials were not 100% ready yet and disorganized when i took her class; which made it harder to study for the class.
She is your mother, your father, your sister, your brother, your best friend, your dentist, your neighbor, your taxi driver and your personal assistant all rolled into one

She is a really awesome professor, sometimes alitle unclear, but she will help your figure it out.  always willing to take time to help you with problems.  Extreamly cool, i highly recomend her for CIS.  Also some sweet stories too.
She is mad cool. She loves teaching and is really interested in her students.

She's often unclear and leaves the class confused, but by the end of the semester I felt that I had learned a lot.  She lets you figure it out on your own but guides you when you ask for help.  You'll definitely learn practical stuff in her class.
She's a great teacher.. very enthusiastic.. it's hard not to pay attention in her class

When I took the class, I was excited at first, but the that slowed. I kept working, however, and put in some effort. Now that I am working, I realized how much I actually did learn in this class. You WILL use this is when you leave RPI. Lael is great!!!!!
She has the knowledge in Business, but know nothing in technology. She will be a great professor in HIPO 1 and 2, but she cannot teach any MIS courses.
Focuses on design and community UX. The course is really interesting I left with a great portfolio piece.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Gives good feedback

comment: Focuses on UX. Pretty good. Enjoyed the class.

Just finished the course and I can tell you this class is awesome. We did real world work and I think made a huge impact with the project. Dowdall really believes in remaking the course every semester and is really good at teaching design in a approachable way. Really makes you think and write. Highly recommend.
I know that he is new I think. I don't know. I really liked the class. Defiantly a philosophy person.
Cool guy cares about his students and the environment. I would highly recommend. The projects are really fun and pretty easy.
Amazing and interesting class. We did really cool projects.

I get it's not his fault he gets 8am class slots but when you do get that, and you know your class is a writing class at an engineering school, why in gods name do you go crazy over attendance? Seems like a nice guy but I dodged going to class without my grade suffering so idk, others have said he rants over useless/boring stuff.
rating_tags: So many papers--Graded by few things

comment: Seems to work hard to make the material cutting-edge and creative. Was my favorite class. Definitely based in theory. Sometimes lecture was confusing.
It was writing heavy but interesting
8am attendance mandatory yapper
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Dr. Dowdall definitely cares about the material he is teaching and the students in the class, but I think he just didn't have a clear vision of what the class was going to be when he started. Overall the class was very easy, so as long as you put in the effort you will do well. Expect the class to be less UX focused and more humanities focused.

At the end of the semester attendance ended up being weighted as 50% of our final grade. This was super unfair to us because it wasn't even mentioned on the syllabus. Participation was mentioned however, it was only said to be worth 15%. On top of all this, it is an 8:00 am class.

He doesn't seem to know much about what he is teaching and is very unorganized. He also never responds to emails. He calls out attendance at the start of the 8 am lecture for the first 20 minutes. One time I emailed him that I was sick and couldn't make it to class, and he ignored my email and lowered my attendance grade anyway.

Most boring professor I've had and he has no sense of his audience. He always has to go the extra mile to make class annoying and bordering on unbearable. He's trying to emphasize writing, rhetoric, and philosophy in a class of IT students.. this is not the class we signed up for
This class does not live up to its name what so ever. This is more of a class about the issues he finds important when considering politics rather than effectively teaching about UX design.
He claims to be teaching HCI, but the content he covers is not related to HCI at all. I don't even know if he is qualified to teach this course, his profile says he is an environmentalist

He's a great guy and super passionate about his work. He definitely tailors Geo 1 toward his field of geophysics, which means it's probably harder than it with most professors. Lots of memorization, but that's kind of the nature of intro classes with lots of jargon. Very complete study guides to quizzes and exams, and a good curve at the end.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: The material is not hard. However, his way of teaching makes it hard. You have to remember every single detail to get good grades.
To be honest, his notes are really bad. Lack of logic.
This person has no idea about teaching. His notes are terrible
waste of time

no one goes to his class except on exam and quiz days. His quizzes and exams are bad. No practice questions to work on at all. If you don't memorize every single word in his notes. You always loss points. He turned his class into a meaningless game of memory.
He doesn't know how to teach.
His class is hard, and outside of my interest, but he's a really great lecturer with clear passion for the subject, and I genuinely enjoy his class even though I'm not doing so well in it.

Roecker is a great professor, always has cool geo-in-the-news-flash where he talks about events in the news and connect them to class material.  Knows his stuff for sure, lots of quiz but tell you what he will ask beforehand, well, he guides you.  The other prof (Abrahano) and the TAs are all cool, too.

really enthusiastic, shares info about common features and relates the science to stuff you actually care about and have always wondered about.  quizzes and tests are doable because he gives you good review sheets.

Interesting class, great guy, nice TAs.  Prof Steve is always pleasant, enthusiastic, and in good spirits.. that extra edge that keeps me attentive in a morning class.  He has a good sense of humor and appreciates the same.
Great professor.  Knows his stuff and you'll learn a lot.
Better field teacher than classroom teacher, but has a lot of experience and if you pay attention you can learn a lot.

Nice guy, but he never seems to know what's going on in class... always out in the field doing research.  Lecture notes were overly complicated, tests ALL FILL-IN (and about ~60-70 fill-ins at that), so it comes down to a game of memorization.
make everything tedious and futile, make me feel Sisyphean. A text-to-speech machine can almost do the same, and without the terrible jokes.
Really goes out of his way to make sure he can explain concepts in a way that you understand

Data Structures in hard no matter what. His lecture's are ok, but you can skip as long as you read the notes. Homeworks can take a very long time and can be challenging but often have curves (same with tests). As long as you aren't too overloaded with other classwork, this class should be ok.

He isn't a great lecturer, just reads from the notes that he didn't write. Doesn't actually code things in lecture. Only reason to go to lecture is for the iclicker questions. He also doesn't hold a lot of office hours, and most of it is for homework help not actually grasping the concepts help. I am retaking with Cutler in the Fall.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--Tough grader

comment: I really love Buster a lot. He's the best professor ever I've ever had. What a guy!!! LOVE data structures!!!!! <3

"He's a new hire and lacks experience. He reads directly from the lecture notes that he didn't write. At times he visibly shows displeasure at having to teach." This is pretty misleading. He has a LOT of experience, just not at RPI, and he shows "displeasure" because he disagrees with professor Cutler on certain things. He is a great, kind teacher!

I took him for Data Structures last semester and Computer Organization this semester. He's a new hire, but he's very knowledgeable and cares about his students. His lectures are so-so (very example and iClicker heavy), but his tests and labs are well-structured.

Still learning to be a teacher, his classes are worth a shot if it suits you. One good aspect is that he tailors the class to his current student body, making sure no-one falls behind. Unlike others who bring students down for the bell curve, he makes a visible effort to help people so no one lags behind.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: A new professor, so I do cut him some slack, however he was very unprepared for lectures. He read directly from notes that he didn't write, for iClicker questions he was extremely vague on the explanations, and sample code was poorly explained. Often times he seemed flustered. For his sake and everyone else's, I hope he gets better w lecturing.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Not a good instructor, its a mistake to take his class. Nor is he as helpful as pretends to be. Assignments are vague, teaching material is bamboozled. A new hire and it definitely shows.

He was new, but he definitely got better as he went through the semester. Lecture could use some work, his style also personally didn't suit me. Not the best organization as far as material covered in lecture and what is on the labs/homework. Very helpful on Piazza.
He's a new professor to this course but he did really well during lectures. This course tends to be easier by semester but the homework and exams are still very intensive.
Anyone rates 1 point only means he/she cannot pass data structures, it does not mean Holzbauer is a unqualified professor.

He's a new hire and lacks of experience. He reads directly from the lecture notes that he didn't write. At times he visibly shows displeasure at having to teach. Exams are tough and homework can take more than 30 hours a week but this is typical for Data Structures since it is one of the hardest classes in the major. Assignments are often unclear.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: Professor Willemain is a wonderful professor who expects you to actually do work and learn. If you put in the effort, you will learn more from him than from anybody else on the RPI campus. Fantastic professor!

The only way you're going to pass this professor's class is if you took a statistics course previously, or if you live in his office (literally). His tests are largely based on how well you can use Minitab, which he does NOT use in class often, and his lectures after the first test are completely useless. He always teaches the T-F 8:30am section.

His classes are hard, as they should be, best professor I've had at RPI. He expects you to work but the classes are very rewarding if you do. The tests aren't like what is covered in class because you have to think which is a plus. Very knowledgeable about his field. Professors like him are the reason you pay to go to RPI and not other schools.

One of the best professors RPI has to offer. Would have hated to have him for an introductory course like MAU, but for advanced topics like Stat. Analysis or Applied Regression - fantastic. You MUST read and he expects that you have read the chapter prior to class. Always helpful in ofice hours, he wants to show how the topics are used in real life

IMHO, he did a good job.  I took AP Stats in high school, and found this course very straightforward.  Just go to class and do the back tests the night before the exams and you should be fine.  There is a 10-15pt curve.  Very knowledgeable, but expects you to work.  If you have questions, go to office hours and he *will* help you.

Prof Willemain is one of the most intelligent professors I've ever met at RPI.  He's very articulate and incredibly passionate about the subjects he teaches.  Overall, I'd highly recommend him to anyone - though, it will be your responsibility to ask questions if you have them.

Albeit being extremely knowledgeable about his subject, he is a very difficult person to learn from. He is very passionate about statistics, but almost to the point where it is discouraging to those who do not understand to ask a question. If you can take the class with a different professor, it is highly recommended.
Pretty good...sort of hard, very helpful at office hours.  Cares about student's using info in real world

One of the best professors I've had at RPI.  Very passionate about his subject. He is extremely supportive of students if they want to learn.  If you need help in a class, or advice about something, he is more than happy to talk.  But be warned, he expects you to actually think in his class.  You have to work to get an A.

Boring as anything but you have to go to class because the textbook makes no sense.  Really you just have to go to learn the computer program.  Gives quizzes every lecture, so unless you want to miss that part of your grade you have to go.

Useless going to class. No effort to portray the material across to the students. First exam and first homework assignment were not on material taught during lectures. Would recommend finding another professor if possible.
Very hard to comprehend.  He knows so much about statistics that he probably invented it, but he certainly doesn't know how to teach.
I was in his MAU class. He didn't following the textbook and his exams are fair if you do your study.

Susan gives high school teacher vibes- always checking in with you and genuinely caring about you. She is great for the Genome and You inquiry class and I hope to have her again in the future. Make sure you study for her exams but if you put effort in, she will reward it!

She is extremely caring about her students and always asks how we're doing. The class is extremely easy and before tests just look over the lecture slides. Sometimes the lectures were a little boring but there was a lot of interesting material! Would definitely recommend her class!

Dr. Smith is the most caring professor I've had yet, repeatedly pushing deadlines back if she learned that her students' other classes had a lot going on. Her course is highly engaging, and I never struggled to pay attention in class. All assignments are fair and reasonable, and her grading is not harsh in the slightest. Highly interesting course.

Professor Smith was incredible for Science Misconduct. Her course was engaging, the workload was fair, and Professor Smith led great class discussions. Her passion for the subject rubs off on the class, and she gives fantastic advice with your presentation and papers. I suggest everyone take this class, as science ethics are important to learn.

This class you are going to learn a lot about hard topics, but this is a class I would recommend to anyone. Tests are easy as long as you show up and participate in class, open note so make sure you take some. Otherwise there were a few assignments the big kicker is the final paper. As long as you do a draft like she asks you'll get it done.
Great lectures. Super fun and easy to understand. Will be more classes with her later.

Not only is Dr Smith very knowledgeable, but she really does care about her students. She always checks up on us at the beginning of class. Her feedback is very helpful, and she makes every lecture interesting. I also don't think she's a tough grader at all, and she's definitely willing to help out if you need it!

She is the absolute best! She did an amazing job, especially considering that she wasn't even meant to teach this class and got dropped in as the prof 2wks into the semester. She's smart, honest, and incredibly caring - she genuinely wants you to learn and understand the material, and she makes sure you know how to apply the info to the real world.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback

comment: Her Genome and You class was very fun and professor Smith is very good at what she does. The class taught me a lot ethical problems surrounding advancing technology and the human genome. Very informative class and I look forward to taking her bioethics class in a later semester.

Easily the best professor I've had at RPI. Genuinely cares about her students, is flexible with deadlines, and is a moderate grader. Is full of information and will definitely give interesting lectures about relevant material. 10/10
Absolutely amazing professor, best professor I've ever had. Cares about students wellbeing in and outside of class. Learned so much, incredibly interesting lectures.

i love dr. smith. the material she teaches is fantastic and is definitely needed at RPI. she is super caring, understanding, and her classes are easy to engage in. you'll have to be able to write a good paper, but i recommend her classes to everybody.

Dr. Smith is fabulous! What a great course. Lectures cover a lot of information but are very interesting. Attendance not required but I often looked forward to coming to class so I went. Tests are of average difficulty, pretty easy if you study, and she has extra credit questions. Some writing and reading.

It is clear that she loves what she teaches and has a real passion for the subject. I would describe her grading as tough but fair. If you don't know the material, you don't know it. She assigns a few books to read some chapters from. It is not mandatory that you read them, so don't stress. But reading the chapter will help with participation.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: The professor is fantastic and was well versed on the subject. It is an online course but very well organized. I especially liked how he kept tabs on each student, pointing out students due to their lack of participation. He was extremely engaging and did a tremendous job given the circumstances.

The webex classes were effective and engaging while the embedded quizzes in the video lectures changed how I actually retain knowledge! I like that the professor requires everyone to open camera, so the class feels very engaging.

This blended format helped me a lot with learning the content and engaging in class. Being able to watch the video and pause or rewind helped me to take better notes and better understand the material. I would love if this blended format could be implemented in further similar classes at RPI.

Great professor, not difficult. If you try at all in his class you should do well. Gives extra credit opportunities and likes students who participate. ALWAYS take notes, you can use them on the quizzes.
rating_tags: Participation matters--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Prof. Zhao is very kind and funny. A lot of games and exercises. However be ready to work. His class is very straight forward. Exams are tough if you don't read book/ppts and remember his examples or videos. He updates grades quickly after quizzes and exams. Will take another course from him!

The three hours in this class flew by each week with how the class was structured. I love how we didn't have long boring lectures, but prof. expected us to know the material so we can use it in practice. Really enjoyed the material, very useful book and class activities were fun and informative. Thanks!
rating_tags: Participation matters--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--Clear grading criteria

comment: One of the best professors in RPI. He made jokes of himself, told interesting stories, and discuss movies to keep the whole class attracted to the otherwise boring material. Learned a lot. Highly recommended!

Zhao is a good professor. He understands students take his class because it is required, so he tries to make it interesting to the uninterested. Sometimes lectures are boring, but overall fine. No complaints except that most of the material overlaps with HR so the class was quite easy. He even provides extra credit, but it was unneeded.
Straight forward syllabus and teaching.  Learned a lot, he wants everyone to get an A so he gives 2 extra credit opportunities.  Class participation is important.
Friendly and passionate in class. Some nice jokes and exercises. More interesting than I expected!
Nice and friendly. It is good he remembers everyone's name in class!
Good teacher, does a lot of teaching off PP slides.  Tests are relatively easy if you just read the slides.  Overall pretty interesting.
easy and fun course with a lot of video, exercises, and case analyses. pop quizzes but there are quite some extra credit opportunities if you miss any quiz.

Professor Sikdar's a really nice guy.  He doesn't do a lot to make the material interesting, so it can be easy to fall asleep.  Other than that, he understands what he's teaching and has no problem elaborating.  Great personality and cares about students more than other professors I've encountered.
Biplab is one of the nicest professors I've ever had! I definately recommend him.
His accent is a little thick but tends to be rather clear. His pacing can be amusing and he understands the material and teaches it well.
I love Biplab.  He is the funniest guy in the whole world.  I don't know where he gets those jokes but they are pure GOLD.
HORRIBLE at teaching! Needs to learn English and make the slides more interesting and better.  I see other small college websites teaching CANOS and they teach very diligently and clear.
great professor.  Explains material very well in class.  For CANOS don't bring your laptop (NERDS!!)  and you will do well

We started out the semester with another professor, and Biplab blew him out of the water.  He explains concepts very thoroughly, and was very helpful in answering questions.  His accent isn't bad if you pay attention.  Plus his constant moving around is very amusing.
He is a good teacher and, yeah, likes to teach, but the class is horrible.  Always willing to help and answer quesitons.  He has no problem answering "dumb" questions either.

When Prof. Sikdar speaks, it's like a locomotive train.  If you don't pay attention early on, it's really hard to get back on track.  He goes so fast at times.  His accent doesn't help either.  He is a great person but I'm sorry, I can't understand him when he teaches hard to understand concepts.
Biplab is the best professor to have.  He is incredible.
Clear, interesting, and most of all -- interested in teaching.  Don't find that much here at RPI
Best professor on campus.  Extremely clear and helpful.  Great personality.
Pretty good at explaining stuff.  The class still sucks, but he is willing to help you try to understand.  A little bit of an accent, but still easy to understand, and funny too.
He does not help. He does not respond to emails.

His class is very difficult, and the grading systems makes you really work hard if you want an A.  He gives very difficult homework assignments, but he is more than willing to help you out with it if you ask or email him.  Going to him for any needed help is key.
Worst Professor ever.
I took two of his classes this semster.He is helpful in some aspects, but he usually gives back our homework at the end of the semster.
He just copies everyting on his notes. He doesn't give feed back on time. I learned everything in this class by myself like other students in my statistics class do.

He is impatience to help students solve problem, sometimes he even get angry when students asked him for help.He just read everything on ppt in class.Also, he gives back our hw at the end of this semster, so we have no idea about our progess at all. He grades the homework basically depends on his self-interest, no fairness at all.

I had him for Discrete Event Simulation.  His lecture slides are very good and he tells you pretty much everything you need to know for the hmwk.  He is very helpful in Office Hours. I found his English to be quite good compared to most professors at RPI, and I did not have trouble understanding him.  I would recommend him, at least in this class.
simple,naive
Actually, the professor needs to improve his teaching skills and oral English. At the same time, the grading policy is unfair.

The professor spends most of the time in class just copying down his notes without any clarification. The lecture is by no means useful; I learn almost everything from reading the textbook by my own.Besides his oral English is poor.

The Statistics course is required for PhD students by the school. I think it's unfair to rate the professor with the school's problematic policy. (A side note: the first rating at the bottom was done on Feb 2, which was only few days after the first lecture.)
No Comments
he admittedly teaches this UNDERGRAD course as if it were PhD-level... cant speak english, he sucks in all aspects
He's the best nuclear engineering professor at RPI.
(Fuel Management) Very interesting class, very easy if you pay attention.
Can't say enough good things about this Professor.  Extremely helpful and wants students to learn. Laid back, relaxed and extremely intelligent.  Take his classes!
easy materials taught not understandable way. hardly understand his lecture.. sorry

Amazing class. The homework made me think and helped me understand everything I'd learned up to that point. Sreepada is a great teacher; he knows everything there is to know about nuclear and draws on a wealth of real-world experience. Available and friendly in office hours, he's a great resource for all nukes and loves discussing nuclear stuff.
God tier professor at rpi if there is such a thing.

Taught this course straight from Podowski's notes, but it was still awesome. Very intelligent, gave clear examples and fair exams & HW. Related topics in class to real-world applications. Very helpful in & out of class. Only complaint is that he listed a $91 textbook as 'required' and then never used it.
Sastry is the man! I don't know how he got stuck teaching MODCON, but he is a wealth of knowledge and very approachable with regards to his nuclear classes. Highly recommend if you're a nuke.

Great teacher. Could tell when I couldn't understand something in class, very smart and very good at explaining material. Kept class lively with jokes, didn't mind it when you pointed out his mistakes. Zero tolerance for late homework, but otherwise laid back & a fun guy to talk to. Posted HW solutions and lecture notes helped a LOT.

Fuel management was a good class and fairly easy if you took good notes. He did a good job getting to the main points of the material as well as alluding to all the different directions you could do further study in.

Interesting class and fairly easy. Practice tests are almost identical to exams. Textbook was used for about 3 homework problems the whole semester- essentially worthless. Kind of quiet and hard to understand, but writes lots of notes to cover the concepts.

Very understanding of your troubles.Teaches relavent information and relates it to real life application. He is very good with thermal hydraulics and could probably teach it to a level as advanced as you would like it to be. He is also very good with answering your questions in person or by email.
Hard to understand...
Guy is a great professor and I highly recommend taking a course with him.

Grade mostly dependent on participation, and essay, and 2 group projects. I didn't really know where I stood in the class grade wise until the end of the semester but lectures were over very relevant topics with nice group discussions throughout. Some readings were really complicated and I didn't feel very necessary.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Amazing lectures --Graded by few things

comment: Easy class and optional attendance. Most classes are lectures (which were streamed on WebEx). The weekly readings could get heavy but you could skim them and still get a good grade.

prof schaffer is very caring and accommodating towards students. while most assignments are not graded, if you want to stand out, you should do the readings and participate in class. they are very encouraging of students' ideas and perspectives.
Very respectful and understanding towards students and the readings/lectures are very interesting and insightful.

Guy is an extremely caring person who prioritizes the needs of his students first. His lectures are interesting and make use of a large variety of multimedia. STSO 1110 has a lot of assigned reading, but if you at least take a look at all the readings and take some notes during lectures, you will have no issue succeeding in this class.

I don't see why everyone likes him so much. The class was completely useless and I learned nothing. He talks about very odd philosophical topics and will agree to anything a student adds even if it makes absolutely no sense. His class is an easy A and the only reading that matters is before presentations. If you want to learn, this is not the class

Really nice guy, he's young so he relates to the students well. Very reasonable with absences; usually doesn't take attendance and is very willing to give extra credit if you miss lots of classes and want to make up your grade.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Group projects

comment: Very political and he makes it clear at the start of the class that that's how he will be, but he also makes it clear that you do not have to agree with him and he likes when students push back on his ideas in respectful ways. He's chill and laid back, lectures are kind of boring, but can also be very weird and interesting.

Guy is one of the best professors I have had at RPI! He really cares about students and strives to be the best instructor he can be. Guy is also just all around a very nice person that wants you to be successful. Guy also focuses more on inquiry, which helps you grow individually in the subject being taught and focus on your own professional goals.

He is an amazing professor who actually cares about what you say. Lectures are not mandatory, recitations are. If you talk during recitation, show you are paying attention and show some kind of interest and time investment in your project you'll get an A. Queries are a pain in the ass, though. But overall, he is a fair grader.
Guy is one of the most easy-going people in RPI! He cares about his students much and gives us great chances to show off our abilities during group projects and presentation.
Guy is one of the BEST professors I've had at RPI. He's funny, caring, and puts lots of effort into teaching his classes.
Really good.
Lecture is typically followed by in class problem solving. That really clarifies the concepts learnt in class
Approachable, helpful and very easy to talk to. Takes time to make us understand. I like that we get to work on the problems in the class immediately after the lecture.
Doesnt make sense. difficult to keep track with class as he is the most boring prof. anyone could ever have.
very helpful and clear

Jayanthi is one of the worst professors at RPI. I honestly believe that if he attempted to put effort into his lesson plans, and show interest in the material or his students, that he would spontaneously combust. Luckily, he gives most of his students A's. It's his only redeeming quality.
Eh, not clear at all, and not too helpful outside of class. Needs to slow down! I learned everything on my own
nice person, good , helpful, accessible,
excellent teaching and very helpful
No Comments

He means well, but he cannot articulate a clear thought. No sooner does he begin the lecture does he want to get it over with. He should never have become a professor and should be stuck in research so that no student ever has to endure a wasted semester with him ever again.
guy has no idea what he is teaching . . . unable to elaborate on this own examples . . . worst professor in a line of bad professors
This guy does not know anything, and he is not prepared for class at all!!!

Its too bad there's no language department anymore, but Lucien was fun while he was here.  The class was really easy, I came in at level 3, but still felt like I learned very little new that semester.  It was often difficult to stay awake through all the videos, and the quizzes were direct memorization, since he gave the answers the previous class.
I took his classes in Fall 00 & Spring 01. I still remember a very understanding, friendly and kind professor. He was very interested in his students. I wish I can keep in touch with him.

I really like Prof. Gerber. He really cares about his students and is always very willing to help, is more like your grand-father teaching you French. He is very knowledgeable and energetic. The only downside to his class is that he teaches through videos which sometimes can be a bit boring.

Class is extremely slow-paced.  Quizzes are based on memorizing minute details instead of understanding fundamentals of grammar.  Does not respond to e-mails, but is very willing to let work be handed in late.  Shows up late for class sometimes, which in and of itself isn't a huge offense, but acts disgusted if anyone else is late.
Best Professor I've had at RPI. Too bad RPI doesn't offer majors in french. If you work, you will learn so much from him. His classes, however, are not for people who have never taken french before.

Great professor if you make an effort to speak correctly and learn instead of being a loser who's afraid to pronounce words in front of their classmates.  I would have gotten an A if I turned in my final paper.  Whoops! :)

Amazing professor- does everything he can to make you understand, very enthusiastic and wants to help his students...a clear passion for his language- very impressive english vocabulary- my favorite professor at RPI-easy A, just read the text and memorize
Very energetic professor
He's good-humored and funny.  Youi probably won't get below a B if you do all the work.  Consider reading over the lesson before quizzes because their mostly memorization.
Monsieur Gerber is a very cool guy. He tries very hard to help you and makes the stuff very clear. Do the HW and you will be fine. Bon journee tout le monde! Bon journee monsieur!
Professor Gerber is the cutest little French guy. If you want to know about the language and the culture, this class is perfect. He is very helpful and very fair when it comes to grading.
Je n'aime pas les francais
Very knowledgable and enthusiastic

A very complicated figure and the most annoying person I know. I'm all fine with a professor with great sassiness, aggressive requirements, and tendencies to give frustrating critique to alter your design but not this one. This guy may know a thing or two about architecture, but is also a down right hypocritical manipulator with little good heart.

Has a lucidly defined interest for his studios, that is, expects his students to rigorously tackle the issues foregrounded, which tend to be rather intriguing contemporary ideas. Maya & Rhino wizard, all his students go on to be highly proficient.  Sometimes, frustrating to deal with his demands, but I’ve come to appreciate how hard he pushed us

Snooty elitist irrelevant waste of time.  Can't butt-kiss ... can't pass here.  Name-dropper, fragile-egoed typical case of someone unable to make it in the real world, so opted to hide in academia.  Avoid this guy if you can
No Comments
No Comments

you can take the man out of harvard, but you can't take the harvard out of the man. This guy is one cocky mofo. Loves it when you kiss up, and often grades unfairly. Doesn't realize that we do have other classes to work on, and we aren't made of money to spend on models. But yes, he is pretty hot, especially since he's trimmed down a bit.
Hes not the best but hes not the worst either.

Be prepared to kiss his ass and if you dont then be prepared to fail. He is not really a very useful professor and he plays favorites. Although he seems to be dedicated to architecture on a personal level, he could care less about meeting the needs of "all" his students. Just a Harvard educated snooty snake in the grass, avoid him if you can.
great teacher and cool guy.  lets you have alot of design freedom, and is really interested in everything, really cares about his and your work and takes pride in the work of his students
No Comments

Began the studio with intense interest in preforming well under his teaching. His ego got in the way. Name Dropper. Loves suckups. Generally very unprofessional in all regards. Allows personal matters to cloud judgement. His past professional accomplishments will be mentioned daily - NAME DROPPER. TAKE COURSES AT OWN RISK!  IF POSSIBLE AVOID!!

Pretty nice guy, he can be a bit vague at times, but overall, I think he's a good designer and a cool professor. He's not the person thats going to baby you through everything, so part of the learning you have to do yourself.

Very arrogant person. Does not know how to teach, very disorganized, and unaware of the financial limitations of his students. Talks way to much about Harvar... like we give a damn. Serious butt kissing and ego stroking needed to pass his course, or you have to do a project you hate to please him. I don't recommend you take his course.

Took him Fall 2024, not bad of a professor. Almost never uploads any of his written lectures. Never holds office hours, so you may have to barge him when you see him. His quizzes had “true” or “all of the above” as the answer. Also never showed up on the exams and almost everything is straightforward except 1 question that is impossible to solve.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: He is the best professor I have had at RPI. He is extremely helpful and will explain concepts in many different ways to ensure understanding. The tests are very easy if you do the homework yourself. His lectures are engaging and relevant. Great person to get to know!

Prof. Bequette teaches what you need to know for the industry. You get time to work on homework in class and some MATLAB code and Simulink files are provided to lessen the coding pain. Exams are fair. He tells stories about his experiences in process control and tries to make lectures relevant and short. Put in a moderate effort and you'll be fine.

He's a great lecturer, because he teaches you what you actually need to know for the working world instead of flooding your brain with tons of math and useless equations. HW tends to be much harder than exams.  He loves MATLAB too, so don't be surprised if he puts it on tests.
sucks

This professor is terrible. He is pompous and arrogant and doesn't care about the students. The whole class is a game of politics. You cannot get a straight answer from either him or the TA. You cannot find the professor out of class, and even when you do find him he is of little assistance.
A decent professor, but not a great advisor.
Arrogant & unhelpful.  I assume research is the only reason he is still around.
Not very clear about the project and rather unhelpful and confusing when answering questions.
Fun class
No Comments
No Comments
maybe someday he will be there for more than an eigth of the class period.
I don't know if I am comin' or goin' in this class.

Picking her for PD1 was probably the best decision I've made here. She is super understanding, kind, and accessible outside of class for things unrelated to course material. She redirected lecture to prep us for the career fair, and has made me feel like I've gotten something out of the class. She pushed me out of my comfort zone enough to succeed.

She is a fantastic professor and very reasonable person overall. If you email her about absences, she will be extremely understanding. As an introverted person. she pushed me out of my comfort zone enough to be challenged, but not enough to be uncomfortable and not want to come back. Will be trying for her PD 3 class

Professor Schierenbeck is really caring and understanding toward students. In PD3, sometimes she scared me with her lectures about interviews and professionalism. She "cold-calls" you and makes you stand up in front of the class to speak. Even though the class was anxiety-inducing, speaking with her privately is a dream. Such a nice person.
Best PD3 professor you can get!

Tracy is passionate + provides keen insights. Be forewarned that PD1 lacks structure + involves many surprises; an intentional move to take students out of their comfort zone. As a result, you will either embrace the ambiguity + see it as a chance to grow, or you will remain uncomfortable + spurn the class. I recommend the former; it's worthwhile.
really nice and enthusiastic

Worthless. She's not in class a lot, never learns students' names and actually believes that PD1 isn't a joke. Would put us on the spot with absurd demands, harsh grading and inane, nonsense comments-apparently those of us who are bad at public speaking shouldn't try to talk in front of groups. Ever.
a charismatic speaker

I know that the instructor is Prof. Staff when you sign up for it, but do your best to get this lady.  She will have an interest in your team and project.  I do not really like the PD-series aka the BS-series, but comparing her teaching on Wed to Murtuza's on M&R, I preferred actually LEARNING in PD1.
Tracy was an AWESOME teacher!

Gives obvious help on the quizes like doing a "review" right beforehand so you know the answers to some of the harder questions.   Makes you stand up in class whenever you speak, and has the class critique your speaking style. At the beginning of each class, she picks some note cards you fill out before, and asks you interview question based on i
No Comments
Easy class and she tried to make this boring class interesting. Although some of the material sucked she did her best to make it interesting.
One of the greatest classes I've taken is PropSys. Frequent his office hours for amazing homework help and life philosophy lessons. Very knowledgeable, hope to take another of his classes.
Very well spoken professor who seems to enjoy what he is doing, the course wasn't particularly hard but he made it very interesting. One of the best professors I have had.

Professor Oehlschlaeger is incredibly caring and easy-going.  Lectures are very well prepared and informative.  Exams are straightforward.  Homework is graded on effort rather than correctness.  Overall, he's probably the best professor I've had at RPI.
One of the best professors in RPI, you should have no problem with the test if you understand the examples in his lecture notes and he is quite generous in grading

Great professor, always makes lectures interesting. Passionate about the subject and always talks about the industry applications to what we are learning - got me inspired to pursue aero while taking his class as meche!

I had him for summer arch TF1. He's a chill professor who's very approachable. He's pretty young (30ish). He lectures well and grades fairly easily. 3 tests are your only grades. He'll spend some time to answer your questions and explain things if need. He's not too pushy so he won't demand class interaction. Great guy, in and out of class.

Excellent professor on all fronts. Lectures are well prepared derivations, tests are challenging but fair, optional homeworks are definitely recommended. Matt is very helpful outside of the classroom as well. I would definitely recommend taking any course that he is teaching because it will be well done.

Matt is easily the best professor I've had at RPI. His lectures were clear and effective, and his enthusiasm for the material helped inspire the class to actually care about it. Tests were fair, as was his grading system. Overall just a wonderful person.

Matt is the greatest professor at this university. He is clear in what he expects and has realistic expectations. He knows what it is like being a student and teaches for you to do well. His lectures are really helpful and he makes difficult material easy to understand. Two thumbs up!

Probably the best teacher I've had.  He's very realistic about how easily students forget things between semesters and he'll brush up on topics to keep everyone current.  In class work was very relevant and engaging.

Great professor, one of the best on campus.  Material was difficult, but the notes he gives in class are superb and he answers emails promptly.  I definitely recommend this professor for any class he's teaching.  One of the few professors that realizes that students have other classes besides his.
This guy is definitely up there on the best teacher list.  He knows that school is important, but knows that life is more important.  Real helpful at office hours, cant say anything bad about him.

This guy is a great teacher.  He is smart, the material for the class was fast paced, but he understands that undergrads will be behind the grads and makes up for it in the grades later.  If he is a choice for a professor, choose him.

I took Professor Lin's class in Fall 2022. He's so wholesome and very knowledgeable. He's always willing to help and genuinely wants everyone to succeed. Very kind professor! As long as you do back exams, you'll be fine on the exams.

Lectures were very short and thorough, this was a good thing because it left a lot of time to effectively finish the activity for class. He was always helpful in assisting students with the activity and questions!

Lectures were good if you had the attention span to follow.  After every lecture there is an activity that you do with a couple of people.  Lin was helpful when there was an issue with the activity or if you had a question.  He is a very smart guy and a good teacher.
Very smart and a good professor. His lectures are very short, but class is basically mandatory because of in-class activities/labs. Exams are pretty straightforward

Guinness world record holder for darkest metal.
He said I was a genius.
Good

Hilarious guy. Photonics is his master subject, and the class reflects that really well. Huge amount of content, but somehow not overwhelming, even for students without prior optics courses. Great graphical intuitions. Good explanations IF you press for them. Homeworks are short and are specific examples. Tests are rather difficult, but not unfair.
Funny guy, although I think the way they teach Physics I and II here isnt very good. He basically reads the powerpoint to us and then does some demonstrations
He is the best physics 1 prof. Made lectures funny and short. Had some very hilarious demos. Very smart guy!

Excellent teacher! I finally understand physics after taking his class! Teachers in my high school could never explain it clearly enough, but professor Lin makes everything easy to understand. If you have ever had trouble with physics, make sure to take his class. His inspirational quotes always get my mood up!
passionate professor, and interesting class

He's a goofy professor. definitely approachable. His lectures are long and a bit boring sometimes, but he is understandable and clear when he explains concepts. He really wants you to do well in his class and enjoy it at the same time!
Professor Lin is the best! He talks and writes slowly when you ask a question so you can understand. His explanations are really helpful. Also, his demonstrations are hilarious!

I took Data and Society - CSCI 4370. This is the type of class where you get what you put into it. The course structure is created to align with what is going on in the current world and allows students to explore the ethics of new technology. No other computer science course at RPI explores the same type of topics and it is quite frankly a need.

The best professor I've had at RPI.  Took Data and Society, and now my life is irreversibly changed.  This course was stupidly easy but also incredibly interesting and applicable to the computer science major and my social life at large.  Take a class with Jim Hendler - you won't regret it.

I had Professor Hendler for my very first CMSC class at UMCP.  He was awesome.  I loved every single class session.  I was already very familiar with programming and software when I started at UMCP, but he was a good first professor to have.

I really like him, so I was surprised to see lots of poor rating for a few years ago. It was obvious he was passionate about the subject, and was really accommodating and friendly. I do think some assignments were vague, but he was easy to get a hold of with the class slack and was there for clarification

Syllabus, homework, and labs were very vague, and were graded in a perfunctory manner. Lectures were on topics that did not seem very serious or relevant; all lectures of substance were outsourced to the TAs, who were not always knowledgeable in the material. Hendler merely adopted the web; but we were born in it and molded by it.

He does not teach about useful information, he is incredibly vague on theories and then gives loose guidelines for assignments he wants done. He does not stop talking about how he is famous and how he works with famous people. He loves to assign reading to papers about him or he wrote.

He frequently came to class unprepared and relied almost entirely on TAs to teach the class. He appears unprofessional, walks around with an undeserved sense of accomplishment, and does very little to help his students succeed. Course consisted of (seemingly) useless exercises and 3 assignments which formed your final grade.  Avoid if you can.

Worst professor ever. There are not words enough to describe the smug look on his face as he lies to you about your grade, and then fails you regardless of the quality of your work.  I would rather be taught by a rock with googly eyes.  Avoid this man like he's trying to ruin your life, because he basically is.

Well I took this course trying to give him a chance despite all of his bad reviews. He is actually pretty horrible. I feel like he has nothing to really offer. I feel like he feels that he is more innovative then he actually is. He doesn't even understand his course content.  He probably couldn't even complete on of our labs successfully.

I took Web Science the first semester he taught it, and the course was pretty discombobulated. The lectures were pretty useless, but his homework assignments were surprisingly challenging and worthwhile. He's hard to reach outside of class and travels a ton. I'm not sure if he tries to deal with students much.

Professors have no business teaching classes about themselves. Furthermore, he's completely changed the format of the IT degree at RPI without supporting classes to back up his thoughts about the web. Disorganized and presents his class interest style-whatever he thought about in the shower that morning and his firefox tabs prove it.

WORST TEACHER EVER! Absolutely ruined the IT program. This so called "inventor of the web" has a huge ego to match his gigantic head. He told us we wouldn't make much money because we won't drink the "web science" kool-aid.  News flash, web science is something you made up guy...  And RPI only offers 1 web science class.  What a joke.  Avoid.......

Hendler is a terrible professor who was of absolutely not help throughout the entire semester. Hendler is the kind of professor who is simply interested in himself, not students. He is quick to dismiss students and I advise you avoid him at all costs.
Passes himself off as a guy who knows finance but you could fill a thimble with what he knows and still have room for two thumbs.

Excellent professor, but extremely difficult. Lectures can be hard to follow, but since he uses everything from the DPV book I'd recommend taking that to class and reading the parts he's covering (it's tiny). Tests are difficult, but open note/open book -- hardest part is the time limit. Homeworks are hard, labs easy.
This guy's fantastic. I never go to most classes, but i actually look forward to this one. Not too much work either (for a restricted elective)

Prof. Das cares about the subject more than most.  Homeworks are really tough. Tests are open note/ open book. If you take his class, be ready to pay attention and participate. The material is hard, so ask questions during class if you don't understand it. More importantly answer his questions or at the very least think about them.

Horrible professor. Concepts are poorly explained, and useful examples are few and far between. Has a policy where class will not move on until somebody answers the question, but due to most of the class being completely lost during lecture, either the same student answers everything or we sit there silently for 5 minutes. Do not take DSA with him.
The most work I've ever put into a CS class, but he knows his stuff and teaches well. I highly recommend him... but do not take the class lightly if you expect to survive it.

His DSA class is ridiculously difficult. The tests are a breeze, labs are fun, but the bi-weekly homeworks are a complete disaster. Das explains new concepts thoroughly, but unfortunately knowing the concepts won't actually help the otherworldly homework. It's like nothing else. The pain...
Good teacher but the homeworks are nightmareish

Dr. Das has the rare combination of wisdom, teaching competence and good fashion sense. He is the prof you'll want for DSA- it's a tough course to take, and it'll beat the snot out of you, but comparing his teaching with the others' is like comparing... Dimetapp with bloodletting. Go with the Dimetapp.
Sanmay Das is great.
Das is great. As a friend told me last semester, take any class with him that you can.
He was really inspired by his subject, and made me want to do better too.
A top quality teacher.  The best CS prof I've had, by every measurement.

Professor Century did a great job teaching this course. Despite being a bit unengaging, his lectures covered the topics well and he made efforts to enhance them through guest speakers. The course expectations were more than fair and he gave extra credit. The communication intensive aspect was well executed through a balance of writing and speaking.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: As long as you show up, do the work, and study a little for the midterm and final you will be fine. The homework is easy and can often be completed without reading the full article. Very kind, easy to communicate with and a great pianist. It was nice that he would play during class.

History of Western Music. Professor Century is far too qualified to be teaching music here tbh (he studied under Nadia Boulanger) but that's all the more reason to take one of his classes. He plays these ridiculous pieces of music in the middle of class on the piano and it's enthralling. Not a free A and attendance is mandatory but worth it.
great professor

Prof. Century certainly made the class much more interesting than I thought it would be. His mixture of teaching with video, text, and music makes the material feel more real. Though most of the EMPAC performances he made us attend had questionable/weird taste, he is happy to help anyone that displays interest in the course material.

Prof. Century.  He's the head of the music department, and teaches the new media theory classes too I believe.  He interesting, and steers clear of 'boring' material.  Occasionally he go into tangents, or long-winded talks, but bearable, and will teach any material well.

His delivery is a little dry, but Professor Century is a very smart guy. He really explains the various art movements very succinctly, and if you can get him onto a tangent, you'll find he can provoke lots of really interesting (and relevant) discussion and debate from the students.

He taught History of Western Music very well. Was thorough and detailed. Not good at keeping the class awake though. Easy grader, its an easy A if you do the reviews on time and read the textbook before quizzes. Students interested in the course can get an easy A.
Take this course if you can. Always something to learn.  Helpful and enthusiastic guy. Not a dynamic entertainer, but something to stick with you long after it's over ... in a GOOD way.
He has a monotonous voice during lecture but if he is helpful!
