The class is pretty boring and useless, but Century is pretty easy and always willing to help.  It's not his fault the course sucks, he tried his best.
Very easy class and he gets very excited about what he presents. He tries very hard to make sure everyone understands the material but he is PAINFULLY, PAINFULLY BORING.
No Comments

I took thermodynamics with professor Smith online. It was alright at best. His lectures are mandatory yet really really boring. He is an easy grader for homeworks and tests, but his quizzes seem arbitrary at times. I would not take the course again, and he needlessly punishes honest students for what cheaters do.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Good professor, very knowledgeable and entertaining in lectures. Tests and HW are very fair with what's covered in class. He's reasonable as well with final grading.

Absolute great professor for Thermodynamics. He puts in ALOT of effort to make sure the material is understandable and balanced. HW is due every week but recitation sessions with TA's clear it all up. Tests are fair. Best thing about this class is the EXTREME leniency in HW and test grading. Plugging and chugging is the key to victory.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Smith is a great professor, while sometimes sidetracked sometimes during a lecture, he definitely puts the material into concepts that students can understand. Lots of example problems related closely to the exam material.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: Good professor, good notes, cares about his students' success. His homeworks can't be found online, and they're pretty hard. But his office door is always open and he's really understanding when you don't get the material. His tests aren't as hard as his homeworks. He's basically a dad
Notes can be more complicated than the textbook. Class is good for anyone who is learning TF for a second or third time, but not a good class for an "introduction" to TF.

This professor thinks that he is the highest valued professor at RPI and he makes sure to let you know that. Help is there if you ask but you must be prepared to deal with his antics.  Grading and work requirements aren't clear

This professor is really knowledgeable, he is a good teacher (although not the best), he is also somewhat kind and occasionally funny. The class is well structured and I never had to read the book... his notes are completely sufficient, and I got A's on all my tests just by studying them. Take this class with him, it's not hard at all.

Homework is much more difficult than other sections and because he creates his own problems there are usually no answers available and the homeworks are graded hard. Tests are ok. Graded fairly for the most part. Probably learn the material better, but if you want a better grade best to take this with another professor.

I think asd a rpofessor and dean that he needs to get an attitude adjustment - he should nto ber rude in answering questions - but to be more understanding and willing to help in any way - try to put a smile in your responses

His homeworks are tricky, but the tests are always fair, you have to work in the class but if you work 4-5 hours a week on you will see decent results class average at the end of the three exams was 72, homework are graded a little harder and are time consuming but help. Try to just listen to him and fill in the blank notes he gives you. Very good

Taught well, made very corny jokes in class. Gets students well prepared for exams, but halfway through the semester he stopped printing out partial notes that he used to teach the class -- we had to print them out or it was difficult to follow along, and that was a pain.

His tests are pretty basic, much easier than homework.  His lectures are boring and often tough to follow because he just reads off notes on the projector.  Still, he's not an awful teacher-- He just doesn't cover material in much detail, but you're expected to understand the details. he is never available for office hours.  the TA was helpful.

Every lecture he emphasizes real world relevance to the material we're learning and mentions companies past students now work for. Quiz and test questions really make you think, but everything is open internet. Offers extra credit too. Probably the most applicable-to-internships BME class I've taken so far.
Great professor, just do the work and it is the easiest A in college!
The exam was unreasonably hard. I memorized the lecture notes and study guides. Still not able to answer the exam questions.
Makes class interesting

Honestly, the only professor at RPI i have actually learned and understood the material from..  Definitely take his classes.. He is incredibly helpful and really prepares you for exams/quizzes. Also a very involved learning environment.

Honestly, the only professor at RPI i have actually learned and understood the material from..  Definitely take his classes.. He is incredibly helpful and really prepares you for exams/quizzes. Also a very involved learning environment.

I really enjoyed Biomaterials with Dr. Gilbert. He promoted a good classroom dynamic, encouraging participation and ensuring he was clearly understood. Reading is a must for this class (at least to do very well) as the lectures supplement the text. If you hate reading, you could still easily manage a 'B' so long as you pay attention in lecture.
Dr. Gilbert was a good lecturer.  His class notes were very clear and he prepares you well for the test.  I found him a bit intimidating when I went to his office for help though.
Professor Gilbert is super cute! Woof! I took his class for the eye candy, but learned a lot! Great class!
Dr. Gilbert does a great job of finding the baseline of information that everyone knows and then building on it. This makes is lectures very clear and engaging. Excellent Professor!
If you actually want to learn the material, take his class. Best professor at actually teaching teacher I have had at rpi
Great teacher.  Really makes things simple and then he adds in great Case Studies to make you think.   Personally, I think he is the best BMED teacher.
His teaching style is very similar to that of a high school teacher.  He actually posts the lectures after class and uses them for the quizzes, so studying is easy.

My guide to getting an A in funflight: Try doing the homework on your own. It's okay to refer to the online answer guide, but be sure you're not using it as a crutch.  Back tests are available and super useful from the APO office and there's a few online if you look hard enough.  Go to office hours to ask for clarifications.

Took Fun Flight with him last semester. The tests are pretty tough the average was always in the D range. Just pay attention in class and make sure you understand all the homework don't just copy it from the answer key. Go to his office hours if you don't understand certain material, he is actually really helpful and a nice guy.

Overall, Professor Amitay was very good for Fun. Flight. Tests are difficult and you must write EXACTLY what he mentioned in class to get full credit. Luckily, he curves the class average to a B. Otherwise, the average would be around a C-D+. Homework was pretty straightforward if you read the book beforehand. He is very helpful to talk to.
He really knows what he's talking about

Idk what that other kid is talking about but this is not a very well taught class. It feels like physics classes from high school in the sense that you just get equations without a real intuitive understanding. He assigns problem from the book that end up having problems that lack either correct answers,and assumptions that don't make sense forsome

Best professor ever! He teaches really well so if you pay attention and do the homework you're going to do well in funflight. His notes are ten times better than the textbook. He condenses material but his explanations cover everything you need to know. He's very approachable for help in funflight.

His class lacks the freedom of a good design course.  He purports to let the design be up to the student, however that's a lie.  Frequently our design was dictated by what might get him more research funding.  Also, Miki never has a clue what progress (or lack thereof) his undergrads have made.  Very close-minded about projects for a researcher.
Amitay was a good professor for IEA. The subject material was hard to grasp at times, but he always walked around asking you personally if you understood what was going on.
The best place to get an A. He himself also doesn't know the subject very well!
Great guy, offered guidance where needed, and was eager to learn what the students had to contribute.
He gave me an A, which is all that matters
Very easy to learn from.
No Comments
Overall a very good professor.
I've had her for only 1 semester and she is a really great professor.
good class
The best class ever
Definitely one of the best professors I had at RPI so far. She is very smart and knows the material very well.

She is very difficult to understand.  Only way to understand what is going on is to read the textbook and the slides that have example problems on it.  She is knowledgeable of the material, but cannot explain it as clear as hoped.
the best professor in the world.

AVOID AT ALL COST. This woman destroyed any interest I had in electromechanics. She writes very quickly (with messy hand writing),and speaks in a gibberish tone. However, this doesn't matter since her notes and homework has no correlation to the absurd exams she gives. The final was awful and long, I mean eight problems?! COME ON!
I enjoyed taking the course. Very good professor.
She is one of the smartest professors at RPI. I had two courses with her and it was worth my time.

I wonder how she talks for 2 hours straight without taking a break. Does lots of examples in class, most of which are copied directly from the book. Test questions are pretty much the same as the year before. Questions are usually in class examples or homework problems with different numbers.
No Comments

The homework is tougher than the examples that she goes over in class, and she doesn't really go into depth about the background of the topics.  She just kind of starts doing examples.  Her tests are exactly the same as those the year before, so find them and you won't get screwed.

I actually had Jefferson for two consecutive semesters.   He's smart and very good at what he does, but if you don't think the same way he does you are going to be in for a painful semester.  Sometimes the ego can be difficult to work around and he plays favorites.  Don't make excuses cause he doesn't care.  Use logic and you'll have a good start.

Amazing architect, great professor for first years. Give tough critiques and will tear stuff apart but can tell who cares. Great to talk to about designs and just your life...cool guy. He also doesn't give pointless side assignments like other section leaders do

Jefferson is an amazing teacher and architect. I can see why some do not like him, he takes interest only if he senses that you have interest in what your doing. His critics are great if you understand that he is trying to help you obtain your own answers.
Stop lying to him you groupies.  Architecture is about architecture. Or is it? Do his students earn there grades? Lol...hes like so alright in a everyday below average professor kinda way.
Hes alright
Jefferson's absolutely gorgeous in that "i'm stranded on the side of a road in the middle of no where" kind of way. plus he's an awesome professor and very laid back.
he is so hooootttttt
great reviewer. you can tell he's a good designer b/c he's perceptive.

Sometimes he can be too bold and appear rude, but he is just a straightfoward kind of guy.  He has an amazing eye for design and is incredibly helpful in your projects.  Plus, he is ruggedly handsome and always nice to look at for 4 hours of class.
He's a great studio prof. He rips projects apart that suck to begin with, thats his job and he does it well
He absolutely thinks he's so amazing. Rips your project apart until it fits what he thinks is alright, after you spent all night and weekend working on it. Obnoxious.
hes good
Knows what he's talking about and extremely helpful.  Plain old cool guy too.

Professor Peng knows his stuff but unfortunately due to language barrier his lectures are difficult so definitely if you are struggling go talk to him or read the textbook. The midterm + final are 70% of your grade so don't fail those!!(you can cheat but you won't learn)
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Prof. Peng (though very nice) made Macro way harder than it needed to be. He has a VERY thick accent and bad handwriting, and he interrupts his own lectures constantly to draw illegible diagrams in pen & paper. Tests are solely T/F and Mult. Choice, so there is no partial credit. Be prepared to buy the textbook and teach yourself the curriculum.

Tbh just do your homework and stop complaining. Dr. Peng is an absolute phenomenal professor. Although his class is hard, he takes an extra mile to help his students understand the concepts. Just come to class and do your homework and the test will be extremely easy!

The course I took with Professor Peng was graded on a curve. As per the syllabus, a final grade between 85 and 89 equates to a letter grade of an A-. I finished the class with an 85.6. However, professor Peng decided to round my 85.6 all the way down to an 84 and give me a B+ instead. Absolutely insane to "round" a grade down 1.6 percentage points.

Professor Peng is really nice and understanding. As long as you attend lectures and do the homework, you'll get at least an A-. Tests are also very similar to the homework/practice problems, so no surprises there or anything.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Don't take Peng's course, because you need to spend $40,000 bucks a year at RPI. Choosing Peng means you lose $10,000 bucks immediately.
Lots of work, overall was a good experience, he is a great professor. He knows what he is talking about. Very difficult, prepare to do a lot of work.

You HAVE to WORK in this class. That is the gist of it. To succeed in his class, prepare to read and go out your comfort zone and ask questions. In numerous occasions he has always stopped by after class to answer questions. If you put in the effort, he will too. He cares about your grades and truly wants you to learn. But you have to work hard.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor is very nice very helfpul. Helps me alot and understandble class. Problem sets are ok if you ask help. Homework is grade booster so do them. Morer effort pays off and get higher score. Quizzes mostl.y multiple choices and true false.

First and foremost, you will NEVER understand a single lecture. I do not know a single person who actively understands the words that comes from this professor's mouth. He's nice for sure, but his lectures are intelligible and he reads off a powerpoint 95% of the time I showed up to 10% of lectures and got away with a B doing self study.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Never take his class, you will learn nothing. He is terrible should not be a professor.

Heavy accent and difficult to understand. Lectures straight for 2 hours often times just using formulas and no examples. Course is graded by 2 tests and 4 assignments. Does not always explain what certain variables mean in his slides. Going to class is useless so you have to self teach. Difficult content hard to get half decent grade.
Just avoid his class for whatever reason even if it's online class.

Great guy and very nice. Ask for help and he'll always help you until you fully understand, or he'll just give you the answer if you want the answer. Lectures are very boring because he reads off slides from a different source, so you have to read the textbook on your own to learn the material. Read the textbook before quizzes to get an easy A
Cool guy, I dont get why he's getting all this flak. I think I liked his class! Would take again. Dedicated to his job, once seen him talk all lecture till he lost his voice!

A good teacher, would be arrogant to say he teaches badly. He looks after the whole spectrum of students in his class and paces it accordingly. Something I've seen few RPI profs do. Simply has a different style of teaching, likes to use visual aids (videos etc.) to make learning simple, trivialise difficult problems and maintain interest.

The lectures may not be the greatest; however, he will help you understand what is troubling you during office hours. Doing this & reading the textbook will earn you a decent grade. The homeworks are simple unlike the quizzes. During breaks, he plays videos the students suggest to relieve stress and show how the concepts we learn are applied irl.

Really disorganized. Uses other peoples powerpoints and focuses on random information such as CPU performance from 10 years ago instead of teaching. Some of the homeworks do not actually have a prompt and you basically just have to figure it out. Stops lecture so people can have conversation with each other. Its not too hard though.

Incredible amount of class time is wasted, course is poorly taught and designed. Homework assignments and quizzes are not clear. Takes long breaks in class. Lets students speak about irrelevant material, which is incredibly disruptive (common theme at RPI), but must CS profs will tell the particular student to speak with them after class.

Homeworks/labs are a week ahead of the material he's teaching. He reads off the powerpoint slides, and quizzes focus primarily on applied CS, which isn't ever covered. Every 4 class sessions has a quiz, and wastes time watching youtube (15min) in class. Homeworks/labs instructions are incredibly vague. Submitty doesn't go up until last minute.

Homeworks and labs are easy to do. Quizzes are pretty hard because the questions are poorly worded. Takes a really long time to grade assignments. Likes to take breaks in lecture to watch club penguin videos.
worst class I've taken at RPI.  Interesting content but the professor teaches class very poorly and makes it difficult
He has no idea on what he is talking about in class.  The explanation is unclear.  and the planning of the class is absolutely BAD.

Terrible professor. Very poor planning of both individual lectures and the overall course. His explanations are meandering, confusing, lacking in detail, and boring. The biweekly tests can be tough, but only because the questions tend to be so unclear. My advice: try to get by on the textbook alone; lectures are too excruciating.

If I understand correctly, he's a postdoc student teaching Comp Org so that his advisor doesn't have to. He is very passionate about the material, but he really doesn't explain anything well because he hasn't yet figured out how to teach properly.
N/AAAAAAAAA
I took Seminar class with her. She's definitely caring and motivational but more of a guidance rather than actually teaching. She is accessible outside of class and is willing to help at any time.
She does not teach. Occasionally will waste class time to ramble. Needs to retire asap
not recommend

Cultural Anthropology was such an interesting class! I learned so much, and thoroughly enjoyed the content, as well as Prof Gordon's passion and humor. Definitely be prepared for the (only 2) pop quizzes based on key words from the readings. The tests were fair, and the group project was an interesting experience. Overall, I learned a lot.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Doc Film is a fun class and a good choice if you need a HASS elective! There are three 5-6 papers, which are easy to write if you stay on top of the readings. Send her a draft before the deadline or go to her office hours so you can get some feedback before you turn in the final draft, she's very accessible. Go to class- the documentaries are great
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Language and Culture had a ton of super interesting material if you have any remote interest in sociology. She knows a lot about what she's teaching and brings in plenty of personal research. Class is easy to get an A if you're willing to write 3 papers, do 3-4 small presentations, and show up to class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Documentary Film itself was an enjoyable class. 3 essays with an optional 4th. Go to her for help on the essays and see what she's looking for. A well-written essay won't get a good grade unless it incorporates everything, and disagreeing with the text is not good.
Really boring class, not helpful at all.  class dropped immediately. Religion in Media

Not a bad professor, but writing the essays for Documentary Film is very laborious. Must include many sources and quotations from the assigned texts, or else even very good papers won't be graded well.
Really friendly, informative and makes the class interesting. Would recommend!
Great teacher. Fun and lively. You can tell she loves her work. So much fun to be away, keeps things interesting.

I had professor Neti as a lab instructor for Embedded Control and he didn't seem like he knew what he was doing. If we asked him for help he would go off on tangents instead of focusing on the problem. He  would always comment on the fact our project wasn't complete/working while we were still developing it, which was very unhelpful and annoying.
He aight

Terrible/Doesn't explain complex topics, slides don't help much either. Sure he gives "extra credit" but it doesn't help those who need the points the most because he asks questions about things he has not taught yet; basically all the extra credit went to one student who probably doesn't need the points in the first place. It's just demoralizing.
Halfway through the semester. Want to drop the course and take it next semester, but he's teaching it again.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Okay lecturer but is getting better. Often distracts himself during lectures and talks about random things, which can be unintentionally hilarious. Cares about students and likes when they ask questions. Test questions are variations of (or the exact same as) the practice problems. He's def better in EES than in signals because his field is power

Gives lectures with one airpod in. Doesn't explain things very well either. He's not clear about expectations, and homework is usually very behind. Very disorganized. Gives a lot of extra credit for answering bonus questions in class, but he won't let you finish answering them before he blurts out the answer. Would never voluntarily take his class

Brilliant man, incompetent professor with incredibly poor communication. No grading scale in the syllabus, and lectures make even simple topics hard to follow, often twisting and turning through various derivations that are never used again. Lists and example problems are all that is needed in this class, but you wont get them from Neti's lectures.
Don't Bother. For the sake of your sanity take it with any other professor.
he touched me after class whem I complained about his style.

Neti is literally the worst professor I have ever had. He drones on in lectures, asking rhetorical questions and interrupting students who answer them. His homework run about a month behind the lecture such that you have had no practice on the contents of the exam by the time you take the exam. Exams are worth 80% of your grade, very mean grader.

Though his lectures are a bit unclear, the homework and tests are not that hard. You can learn a lot of things from his lecture. And if you go to ask him questions, he will answer thoroughly and patiently.

Questions he asks are so irrelevant that they are either basic questions from Calc 2, or something oversimplified. If you start to answer, he WILL interrupt you with the answer to the question and then go on a tangent. Never goes through an example and just gives you solutions, he will not do a problem in class. Retired and teaches as a "hobby".

By far the worst Professor I have ever had. His lectures are awful.. how does someone learn math by just looking at slides??? This class might actually be worse than data structures and that is saying something. I wish we had HAMEEEEED ��
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Professor Zhang is really nice but seems to lack skills as a lecturer. Almost every other lecture, she would make a mistake in her example solution, which would derail her work for the entire example and would take an extra half hour to correct. She often had trouble understanding questions and couldn't answer (when they weren't that confusing).

Avoid if you can, I can't tell if its the difficulty of the material, or if its her, but this class was nasty. This class is supposed to be learning NX-12 Nastran Stress simulation software, but the heavily weighted tests have nothing to do with it - there is a lot of material in this class that is nonrelevant to engineering.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Group projects--Lecture heavy

comment: For this class (finite elements) just awful. Tends to discourage students by stating that if you don't know a certain concept that you should drop the class. Goes very fast with powerpoint slides, easily fall back on notetaking. Exams are difficult! Exam 1 no calculator nor crib sheet and Exam 2 1 crib sheet that is given, but useless.

I had her for strengths of materials last semester, and I felt like I learned what I needed to in lectures without a problem.  She has a slight accent, but it's very easy to understand her.  I thought the tests were fair.  All things considered, I think she's a good professor.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: She seems to teach well but her tests are just the hardest thing ever and her grading doesn't get any better. Stayed on par with the rest of the class but still got a low grade. Take Strengths with another professor if you can!
WORST PROFESSOR EVER...no partial credit on tests...the material covered is simple just her grading style doesn't make any sense
great professor. very helpful. she really spends time with you whenever you need extra help.
she is absolutely the worst professor or teacher i have ever had. cute though, wouldnt mind taking her to dinner, but thats it.

Have her for strengths, too. Really does care about getting students to learn, but doesn't always know a good way to explain the material in a way that's not somewhat confusing. I'd say better than most teachers, mostly due to genuine student interest, but could still use a lot of work.
Awesome teacher. Retook IEA to get better grade and succeeded. In great part due to Prof Zhang explaining stuff better than Professor Henry Scarton did the first time around.
No Comments
I'm not sure if she's bad at explaining the material or if the material is just hard to explain in general but either way this class has required me to teach myself.

Lewis is a nice person, but she's too heavily rooted in research and doesn't understand how to teach students who know nothing about Physics. She also didn't respect that many students in the class were Archies and had other priorities. Overall, you can definitely pass this class, but avoid her if possible; you won't get an A unless you really try.

Replaced Dwyer halfway through the semester for unknown reasons. Big mistake. Nowhere even close to how good he was and tests were even harder. Uses bad powerpoints to teach and the rest is on your own. Test average was 70 the whole semester with no curve. Not sure how that is ok

Professor Lewis has no interest in the education or well being of her students, not that she has the proper ability to educate them even if she did care. She copies directly from her notes which are a more confusing version of the textbook and is horrendous at answering students questions. Avoid this professor at all costs.

Not a bad professor, but doesn't stand out. Her handwriting and speaking is clear, but her lectures were mostly just book material and if you asked a question that she hadn't explicitly prepared for she often got tripped up and couldn't answer satisfactorily or until the next class.  Tests were generally easy, and had large multiple choice sections

I would disagree with most of the comments here.  Tests are hard, but if your prepare for them using the book, class notes, and homework examples, you can be successful.  You can't just memorize the formulas; you have to know how and when they are applied.  I have gone to her office hours to ask her questions and she has been helpful.

I'm sure Dr. Lewis was a great professor in a phys 2 where she did not have to develop her own course materials. She is terrible at preparing this class. Her lectures are just quotes from the book. Tests are hard, homework is harder. Doesn't give good study material for tests and could care less about her students. Avoid this professor at all costs

We thought she would be a good step up from the professor that taught last year. Unfortunately, she does not care about her students at all. She recites the book to the class during lecture, using no unique notes or examples. She gives tests that cover subjects not covered during class. And she is rude and uncaring toward her students.
No Comments

Physics II for non-physics minded people will be difficult.  The course is hard, however Professor Lewis is a good professor.  The labs and exams are all standardized through all of the sections.  Lewis is very helpful in office hours;  this is where I learned most of the material on the mandatory homework and of course this helped greatly on exams
Clear and concise. Her in-class examples did a good job of reinforcing the material. Presented everything to us in a down to earth fashion that made a difficult subject easy to understand.
She's a good teacher. Go to her office hours, she's really helpful with homework. And study alot and you'll get an A.
Excellent teacher, likes to help. She cares for her students a lot.

I wish Dr. Liu taught more Nuke classes than just Phenom. She is so sweet and so nice and if you like the content of the class it will make the class genuinely something you look forward too. Never heard someone say something negative about her.

Dr. Liu is the sweetest lady lectures are so enjoyable. Sometimes it does feel like it goes forever but she provides breaks and snacks during exams. Overall very good professor, sucks that you will never see her after Nuclear Phenomena lol.

I really enjoyed Nuclear Phenomena and I really enjoyed having Professor Liu. Very kind, engaging, and approachable. Lecture slides are clear and accessible. Textbook is basically irrelevant. Do the back exams and the actual exams will be easy.
She's very nice, and the material and grading is not too difficult. she does have to leave class occasionally for business that she does outside of teaching

Professor Liu is the best professor I have ever had. Her accent is understandable and her course material is clear concise and easy to understand. All is available on LMS and test are super easy to prepare for, just do the back exams and you will be fine. The homework is a little challenging but she can in office hours or by email.

Prof. Liu is extremely nice, and she knows what she's talking about.  Her accent isn't particularly strong either.  Her Power Point lectures aren't the most helpful, but the book is very informative and useful.  Her tests are fair, and she lets you use a crib sheet on them.

The sweetest lady you'll ever meet at RPI. She cares so much about her students and truly wants to see them succeed. Homework 1/week, tests similar to backtests, few quizzes, lets you use laptops in class, and everything you need is on lms. her anonymous online question forum is excellent for asking questions when you've missed a class or two
She goes through the powerpoint in class, then elaborates on key points. The book is a good read and can be helpful if you get stuck on the homework
She's an OK teacher and is very helpful in office hours, but the book is completely superfluous.
She didn't use videos this time. And she is very concerned about our questions. It is a nice taught class.

She's nice and fair, but relied on LMS/WebCT more than I would have liked. I did NOT like how the video lectures were the primary lectures for learning, and the classroom was treated as a supplement. It should have been the other way around.
She is nice. She cares about students and is easy to be found.

She's basically worthless. Gives "on-class" questions, which she makes us sit there and work on for 40 minutes, then doesn't explain how to actually solve it. If this class wasn't mandatory, you could bet half the class wouldn't be here.

I took ENGR2530 (Strengths of Materials), which is not a selectable option.  While he had a rough start, I believe he got better as the semester went on, making less mistakes and giving better explanations.  By the end of the semester, I was perfectly happy in his class.  Occasionally needs to be reminded to center his notes under the projector.
Save yourself and DO NOT take his course. His course is just a disaster.

I took Shenogin for ENGR 2530 (Strengths of Materials), and it didnt help that this was his first time teaching the course. He reads directly off other profesors' slides, focuses more on theory rather than going through examples and makes frequent mistakes when he does do examples.

I have had this professor for both strengths and MAU. He just reads off of other professor's lecture slides and solves problems on his own, often asking the students if he is correct or how to solve something. He makes many mistakes and often has to be corrected. Please do not take his classes unless you want to learn everything yourself.
Please save yourself and take another professor.

He often can't solve problems because he himself doesn't know what he is doing as he is just copying off an answer sheet and blames the students for their low grades. Both of his sections had the lowest class average and still believes it isn't his teaching. Do not take Strength of Materials with this professor as you won't understand anything.

Hard to even understand him and at times has no idea what he's doing, asking students for help multiple times and taking terrible notes. Really no point in attending his lectures, please switch your professor unless you have no problem learning all the material yourself
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Shenogin is an absolute nightmare. He's completely incompetent—can't solve problems, struggles to explain anything, and often asks students for help. I barely scraped by in his MAU class, thanks only to friends with a different professor. Do yourself a favor and stay far away; he made my semester a total disaster.

I had this professor for MAU and he constantly had no clue what he was teaching. Many days he had to ask students for help solving in-class examples. Many people just straight up didn't show up to lecture and I used his lecture time to study other lecture notes. I almost wish I failed this class so that his average class rating would be lower.

I have taken a short intro course at a different college for strength of materials so I was familiar with the content of the first few days but the way he teaches is way too overcomplicated for the content and he is bad at explaining things which makes it impossible to do the homework without going to a TA or another professor.

Professor Shenogin is by far the worst professor I have had at RPI.  He uses the wrong edition of the textbook, ignores his lecture slides, scribbles notes all over messy sheets of paper, and admits he can't solve example problems.  There are no grading criteria for anything, and some of his solutions are incorrect or end with "too complicated".

Easily one of the worst professors I have ever taken at RPI. Lectures are useless, and half the time it doesn't even seem like he knows how to solve the problems. Very messy hand writing and notes. Tests are completely random, in the same section there will be different versions with some easier than others. Would not recommend.

He has absolutely no clue how to solve the example problems, teaches from a textbook different from the one in the syllabus, and grades by writing a score on the paper without posting a rubric or any grading feedback. I went to another section's professor for help with a problem and he said "What is this guy even trying to teach you?"

Took MAU, not IED with him. Awful handwriting and scribbling all over the page. Never posted lecture notes so if you didn't show up to class you had no clue what was going on. Constantly admitted he had no idea how to solve examples and had to get help from students. Also had no idea when/where exams were so had to ask other sections. Avoid. Him.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: The IED Pilot course has many flaws and Sergei is the most incompetent person to be teaching it. Yes, he's passionate about teaching and an easy grader but multiple times I've had to remind him when assignments were due and rubric criteria. However, he'd always ask the course coordinator my questions and have extended due dates multiple times.
very interesting

Mike is a great guy and a caring teacher. Sometimes the subject is pretty dry, but you just have to force yourself to pay attention and do the work properly. If you do all that, you'll get a great grade. I learned *a lot* of statistics from Mike and, with his help, I finished an award-winning thesis.

Did a thesis independent study with Kalsher. Was completely nonresponsive to emails throughout TWO semesters, and never submitted my grade once my thesis was submitted, which almost kept me from graduating. Completely not helpful, distant, and seems uninterested.
Easy, fun and interesting. Encouraged student participation and gave lots of opportunities to improve one's grade.
A dynamic and interesting professor.

Positive Psych was a great elective class that everyone should take-- for no one else but yourself! Its nice to know the little things you can do to bunce back from failures quicker and generally be happier.
Great Prof. He made the class really interesting and pretty easy

Mediocre lecturer, a bit too boring for me, but he definitely know his stuff.  This class used to be a breeze in previous semesters, but now he's really on the ball about going through most of the pertinent statistical analyses than an undergraduate should know.
Good lecturer and speaker.
Enjoyable classes, charismatic professor.
Awesome teacher! He is hilarious, especially his story about "Doug."
Great professor! Gave us tons of insight into Forensic Psych! Used lots of materials, guest speakers, and projects to make Forensic Psych a great experience! Love those take-home exams too.

All-hail the Comb-Over King. Easily the best Signals prof. Horrible people skills but great prepared notes. Explains concepts using pictures rather than equations which is very helpful. He is simple and straight-forward about the material that needs to be learned and does not over-complicate the class like Wozny.

Lecture is confusing at start of semester because he teaches all the tools first. Things make sense later. Tests are hard but the material is all taught. Professor is very understanding and willing to help. Thorough explanations of the material he covers. Hard, but I would take another course with him.

I haven't even finished this course yet and I can tell you it is going to be a train wreck. Until this point, I have done very well (3.7) in all my courses at RPI. But this course is so poorly taught. His examples are not well explained and he assumes you know WAY more than you realistically would know prior to completing this course.
He is very unfriendly. His teaching style is not very good, he assumes u can skip steps and that you know the materials already.
Terrible teaching. His notes are from 5 years ago. Doesn't connect with students. Can't be compared with Wozny.
His notes are very clear and to the point.  He teaches you everything you need to know in a concise manner.  He's impatient when it comes to questions though.
Professor is horrible. Can't teach. Need help in sending ideas across to students.

Out dated course material--I got out of school and never really could use this material except for conceptualizing "degrees of freedom"  The hand worked matrix algebra may be useful for understanding exactly how a computer works, but not practic
Easily the best Signals prof.  Like stated earlier, he doesn't ramble.  His notes are killer. However, if you want help after class, go to Wozny's office hours.

Best professor you can get for Signals, explains all concepts and will greatly improve your understanding. If you want to actually do well in the class take Desrochers, he doesnt ramble or get side tracked like Wozny. Could be more approachable however.

Not a good professor.  Explains concepts eventually, but beats around the bush a lot.  Not approachable after class at all. Zero people skills.  Get Wozny and save yourself the frustration.  Mike Wozny should be president.

the best comb-over in the college. it starts at one ear and goes to the other; this guy could put a 10 year old boy on stacker caffeine pills to sleep. get wozny for signals and you'll thank yourself later..

2nd class w/. Initially comes off arrogant but genuinely cares you are learning. Assignments, poorly communicated but open-ended. You can submit a lot or a little so long as you show improvementv. easy grader. This class is tangentially MTLE but the topics/skills are very useful. Highly recommend but LOTS of work (10-20 hr/wk) for quality hw.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Unclear assignments and lots of reading, lectures are not very helpful
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: His attempt to explain things in a simpler way makes the material more difficult to grasp. The book doesn't help either as the book goes not helpful material. The book chosen does a poor job preparing students for homework problems in the book. Students end up spending a lot of time in homework but not really learning. His class is also unorganized

He is really passionate about materials science and cares about teaching his students. He makes class interesting since he is so into what he is teaching.  He is definitely willing to meet with students to go over any confusing concepts.  Tests and quizzes are fair.  If you read the textbook, go to class, and study a good amount, you will do well.
Lewis was rude and unprofessional.  He has almost single handedly ruined this school for me.

You need to read the book for his class. What he says is interesting and fun, but not always entirely relevant. Each professor makes his own weekly quizzes with the exception of 4 cumulative quizzes. Prof. Lewis' quizzes are hard, so the cumulative quizzes shouldn't seem that bad.

Passionate teacher who would make a good lab assistant.  NOT a teacher.  He can't convey simple concepts to students because gets too excited and goes off on crazy table-standing tangents.  Also, hes kind of a jerk.
Quizzes are hard but good professor

Even though the subject material was not something I really cared for, Prof. Lewis presented it in a way that made me enjoy attending the class (even at 8am on Mondays.) Prof Lewis always put 110% into teaching this class. His passion for this material really shown in his lectures which is something one does not see often at RPI. Since I am not a M

Very good professor (at least for Mat. Sci).  Showed a genuine interest in his students' learning.  Knows his stuff and is good in getting the material in lectures.  Also, very helpful outside of class.  I'd recommend him highly to anyone taking this course.

Prof. Lewis is an excellent professor. You need to really know your stuff to do well in his class and on quizzes, but he makes the material interesting, and sincerely wants to help you understand things. Recommended for MatSci.

He is the only IEA prof. to use webCT and he has all of his powerpoint presentations online so you can look at them while you are doing homework. Me almost gives away hw points by giving you the answer to the hw questiosn, no other iea prof. does that. if you want to do well and learn, prof. lewis is a great teacher

I had him for circuits in Spring 2011 and thought he was excellent. His notes style was a little hard to follow but he really knows the course material and is very willing to answer any questions you have, even if it isn't directly related to the course.

Schoch is a great guy and was great for LITEC but in terms of circuits he is quite bad in circuits. He is fine for the earlier topics but as you get into the later part of the class his explanations are awful, his notes are incomprehensible and the course is so out of order.
Schoch is a nice guy but can't seem to make himself stop talking, despite the fact that Litec is a lab and not a lecture.  His lectures were about two hours long and worthless.
Schoch is the man. lol. The guy knows his stuff. You call his name, he glances at your code and bam that guy has the solution right a way. Nice guy too and very out going.

I didn't take the class with him, but I have been a LITEC TA with several professors, including Schoch. I can say for sure that the students in his classes come out with the most thorough knowledge of the subject, compared to the other professors.
Schoch really knows his stuff and is helpful in getting his students to succeed.

good guy. If you have a problem with code, he'll see in 30 seconds what would take 5 TA's a week. Fair, knows the course material very well, as far as lectures go, he usually goes a little long, but he's the best of the available options

Best LITEC teacher,though there were problems with the course structure. Once the blimp project of LITEC gets settled, he is the best teacher because he has worked on it the whole time and will have the most experience with the class.  Did not go out of his way to help, but when summoned was helpful
Great guy. Very Knowlegable and competent. If I were in his specific curriculum, I would take another class from him again.
The best professor that you can ask for. He's so easy going. Schoch is very knowlegable. I like this man!!
No Comments
Great Analog Electronics prof. Very good at explaining the material. Helps students understand how to solve problems and why their solutions work. Uses the studio format well.

Professor is a complete and utter mess. I did not receive a single grade back until the end of October for the fall semester. Assignments are extremely unclear and will leave you wondering what he wants with the assignment. Half of time spent completing the assignments is deciphering what he wants. Syllabus says TBD on how we are being graded.
He is very knowledgeable and relates what you are learning to industry. He is very good at making visual aids for students and is always excited to teach.

Awful, awful professor. Failed to update grades for months at a time, leaving us completely blind to how we were doing all semester. Misgendered me constantly, despite being corrected often. Assigned ludicrous homeworks and then complained that his TAs were overworked (from all the grading) when we asked for even a shred of quality control.

EMD was super tough. He was obviously very knowledgeable about the subject but went through his 60-slide lectures way too fast. Refuses to answer questions during class, and will end the WebEx as soon as he's done without taking time for questions. Terrible at communicating through email, which is the only way we could contact him.

horrible horrible. I dont usually leave reviews but had to leave this one . Even if you understand all the information perfectly during lectures, dont worry because he will make the exams a race so youll still do badly anyways .
Lecture slides are a mess and EXTREMELY difficult to follow. Isn't clear during lectures either. Exams are a race to finish.

Lecture notes are a mess and hard to follow. Exams are poorly formatted making them even more difficult. Professor Bagepalli also actively deters students from attending office hours or asking the TAs for help, leaving us with nothing but his chaotic lecture slides.
Very thorough and clear lectures. Useful topics and he really cares about his students. Listen to him when he tells you to take notes
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Lecture heavy

comment: Probably the worst professor I have had. The slides are extremely unorganized and the homeworks are unclear. If a question is asked during class, he will get annoyed at the student for not understanding the first time and doesn't like answering questions before or after class. I found strength of materials to be a breeze, but this is really bad.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: The whole class is just him lecturing, and very hard to pay attention to. The slides are basically everything in the class, but are hard to follow and pretty messy. The homeworks are reasonable, but expect to have to study everything yourself.
B2 is a great professor. It is very apparent he cares about his students. His lectures are easy to understand and are paced appropriately. On top of it all, he is quite a character!

Tests are races, with performance depending more on how much practice the student has as opposed to understanding of material.  While tests are overly punishing, homework and solutions provided by the course are effective at teaching course material.  Lectures are repetitive with error-prone examples.  Attendance dropped as the semester proceeded.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Every single negative trait in this thread was shown by him every time we met. First professor I would give an F to. Only upside is that the chief engineers(who do the actual grading) will take pity on you. Hes a constant roadblock to your progress and loves wasting time. He hates being wrong and always thinks he is the smartest person in the room.
Mark is the worst professor I've ever had at RPI. He is constantly passive aggressive and will never give you clear feedback. DO NOT TAKE!!!!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: DO NOT TAKE

I found Professor Anderson to be extremely unhelpful for capstone. His directions and expectations were never clear, and his tone towards students was often extremely passive aggressive. If you have Anderson for your capstone group, I would strongly advise trying to find a different prof or a substitute class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Mark Anderson was an awful Capstone PE. He refused to answer questions directly, but got angry when things didn't go his way. He lectured us about things he doesn't understand, like mechanical engineering. He lied to us about the previous status of the project, then literally made us keep working on it after our final presentation was over.

Tbh, one of the most underrate person at RPI. He teaches you how to think like a real engineer and had helped us tremendously in our project. The grade received was awful, but he was not one giving us the final grades, don't blame him.

He is incredibly rude, interrupts you constantly so that you can never justify anything you do, treats women like they're hysterical, and makes team members cry. He will never give you direct feedback. It always feels like he's taking you on a long journey about how he's right and you're wrong. I hate the thought of going to class every time.

Mr. Anderson is the worst teacher I have ever met. He gives you hard time during lectures and always tells you he doesn't care about the problem you encountered rather than helping you. Takes forever for him to go through your presentation because he always tells you where you are wrong. Don't take his class if not necessary.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Mr. Anderson is impatient and always tells you that you are wrong. He criticizes you without knowing the whole story and focuses on details that should not matter. In addition, he speaks so fast and it is hard for you to concentrate for the whole class to get everything he says, and he seems to be proud of that. Do not take his class if you can.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Professor Anderson is not a good person. This man refuses to give positive feedback about ANYTHING and will make your group members cry. He wastes class time lecturing the group about why he's right and you're wrong. He treats group members like children. My entire experience at RPI is tainted because of Mark Anderson.
Worst professor at RPI.

I had a great RPI experience, not a single bad professor, until Mark. Most of the feedback you receive from him is negative and sometimes rude. He forces you to do some work of the project, and the next class he claims that he never did . If you have the chance to drop the class just do.  Kept saying for the group that we will get an incomplete

Anderson will always say why what your doing is bad so your not allowed to do it but won't tell you what you should do instead resulting in a continuous cycle of failed proposals and nothing accomplished. If you get anderson I would highly recommend dropping the course and taking it the next semester. Trust me it's worth it.

Had him for comp org. He was super chill and laid back all semester. Explained concepts pretty well and always went over HW/Lab/Test solutions in class which not a lot of professors do. Curved exams with low averages and gave extra credit if you did the practice exam. Highly recommend his Comp Org class, it was a lot of fun.

Very chill professor. Gave extra credit on almost every exam for an easy task that helped you study. Prof Slota thouroughly went over every lab and homework assignment. He also highlighted the important slides for exams, which was very helpful because some lectures were confusing.
Had a fun Comp Org lecture and informative homeworks and labs. It is very clear to find information you need and the exams throughout the year were fair assessments of the content we learned.

Took graph theory last year, graph mining this year with Slota. He's by far my favorite CS professor. Great sense of humor, super chill, and lenient. Great lectures, always posted.

He's a little disorganized which is probably not great for core CS classes, but is perfectly fine for electives (tbh ideal because he'll push due dates back sometimes).

Great professor; he was a funny guy, lenient and laid back, gave extra credit, and took time during class to go through exams, hws, and labs. You'll do fairly well in his class as long as you go to his lectures and/or read the slides. There's one group project at the end that was a bit complex but all in all one of the easier cs classes I've taken.
good lecturer with notes; sometimes lectures were hard to understand but fine overall. no tests in this semester, just lots of homework.

Real nice guy, but very disorganized lecturer. His lazy style of teaching often renders his lectures near-incomprehensible, and I got the impression he didn't care much about teaching the class. Spends too much time reading simple HW instructions in class and fooling around. His tests are very easy (probably too easy).

The course itself is abstract and boring since it is about the hardware. Professor Slota did very well making his lecture fun and attractive. He is the very few professors I seen that will go over homework, labs, and exams in his lecture.
He's a good guy; I just think he's a bit disorganized. I took class asynchronously and missed a lot of assignments because there was 0 communication outside lecture videos.

Slota was okay for Comp Org. He didn't seem to really care too much about the course, nor did he seem to be fully aware of what students knew coming in. He was very approachable and helpful though if you asked questions or went to office hours. He wasn't a great teacher, but he doesn't usually teach this class so I guess he did okay.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: The professor is very good. He gives me a ideal grades

The professor doesn't know what he's teaching. He tried to prove the wrong statement in class and a student showed the counter-example, then he tried to cover his mistake by proving in a totally wrong way. The grades are 100% based on tests. And the syllabus first says tests are open book open notes, then he changed that to close books.

The lectures were boring, I frequently struggled to stay awake, or sometimes even show up. The lectures were kinda slow and repetitive and he's not tech savvy. But the lecture notes were great, it's just a big PDF of great notes, reasoning, and examples, with important equations highlighted clearly for you to put on your crib sheet. Learned a lot!

One of the best professors I have had at RPI. His handwriting is super neat and notes are very clear. He is very fair with his assessments. He doesn't expect you to know things he hasn't taught you. He also cares about his students. After hearing that the first lab took us 6 hours to complete, he modified ALL of his labs to make them only 2hrs max.

Really good Professor. One of the best Professors I had ever met. Wonderful experience in ECSE2050. His writings through his lectures provided enough time to take notes and his explanation of concepts are clear and brief. I did learn a lot and have a thorough understanding of MOSFET BJT in his lecture. You are not going to regret taking IE with him

The material turned out to be alright, and he managed to teach them coherently most of the time, though he does include some questions that weren't clearly elaborated on. The class was a bit disorganized, though, as there were only 2 mentors and they kept changing their office hours. Overall, my experience in this class was alright, I guess.

Is easy to reach out to, very fair when it comes to grading, and has a more interesting approach with lectures and laboratory experiments that helps students further understand the information taught in the course.

Fields and Waves 1 is a tough course but prof. Schubert definitely made it a great learning experience. His lecture's pace is good and makes sure you have time to copy everything down. We only had 8 homework this semester and it was a good complement for lectures. Plus, his tests are not heavy and grading is fair. Past exams are accessible online.

I enjoyed the lecture. Professor Schubert always wrote everything down in beautiful handwriting, which I respect a lot. The lab was fun and not stressful. He is good in teaching among professors in ECSE department. He also cares about students.

Schubert makes Fields and Waves as painless as possible. He take notes in class so you have time to copy everything down, he allows you to have anything handwritten with you on the exams, his back exams are easily found online, his exam questions and homework questions are often reused, and his labs are incredibly easy. He respects your time

He has confusing and fast pace lectures, and does not care about students' feelnigs on exam date. He makes the test on the first day after spring break and after a class-cancelled day was cancelled. Have no idea what he is thinking about.
Fantastic professor. Learned all of the material very well and in a totally painless way.
Good Professor

by far the easiest class ive taken so far. easy A. some homework assignments but the grading is more like, did you do it? instead of did you do it right. i was surprised when i recieved an A because i didnt attend many lectures and i did miss a few assignments

The exams had questions that didn't pertain to anything even touched that much during the lectures. The lectures were too much material in a short amount of time. Very tough grader and the class was unnecessarily hard for a subject that isn't even that difficult.

Micheal Klein outs himself as never once being invited to a party by writing in his syllabus that the quizzes are "from 6AM to midnight on Wednesdays" and by some miracle of incompetence meaning that they are meant to be done on Tuesday, even though every other assignment IS due on Wednesdays.

Dr.Klein knows his stuff but is an awful professor. He rambles during lectures and if you are not specific in the free response section of his exam you'll never get higher than a 65 on his tests. He also sets up review sessions but never checks to see if the mentors can make it so about 50% there is no mentor to help you prepare for your exams.

Dr. Klein is a respectable scientist, but he is not the greatest professor. He tends to forget that it is a course designed for first-year biology majors. He wasted the majority of lecture time rambling about irrelevant information, which made his exams more challenging than necessary. You also must memorize over 200 slides per exam to do well.
Dr.Klein is a very tough grader and if you don't write the answer he wants then you will get no points on the open ended parts of his exam.

exams ar every hard and does not understand the level the students are at. So he has to give back multiple points on the exams because questions are too hard. he does have extra credit tho so thats good
bad communicator and very hard exams

Cell and molec bio is a weed out class, so it's hard by design. Dr. Klein teaches the material well, though, and you can come into lecture for the online tests so you can ask him questions. Very smart guy. Labs were a lot of fun but the reports were long. Extra credit was offered both for the AEFIS survey and for posting on the discussion board.

He isn't an "exciting" lecturer, but he is organized and clear. Reserved but extremely nice & caring towards his students. I had him during covid (online) and he did little cute things for class like starting all his lectures with a montage of frogs, or listening to jazz during exams on WebEx.Grading is clear. Exam content is from the PowerPoints.

This class is much harder than Intro to Biology, so be prepared to actually study. There is a lot of homework for this course, pre- and post-class. Dr. Klein has a clear understanding of what his students' background knowledge is, so don't be afraid to ask "dumb" questions because he will happily answer them.
BIOL 2120 with Dr. Klein was much harder than taking it with other professors. Tests and quizzes are extremely tough.

Professor Olson is one of the worst professors I've had at RPI. During his lectures he never solves out problems which leaves students at a disadvantage and also is not useful for the homework's. He also never proofreads his exams beforehand and likes to add in missing information/change information during the exams. Get ready to self-study.

Olson is probably a great professor for nuclear classes, but he certainly should not be allowed to teach an INTRO Thermo class. He does not do ANY problem solving in lecture, he rambles trying to get students to understand the "big picture" of Thermo but makes 0 sense, and he doesn't even proofread his exams (expect actually impossible questions)

I passed the class, so he managed to teach me a bit.  But almost all learning came from doing homework, not from his lectures.  In his lectures, he showed not only his huge ego but also gave very little actual information about thermodynamics.  Textbook required not only for tables of info but also to actually learn anything.

AVOID AT ALL COSTS - the lecture slides are almost entirely irrelevant to hw/exams and he makes sure to never explain anything fully or properly. He rambles constantly about engineering as a whole but never about thermo. ALL exams including the final have had serious typos and mistakes and overall he seems to have no regards for his students.

Take ANYONE else. Lectures are packed with misinformation that can and will cause you to get wrong answers on exams. Allergic to doing examples. Homeworks/quizzes are nothing like lecture. Multiple hour+ rambles into nowhere. Endless errors on exams. If you're unfortunate enough to have him for Thermo, expect to cling to the textbook for dear life.

AVOID AT ALL COSTS. Simply cannot teach. Readings are usually irrelevant to his lectures. Shows hardly any example problems. So many errors in lectures that if he does convey a point, you are left wondering whether it is accurate. Doesn't accept criticism, and grades harshly if you deviate from "his" method on exams, which are RIDDLED WITH ERRORS!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: WHY IS HE TEACHING THERMO? I can never read his notes, which is very irrelevant to exams. Try another professor if you have any other choices...

The professor has made mistakes on almost every exam, including the Final Exam. His notes are difficult to read and contain some mistakes. There were a few errors with due dates too. He is better at explaining course material at office hours. During lectures he can get off-topic and talks about sustainable energy and other semi-related topics.

everyone is review bombed him because of his thermo class this year, but much of his shortcomings this year were not all his fault. the exams this year were missing key variables in order to solve the problems, but in respect to the actual course and how he taught it, i dont know how it would be done better. in his office hours he was very helpful.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback

comment: He understands the material well and gave a lot of opportunities for students to do well. The exams were difficult but he gave points for getting the basics down even if you didn't get the question completely right. With that said, he took lecture notes using a mousepad and you could barely make out his handwriting...
Messed up 3 exams, the back and practice exams don't help, take thermo with any other professor if you can, even if you have to wait.
great man, big arms
Very vague in his explanations and very messy hand writing

Don't take for thermo try someone else. His lectures almost never have anything to do with test material. Never even did a practice problem he just rambles on about engineering stuff not related to course material. Almost all of the learning is done through homework by teaching yourself as his lectures don't help.

I both love and hate Olson as a lecturer. His lectures are very interesting and engaging. However, they're irrelevant to the homework/exam content 70% of the time. Expect most lectures to be rambly and opinionated, mainly covering engineering as a whole. If you like fun lectures and can teach yourself the material, pick Olson. Otherwise, don't.

He really wanted students to learn to problem-solve as opposed to just memorizing course content. Lectures weren't always super helpful with homework, so some reading in the textbook helped a lot with unfamiliar content, but I thought they were pretty engaging and to the point most of the time.

Lectures can deviate greatly from homework and exams but are interesting and intended to make you understand fundamental and real-world applications of Thermodynamics. Most of the learning is from homework.

The reading is not required but is recommended for people who would normally rely on lectures for course content.
He is the best professor i have ever had. nobody can teach np completeness like him. he understands student psychology very well and caters his lectures accordingly.

Professor Goldberg seemed a bit quiet the first couple of lectures, but he explains the material very well.  His grading is very lenient, but that is partially offset by having slightly higher cutoffs.

Good professor. Knows his material. Always willing to help and replies to emails in seconds. Unfortunately has difficulty teaching material 'cause of his age and accent. I think it's funny that he answers his phone in the middle of lectures. Who's calling him so much?

Goldberg is one of the few people in the theory wing of the CS Dept who seems to care about undergraduate students.  He really seemed interested in getting us to understand the material, and while at times he was boring, his accent was a non-issue and his HW/test questions were challenging yet fair.
Knows what he is doing. You will hate him at the begining and love him by the end.
Lectures were illuminating, but disorganized.  Helpful course website with full lecture notes and grades.  The final was much harder than the rest of the class.

He has a strong accent that is very hard to understand, and his intelligence is at a level where his thought process really makes people too confused to understand what he is trying to teach.  But his grading is very lax.
Prof. Goldberg is very intelligent, and very helpful.  His classes are difficult but you will definatly walk away with a good understanding of the material if you take it seriously.
the worst
Goldberg rules!  Exceptionally helpful; excellent classes, great resource
One of the worst Comp Sci professors the Institute hired, apathetic to students

Pretty good professor, only had him for the lecture part of the class I took and not the lab. He explained the material well and provided a lot of resources to study for tests, even giving out more back exams when students requested. He is pretty available online outside of class hours as well.

Tough class, coding in C, lecture is really helpful for the lab. Wilt is professional but still very approachable and willing to help (particularly if you attended lecture).
The software and hardware are pretty finicky so expect a lot of debugging, read the very through documentation as many possible issues are recorded. 
Knowing basic C is helpful

The class is a lot of work, but Wilt helps a lot if you get stuck. He's a cool guy and really knows his stuff. Get a good lab partner, especially if you aren't too strong coding. Tests and quizzes are difficult, strongly recommend going to lecture.

emb cont is time consuming and tough. Wilt makes the lectures as interesting as he can but most of them are pretty boring. Get a good lab partner and prepare to spend hours in open shop. The quizzes are very tough and the tests are rough but most of your grade comes from the labs. If you fully complete all the labs, you'll do well in the class.

Good professor and cool guy. For ENGR-2350, I highly recommend. For ECSE-4790, not so much, unless you really want to get into embedded systems. The class is a ton of work, particularly the lab reports, which need to be like 20-30 pages to get a good grade. Take this with a grain of salt though because he might change the class in the future.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Engaging and highly relevant lectures, which integrated very well with the lab and activities portion of the course.
Probably the best professor at RPI, he's great
Pay attention during lecture and actually do the labs if you wanna do well in the class. The prof is available outside class, and his office hours are a ton of help.
He's energetic, passionate and friendly. He knows a lot and cares a lot about his students. He's young, too. Talking to him is like talking to a dude , but with repect.
Dr. Wilt is a BIG BOSS. He's awesome and he's full of energy. Take any class he teaches!

I had LITEC with him last semester.  I liked the lecure content, but they got pretty boring sometimes.  The textbook was a PDF that we could print out, and we could use any printed reference materials on the tests, which were absurdly difficult but curved.  I liked the labs, but make sure you get good partners.
He basically doesn't teach and doesn't have much interactions with students, especially with male students.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Dr. Patterson's ability to cover the material in a thorough and engaging way made it very worthwhile to attend lecture. She wanted each and every one of us to succeed and made sure the course was well-organized. Although certain exams were difficult, she was honest about this and curved our grades fairly, even providing us with extra credit.

Kept the class running smoothly even though this was her first semester teaching it. Exams were nearly 100% of the grade, but there were a few quizzes to encourage attendance. HW was required to pass. You can only succeed in this class if you have the ability to invent algorithms on the fly during exams. Just knowing the material is not enough.

Dr. Patterson did a great job teaching intro to algo given that it was her first time teaching the class. She stayed very organized and posted all of her lecture notes and made sure to reiterate past material which made it much easier to comprehend. Entire grade was made up of exams, and she gave a fair curve to each exam.

Patterson seemed to really care about her students and the content she taught. She was engaging in her lectures, and was open in how she graded and how she made her exams. She provided ample review material for exams, of which your entire grade was based on. But she gave up to 5% extra credit, and even curved at the end.
This class is pretty hard, do a lot of practice problems to study for exams.

The main goal of her lectures is to explain how smart she is. Intentionally withholds information from lectures so that it can be asked on exams. Her answer to almost any question you ask during office hours will be to figure it out yourself. Keeps deleting Submitty forum posts and then complains that the forum isn't active. Rewarding homeworks.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Gives amazing feedback, is very invested in her students and clearly wants everyone to get good grades and understand the material. Is very willing to engage with the students (she also appreciates some good humor with the students, which makes the class's atmosphere much better). She definitely knows her stuff and is enthusiastic about teaching

No photographing in class allowed. Released lecture slides w/o annotations is basically blank. *Releases little solutions* to practice, review and homework problems. These factors combined have made reviewing difficult. Homework problems rather difficult and *not* from textbook. Not as willing to apply grade curve as other prof for this class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Beware of pop quizzes--Tough grader

comment: I have to say she is pretty and gives really awesome lectures. Its a pleasure to be in her lecture. However, she cares about her authority a lot, does not post hand writing notes like other profs, and makes hw harder than other profs who teach the same class. its a bit not nice to non native English speakers who sometimes cant keep up her lectu
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Amazing lectures

comment: Not the course for undergraduate level
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--SO MANY PAPERS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: One of the best courses I have taken at RPI. Why? Reasons below: The classes are driven by participation of fellow students.  The exam and quiz questions test the concepts well and are cheating-proof. You have to work out the answer, it is not available on the internet or in the notes directly.

Has a clearly defined schedule in the syllabus from the beginning of the semester, and grading criteria is always well-explained, particularly on lab reports. Always on top of his responsibilities as a professor (holding extra study hours, responding to emails, etc.).

Was a great class, and surprisingly the best intro course by far. Don't be afraid to take this class with Lander, great guy and very to the point. Also, he may come off as a bit sassy at times but this isn't anything to worry about. Accent is the best too, fits the class perfectly.
He is a nice guy but he can be pretty disorganized at times. For labs he is very specific on formatting. I liked that final was optional.

Great man love the accent too
Easy-to-follow lectures and exams are fair. I also like that the final was optional.
This man is an absolute G. You can tell he was raised by the streets and is respects the code. He will never cross you and will always take the time to explain things better.
dan lander is undefeated

Surprisingly nice and understanding guy, class is engaging despite occasionally dull material. He realizes that some of the concepts are very confusing and does his best to address students' difficulties. Not a pushover, will make sure you actually do the work but it is in the interest of making sure people actually learn the material.

He loves the material, he is funny, a little snarky, and actually cares about you learning the material (Hint, he is obsessed with triggering turbulent flow). He is passionate about climate change, and the homework reflects the material well. The homework can be supported by chegg, however, the numbers/exact details will be different.

3 Tests, weekly homework, 4 quizzes, and a group project will define your grade for his thermals and fluids class. He's a very knowledgeable guy but has no idea how to pass on that knowledge. Very boring lectures and unless you've got previous background on the subject, you probably aren't going to follow along very well.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Lander is easy to be impatient when someone asks simple questions in class. The lecture notes are a little bit messy. His tests are quite tricky including conceptual questions and extended answer questions. The time for tests is really limited. About the homework, we have at least one homework per week.

Dan Lander is an excellent IED professor! He is a very friendly and approachable person. Also, he appears to be one of the most generous grading IED professors. Despite two of our subsystems not working properly, my group was still able to pull a B+ on the demo. We also got an A+ on the final memo, and many other professors simply dont give A+s.

Dr. Bello taught the last few weeks of PChem, and I really enjoyed his portion of the class. The material is a bit challenging, but he walks you through examples in class and assigns homework that is both relevant and graded. He somehow made PChem less scary.
Hes a great teacher and has a lot of life experience in the medical and chemistry fields. Definitely willing to go out of his way to help you out with classwork or understanding the material.
He was really helpful and his lab sessions were very informative. He is a lot better than Prof Korenowski and he knows the matierial. Good teacher!

I had him for the last quarter of Physical Chem and I learned so much just from those 7 lectures, it was amazing, I learned a lot more than I did from  Professor Chang Ryu for sure.  Bello will go out of his way to help you and definitely cares about making you understand the material :)
