Great teacher. (Molecular Biochemistry II) is heavy material, but he explains it very clearly. He makes biochem so interesting by relating it back to medicine.
Nice guy, helpful and clear in class, but tends to be a little long-winded
He Pretty much rocks! He held extra study sessions on the weekend to help with tests... hes really smart and will help you alot if you let him!
Helps a lot, a really nice guy
No Comments
I loved him as a teacher...a lil boring at times ..but cared about ur grades if u asked for help always willing
Lots of interactive teaching. Provides precise materail to study with. Tests are moderately challenging but he prepares you very well for them.

Professor never really seems terribly prepared, nor does he demonstrate mastery of the material. He reads directly off of the slides, which he posts online; paying attention is almost a game. His exams way exceed how he presents himself and the material in lecture. Wait a semester and take it with a different professor.

Biomaterials with Tacy is actually not that bad... he seems to be knowledgeable and interested. There is a lot of focus on the monstrous textbook, but you can easily get good grade in the class by just studying the lecture slides and skimming the textbook. Only reason I go to class is for quizzes and the sporadic attendance taking.
Not a very helpful professor. Reads verbatim off the sides and does not know much about what needs to be done for class.

Prof Tacy is a great professor. He really cares about his students and is very easy to talk with. He has a great interest in the topics of this course, despite it sometimes being boring. Highly recommend taking any class with him!

Has good intentions, and knows the material well (as hard and annoying as it is), but his lectures are kind of boring because he tends to speak in a monotone.  Very helpful in office hours though.  If you have questions, make sure to go to him and/or ALAC tutoring.  Tests are almost always medium-difficulty problems right from the homework section.

I had Tacy for Strengths, and he was horrible at expalining the material. In class examples, we would spend half the time doing basic arithmetic, making it impossible to stay engaged. He also refused to use units in examples, making them hard to follow.
One of the better professors at RPI. Clearly explains concepts and answers questions well. Uses the same lecture slides as everyone but he explains them well and engages the class.

Good, straightforward, easy to understand professor. Lectures are directly from the slides, but he does a good job explaining concepts. Most importantly, all the test material is covered thoroughly and effectively.  Always helpful in office hours or after class. Recommended.

Prof. Tacy was great. Helped students when needed. Material was presented on PowerPoint that was awful but not his fault given to him by department. He displayed a amazing understanding of the material and a commitment to the students.  Before test reviews were the most important class. This s where prof tacy excelled!
Reads off a powerpoint, go to SI sessions to learn the material
This proffessor repeats himself many times during class. It seems as if he does not read the slides before class. He has a very boring presentation style.
I really enjoyed the course and learned a whole lot. I truly believe that the general awareness on how robots will affect society is extremely low

I have taken several classes with this professor. At first I was impressed because I thought he was really interesting and unique. But eventually his **** and inappropriate comments and ego centric attitude became too much to deal with. He has limited usefulness, all his classes are the same stories over again.

Good teacher who is actually interested in teaching students. He is radical and very opinionated, but that makes for a strong professor. Some may not like his seemingly self-centered attitude, but I found it made the class more interesting.

Coolest professor I've had so far!  Encourages you to actually think about customs like marriage and religion, and is pretty funny as well.  Class consists of reading a chapter from textbook for homework, writing a 1-2 page paper on the topic every week, and taking a short quiz on the topic each week.
No Comments
huge ego, entire time he tries to make everyone an athiest and then tells us that capitalism is a bad form of government and we should embrace communism.  Huge Marx fan, total ****
yeah, he has an ego. but is IS right so there's not much you can argue with there. considering this is a tech school, most of the people taking the class really DON'T know what they're talking about.

Expect a *very* interesting course.  Note:  he says he wants you to "think" and to hone your "bs detector" but, hypocritrically, often expects you to take what he says with faith.  Or he may refer you to some variety of Sociology research that goes beyond an intro course.
Sal did have an ego, but he made you think and test your own views. His class was awesome.
Restivo definitely has an ego on him. It made establishing your own views on the material very difficult, especially if they opposed his. I think the course was pretty one-sided.
Awesome professor.  Helps you see the world completely different.
Dr. Tessier is a great professor and a great guy. His classes are difficult, so take his lectures seriously. He is very willing to help students if they seek it out. Awesome facial hair.
i china student can't get him very well. but good proffosor.

This man is amazing. If you want to do well in the class, he will put forth all of his energy to make sure you do so. Very helpful. Absurdly difficult exams, but he makes sure people don't fail. He connects with students and changes the class to fit the needs of the students. All around great guy. His wife bringing in desserts was a plus too!!

Where to start? Congrats to RPI for taking a hold of Tessier. Amazing Professor with plenty of passion towards his profession. It gets better, Tessier is brilliant. He is extremely devoted to teaching, prepares his lectures and students incredibly well. He also rewards his class by encouraging them and praising those who participate and are active.
One of the best professors I've met at RPI.  If you show interest in the class, he will like you and help you.
very very helpful. at the same time, the test is very very difficult
Very nice guy. He tries very hard to help you out when you need it. Exams can be difficult but he does curve them to a B- average. Lectures are very useful and necessary.

Very good professor. He wants his class to be challenging but makes it so that if you don't understand at first, you get many chances to get a grasp on it. Wife's a great cook, review sessions he gives the test out. ADORABLE little girls! One of the few professors who actually knows your name! A nice alternative to the typical professor.
Great professor.  He really tries to make sure you understand what he's teaching.  Changes his style to fit the class needs.  Just all around a great guy.
Would give everyone a A if he could! He is laid back and amazing and will give his tests out in review sessions

Extremely good teacher.  You learn everything you need to learn and he gives excellent examples in class.  Lots of opportunities to get essentially free points and test questions are given during the review session.  Excellent Professor!!
Sometimes grading out of the momentary feeling. Educational and well prepared lectures are recommended. Easy course testing materials as well as the homeworks.
Amazing professor and course. You will love the lectures and course both. He is very easy-going and respects his students.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Best RPI MANE Professor.
This class was very challenging but I enjoyed it because he is such a good professor. Very funny and easy to understand despite the complex subject matter
Great professor who can explain the heavy staffs in clearest possible manner
one of the best professors ever met in RPI
Had him for Fracture Mechanics and fatigue of materials. He knows his stuff, explains it well, and obviously cares about the students. Is surprisingly easy to meet with. Highly recommend.
This guy knows his s**t, and he can explain it very well. Excellent use of diagrams and examples in class. He can be pretty funny too.

I like him. He didn't use powerpoints during lecture so I had to pay attention to what he was writing down and the examples he did. He explains concepts quite clearly and is actually a pretty entertaining guy.

One of the few professors at RPI that knows his stuff and can also explain it. Ask him any materials science question and he'll have an answer. He jokes around in class a lot and is a generally nice guy.
No Comments

I had her for Phys 1250. She is a very nice person. However, I struggle day-in and day-out to comprehend her lectures. Almost every time I ask for help she cannot give a concise answer. She is passionate, but she expects us to do so much with a new topic; her in-class activities will take you well after class time to complete and leave you confused

E&M is already a hard topic to learn and Wertz just made it worse. The workload in the course is ridiculous with daily lecture activities, and HW that she never goes over. The exams while not being worth that much are very difficult and her grading is rather unforgiving. Constant labs being in Jupiter notebook only add to the intense workload

Exams go beyond class content, including conceptual questions not adequately covered. The course pressure is unusually high due to perceived unfairness in exam questions and the dullness of the content. Professor Wertz focuses heavily on formula derivation, neglecting the explanation of physical significance and interesting anecdotes.

Her lectures were basically just reading off the slides, and she can't really explain concepts in any other way - if you didn't get it the first time, she won't be able to help. All of the grading was done by the TA (who was actually really cool). Tests (for all of phys I) are all multiple choice, the rest of the grade is in-class activities + HW.

It was an online course during the covid era. She simply did not give any lecturing and asked us read textbook by ourselves. Besides, she would straight give you 0 out 5 participation points if you not talking in "5 min feminism" (which was usually 30 min btw), which capped your overall grade at 95%, making it extremely hard to get an A.

Be very careful of the participation!!! You not only need to attend the class but actually answer the question. I got good grades in all exams, quizzes, and homework. I only got 1 out of 5 of participation points just because I didn't answer questions during the class.

I came into this class with such high hopes only to be utterly disappointed. I literally feel as if I learned nothing in this class. When I tried to ask basic questions, Wertz could not even answer really. She gets so nervous. She is so out of touch with difficulty levels so hw assignments are long and beyond difficult and the exams are cruel.

Exceedingly tough class. The exams aren't all that bad, and the quizzes are also fairly ok, but the homeworks... god, the homeworks. Also home of the infamous five minutes of feminism. People might say they disliked it, but imo it is one of the most important parts of the class, because you talk about things physicists need to think more about.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: I have had Wertz for EM theory and nano optics. She's OK but slightly below average. I learned my stuff in EM theory but honestly can't say I learned any nanoptics. She doesn't always know EM as well as she should and is very self conscious. She can grade surprisingly harshly and for nano optics assigned way to much(unrelated) work for 2 credits.

Professor Wertz is very nice and if you ask her for help she will gladly give it to you. She also heads Women in Physics. EM Theory is tough as anything but Professor Wertz makes it accessible, and the tests are tough but survivable. I enjoyed having class with her!
rating_tags: Respected--Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Electromag theory was probably the worst class I've ever taken. Unfortunately, Prof. Wertz is extremely out of touch with what students need more time on, which is partly the students' faults for never asking questions. Explanations usually rather non-intuitive. Tests not that difficult. DEMONICALLY difficult and long homeworks from the get-go.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: I received a hard earned A- after a very challenging final but this class is absolutely worth taking. Uchida replies emails in a very timely manner and also sets his office hour 24/7. This class could be challenging, need TA's help during class, but all these could be overcame with office hours. 10/10 would take again.

Professor Uchida is what made me stay at RPI. IEA is so unbearably hard, but this man made it go by not as bad as it could have. The most caring professor I've ever had. He cares, 95% of professors don't. Will go out of his way to help is students get the best grade as possible and helps the students (me) struggling get through the semester. 10/10
Dude is very nice and actually cares about his students. He is sometimes difficult to understand because he has every accent under the sun. Best teacher I've had here so far.
Very good professor, cares a lot. If he sees you working hard in class and sees you show your work as he walks around, it won't go unnoticed. He is a very good professor and IEA is easier with him
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --So many papers--Accessible outside class

comment: One of *the* best professors at RPI by a long shot. He's very nice and actually cares about his students. He's approachable and tries to make sure that everyone understands the material. The class material can be difficult but the way he taught made things a lot easier. I 100% would recommend taking his section if you can.
Do not take this professor for IEA. Other professors will let you use crib sheets, he will not, and you will only find this out after the add deadline.

He is such a great professor. Unlike the administration here, he actually cares and wants to see you succeed. Just ask for help if you are struggling and he will help you out. Best professor I have had so far.

Easily the best professor I've had during my time at RPI. Incredibly engaging during lectures, doesn't waste time, and is so helpful with learning the material. He is very accessible outside of class, responds to emails quickly, and clearly cares that students learn the material. I looked forward to every class.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: He is really good at teaching. If you pay attention to his class, the course will be really easy for you. He will reply the email as soon as possible , especially before big test. You will love IEA, if you take his class.

The homework is a lot harder than the lectures and the tests. As long as you do a couple back exams before the tests and do the example problems during lecture, you will do fine. Shun is a good teacher who cares about his students and will give you points back on practically anything on the tests if you explain yourself. He is cheerful and lectures
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Good at teaching in general Wants you to do well and gives multiple opportunities to do so Understanding Interesting accent, easy to understand, but interesting Funny guy

The tests were very difficult but there was a massive curve for the class. It's composed of both undergraduate and graduate students. He's a very good professor and the subject is very difficult. If you go to him he can help you a lot but don't take this class if you plan on getting a good grade. But you will learn a lot about Polymers.
V good

I have interacted with professors various universities in Germany, France and India, but I rate him on the top in all aspects. Students working with him are really lucky. He is a very good mentor, teacher and friend
i dont know about his classes but i did research with him and i loved it. one of the best people i ve ever worked for period. i ve not seen such a nice gentleman ever before.
takes time to explain what is really going on in the experiment, his quizes suck, but he is a good prof

Had him for lab, very nice and very helpful...his bad days were like Prof. Moore's exceptionally good days, so it was a treat for me after having Moore for a semester.  Explained all of the reactions really well and was totally fair about grading.  Would write out formulas on the hood so you could see them while you work.
Really fair, and not too difficult.
this guy is nice, i like him...
If u make the mistake of askin this dude a question, then clear your schedual cause u gonna be there for a hot minute. TALKS TO MUCH!!!!!!
over-demanding.  if you fell behind he left you behind
No Comments

She is a lovely person, but her lecturing ability left a little to be desired.  Her lectures were always under time, which was nice, but I would have liked a little more in-depth explanation.  When I went to her office hours, she was very cordial and patient, which is her most redeeming quality.  Her tests were variable in difficulty as well.

Aminian  is a nice person, but she isn't a very good professor. She really just reads the textbook for an hour. Regardless, calc 2 is easy and her tests are simple. just go to recitation and skip the lectures.

I thought she was very nice but her lectures were dry. Most of differential equations was explaining how to get the formulas you needed. Let you have equation sheets. Overall I thought the class was good.

Probably the worst math professor I've ever had. She's nice and everything but she does a horrible job teaching. She speaks very softly and her lectures are very dry. Don't bother going to the lectures cuz she'll just confuse you. She doesn't help much in office hours. I never went to class, just for the tests which were not bad.

I'm fairly certain she only taught the course because Prof. Reubenfield died a month before semester started. Regardless, I regret ever having gone to her class. It's boring, dry, she can't teach basic concepts (her description of a function was two circles with arrows pointing from one to the other). Avoid unless you already know the material.
most boring professor ever

Professor Aminian teaches lectures very thoroughly. She goes through every step painstakingly slow. But, if you want to learn, she certainly provides you with a wealth of information. Calculus tests are extremely easy, mandatory (for a good grade) weekly quizzes are bothersome.

My friend just posted a review of her and I agree. She's probably a nice person, but her training in CS is very limited and I find it hard to believe she has a Ph.D. Fortunately, the other RPI profs more than make up for her.

I can understand where the previous opinions are coming from, but this professor is not that bad. Yes, she isn't very clear sometimes, but you should still try to understand/learn the material before you judge her. You can be more in control of your grade in this class than you think, especially since the exams are easy. Just put in some effort!

Very unclear. On the first day, for example, she wrote on the chalkboard in something only somewhat larger than normal handwriting, so I couldn't read it even from the third row with my glasses on. She went on to fix this issue, but there were still consistent problems with her class.

Her lectures are usless, she takes the most round about and confusing method to explain concepts. She only used book examples. If we didn't have a quiz nearly every lecture, i don't think anyone would attend.
Great course...best HASS I've taken at RPI. Grades are based on papers and a final performance project. Fun class.

She's a philosophy major teaching non-philosophy courses. Has no idea how to perform the most basic tasks on a computer, which would normally not be an issue in a literature class; however, she likes to take up class periods with presentations on the background of a book or on surrealist art. Grades easy, but class is boring.

Horrible teacher. Scattered in style, doesn't know what she's doing electronically, and constantly goes off topic for no reason. She's boring, monotonous, and generally just not a fun person to be in the room with.
Easy class, but hard to sit through--she's pretty scatterbrained and has a habit of going off topic. Overall, not horrible, but I wouldn't recommend it unless you love the subject.

Visual Culture was originally 4000-level, but got demoted to 2000-level during this past semester. That was probably a good idea. Though I learned a lot, and though Esrock is knowledgeable, class discussion relied heavily on student participation. Also, for too much of the time we were learning straight from the text. That's not how culture works.
Boring class. Read a lot of books and a presentation. She's sometimes unfair with her grading. But, otherwise, it's a fairly easy class to take.

Worst class I have ever taken!!!! She is flippin crazy!!!! She spent atleast 2/3 of the class reading aloud. This was a graduate course, normally we are expected to read for ourselves. She was rude and disrespectful to students during private meetings. In class she was unable to answer basic questions, and unable to lead a discussion.
Scatterbrained and totally out there. Avoid her at all costs. She thinks she knows what she's talking about but just ends up running herself in circles and half the time she's wrong.
No Comments

She always tries philosophizing during class time, and just ends up going in circles about nothing. Doesn't let you think for yourself. A relatively easy class, but the material covered was awful, and she just presses her own opinion on you, even on debatable concepts such as surrealism and abstract performance. Cant spark discussions for anything.
Ellen is great!  She is really laid back, flexible, full of crazy stories, and makes class really enjoyable.  She's quite an interesting character.

Took Intro to Graphic Design with her. I absolutely loved her. Very knowledgeable and gives excellent feedback. Projects have clear guidelines for grading but not for specific content so requires some creativity. She's very willing to help you with projects and with other non-course stuff too. Definitely recommend.
An excellent professor!! She always provides me with excellent advice and ways to improve my pieces in critique. Best teacher for the start of the graphic design
not recommend
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Amazing professor!! She places a high value on the creative progress of every student, regardless of their major. She motivates me to strive for improvement as an artist and venture beyond my comfort zone. She is also incredibly skilled at providing constructive feedback that helps her students grow and improve.

Prof. Tack has a wealth of knowledge to offer and a consistent dedication to making sure we get the most out of our courses - like organizing field trips to local design studios, and bringing in guest lecturers. By offering diligent and individualized attention to every student's work, I felt that she was fully committed to helping us succeed.
Extremely hard as an intro level design course. Reviews and feedback are always are mostly negative.

The hardest part was that class was at 8:00. I woke up at 6:00 for class once. You must have work printed out and posted on the board before class starts. The large-scale printing assignment was the most frustrating because of this, esp. dealing with the VCC plotter. Listen to feedback and integrate it for a good final grade. Adobe is fun to use
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Probably one of the best design professors at RPI, though she is extremely tough. She makes you work for your grade, though you come out of every class with a vast amount of design knowledge.

She's an excellent teacher,the best design teacher in RPI. BUT she is tough. Classes are usually at 8am and if you get there more than 5 min late you get points off. You have to work hard in this class but you learn a lot and it pays off in the end. At first she seems like she's super anal but she means well.
Very friendly and easy to talk to. Good designer and teacher.
I took her color theory class and I felt I learned a lot about color.  She has a very casual way of teaching.  Also she has constant he responsive feedback that is very useful.
The lecture is very clear. She always gives clear instructions and if you read through the lab notebooks, it is very easy to follow. Easy to get above 95 for her tests.

Class is a combination of using R for coding and pen/paper math. Grade consists of weekly labs, bi-weekly homework, two group projects, and two exams. Overall Prof Bennett is fairly solid. Gives clear instructions, notes are easy to understand, and the work is challenging but not extremely hard.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Group projects--Caring

comment: She's a decent professor along with Professor Erickson, the class definitely requires for you to be there and put effort from the beginning. Most assignments and exams are cumulative, so you should have a good understanding of previous topics and continue with that. Put in work and you should do fine, I found the TA Karan extremely helpful.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Group projects--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Seems she genuinely wants students to learn the material, but it would help if she prepared before each lecture. She often seems to have forgotten key points she's trying to convey, and the discontinuity of thought as she tries to piece things together at the board ends up more confusing than helpful. Also be ready to come up with your own project

She doesn't really explain things all that well and she doesn't do enough examples. I think it also would have been helpful if she'd stuck to the textbook a little more which would have made it more useful.
She makes mistakes an nearly every slide. She also goes through things too quickly.

Terrible professor.  You can see she has put some time into preparing slides for this class but is absolutely awful at teaching any of it.  She needs to prepare before class, not let her voice die down in the middle of a sentence, and use lots and lots of examples in class.  Also, I thought the grading system was terrible.  Avoid her if you can.
No Comments

plenty of examples in class - if only she had worked out the examples ahead of time there would be fewer small mistakes that students have to point out to her - the in-class tests were relatively easy and the final was moderately challenging - overall, a pretty decent prof
Needs to stop eating her marker.  And I would appreciate not seeing her entire thought process in my lecture notes 3 weeks later.  PS - I love the black velvet jumpsuit... that's ****in hot as hell
Cute
Professor keeps classes extremely interesting. This was my favorite class at RPI so far.

it's refreshing to take class from someone different than other profs here. grandeau is no scholar. he's a professional who teaches on the side. that's why the intellectual content is simple. a break from th demanding classes taught by profs

Still recovering...  I learned a lot about contracts which I now think about all the time.  I think that is a good thing.  I suggest recording every class and bring a pocket constitution to class, he will appreciate that. I liked going to class everyday.  Don't worry about the points thing, just earn as much as you can whenever possible.
This class was always interesting and for the people who said he doesn't teach anything, they obviously just did not understand the concepts; I learned a ton.
He is a very interest guy. Show up all the time and be careful with the game he plays and you'll be good.

Whoever says Grandeau teaches nothing in this class is clearly too big of a moron to understand the whole underlying lessons to what may seem like idiotic babble. This class really gets you into the mindset that you need to learn the principles and Grandeau makes it engaging. This is a great class and a lot of fun. I would definitely reccomend it.
Hated this class..he doles out points randomly. I couldn't pay attention ever in this class. Your grade fluctuates a lot..you are never sure if you have an A or not.

One of the worst professors at RPI.  He is not qualified to teach, and RPI decided to have him back since the tenured professor for the course retired.  He uses no textbook and there is no homework.  You are graded on the little quizzes and tests he has as well as the random points he gives out.  If you are not on a team he likes you will not get a
A BLAST. I loved every second of his class.

This guy is a freackin character.  We dont use any textbooks.  He makes up crazy stories and has the class determine whether someone can get sued, or whether its illegal, etc....Grading:  If you are within 50 % of the highest point total you get a B, 80 % of the highest point total you get an A.  He didnt follow this and gave half the class A's
Funny as heck... great class... learn a lot and didn't mind getting up at 7:00 to go to his class
the worst professor I ever see

He does iclicker questions, but does not actually care when 70% of the class gets a question wrong. He is not clear, he uses the book he wrote, but it is filled with mistakes. The first test was similar to homework but the second test and the final were very different. Attendance is not mandatory, but highly suggested just for the iclicker points.
Easiest A

He spends a lot of time in the math and rarely relates it to tangible things. The homeworks are reasonable, and though he claims if you do the homework you will be fine for exams, it isn't true. The exams are utterly  pulled out of thin air. Even the best students are left confused by the questions. Sadly hasn't figured out iClicker tech yet.

Amazing professor. I can't think of anyway I would have survived probability and statistics without Professor Woods' keen intellect and desire to teach. I came in with little to no knowledge in the subject matter, but he really helped me along the way and I have grown not just as a student, but as a man as well. 1010 would take again.

Excellent course, I found PEA to be one of the most interesting courses I have taken at RPI.  This is not a course where you can get away with only a cursory knowledge of the material, you have to work at it but it is worth it.  Although I didn't really feel the need, Papoulis is a good supplemental book if Wood's book is not sufficient.

This guy is truly the worst professor I've ever had at RPI. He does not know how to convey the material in any other way than using equations. His notations make the course an exercise in understanding what he's trying to say and not in understanding the concepts. He claims that English is not specific enough-- I claim that he is not being helpful.

By far the worst professor I've ever had at RPI. His tests ARE RIDICULOUSLY DIFFICULT! Don't bother going to class, you will fall asleep. The textbook is hard to understand and it makes too many assumptions. Hopefully you get a good TA, probably won't though. Have to stay an extra semester because of this course! Stereotypical arrogant professor.

As a senior, I've been through quite a few bag professors, but Woods is by far the worst. Not only is he extremely arrogant and full of himself, his lectures, exams, homeworks, and the book he wrote are all awful. PEA has been the worst experience I have had at this awful school. To top it off, he is a useless advisor. Avoid him if you can!

Avoid, avoid, avoid! He is horrible PEA professor. The PEA textbook that he co-authored is horrible as well. Reading the old textbook was the only way I was able to learn the material. Try and find the old textbook (Probability & Stochastic Processes, 2nd edition, by Yates & Goodman) if you actually want to learn the PEA material .

Oh yeah, I forgot to mention.  He is also the absolute worst professor I have ever had.  And that says a lot, considering how horrible a large percentage of RPI professors are.  Avoid this man at all costs.  Please!!

While I feel this class doesn't require a particularly good professor, I nonetheless feel he is a great professor to have. Grading criteria is reasonable, workload is on-par with a 1 credit class, and the final project/presentation is easy. If you're forced to take BIOL-1010, I highly recommend this class and professor.
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: While a good professor, his lectures didn't always seem 100% relevant to material being tested. He does have a very dry sense of humor, which I appreciated, and I walked into Biostats knowing nothing, and learned a lot. He was very helpful if you needed it.
rating_tags: Group projects--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: Lectures were easy to follow and interesting. He is a very kind person. However I don't think grading criteria was clear and I lost points on the last project even though I definitely think that I checked all the boxes on the rubric. but overall a very smooth experience.

While I think it's clear he is here to do research, his class was interesting and pretty easy to follow. The hardest part of the lab work was following his code in R studio but if you have had previous experience with coding it is pretty straightforward and much better than a traditional lab.

Dr. Stetler did not assign more work than should be required by a 1 credit class. The use of real-world data sets made data analysis with R interesting. The design of his course, specifically the final group project, was effective in helping us develop important soft skills and he gave us ample opportunity to build on these skills further.
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Very nice professor, his biostatistics class is also highly recommended!
An excellent professor!

Dr. Stetler is nice, but he's really only passionate about lakes and climate change. He reads off the slides and says "I don't know" to most questions, especially in the genetics unit. He gives plenty of time for projects, but make sure to write down the due dates because he does not have the deadlines listed in one clear spot.

dr. stetler is a funny and really nice guy. i only have him for lab this semester, and i've really enjoyed it. i was expecting it to be awful bc they changed my lab section to be computational bio, but he's really made me enjoy data analysis with R.

Gives so much more work than the other professors in Intro to Bio and has really uninspiring lectures. He's a nice guy but take any other professor if you don't want to spend many tedious hours doing busy work.

He was hired a few weeks before my first day of class, so we essentially had to teach him how to be a teacher. I suggest giving him a few years of experience before taking his class. He's nice, but he really likes climate change and group projects. My main issue is that he is too new to teaching, he just got out of grad school.
This teacher was great for the 2-credit PD-Tech course and very manageable and understanding with late work.

PD-TECH2 is such a good class. Professor Hoffman's enthusiasm makes the class even more interesting. She's the best professor I've had. The class goes at an excellent pace. You should definitely take this class.

Dr. Hoffman always had engaging lectures, and I never felt like the coursework was stressful. Getting a decent grade is easy so long as you show up and participate in class. Weekly readings, a group presentation, and a final paper, all of which are graded extremely leniently. Altogether a great professor who teaches the content of PD2 well.

She's literally so nice. Took PD2 with her as a graduation requirement, but had to change majors mid semester. Stayed in the class despite not needing it anymore because it was so fun. She genuinely makes it interesting while not overwhelming you with work. If you wanna take PD2, take it with her.
One of the best professor. Her STSO4100 workload is very appropriate. The professor is also very patient. She gives very fair grade.
She was so nice and understanding when it came to late assignments. She wants you to do well as much as you want yourself to do well.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: I just took with Hoffman this class in the first 6 weeks of the summer semester. She assigns weekly reading assignments and you have one group presentation in the end. Her class was easy if you do the work and participate in class. Overall this class made me think more as an ethical engineer.
PDII wit Hoffman is awesome, she is super nice and very straight forward. If you do what she asks you will get an A no problem. Definitely recommend.

Information was interesting. Lectures were dry. No attendance required. 2 exams consist of 50 MC questions which accounts for your total grade. Questions are clear. Some questions asked aren't in power point slides but said in class. Need to study only a few hours before each exam. Offers optional paper to get 10 points extra credit. She's nice :-)
Tries to keep lectures short. Allows students to come to class if they choose. Posts lectures to LMS. Provides study guides for 2 exams. Offers extra credit paper

PD2 with Hoffman is very easy. No presentations, one easy 2-3 page paper, two exams that can be tricky if you don't study the lecture slides carefully enough, but she give you study guides for each of them. If you don't have an A yet, go to the extra credit session at the end and bump your grade up for no real work. Interesting class though!

I took her Ecological Economics class, and I liked it.  She's interested in everyone's opinion, and is willing to admit when she's wrong, or if she doesn't know the answer to a question.  She mostly teaches upper-class and graduate classes, and she grades as such.  As an underclassman, I felt a bit overwhelmed by her expectations, but I had fun.

My experience in Global Economics was wonderful. A lot of the class was spent in discussions, and professor Duchin really helps to foster debate. The class itself was not overtly difficult if class was attended daily. A plethora of videos kept the class grounded in reality.

One of my most favorite classes my freshmen year. I loved her global econ. class! I got the chance to know her a bit better over a scholarship dinner at my fraternity and she's pretty much the coolest I met my first year of college. The class is good, but it would be nice if the book was easier to read. She describes it pretty well during class tho
Insightful on topics of discussion.  Interested in students' comments.

I didn't have the greatest time in the class, you work for the grade you receive. Midterm and Final exam questions are very subjective. A lot of movie presentations and discussion in class, so you definetely cannot sleep through it. She has a lot of personal experience in the field so know what you're saying.

Excellent class if you are interested in what's going on in the world. The prof. has exceptionally rich knowledge in global issues. Her in-depth analysis on every topic is very helpful in organizing and developing your own view.
It's just a bad class.  No prof could make it interesting.  Just don't take the class, even if you are interested in econ (like i was), because it makes you dislike the subject :(
An excellent professor. Exceptionally helpful, and amazingly knowledgeable.

If ever there were a completely useless class, this is it.  The material taught in this class consists of things any educated person should already know.  The workload for this class is enormous, the grading is strict, and it is almost completely uneducational.
Assigns a lot of readings, but these are not required to do well in the course. Pretty objective about controversial material. Highly values attendance and participation.

Definitely very passionate. You can see his eyes light up when you mention a topic he likes. I took experimental physics with him so it wasn't quite the same as a normal course. It was a pretty brutal course by it's nature but he's probably the best guy for administering that mandatory pain. He is very reasonable and will offer extensions and aid.

He is an extremely kind and good person, and the course grading is fair, but his accent plus his lecture style DOES make learning during the lectures difficult, ESPECIALLY if you aren't interested or well acquainted with Phys 1 concepts already.  His English is very subpar and he speaks very softly.You will be learning a lot on your own.
Good professor, is helpful when you ask him for help. His slight accent does not get in the way at all.
Very good professor! Really cares about his students. He explained everything clearly and his accent didn't bother me at all. Overall, one of the best instructors I have had here at RPI.
Hard to understand, so if you don't listen up lectures can be pointless. Great teacher though, extremely helpful if you ask for help.

You might not like him at first because of his accent, but he is a very good teacher. I emailed him a bunch of times before my exams and he was very helpful. Also, go to his office hours - they help a lot!
Extremely helpful!
lectures are usless, since he doesn't speak engilish well. but the course is easy so whatever
The Class was easy and he is very helpful if you email him or go to office hours.
No Comments
Amazing professor, very knowledgeable and clear while teaching. Going to his office hours were nice because he's a really good person to talk to and cares a lot about his students.

ABSOLUTELY FANTASTIC PROFESSOR!!! This guy is the ONLY reason I survived Physics 1. At first I was horrible, but this guy saved me from failing the course. He allowed me to stay in his office hours and really taught material from inside out. It inspired me to enjoy physics and understand it . Super chill and fun to talk. IT'S A MUST TO TAKE HIM!!!

One of the best professors I've had so far. You can tell he really cares about lecturing and how his students turn out. This class really peaked my interest in astronomy (the night lab was the best part) and if I could do it all over again I would
Super chill and very clear with his voice. He takes the time to reiterate things if you're confused and cares about the mental health of his students.
Professor Martin is great and he runs a good physics class.

Admittedly, this only applies to Spring 2020. He gave a 10 hour exam for us, and expected us (during the COVID-19 crisis) to do this crazy exam in 2 days. Professor, surprisingly we are not just sitting around waiting for more work because we are taking remote classes, we are attempting to navigate an academic environment amidst a global pandemic.

Professor Martin is very approachable, and his lectures are very easy to understand. He does not just read from the power points; he explains concepts thoroughly and does plenty of examples both on the board and through experiments. Highly recommend going to his office hours for extra help.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: LONG powerpoint lectures but cool night labs at Hirsch Observatory

Took him for Theoretical Mechanics. Lectures are very clear, and he answers questions very well. Office hours very helpful. Homework worth a lot of points, but graded tough. Beware, TMech is a very, very difficult class compared to Phys 1. Be sure to talk with him early if you feel your math isn't up to snuff, tests can have tough math, but r fair.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--Caring

comment: Just started taking physics I from this professor. The class is only slightly harder than his abs, but I'd still be down.

Took him for Earth and Sky and it was his first time ever as a professor (Recent RPI grad). Test are all MC, T/F and short response. They were much like the back tests from the prof who taught before him. Material is very interesting, it's just a lot of memorization if you don't go to class regularly. 10/10 recommend.

He is super inaccessible outside of class, which was super frustrating, because no matter how hard I tried, I could never get an in-person meeting. He promised that he would continue to be avaliable after we had a professor switch, but that was not the case. He didn't have any clear reasoning on grading our design projects, which kinda sucked.

He's a really solid lecturer and seems to really care about students he has. MEEBal was wonderful with him and he made it easy to transition into, especially as a budding cheme. Isn't great about office hours and isn't very good at responding to emails though.

He rushed through problems in class & moved on even if students didn't understand. Very inaccessible outside of class -he didn't respond to a single email & cancelled his office hours last minute. Exams were difficult & counted for most of the grade. Since he curved grades at the end, you didn't know your grade all semester, until it was finalized.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: MEEBAL was very hard, but he wanted to make sure everyone understood the material. Often went too fast when solving problems, but took class feedback and was accessible outside of class.

Prof. Karande is the best professor I've had at RPI. He genuinely cares and wants to make absolutely sure that his students understand the material. He tries not to overwhelm, even though MEEBAL can be an overwhelming course.

Dr. Karande is probably the best professor I've had at RPI thus far. He really cares about making sure his students understand the concepts he teaches. He thoroughly goes through problem solving methods to the point that one example will give you a complete understanding of how to solve any problem of that nature. Great professor!!
PK is my favorite professor so far at RPI. He's extremely helpful if you go to his office hours or if you ask questions in class. Funny guy, great professor.
This class is wery wery interesting. I absolutely love this guy!
Use his office hours esp. for the design projects. He definitely appreciates kids he sees putting in effort, and reciprocates equally.

Design projects are hard but turn out to be fun if you have a good group. He is awesome if you get to know him and his test are straight forward as long as you go to class and understand what you do in class. i really liked him

I took a few classes of Dr. Spina-Caza's and she's honestly an amazing professor. She really looks out for her students and genuinely cares about each of them. As long as you demonstrate effort and learning then you'll be fine in the class. She gives good feedback and guidance too so I'd take advantage of it while you can.

I took Professor Spina-Cazas Writing for the Screen course Spring 2020. I really enjoyed the outline of the class and all the work we were assigned. She is very understanding, coherent and truly teaching something that is very interesting. In this day and age, we are constantly surrounded by screens. I learned a lot and had a great time.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Group projects

comment: I took 3 classes with Prof. Spina-Caza and I always enjoyed them. She is understanding and goal oriented, and easy to talk to. I do think sometimes the assignments can be a unclear, but it's easy to ask for clarification. Most classes with her you'll be working in groups to some capacity... which can be the most frustrating part. Good practice tho
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--So many papers

comment: Really really nice woman, gives lots of constructive feedback in a really positive way. Not too hard of a grader either. Class as decently entertaining, but the projects were the heavily-graded part of the class, which required a fair amount of outside work. Overall, great choice of professor and class.

There isn't an overbearing amount of writing. I wrote 3 journals, each 700-800 words. The most time-consuming work you'll do are group projects. I presented twice with my group, and each presentation was 20-25 minutes long on theories that you find in the book. Spina-Caza is nice but her lectures are dry and a bit boring. You have to read to pass.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Professor Spina-Caza is generally pretty lazy with her course construction. She creates arbitrary guidelines for presentations and a lot of the course has to do with busywork. Primarily, the course follows the trend of having the student do the reading, and then the professor tests you on it and covers the content again in class. Very frustrating.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: The content is easy and she's a nice person. However, the class is terrible. This was my most-hated class this semester and I'm a comm major. The work never ends, and basically all of it is stressful and has a ton of requirements that are difficult to meet. It felt like busywork rather than actual learning material, and I was burned out by October.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: She does an amazing job teaching. I have taken COMM 1510,  4550, and 4960, all of which have been largely group-based. This tactic allows you to build valuable skills regarding working with others. She is extremely open to talking with students, whether it is about saying hello or about grades. The courses also apply to real-world applications.

Course involved a lot of reading&discussion, w expected amounts of writing. Interesting content - assts allow you to take control based on your interests. With careeffortrespect for materialquestions you'll do well. Prof SC is passionate & knowledgeable within video comm & crisis comm; also kind-hearted. No "bs" humanities w SC you will LEARN!

For a professor of Communication, she sure SUCKS at it. Assignments are pretty vague, and then she gets pissed that she didn't get what she wanted from you. Also, she's irritatingly condescending. Oh, and she doesn't teach. She makes you read the text and then has the TA do the rest.

An absolutely Insufferable Professor. While he has a good explanation during lectures, his attitude kills the mood. He is strict and very heavy during lectures. During office hours he refuses to explain material. His catch phrase is “What's your question?” While knows his stuff, impossible to approach. The course is very hard
Please don't take him.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lots of homework

comment: He definitely is intense in class but as long as you show up on time and pay attention everything will be good. Definitely visit office hours, he's a lot less intense there and will take the time to explain concepts more thoroughly if needed. He is strict but also cares a lot about his students and wants them all to learn.

Absolutely fantastic professor. Seems scary but as long as you show up to class on time and pay attention you won't make him upset. Going to him after poor test/homework performance is really useful and he takes his time explaining things to you. A pleasure to learn from.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Beware of pop quizzes

comment: I took group theory with professor Georg. the class was very difficult, and Julian is very intense, but he wants his students to succeed. If you don't ask stupid questions, and pay attention, and don't let the course work overwhelm you, you'll be fine. Get him talking about cosmology or something he's passionate about and he's a new man.

Professor Georg is an intense guy, but if you keep your head down, do the work and GET TO CLASS ON TIME, the class is a breeze, very simple if you took Physics and calc in High school. The man can teach difficult topics well, and he started to lighten up towards the end. make sure you do lots of back tests the questions are almost exactly the same.
If you know physics before this class, you'll do fine. If you didn't, you have to work hard. His lectures are really good and entertaining to watch. I also recommend doing bac exams before tests.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Best physics professor I have ever had! I love his lectures and he always makes learning fun in class.

Many say you should take responsibility for your learning and not blame the professor. But oh my goodness, I honestly don't see how this professor got a job in education. He is just plain awful. If condescending, rude, unhelpful, and ignorant was a person it would be him. It made being in class unbearable and learning the material seemed pointless
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: The professor is the biggest bigot and pretentious person on the campus. He disregards the student's questions and claims any slightly excessive questions as "stupid". He has subpar teaching skills and his class is absolutely not enjoyable.

Bros actual thingy was straight up visible through his pants that were very clearly three sizes too small. Mans doesn't know how to shop for himself. The class itself would've been helpful if he didn't spend it being the most insufferable, pretentious man I have ever had the displeasure of meeting. Only blind and deaf people should take this class.

Genuinely one of the worst professors I've had at this school. He is extremely unaccommodating for uncontrollable/unplanned circumstances. I was doing work for 3 people in a group because they didn't do their part and when I expressed my issues with him, he basically told me to deal with it because he didn't want to because he doesn't care.

His lectures are not very useful when it comes to the testing material. Memorize the test book because lectures only cover about half of the exam material and lecture slides contain minimal information so take notes on what he says. Your standard teach it to yourself class. Grading by the TA's are very inconsistent.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Group projects--Tough grader

comment: Rude, arrogant, condescending, inappropriate, unprofessional, and awkward. He is not even competent with material: disorganized, unable to answer questions, and constantly confusing himself. He acts as if students existing is an inconvenience to him. Almost your entire grade is three exams. If you have to take him, focus on his lectures 100%.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: EACH test is 20% of your grade and covers 8 chapters! Higher expectations for students than himself. Confuses himself constantly and can't answer questions. EVERYTHING comes from lectures that are read from disorganized, misspelled powerpoints. Acts annoyed if you talk to him. He needs to leave this position or gain some empathy.

Powerpoints are TERRIBLE and make no sense so you actually have to go to class and take word for word notes to understand them. He also teaches stuff thats not in the textbook so even though you read EVERYTHING- only some of it is on the test. Powerpoint are also random things about physiology- not the most important concepts. Studios were annoying

He mumbles and his powerpoint slides are very difficult to understand. Says "right?" about every 10 seconds. When you ask questions, he doesn't seem to know the material well and it's better to ask the TA. Watch videos on Khan Academy to learn the material.

Overall, I found him to be a pretty decent professor. The tests are fairly graded and mostly based on backwork, and the lab reports take a while to complete but are not very difficult. I definitely learned a lot from this class and consider it a very useful course.

He is a bit of a timid professor, but he knows what he is talking about and is actually very nice. Overslept for a test once and he let me take it anyway. The book, his lectures, and the labs work well together to teach physiology cohesively, but the lectures were probably least useful of the three if you are going to skip one.

He's a terrible lecturer, but if you can somehow pay attention to what he says you'll be fine.  I never used the textbook, and just tried following his slideshows and did well.  The studios seem pointless most of the time, but a few of them are actually useful to know whats going on because they make the lectures make more sense.

You basically have to teach yourself the class.  He is very quiet and nervous and most of his slides make very little sense, if any. Studio is a complete waste of time, but the corresponding sections in the book are what he will test you on.  There are only two exams, so keep up on the material because there is alot of it...
Scatter brain, very approachable but hardly makes sense. Interesting to watch her thought process in class but thats the only reason to go.

She is a bit hyper but definitely knows what she is talking about and if you need help she actually lets you plan office hours with her not only around her schedule but yours as well. The only downfall is the multiple choice test but she teaches the material well and her notes are great as long as you pay attention in class and keep up.
Her lectures are sporadic and sometimes incomprehensible. All back tests are given out so getting a good grade is manageable.
She jumps around a lot which makes it very difficult follow.  She also changed her grading style this year so the back tests are useless. Her tests are multiple choice on proofs.

She jumps around too much, and is far more concerned with teaching us how to do things rather than explaining why we do things.  Even so, she is good at what she does, and she definitely teaches the required material.

Not being good at math to begin with made this class a nightmare. Her lectures jump around and jump bettween two different overheads. So the notes dont stay on the screen to long. Lots of back tests, but when  her teaching is less then par it does not help to much.
Wicked Hottie!

Definitely the best professor I've had at RPI.  Very thorough and actually gives example problems.  Reviews previous class' material each class which is very helpful.  Probably the only teacher I've had that reviews lecture notes before teaching them.
Beats problems to death with examples, but never really explains theory too much.  Tells you almost exactly what will be on tests.  She is wicked hyper, so write fast stay focused.
She's a great professor! She's also taught DiffEQ and incredible number of times so the number of backtests she posts online make it very easy to prepare for the exams.
At first I was not to fond of Mark. It wasn't until after the semester that I understood that he really is an amazing professor. Much respect for what he has done for RPI and continues to do.
The previous response is accurate. He did the same thing to me only tempered it with unethical comments.

If he tries to change your project close to a final review, do not change it.  Keep what you have and develop it so you can prove you have enough to pass.  I saw him fail students by doing this, leaving the student vulnerable and without a project to show a passing grade for.  I hate to give a bad review, but he left much to be desired.

He rewards butt-kissing. If you don't suck up, you don't exist as far as he is concerned. Elitist. He has the most mainstream approach to architecture out of the entire faculty. He only knows enough to convince you that he understands what he's talking about, and nothing more. He's actually an easier grader than his demeanour suggests.

the most unorganized man on the planet, if not for other professors in DD, it'd be a complete mess. Loves it when you kiss up and forgets your name if you don't. Won't give you any good feedback until you make all of the changes he pushes on you, making it HIS project, not yours. he picks a select few to reward and leaves the rest out in the cold.
No Comments

if you don't suck up, he'll ignore you, design your project for you, or thwart your progress by making you start over. and over. and over. two degrees from rpi and never left; it shows. he's also admin, so some faculty have to suck up, too, which is revolting to watch.
No Comments
Likes color and materiality because his knowledge of ideological issues is lacking.  Has lived in the world of academia his whole life.  Not trustworthy.  Two-faced.
very good human being

Also, this professor doesn't care about your grade, she lets the TA do everything for her, if you go ask her about grading issues, she lets you bother the TA instead. In addition, I would say I would rather watch a 10-minute YouTube video instead of watching her entire lecture.

I've learned a lesson from her: Do not trust your professor or lecture that we don't have a quiz or test in the upcoming class just because they didn't announce it in the previous class. If you take this professor's class, remember to read the syllabus because she won't announce anything in the class and didn't include anything in the lecture note
Not a good teacher, rushes the lectures, hardly any back exams, difficult tests. Would not recommend it. Material was very fun tho, but again not a good professor.

Sometimes nice and makes jokes, sometimes rude af. Your grade basically depends on how she is feeling at that moment. Only thing I can say as a pro is that she never singled anyone in my class out. Participation is mandatory... sometimes when she feels like it. She is also very against taking pictures of notes. Overall rating: Yikes.
She doesn't teach, we self-learned the whole semester. Tough grader, no accommodation for exams
Avoid this professor for ur grade and future

Overall well taught class. Prof. Mahmoudi would always be prepared and was pretty engaging during most lectures. Generally let the class out early for 1-1 questions. Does expect participation. A lot of time ahead given for HWs and the presentation for which is given a lot of freedom in when you present and what you want to present about.

Dr. Mahmoudi can be lively & lovely in class, but blase on other days. While she clearly has a passion for Econ, she only occasionally explores material outside the PowerPoint lectures, perhaps because of RPI's perceived underinvestment in HASS disciplines. Strict to the syllabus, but still accommodating, she's a nice member of faculty.
Terrible teacher, difficult exam, just stay away from this class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: She always says that things are extremely easy and when the class average is a 50% she gets confused as to how we could do so terribly without considering the fact that she may be an awful professor.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: She's friendly, I had her twice, spring 2021 for international macro, and fall 2021 for macroeconomics masters level. both classes were online, lots of examples for the exams in the notes, and she goes over what you need to know, she curves the grades, honestly, you can't fail unless you're an idiot, she cares about all her students

RPI teacher in Albany class. Absolute the horrible professor I've ever seen. homework does not make any sense and grade is very bad for the whole class. No connections with students and zoom lectures are bored. I don't think the RPI professor all like this but she really gives me a bad experience.
Class was fine as long as you show up and pay attention. I was able to understand the material from her by just doing that

Her lectures felt like a waste of time and takes up majority lab time. Main problem with her lecture is that it felt very vague and surface level, you will be more lost than before by listening to his hard to follow lectures. Exams are also so ridiculously hard and barely resembles HW. She comes off as cold and uncaring, even for emergency cases.
rating_tags: Group projects--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: She expects very much out of her class but does not provide quality instruction. Be aware, pop quizzes are not excused if you miss class even though attendance is optional, and she has assigned hw due AFTER reading days and on the days of finals. Lectures are not comprehensible but hw is a guaranteed 100.

I take BMED2050 with Dr. Maldonado. I do not want to outright say that she is the worst, however, she teaches this class with very high expectations. Majority of the class never had any programming knowledge but she teaches as if we are CS majors. She does not explain clearly, and there are many pop quizzes where none of them are excused. Avoid her
rating_tags: Tough grader--Beware of pop quizzes--Graded by few things

comment: Worst BMED2050 prof. Lectures aren't useful and you cannot learn anything from them if you try to look back on them. She gives unannounced quizzes whenever she pleases and does not let you make them up for any reason, even though this is an attendance optional class. Does not explain how to code or why a program works and expects you to learn.

Her lectures take up half of lab time and are poorly structured. The heavy accent makes it impossible to even attempt to follow along. Tests are ridiculous, homeworks confusing, and there is way too little time to finish the labs. I haven't found anyone in the entire class that knows what's going on, or, bluntly, cares anymore. Find any other prof.

The group projects are great, and you can get pretty good grades on the experiments and projects, but the exam. HER EXAM IS SO HARD. It's not like the back exam, where she expects you to know based on lectures and experiments. She's nice but very hard

Very unhelpful. Generally gets tuned out when lecturing, as her lectures are hard to follow and unrelated to the course content. Her lectures take forever and cut into lab time, while providing no useful information and leaving students more lost than before they walked in. Don't dare ask questions, she is condescending and won't help.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Lots of homework

comment: Professor Maldonado is nice and understands to students' difficulties. But in MAU, I believe she didn't do the best just because of the structure of the class itself. Id sooner see the class be individually taught by professors instead of standardized because its unfair to students. She taught very well in office hours, just not perfect in class.

I dropped out of her MAU class early in the semester. There were no phones or computers allowed and I couldn't understand what she was explaining. She speaks a bit fast and when she's showing her work, the camera was either never focused or half of what she was writing was off the screen so no one could see. I don't really recommend her.

Dr. Martinez led MAU lecture at an extremely slow pace. She forced all students to put away their laptops and phones which made her lectures even more insufferable. 1 month in, most of the class would skip. She would often make mistakes when doing problems, even forgetting how to do them. I feel she would be better served to teaching HS students.
Super chill and knowledgable!

Professor Kilduff is the backbone of the ENVE track. He truly cares about academic, professional, and personal growth. I recommend taking notes on key things said in lecture, doing the in class problems. Do not worry about taking notes off the slides (he goes too fast) & you have access to them on LMS. Exams are similar to exams from past years.
Excellent.  Difficult class and teaches at a high level.  Very accessible and always willing to help you learn.

He's always a few minutes late, but you get over it once you realize that he's an awesome professor.  The material is pretty difficult, but he is very helpful and flexible.  His office hours are usually pretty busy though, so it is a good idea to get there early or make an appointment.
Taps teeth and chews on overhead markers usually a few minutes late.  Otherwise a great teacher, very clear and accessible. Made material clear in class.
Awesome
Best professor I had at RPI.  Tough classes but he will work with you individually to help you learn.  Outstanding.
I think he is a great professor, definitely very helpful. All you have to do is ask!
Too Smart for himself.  Good luck to you seniors!
No Comments

Actually this comment is for ECSE-4030, she has no plans for her teaching and she does not care about all the students but just the top students. If you are not confident with your academic ability, don't take her class.
Dr. Hella really knows her stuff. My only complaint is that she lectures really fast in class so it is difficult to take notes.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Clear grading criteria--TEST HEAVY

comment: Goes way too fast in class. Tests are super hard but fair. Can't say the same about homeworks or labs though. She teaches some material after the lab session or after the homework is due with that same material on it
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: I really liked this course. Her teaching style was all about in-class examples. For 110 minutes straight, she would solve problem after problem. The repetition made the tests pretty fair (for the people who showed up).

Great teacher. Gives a bunch of examples and I was always able to take good notes. You can pretty much turn on autopilot in class, copy everything she writes, and than figure it out later. Book was really good too, even though it was huge. Extremely hard tests, but HW was pretty straight forward.

Prof Hella does an excellent job teaching the course. She works through plenty of examples and reviews. Most negative comments are a result of the fact that her tests are extremely difficult. If you pay attention and keep up with the work, you will get a lot out of the course.

The only professor teaching the course, so not much choice in the matter, but she does a pretty good job.  Lectures make sense and the work's not overly hard.  Exams are on the tricky side, make sure to study and write a good crib sheet or you'll be up the creek without a paddle.
she's an idiot ... enough said
I'd agree
Basically, she's not good at teaching.  Basically, she can't answer questions you ask about the labs in class. Basically, she says basically too much.

MGMT 1100 is one of the hardest classes in the business program in my opinion if you are taking it with Dr. McDermott. There are three 'quizzes' that are 50 questions each it really is an exam. There are homework's she doesn't tell you about and they just appear. Good luck, and show up to class. Whole letter grade gone if you don't.

Very kind and clear professor, class is very easy since it is into to managment so all you have to do is show up and do minimal work. Attendance is required but I was very active in class and asked her a lot of questions so even though I skipped half the classes she didnt penalize me.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: We would watch prerecorded lectures before class and then she would elaborate in class and we would have activities relevant to what we learn. As long as you show up and put in the effort you'll be fine. She's really caring and gives good advice so you can always go to her.

AWESOME. Highly recommend. This class does have a lot of work but she tells you exactly what she is looking for. She also takes into account peer evaluations for group projects (most professors don't) If you do the work you will get an A no problem. She'll even check over your cover letter and resume if you ask her
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: I took her class last semester. She teaches well, provides useful materials, and lets you learn with real world cases. A lot of work but you learn a lot. A lot of team work and presentations but not very hard if you try, but they do take a lot of time. Study for the tests, and you will do good. Definitely recommend her for Intro to Management.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Kinda boring. Her idea of "fun" is giving us 3 riddles on Halloween and taking 20 minutes to go buy a breakfast sandwich and document the process.  Presentations and/or group write ups every week, and huge (50-90 pages) paper at the end of the semester. Overall, eh. A lot of work.
If you take Intro to Management at any point, take with her.
A lot of work including a 50 page paper and presentations every week.
No Comments

The material is pretty stupid, and you'll feel like you're in high school again. Group discussions are on such simple topics that it's painful to raise your hand to contribute, unless of course you're a dumb jock and need constant validation that you're not a complete moron.

My first year at RPI as a graduate student and he is by far my favorite professor. NDO is an amazing course and you can tell he really cares about it, and helps you out whenever you need it. Not sure if I've ever learned so much in a class before

An amazing professor and I love his passion! One of the best professors I've ever met at RPI so far. He knows what he is teaching but I would recommend using less of his aero-engineering examples, so that some sophomore students won't start to panic. If you concentrate in class, the ICA, and the homework, you will do fine on the quizzes.

Had him for NumOpt. Amazing professor. Knows exactly the level of understanding of students and doesn't make projects/tests unnecessarily difficult. Always has time to help and his help is actually helpful, not cryptic. Great guy all around.

Hicken was a fantastic professor. His abbreviated in-person lectures were very effective at teaching the content. He always had energy and a dry sense of humor and his lectures genuinely made me enjoy the class and even look to take more related coursework. His class was one of the best academic experiences I've had at RPI.

Lectures are prerecorded and expected to be watched before class. Classes are just for a short 15 minute lecture and then the rest of the class was used for the in class assignments. Once you finished your assignments you could leave, I was never there for more than an hour. Tests are very hard but your final grade is based mostly on homework.

The material is difficult at first but his lectures and PPT slides do a very good job explaining each topic and are a GREAT way to study for the exams. There are graded in-class assignments every lecture. Homeworks are long, start early. Try to know a little bit of Python before this class, though not required, it will help greatly.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: If this is your first programming class, watch out! Professor Hicken is a very smart man, but fails to recognize that half his class is new to Python. Uses complicated examples to teach that favor Aero's. Class itself is flawed because 3 credits is not enough time to teach beginning programming and learn numerical methods. Be ready for hours of HW!

Design Optimization is one of the most useful classes I have taken at RPI. The projects are realistic and his lecture slides are very clear. He is clearly enthusiastic about his area of expertise and is very helpful in office hours.

Very interesting professor, cares about the subject, cares about the students learning the material. He is a fair grader, but expects a lot. Best teacher to take aerodynamics from. Although he is young so class will not go smoothly all the time.
He was an alright teacher but didnt really care much. Didnt always know what he was talking abt.
Took TF1 with Leong in Fall 2015. His lectures were very clear and straightforward. Exams were decently difficult, but he gives opportunity for extra credit on his exams. Very much enjoyed the class

You must take TF1 at RPI with prof Leong. At first I was turned off by the 8 am class, but it's all worth it because the professor is very knowledgeable and you actually learn. If you go to his lectures, do hw and go to his review sessions, you will do well on the exams. He is very helpful during his office hours. The class is curved
Very fair and understandable professor that knows what he is doing. His exams are a decent evaluation of the course material. His lectures are extremely thorough and clear.
Easily the best professor I've had at RPI.  Lectures are clear, and very well organized.  Always has multiple examples in case the primary one isn't easily understood.  Take this class with him!

Chia is the best professor I have had at RPI so far.  His class is full of difficult topics, but he does his best to make them as easy to understand as possible.  Writes out his notes, shows videos, does demonstrations, holds review sessions before exams.  Great teacher

Prof. Leong is one of the most dedicated and helpful professors that I have met. He helps build understanding by expanding upon material in the book and doing in class demonstrations. He also offers tons of help in office hours. He definitely made me think about the material. If you do the work and stay engaged, you can do well in his class.

A professor that actually writes out his notes and example problems in class instead of lecture slides. Somewhat lengthy tests but very similar to old exams that he puts up on LMS beforehand for students to look at. Also does extra problem solving sessions that are helpful for exams. Final = 40% of final grade. Patient and helpful @ office hours.

Very nice guy, maybe a little difficult but then again your going to RPI. Tests are hard and homework is all online. Uses open book and notes on tests. Final is 40% of grade. Is a class that can be difficult if you don't pay attention as well.
He is a very good professor, and he did really try to give easy exams. He is very friendly, helpful and patient.

He's clearly new-the pacing was uneven, he frequently fell behind the syllabus and had difficulty explaining the last(hardest) topics covered in class, but he was enthusiastic. His idea of an "easy" test was brutal, and the 1st 2 tests took more than the allocated 2 hours for most people. Questions on a given test varied widely in difficulty.

Incredible learning experience. Professor Ji is one of the best in the NLP game and it was a privilege to take this course offered by her. Assignments and homework were fun. Based on latest NLP research.
Can't say enough positive things about Dr. Ji. Her class is designed in a way where you get out what you put in. Very research focused if you're interested in purusing research.
rating_tags: Respected--Accessible outside class--Get ready to read

comment: Caring and Inspirational. Reading materials are pretty helpful for finding interests in NLP. Final project is a good way to test yourself if you are a good fit for research/PhD career. We received a lot of hand in hand help and instructions for choosing topic, refining models and selecting reference literature.

I took two of her courses, and really enjoyed all of her lectures and suggestions she gave during her office hours. She was always available during office hours and appointments made in advance.
