One of those teachers where you'll never understand his justification for grading on the projects, or maybe I do (The Hockey players get A's for goofing off, and the rest of the class gets C's to make it look even).
Test are based off the text book, not a bad class, fun teacher.

He goes over everything he has to and obviously knows what he's talking about. He just teaches like everyone already knows the topics which is fine for students who have taken a physics before, but for others, it won't be "easy," but I don't know who else is better. Exams are all multiple choice, short labs in class which count as attendance checks

No complaints on him as a professor with him being very knowledgeable and answering questions well in class and during oh. Personally don't agree with people saying he moves too fast just make sure you pay attention in lecture and don't go on ur phone. The course is very hard with the tests being an average of about 55-65 but overall a great choice
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Test heavy

comment: Talks way too fast, and the help he gives during class isn't helpful unless you already understood the material before it was taught. Nice guy, but he doesn't care about your success.
Hes a pretty funny guy
not so much the class or lectures, but man is he unresponsive and uncaring towards his students! good lecturerer, but i would rather have anyone else if i wanted to feel respected.
If you have taken AP physics in HS, West is great. I found his lectures helpful, and he is always happy. Physics 1 is intensely built on doing the back exams.

Super chill dude but offers like 1 hour of office hours each week. If you took and did well in AP physics in high school he's your guy but if you need more help the German guy or Kim are probably the better choices.

Prof. West is a really great guy- really kind, knowledgeable, and has a sense of humor. Very efficient with lectures so that we could usually leave class early after lab. Sometimes he would move a bit fast with the lectures, so if you've never taken physics before it might be a bit harder. if you've taken physics before tho def recommend Prof. West

Explains things very clearly. Chats with students casually. Has great patience.
The thing is he doesn't provide enough practice questions. Nor does he give out any back tests. Although the exams are similar to activities and homework, it's still not adequate for students to fully understand them.
Quantum computing is hard, maybe I'm too stupid.
Good lectures and very easy going
Not too hard, but they material was really cool. The class had tons of in class activities. Prof West was a great lecturer, pretty laid back and super helpful.
Do not reply to any emails and no responses.
Great teaching skills to penetrate deep inside the subject. Exams are a bit tricky but easy if you understand the basics.
He presents the material in the driest way possible. I was very afraid to go to him for office hours because he was very unapproachable.

Avoid if at all possible. Boring lectures followed by tests that he likes to nit pick at to find every little mistake and will check for more errors that you did if he makes one on tests and homeworks. Takes too many pauses and makes you fall asleep.
Symans is a good professor. He takes care to clarify his lectures and provides all the slides from the lecture afterwards. He is very helpful, especially regarding test/grading
No Comments
No Comments

Uses slides made by another professor and edits them for his own use. Flounders in class and seems very disorganized. Confuses a lot of the students with his flipflopping, but with more experience in teaching the course, could be good. Plays REALLY CRAPPY celtic music and Enya during in class problems, but sometimes plays 80s.

Dont take his SDMI unless you have to, like if you know it clearly and for sure your research area is based on the content of this course. Otherwise, NO! 
Boring and difficult, and he intentionally made it more challenging. It can easily make you discouraged and no longer interested in the area, even if you used to like it.
He writes down notes during class which makes the class easier to follow. Also he cares a lot about students. Much better than the other professor who teaches this class.
Not sure if that course number is right, it was Fields and Waves.
I have taken several classes with Paul Chow.  He is prone to irrelevant tangents, makes hard subjects worse, and routinely berates his students through "humor".

Professor Chow is very enthusiastic about helping students learn. His in class pop quiz keeps students from day dreaming. The class itself is very hard, thus efforts are needed to ace the class as well. This applies any any class.
No lack of enthusiasm or jokes.  Not very prepared as far as method of displaying material; goes between hand written notes and a few lecture slides.  Hard to understand material.

All of the material for this course is not his own.  He does not have a clue.  He does not explain beyond hand-waving at a powerpoint someone else wrote.  His tests have bad grammar.  How did this guy even become a professor?

Didn't write a curriculum. Didn't prepare for lecture. Couldn't operate classroom projectors. Prone to unintelligible tangents about subjects selected at random. Some of the most frustrating moments of my entire life were the product of the quality of instruction provided in this class.
8AM class was rough (due to mandatory attendance). But, this was a great class...learned a lot
A good class to show up baked for.

Professor is funny but his speaking style was kind of annoying. He had side stories that he tried to make seem like they were related, but really weren't. Pretty easy- two mandatory and one optional paper. He could speak for the entire 1 hour and 50 minute class. This got to be pretty boring.

Joe tries to engage students in lively class discussions through stories he knows of from life. Rather than try and instill curiosity for philosophical discussion or maintain neutrality to help students find out for themselves how aspects of philosophy operate, he instead interjects his own views. The class is very by-the-book.
He's a bit tough on essay grading, but otherwise the course is great.  It's not a ton of work to get a good grade.  He explains everything thoroughly and is exceptionally cool.
Awesome professor. His class is fun and easy. Just do well on the essays he gives out. You don't even really need to read the textbook as he doesn't check or care.

His lectures sort of went off in wierd directions, and he didn't really stay focused. Too often he'd get distracted by pseudo-philosophical arguments with a couple of very talkative students in the front row. But in the end it didn't really matter; it was an extremely easy course. Just do a decent job on the two essays and you're fine.
In his class there is a lot of reading (which you could easily get by without doing) and very few essays. The rest is just discussion, and listening to his funny stories

Dr.Ledet is an amazing professor who has his concepts superbly clear. He is approachable and funny and always helps students out with change of exam dates, late submissions etc. He is easy going when it comes to studying the subject but is not very easy going when it comes to grading and with good reason.Be prepared to work hard!

Best prof ever ^^, very funny, keeps you engaged always. Loved the senior project. He did make fun of me in class for falling asleep though (when another teacher was in to do a guest lecture... not a big fan of other teacher) Regardless just do the work, double/triple check your reports and it won't be too bad getting that A

Best class I have taken at RPI. Enough said. I have recommended it to all my friends in BME. Finally felt like i got my money's worth. It was refreshing to have a professor who albeit, is a little idiosyncratic, shows great enthusiasm for his area of study. It really shows in the effort he puts into teaching the class.
This guy is pretyt funny in class. I dont really agreed with the comments that say he is really sweet and nice. I feel that he looks at the face and treats you accordingly.
he's one of the nicest sweetest professors i've ever had. he's incredibly patient and just a really nice guy. he's really hot too.
Dr. Ledet is a great Prof-- Has a sense of humor that makes the lectures and project work even more interesting.
Helpful and personable.  The kind of guy you could sit down and just chat with.  Lectures were kind of pointless for the class, but what lectures aren't in a hands-on project-based design class?
Ledet is awesome.  He tries to have fun with his students which makes class interesting.  He always tries to make jokes and stuff.  But you learn a lot from him which is good.
Incredible professor. 10/11
Would love to take her class again!

I absolutely LOVE Prof. Search! I am taking a class with her currently and she is easily one of the most caring profs I've ever had. I am not a HASS major and don't usually write papers, so I consider the class to have a lot of papers (5-6). But, she always has really helpful feedback and is an easy grader. I already look forward to COMM 4320!

Had her for Visual Design and she was excellent. Class was rarely boring, she was very helpful in critiques, and she understood that students had different skill levels. One of the best classes I've taken at RPI. As long as you put effort in and iterate your designs you'll do fine.

Pat has an immense amount of insight into interface design, art, and the humanities.  She brings her expansive background into the classroom to make her courses enjoyable and enlightening.  She's a great mentor and friend on the side, too.  Her courses helped me to not just gain knowledge but also grow as a person.

She has many hypermedia-related classes; COMM 4780 is a great course that covers interactive narratives. I think she's great- she's always very helpful, and open-minded. She's constantly looking for things that'll tie into the class material, so field trips, guest lecturers and interesting videos are commonplace in her classroom.
No Comments

contrary to the hype the word hypermeida; you learn alot about tesxt based web stuff thats kind of dull. shes only a dabbler in programming for flash and director, shes a good teacher and nice advisor and knows alot of research but her computer skills are only mediocre.
Can't miss class, confusing lectures, relies heavily on TA's. Not accessible outside class whatsoever. Good luck.

He was a lot of fun in tour of the solar system. We mostly watched movies and did some activities and everyone got As. He's extremely enthusiastic about astronomy and if you are too you will enjoy his astro classes. But I've heard he should be avoided for physics classes.

His "lectures" prior to the activities are very broad and he expects you to know the material already. Compared to other professors, his teaching is minimal and as a result our class average on tests was significantly lower than those of other classes.

Great guy, realistic, just need to get to know him. He was next door class teacher at Shaker High, and then "moved with me" to HVCC. I always could come to him after class to have clarify material that I did not understood in my class. He was able to explain in easy and way the concepts so it became a common sense. - bohdan

This guy is a nut job he gives crazy examples about stuff nobody can understand, he smiles when he is nervous and when nobody wants to answer his questions. He is a very nice teacher and really smart but he just cannot get his points across. Do the homework and you will do well in this class.

The Trink is the man! He's a great professor that will teach you above and  beyond what you need to know for the test. He will often give you derivations of equations and explain to you why things work instead of just throwing material at you. He gives a lot of the mathematical background to physics as well. Also he is a great help one-on-one.
No Comments
No Comments

Started the first class with "I normally teach Java, but..." Yeah, not so great when most of the class involves low abstraction. Relied heavily on the textbook. The next year, I had him for Java. Thought it would be better until he opened lecture with, and I quote: "I haven't actually written Java in over 5 years." Avoid this one.

He's good guy, but knows nothing about the course material. He tends to reference Java when asked a question. The problem is that Java and MIPS or x86 ASM have very little to do with each other.  Quizzes and homeworks are absolutely murderous, mostly because he doesn't teach the material.  I would avoid this guy for class CSCI-2500.

This class was easy, but it was not at all fun. And that's because most Java apps from textbooks are not fun. Mehta made lemonade, so to speak, and I commend him for that- but the homework, which makes up most of your grade in the class, was pure drudgery.
Good guy and professor. Tries to make lectures interesting by showing random examples of java-related things.  Online lectures and use of Google will get you an A in this class.

Very clear, and teaches everything well. Well prepared for his class and homeworks are reasonable. No one shows up to class and participation is very low, but it'll teach me Java and it's a very easy 2 credits.
He's a nice guy, but you have to know a bit about the subject material to keep up with his lectures.  Talks fairly quickly, so taking notes is difficult.

Not a hard class, not a hard prof.  Gives good lecture material for you to reference.  Also does plenty of in class examples for those that bother to show up (~10% of the class).  Easiest CS class I've taken since CS2.
No Comments

Professor Keblinski tries to make jokes to engage the class, but they often do not land well, and his class is usually boring.  Some of his quiz questions can be ambiguous, but he lets you use anything on quizzes and exams, including digital notes and LMS.  The labs were easy, but he wastes half the time repeating what is stated in the lab manual.

While he can be a funny guy, he's not the best at teaching the material. My course is not even half way completed and the average scores on quizzes and exams seems to be an F. Don't advise taking him for this course. MAybe for a MTLE instead.
Super boring classes. Difficult course. He will never learn to teach properly.
A solid professor with a very good sense of humor, if you can get past the accent, you'll be fine.  Just make sure you read the textbook too for MatSci.

MatSci is a very difficult class to do well in, and extremely tough to pay attention in.  That being said, Keblinski isn't a bad professor considering the class.  Don't expect to do too well in this class with any professor, but I've heard that Keblinski's classes get higher grades than most of the rest.
Prof. Keblinski explained material well. Definitely have to pay attention and put effort in though. One of the better MatSci professors.
I had him for MatSci which is his field and he was horribly difficult to understand. He rambled and didn't even use the slides. I learned more from the subs than I did from Pawel.
Only reads from powerpoint.

Overall a great lecturer and very knowledgeable in the subject area. Sometimes can move slightly too fast or skip steps when explaining, but is good with answering questions (if he sees your hand). Provides tips for how to study for exams, and I found his office hours very helpful, which I would recommend if you are struggling with the homework.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Bhaduri is a great lecturer and clearly understands the course material. He's compassionate and understands students' usual challenges/wrongdoings, occasionally giving hints to ICAs. He provides interesting real-life-application scenarios and wants everyone to succeed.

I had a very positive experience with Prof. Bhaduri in his Intro to Engineering Analysis class in the Fall 2024 Semester. He is very knowledgeable in his field and provided students with clear, well-structured lectures that provided us all of the content needed for our exams. Be sure to attend his lectures to complete the In-Class Assignments.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: He is a very smart professor and understands the material very well, almost to well to leave behind some steps he thinks are common sense. The test's are quite difficult and go to every single lecture. It counts towards your grade and will help you so much

He's a great lecturer for a notoriously difficult class, and I highly recommend him if you're a visual learner. It's worth noting that he doesn't write the tests or the grading rubrics - those are done by the course coordinator who oversees iea.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: I found it very hard to stay focused during Prof. Bhaduri's lectures, even if you could tell he was knowledgeable on the course material. Small mistakes on exams and written homework assignments would be punished more than in other classes.
Bhaduri is very knowledgeable about the course material and lectures in an accessible manner. He's very good at answering questions and provides helpful tips for solving the in-class assignments.

He's a real nice prof - lectures are well-structured, and his explanations are in-depth. Despite the difficulty of the class, he is very encouraging and helpful; he seems to genuinely want his students to succeed.
Professor Bhaduri is a welcoming professor and is very nice, he cares about his student and has good office hours, he usually responds quickly on Webex too. We love him
We love Professor bhaduri

Professor Bhaduri is a good Strengths professor, especially considering the difficulty of the class. The tests and homework are rigorous but fair, and the lectures are helpful. Sometimes Bhaduri forgets the difficulty of the class and can also be quite monotone. El-Shafee would be a better pick but both professors teach the class well.

Professor is Very knowledgeable on Course content and subject matter concepts, But forgets his class is very difficult for a lot of people. Overall a good lecturer but sometimes there is confusions in his explanations due to many circumstances.

He's clearly very knowledgeable on the subject, his lectures are necessary for passing the class however he goes on tangents of higher-level concepts often and he covers things so quickly that it's hard to keep up with him. If you can keep up, he's a great professor!
Also, he welcomes questions but will make you feel like an idiot if you ask any.

Prof Radke is definitely standing on the front lines against grade inflation. I wouldn't be surprised if more people get F's than A's in this class (exam averages ranged from 61 to 71 with 2-5 percentage points added as a curve at the course's end, and the average RPI EE student isn't exactly lazy or bad at math either). But a good prof overall.
Has "Probability Bites" videos that supplements well with his great lectures. Tests and homework is a bit tough, but completely fair to how well he teaches.

Dr. Radke is the best professor I've had in my educational career. His lectures are fantastic, the classes are perfectly structured and paced, he's one of the most accessible/helpful professors outside of class, and the homeworks are incredibly interesting. But above all, it's clear that he truly loves teaching and cares about the students.

Good guy. Does not go out of his way to make simple concepts difficult like some other people. Instead elucidates on all complex one's with simple epiphanies of understanding. Go to his classes. Not only would you learn but you would obtain clear knowledge about the field. Always helps his students. Class extremely well structured.
Best professor I had in RPI. He knows how to teach! Super friendly as well!

Amazing professor. One of the best I've at RPI simply for his dedication to the students, material, and field. He creates his own homework problems with fun premises and he is always available to help online through Piazza. Quality professor and quality man. Also: he has great shirts.
Excellent professor.  Explains material thoroughly and answers questions well.  Very available for out of class help and responsive to e-mail and WebCT.  Some of the homeworks were tricky.
Great professor - knows his stuff and is able to teach it well.  Uses as many illustrative examples and demos as possible.  Always takes time to clarify or explain if you are lost.

Lectures are intensive.
Labs are demanding.
rating_tags: Group projects--Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Gives pop quizzes at the start of lectures. Made the 3-time lab into an 11-week lab with a lab report with no direction of what is expected. Hw given at any time, even if it is due the next day. There is a project (not on syllabus) & no hw schedule. Professor consistently cancels office hrs last minute every time they are supposed to be available.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: RUN!!!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: she is very knowledgeable, but you need to be good at taking note and write everything down to succeed the class
Her lectures are very informative and relevant, though a bit dry. She grades fairly gently and gives a lot of opportunities for extra credit. She's also very patient and helpful if you ask for help.
Excellent professor - keeps lectures relevant and materials very appropriate to curriculum

She is the only professor I've had for an engineering course at RPI who actually teaches the material well.  I learn more from her than my textbook.  She is a pretty easy grader, doesn't try to trick you on exams, and she's very approachable.
Super Approachable, really friendly.  Enjoys teaching.  Hard class because many levels of knowledge required

Dr. Mistry is an interesting guy to say the least. A lot of this class will be spent trying  to teach yourself the material. The textbook is super obscure and you have to paypal someone to get it which I hated. Homeworks are mid, quizzes are difficult, and the exams are evil. I swear studying sometimes won't help you. Also you have to participate!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Awful
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Group projects

comment: Incredibly disorganized professor- follows a paper syllabus for homework and always changes the dates so no one ever knows what is due. He calls on people when no one participates and he takes attendance every day

His class is pretty boring but honestly I didnt pay attention all semester then watched 2 hours of Youtube videos and aced the final. As a person he is a really interesting guy if you care about his stories, theyre pretty funny and he is very reasonable if you get to know him.

Jimmy is a great professor. He does care about participation and showing up to class on time as the number of students in each class is small. Tough quizzes but refer to the back quizzes if you can find some. He really cares about his students so put in some effort and you'll enjoy your time with him.

Overall, he is a very disorganized professor. He will constantly say "participation is 10% of your grade" every time he finishes a thought, which quickly gets exhausting. The calendar in the syllabus is never correct, and he changes when assignments are due constantly. You'll also be waiting a month or longer to get a grade on anything assigned

He does not follow the syllabus schedual, update it, or clearly state what is due when. He does not remember what we have and haven't done. Talkes down to you for asking questions. Not a difficult class at all but I have not learned nearly as much as I could. He is also a bad lecturer and spends too much time telling stories instead of teaching.

Really cool guy. No one ever participates, so if you participate he will absolutely love you. He reminds me of a really nice uncle, and he likes to joke around every now and then. He doesn't give a lot of work. His tests aren't too hard, they're fair.

WORST CLASS I EVER TOOK. Could not understand anything he says, his power points sucked when you looked later, and if you had a question you would need to yell 3 times for him to hear you. The Labs were almost impossible to do, and when he came in to check on everyone he was surprised that no one finished...even though this happened every week! BAD
Nagy was the best Coco professor ever!  His jokes were hilarious if you actually went to class.  I have a newfound appreciation for Hungarian culture.
Conservative man. Hard of hearing which can be difficult to ask questions. I think he does fine. Nice guy though.

Expect to learn definitely nothing from his class, I rather you spend the time to read the book or notes then listen to his lecture. He tried everything to keep his students in class, including in class extra credit quizzes, but it's just not helpful at all and most decided to just do their own thing in class time, class attendance in only about 25
Very deaf but good at teaching!

Cannot hear anything you say.  The whole class has to yell for him to hear anything.  The accent is a little thick, but you actually get used to it.  It get to the point you dont want to ask anything though.
He loves teaching, but sometimes you may find reading the textbook more helpful.
Nagy is very old and very very deaf. His style of teaching is difficult to understand.

his class is quite suitable for both math and non-math students. His lecture is boring( actually he is a little nervous) but is very helpful. Not hard at all but really push you to learn(no such thins called drop the lowest).

unlike my experience with other professors,he is really patient with student who ask questions, and he is warm hearted! though lecture is a little boring, but he is really willing to help in office hours or whenever he is in office. He is well prepared with coursework. Besides, even though his gave few back exam, his exams don't diverge a lot.

Prof. Olson may be very knowledgeable in what he teaches, however the structure of his class makes it extremely hard to learn. He supplies very little material to study outside of lecture (no problem examples in lecture notes and only 1 back exam/test). His tests are very difficult and he is not generous with partial credit. Would not take again.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Taken for Advanced Calculus. Really wish there was a 6 on the difficulty slider for this. Prof Olson is good, but class is proof-centered and are devoid of examples. This class is meant for the pure mathematician who loves proofs and rigor. Tests very well made (few proofs), avgs 83%, but graded homeworks impossible, long, and mostly proofs.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I took Diff Eq with Derek and really learned a lot. He's very approachable and really wants to make sure you succeed. Office hours with Derek are really helpful, homeworks are never due but helpful, and he takes his time with derivations and graphical explanations in class so that you really understand the topic.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria

comment: Ok professor, ridiculously hard tests. Grade is based only on quizzes tests and the final exam
rating_tags: Tough Grader--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Tests are tough

comment: I took DIFF EQs with professor Olson and I really enjoyed the class. He was very clear in class and his examples did a good job explaining how to do the homework problems. Homework was optional so that was nice and if you could do the homework and the weekly quizzes you would do fine on the tests.

He's a new professor here. He's super laid back, but his teaching style is terrible. He expects people to learn based off of the proofs he shows in class, and his lecture notes don't have any examples. He talks himself through the problems in front of the class, and his tests are ridiculously difficult. He's not generous with partial credit either.

If you need extra help, he wont give it to you because he "doesnt have time". For Mechanisms, he provided back exams without answers. When I asked him if he had an answer key, he said no because it took too much time to make one. If it was a back exam, there should be some sort of grading criteria from the past which he could easily provide. Lazy.

Excellent at explaining concepts, makes sure his students understand the material, takes feedback on what he can improve upon. There is a lot of work involved, but that's more from the class itself and the material rather than from the guy himself. You might not get an A but if you don't pass the class, you aren't really trying.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Prof Samuel is one of the best profs I've ever had. He cares about his students and wants us to succeed. He gives clear concepts of materials and his lecture is pretty good.

Prof. Samuel clearly cares about his students and their success, not only in his class but moving on in engineering. His lectures are clear and will go through examples during the class to drive in concepts. Tests are not particularly difficult and the homework is relatively easy.

Samuel is the ideal professor that all other instructors should look up to. He cares about each student and will take the time to make sure everyone succeeds. His in class assignments and online resources are extremely helpful. Samuel manages to convey a semi-difficult subject in a precise and easy to understand way. 12/10
Take home exams, project and homework take a lot of time. But he's a really kind and helpful professor.

One of the best instructors I have ever had.  Don't miss this class if you are weak in math.   The test review lectures are fantastic, he lays out what the problem types are for each test, including the final and has  many back tests posted to study off of.  He knows where a typical student may have issues and makes sure to address it thoroughly.
Awesome
Great professor, great class. The course isn't easy but it's very interesting and valuable.
Easily the best professor I've had at RPI! He's very passionate about the subjects he teaches. Generally, his classes are very difficult, but he'll help you through it.

Dr. Mishra cares that the students understand the material and is unconcerned with grades. For Mechatronics, he assigned a lot of labs and homework but graded them leniently. His exams were not difficult conceptually, but they were difficult to complete within the given amount of time. He is a solid choice out of all the Mechatronics profs
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--TEST HEAVY

comment: Dr. Mishra is an amazing lecturer! He is very clear and gives lots of real-world examples. His Mechatronnics exams are hard (most people don't finish) and there is a lot to do outside of class (labs and homeworks) but it's honestly worth it. At the end of the day, I learned a lot.
Great professor! Definitely one of the best I've ever met. Lectures are clear and fun. Always available to help with any types questions. Really nice man. Take him if you can.
Very nice, helpful professor. Some material is difficult. Pays to go to class.

Great professor.  I have zero interest in control systems, but he is very clear in his explanations, and very helpful with questions.  Got an A in the class with an average amount of effort for an RPI course
Helpful but the course content was not always very clear.

Rhone has to be one of the most worst professors I've ever had. Very hard to understand in lecture, unable to answer most questions, and very unforgiving in grading. On the final he made a typo, and didn't announce it until 3 minutes before the end of the exam, just to say "the mistake was obvious" not giving us any additional time.

I remember one thing that Professor Rhone once said: "I do not give you your grade; I simply report back to you what you gave to me". If you made a calculation error, he would give you partial credit to your other hard work; if the mistake were conceptual, there would be no partial credits owing to the fundamental misunderstanding.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: Class is not really mandatory, but going to class is helpful for in-class assignments. His notes are a bit unclear at times, so definitely read the textbook, it is great; short, clear chapters. Exams are forgiving, he does partner exams where you take it alone then again with a partner. Get to know people in the class, helps with hw.

Claims to care about students then shows absolutely 0 care when contacted directly. Asking him for information about how something was graded will lead to vague responses. Doesn't really incorporate student feedback into writing tests. His method of lecturing is good but he cannot actually teach a concept for someone to understand, only can explain

Lecture notes are handwritten and aren't clear, but the office hour was somehow useful. Homeworks are not really connected to the lectures and the difficulty varies. In-class assignments are easy. Three tests are weighted 70% of the overall grade.

Professor Rhone is not clear during lectures and only repeats material form the textbook, I learned almost nothing from him and more or less everything from the textbook and the TA. The in class problems are free points, and the HWs are sometimes easy and sometimes hard. Unbalanced partner exams. Had a question on the final that we didn't learn.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: He sets up lectures in a way that you actually learn how to do the difficult problems. Be prepared for confusion but somehow you learn from it. Very flexible with office hours and genuinely wants success for his students.

Great professor and did an amazing job adapting to online teaching. Really good job at explaining difficult concepts (it was even better if you compare what he says to the textbook although this is for every class). 10/10 would take again
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Throughing it out there that an Education Attorney can help with bullying and PI neglect. This man's attitude towards his graduate students is not appropriate for fostering growth and development. My experience was that he was quick to judge, slow to defend, and put in effort to diminish my mental health instead of growth my skillset.

Manipulative, gaslightning, and all around unprofessional for research. He pushed his insecurities onto me, repeatedly beat me down and discouraged me, and undermined opportunities I had set up before different institutions and organizations by always responding late/last minute and accused me of holding up projects. AVOID THIS RESEARCH PI!!!!

He is a brilliant and knowledgeable man for chemistry. Learning to talk with us in class and not just at us will help him grow in lecture.
As a research instructor, he did not shy from demeaning me in private, before other instructors, and during lecture. He has thrown his research students under the bus to divert blame on unsuccessful projects.
He is a good professor but the course was just wayyyyyy to hard
Inorganic Chemistry with Dinolfo was the worst experience I've had. Absolute GPA destroyer. Only grades are tests and quizzes, and the tests are extremely difficult.

He is by far the worse professor I have had at RPI. The grading is ridiculous and unreasonable. The class should not be difficult but because it is taught by Dr. Peter Dinolfo, he insist for students to not do well. Just a terrible experience overall.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Very helpful and knowledgeable. However, the way the lectures are set up can be confusing

Dinolfo is a pretty good chem teacher, the way his lectures are set up make it somewhat hard to follow along and copy down the notes successfully.  However, he is very good at explaining the material and presents it in a logical way.

Dr. Hahn is clearly very smart and qualified to teach the class. However, she's very disorganized and chaotic, and often lets her personal issues affect the class. This improved throughout the semester but she lost the attention of most of the class in the beginning- so stick with it! Pay attention in lecture, take good notes, and READ THE TEXTBOOK

She is a much better teacher than she thinks she is. I enjoyed the class and she is clearly knowledgeable about the subject material. Wish she would prepare for lecture a little more, often crosses out her notes and has the class start over. I would take her again and respect her as a teacher very much, although she takes getting used to.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria

comment: Boring lecturer. Berates students for asking questions. When asked about final grade, was told to calculate it myself. I did and she got mad at me that it was different from the grade she calculated. She didn't understand why the textbook made simplifications. All of her knowledge came from textbook. Very dispassionate about the subject.

Dr. Hahn is a great person but mediocre lecturer. The jokes she told took away from the learning and talked a little too much about her personal life. Tests were not very hard, studied book for most of the information.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Lots of materials were covered. Lots of studying. Lots of work. But in the end, not much  substance was learned.

Dr. Hahn is great. Makes the material really interesting. She does make a lot of dumb jokes but they're kind of funny. Grading is hard but fair so you have to study pretty hard for the tests. Going to class is not only part of your grade but pretty much the only way to pass as the book doesn't match the class very well. So make sure to take notes.
Dr hahn is brilliant. Shes also the sweetest prof i've ever had. Would take the class again if I could. Interesting material but you've got to study pretty hard for the exams.
She's a good teacher, but has very low confidence.  She tries to make up for this by making stupid jokes and putting herself down.  Overall better than Gilbert for materials though.

He must have some sort of complex internal bigotry, because he consistently picked on me every studio. He had to audacity to curse at me and tell me I had no work and he was going to fail me in a week, halfway through the semester. I am not a slacker by any means. This man has a reputation for making students cry in his studio. (he's fired now)

Extremely bright professor and brutally honest studio critic. His stance on technology in the context of architecture is unique at RPI, and he will open your eyes to emerging materials, processes and ways of thinking.
smart guy but can't teach. Would have been  helpful if studio was more structured and if given more time than a couple of weeks to develop it.

Ted is the****!  He's very clear in what he's looking for, and a great guy!  Funny as hell, too.  Pushes you as far as you're willing to go; different personality than most studio professors, but it still definitely works.
No Comments

Push over. He's useless. I have no idea why hes working as a Studio professer, maybe his inside friends Jefferson Ellinger and Andrew Saunders got him the job. I guess they figure that if they load the Greene Building with their buddies that they could all get away with poor behavior.  He doesn't do a damb thing.
Worst studio professor I've ever had, by far.  Very unhelpful, and does poorly in setting a schedule to get projects accomplished in a timely manner.  His behavior is very inappropriate at times.
Larry teaches the AML course here, a course so important that it should be taken by every mechanical engineer.

He teaches this class very, very well. Is very helpful for both projects and tries to make the somewhat constrained curriculum more interesting. Easily worth getting up at 8 AM for rather than risking a disinterested professor.
Ruff's class overall is awesome, but he isn't very clear on what he wants for some assignments and follows that up with a poor grade.  He also doesn't seem to like people who have little experience.
Ruff is the man.
Awesome Guy
Larry Ruff is the man
Awesome Prof. Helpful in everyway, and shows a genuine interest in students. Runs the AML which has stuff in it every Mech E should know how to use.

Larry is the best prof. for this class.  Downside: only teaches the 8am section.  Upside: He says that his sections normally do the best in the competitions.  I can back this up with my group's performance. He's very helpful, plus he runs the AML which is helpful because he can do stuff others can't

She's very unorganized. Her explanations are all over the place. Most classes are useless. Don't expect to take much from her lectures. Don't buy the textbook cuz you are never gonna use it. It's a waste of money.

Professor Sanderson was unclear about every aspect of the class. Long boring lectures regarding her personal research, with little to no tie back into course material. Students are very unclear of her expectations, which lead to much confusion about projects and assignments. Take with someone else if you want to learn something. Easy class, though.

Dr. Sanderson is very opinionated and grades based off of her understanding of the idea, and rarely grades the overall process. You can hit her with cold-hard facts, but she refutes them with her feelings of concepts and business ideas. She believes 9.5 out of 10 businesses fail and that we need to start them for social welfare or else they are bad

She was very vague in her feedback and her directions for assignments were very vague. I would have to say constructive feedback from professor, which was such a critical factor for this class, was almost nonexistent. Easy class though.

you will not want to go to class, because she repeats everything over and over again. very unclear on assignments and projects. Does not care about timelines or syllabus at all. she thinks she is a product design teacher, but she knows nothing about design or production.

Class was very easy, and Professor Sanderson didnt mind when work was not done on time. The assignments themselves were vague and unclear, but because she was so nice, whatever was turned in ended up being ok. Making the business plan was the best part of the course.
I'm sure that she means well but its like she doesn't take the time to make things organized and understand what she is doing

Consistantly gave unclear assignments/directions. whenever you had a question, the answer was always 'do more research' and if you came back with research, she would tell you that you were wrong. was unable to take control of the class, no one ever showed up. unclear grading. if you are respectful and somewhat apply yourself, you might do well.
Dr. Chen was a great lecturer! Everything was very organized and she is always willing to help.
Good professor
Lectures are fast-paced, yet informative. Dr. Chen is extremely knowledgeable about the subject; when things are unclear, its important to ask for help.
She demonstrates that she is a truly good professor by developing and improving.
She has learned and improved as a professor. She is very willing to help but busy with traveling which can affect class.
As an advisor she is the worth idea ever. She is young and has no idea about the project. She has a lot if stress and will pass it to you!

Course material, textbook material, and homework have almost nothing to do with what's on the tests.  Labs are poorly organized and choose materials that have little relevance to real world applications.

She's not bad. She's nice but also very quiet. MatSci isn't bad, just poorly organized. Different people run the lectures, make the exams and create the homework. The final exam's average was a 56. As advice, read the book before class as it really does help. Go to office hours. She will help. And again. The Material isn't hard to understand.

Impressive professor. His class always consists clear and interesting explanations. He is both kind and inspiring. He would always be there to solve your problems. I view his class as a primary introduction, and it raises interest a lot. Feel free to discuss with him if you are interested in art. Wish I can take other classes taught by him.

Great Professor, highly recommended. He helps us nail the test. Amazing lectures. If you do your work, you will get an A. There are extra credits. Good stuff. The material focus more on Art than History.

Best professor ever had in RPI! He is really knowledgable to the course materials and is always able to inspire the class. He is more like a good friend, who would always be there to help you. Definitely would like to take other courses taught by him, and if you 'd like to explore your interest on art history, you should definitely take his class.

He is very interesting and passionate about art, but he is unclear about grading criteria and often doesn't seem to know the best methods for our projects. I think he doesn't realize how difficult other classes are at RPI, and it's more important that we learn and be creative rather than produce a perfect product.
The papers and presentations are graded very easily. Tests are no partial credit. Get ready to talk about about vag every day for the last month of class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Kielwagen is awesome. Super cool guy and great personality. Tests were pretty straightfoward as he goes over important pieces during the lecture before the test date.  Had to write two papers but they were not hard to do. Do the required work and show up to class and you will get a good grade. Highly recommend if you enjoy History or Art History.

Jefferson is among the most interesting people i have ever met. He is young and feels almost more like a friend or older brother than a teacher. The class is a real time sink as it is a lot more work than i had expected to sculpt but it is a great time. One of the few classes to express oneself at RPI.

It's A LOT of reading. Basically you have to read the whole textbook and know the main points of each chapter. The tests are ok-ish. He points out the important parts in class. Extra credits are also very helpful.
really nice and kind
I love this professor. He is nice and kind.
Best professor evaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaar.  Open book tests.

This class was a total joke.  I did 30 minutes of work for the mini project and our team project was half done and he accepted it.  Still got an A-.  Deadlines are flexible and he is happy as long as you put in effort for it.  Has high expectations to start then lowers them.

Completely incomprehensible. I don't understand 2/3 of the words he says, and the other 1/3 is useless information. Like the other users, I recommend avoiding at all costs (even if you graduate late, you will still thank me).
The worst.  What a waste of time.  You'll wind up teaching yourself the entire class.  And you'll still have the pay for the class, of course.

AVOID AT ALL COSTS!!! Will lecture for hours on the most useless info. Quizzes are based on things that were never discussed in class. If the quizzes aren't bad enough, you can get NEGATIVE grades on them. Homework is mostly jokingly easy, but the quizzes kill it. He even said he gave a 50 question TF quiz where every answer was F! Stay away!

HORRIBLE!!!!!  you can't understand a word he says, and spends the whole class flipping through power point slides.  Is very unclear about what is expected of the students.  NEVER TAKE HIS CLASS!!!!!!!!

Dr. Makhatadze, while very smart, clearly does not want to teach this course. He is fairly dismissive of questions in lecture, and when asked for help he tells students to ask the TA. Every class is just a lecture for 2 hours; it is quite boring. He doesn't show up to exams. You will do 1000 HW questions. Exams are a bit difficult but reasonable.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--TEST HEAVY

comment: Exams are difficult.
rating_tags: Respected--Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: He is a good guy who knows his material, but the material and tests are badly structured. Makhatadze teaches Biochemistry as if it is not a science, but something akin to History. Instead of helping you understand the biochemical processes and mechanisms he wants you to learn random details about them by heart. Lots of unhelpful homework too.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He doesn't take attendance but he requires WileyPlus ($140) and has homework due every class, ranging from 30 to 100 questions each time. The book is useless and his lectures are dry and awful. Only plus side is most of the test questions are from back tests

The class was ok.  He is passionate about his area of expertise and is not that interested in teaching.  Brilliant biophysicist,  would have rather taken a more specific course with him, he would have been better.

Boring class. Just goes through the slides provided by the textbook publisher. Very smart guy but doesn't care about students unless they show an active interest. Uses WileyPlus for online homework which is the most annoying part of the course. Exams are all multiple choice and change very little from year to year. No final exam.
Don't need textbook but highly useful. Lectures boring, study from the slides and book. Responds to email quickly. Really a self-teaching class.
No Comments

I've taken 3 different classes with Dr. Aldersley and am taking a 4th one this semester. He reminds me very much of Mr. Fletcher from the movie "Whiplash". Demanding attitude; lots of knowledge to share; difficult, hand-crafted tests, which will test your actual understanding, not your ability to memorize lecture slides. Plus brilliant humor.

He's a good guy, especially in smaller groups.  He can be very abrasive at times, and he'll hound on you if you get a question wrong in lecture, but his intentions are good.  He's also extremely good at getting the material across.

Honestly, don't ask this guy a question unless you want to feel dumb in class. He did NOT teach my organic class, he only graded. Boy did those backwards check marks make me mad. Anyway, he knows what he's talking about, he's more helpful than Moore. Listen but do NOT ask this man anything. Very harsh grader. Plays "stupid" and removes points.

Amazing professor. Very informative course and incredibly helpful. Any lecture that I stayed back to review the overhead notes (he goes fast + lots of notes) he would stay in class and talk as long as I wanted to. Any question asked in class would warrant a accurate detailed answer and explanation. The British humor is great! btw: summer course

Wow, very very interesting.  I am in the crowd who had him after Cutler had back problems.  Not so good; he could not answer questions and was an okay lecturer. "as per the addition of bromine" still bothers me. The English accent and English humor was entertaining, but teaching "equals naught." Would not take ever again; liked Cutler a lot better.
Horrible. He took over for Cutler 3/4 of the way through the semester. Assumed anyone who asked a question was a moron and treated students like dirt...avoid him if you can.

He goes really fast and just assumes you're stupid if you ask questions :( He had to take over for Cutler for the last five lectures, soooo glad I don't have to deal with him after this! I can't imagine having him as my real teacher for ochem, I'd learn nothing! Though, admittedly, he's extremely witty and funny
No Comments

Great and respected professor! Really put great effort into teaching, inspire students to ask questions and would like all students to succeed, though he created a lot of homework but tests were all fair. Very knowledgeable!

Professor Shah is super knowledgable and helpful. You will learn a LOT from him if you pay attention in class and do (Not copy) hw. He cares about you learning concepts and real applications (not memorize formulas). He gave lots of hw and gave open notes exams. If youre going for power engineering, you must take a at least one class with him:)
Terrible lectures and a lot of homework.

Oh Manoj. Basically, he is a one trick pony, generators. It is clear he knows a lot but he is an awful teacher. He'll give off topic talks all class and sometimes show examples but when it comes to the exam, it's either conceptual you've never seen or he throws some wrench in to screw you up. Does a horrible job then wonders why people copy HW

He is very knowledgeable and has many respectable achivements. When it comes to teaching his style is not the best. He puts prewritten notes on the screen and the handwriting is not legible. Then he just talks through the notes rarely writing down anything extra. There are examples in the notes but they are hard to follow since cant read writing.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Dr. Shah's notes are wonderful. Dr. Shah projecting his pre-written notes onto an overhead in class means that it can be difficult to keep up with him during lecture. He is very helpful in office hours, but is prone to going extended, yet oftentimes interesting, tangents. Make sure he recognizes your face and he will go the extra mile for you.

Dr. Shah is very nice and is willing to go the extra mile to help. He has lots of industry experience and gives amazing real-life examples. He can just be confusing at times, most likely because he teaches at a high level - as if we have as much experience as he does.

Overall a really nice and cool guy. However his expectations on students is too high. He will gloss over material, assuming we've covered it in previous courses, which we hadn't. Lectures are prewritten and are mostly him talking at you. Test averages were all failing. By the end he seemed to recognize his faults, so hopefully he'll improve.

Dr. Argarwal is a wonderfully spectacular instructor. It is easy to get an A+ in this course since she is forgiving and gives great feedback. She definitely did not intimidate students by reminding us that she has the power to fail us and prevent moving forward in the curriculum or from graduating. Also TAs came well prepared every time for lab!

Dr. Agarwal is a good lecturer, I will give her that. With that being said, she will smile as she hands you a failing grade. She grades very objectively, so take it seriously when other people say she is HARSH when grading. I found her feedback fairly unhelpful as well.

To be honest, she is extremely nice and personable and that is noticeable if you talk one on one with her or in a small group, although she may appear to be a tad rude in the lecture. If you need help in the lab, she's there for you no matter what. But she is a TOUGH grader. Ask TAs for help in the first few labs because she grades the rest herself
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: The class is boring. The labs are cool but it sucks if you don't get the lab you want. Grading is harsh but at least it's consistent. Try to coordinate with friends if you want to get your first pick of the labs

The grading criteria in BME lab is insane. It took my group (3 competent people, in my opinion) 4+ hours to write each lab and then another 2+ hours just formatting. We barely got C's. None of us know anyone that ever got an A on their labs. Get to know the TA's and see if you can get them to look at your labs ahead of time. They will save you.

Dr. Agarwal's grading criteria for BME Lab is harsh. Don't be surprised if your lab reports are returned all marked up. On one hand, this means she cares. On the other hand, it means you get a lot of points taken off for anal reasons. Make sure you are never seen with your phone/laptop in class or in lab. She will find you and she will fail you...
rating_tags: Tough Grader--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: Dr. Agarwal is very caring and willing to go the extra mile to help you but her Biomedical Engineering Lab course was a lot of work and the grading criteria was unclear. Lab reports are graded very harshly - make sure you take note of any lab report writing tips in class or you will probably fail a lab report or two
Lot of work and too much information scattered in slides.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Prof. Michael doesn't add much to his lecture slides, but he'll do demos sometimes. Not much lecturing each class, time is taken up with labs (which are useless). He gives formulas but there's not enough focus on understanding concepts. He still might be one of the better professors, but that's not saying much. He is flexible w/ office hours.

This professor pretty much just reads off the slides but he will always help when you are confused with something. I think I only did well on physics because of the crib sheets and the fact that exams are reused questions from back exams.

NOTE: This is for PHYS2350

I do not understand all the negative feedback about professor Michael as I really liked him. He goes over the syllabus on the first day and sets his expectations very clearly immediately. If you ask for help during the labs he will gladly help. Only is rude if you are rude first/disrespectful first. He is straightforward

(for phys 2350 but the option isn't available)

Class is almost exclusively self-taught, with the professor only coming in to fix experiment equipment problems.  Fairly disrespectful to students, has a huge ego, and is very disconnected with the students' knowledge about the course (mostly because he's not teaching).  Amazing TA's though.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: Horrible lecturer. Literally reads off of slides for 30 minutes ON WEBEX while IN PERSON. Forced you to attend class with activities even though they could easily be done outside class. Does not teach physics in an engaging nor inspiring way.

Prof. Michael is a solid teacher. His lectures often lack enthusiasm, but he does a good job of explaining concepts. My main issue with this class is that no practice problems were ever done in class. This is not helpful, and I feel like we were never taught how to approach problems. I often relied on my high school physics experience for exams.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Tough grader

comment: One of the nicest professors I have had so far, the exams are kinda difficult, but overall, good class and his lectures are pretty good, If you have any questions, ask, also he genuinely cares about his students. I asked him questions on other physic work, and he stayed like 15 minutes after class to explain it to me. overall, amazing person
He's a great teacher but the course overall is pretty difficult. You can't miss class since there are in class labs every class. He does what he can to help and is always available for office hours.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: He prefers we call him Darryl and isnt the best lecturer. He wouldnt give me credit back for a grade incorrectly put in the system, so I got a 0 for a homework i actually got a 100 on. This was the difference between a B and a B- I would not take him again.
rating_tags: Participation matters--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Tests are tough

comment: She is good at explaining things. And she gave us practice problems for bonus.

Boring lectures, Awful at explaining anything, got mad at me when I went to office hours because the question was so simple yet I had a hard time understanding it in Class. Instead of teaching my how to do the problem she told me to figure it out myself while she sat there.
excellent

Dr. Zhou is an excellent Introduction to Engineering Analysis instructor. Her class lectures are pretty boring, but she includes students in the class discussions and she encourages students to ask questions. She has an accent, but it is not bad. As far as tests go, if you pay attention in class and practice with back exams, you should do fine.

Dr. Zhou is a very nice lady and is an alright instructor for IEA. She does have an accent but it's manageable. As long as you do the back exams and at least partially pay attention in lecture you'll do well.

Professor Zhou is an extremely difficult teacher to take IEA with. She is boring, makes mistakes, and is not good at getting through all of her lecture. Many times we would have additional class assignments that ended up as homework because she didn't finish in time.

Accent's not a problem, just too quiet for a lecturer. Obviously cares about individual students but not IED. She's an easy grader; my mini-project didn't work and the memo was mostly written the morning of-84%! She is very intelligent and motivated when it comes to nuclear stuff, particularly risk assessment and waste management.

LITEC is the worst class you will probably take at RPI. Kraft is a decent professor but isn't aware that most of his students are mechs who can't code. The labs will take up 20 to 30 hours a week and are barely worth a quarter of your grade. The tests are ridiculously long and hard. Basically a 3 hour test in a 2 hours Avoid LITEC at all costs

Nice professor! He cares about his students a lot and never shouts or yells to his students. He always smiles to you and explains things patiently. As this course is relatively difficult, choose this professor might be a wise way to get a satisfying grade finally.

This is a rough class for most, pick your team wisely. Professor kraft is a good guy to deal with, he responds to email promptly, will help you if you get behind, but if you wait too long trying to fix it yourself, you'll be chastised for it. Typically far less lenient with reports or projects than other professors. Be on the dot or else -20pts.
Excellent professor. Will go far out of his way to help you if needed.
Great professor and a pleasure to work with.

Not a very good teacher. He may be OK if you are an Electrical Engineer or Computer Systems Engineer, but if you are a Mechanical Engineer or something similar he teaches at too high of a level. He expects you to have too much experience with programming when you enter the class.
Professor is outgoing and fun. LITEC always sucks but he is on top of things and always willing to help. Glad I got him

falls asleep during lecture. changed notion for everything so you cant even read a textbook when his lectures fail you. lecture notes are riddled with errors; had 86 revisions in the first week of classes alone.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment:
He is not an evil man. He is just an older professor who is used to lecturing to grad students. If you go to his office hours he does a great job explaining the problems and concepts.

HOWEVER
his lectures this semester have been ROUGH. He basically just reads a textbook. They are trying something new this year, and most likely will fix in future
He just read his 200-page note that changed 14 times in a month

For FEM, lecture notes consist of summarized notes from textbook which are basically just all theory and very hard to understand. Homework questions are then given with limited examples to pull from, and expected to derive the needed equations based on weird notation and expressions given in notes. Would not take again after just three weeks.

The lectures are unhelpful and leave you more confused than when you walk in. Said lectures consist of reading a glorified parallel version of the textbook, no examples, extreme amounts of poorly explained notation and no written work. Dictionary definition of a LECTURER.
this is one of the most annoying teachers ever
rating_tags: Tough grader--Beware of pop quizzes--Test heavy

comment: Worst professor ever. I even doubt that whether he is qualified for teaching. Never take his class or you will want to go home.

He seems like a very nice and good person but speaks very softly. Primarily reads his lecture slides with little to no additions, so the lecture feels kind of useless. The exams were much harder than hws/ example problems; the average for exam 1 was 40%. And with each exam weighing 40% of your grade, you need to do well on them.
Homework is hard and exams are even harder. Questions on exams are totally novel, which are all created by the professor.

Professor Tajer is very clear and detailed with helpful feedback. At the end of each exams and of the course he provides indepth feedback and potential future paths. His tests and homework are more than just memorization of the concept but rather analysis and applying what has been found.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Test heavy

comment: Excessive amounts of work are expected to be done on the homework. Lectures do not prepare you for the questions that are asked. Questions asked on Piazza are usually not answered usefully.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Dr. Tajer's lecture are clear and understandable. He is able to make the purely new and complex materials easier to make sense although it is a very tough course. He gives good feedback, after 1st midterm he said we are strongly recommended to attend lectures according to the statistics he made about our grades. He kept inspiring us to improve.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: He's fine... I guess. His lectures are mediocre and often lack details needed for the homework. In my opinion his feedback needs improvement. He often answers questions with "We went over it in lecture" to the point I wonder why he even bothers responding. I feel he could condense the 2 homework assignments a week into one longer one. Overall okay.

I think that the professor is the one who made this course as great as it was. While it was very challenging, the professor was not only gracious in evaluation, but also very accessible and very good at explaining the concepts.

Took Fotis in the Spring '23 in the last semester he implemented the "certificate" grading system. If you did the work, and understood the content, you'd get an A. I definitely learned a lot not only through homeworks, but through projects related to my interest. Very good professor, unfortunate he does not teach any other courses.

I had Fotios back in 2018. He ran through practice problems with me after class and carefully and patiently explained to me what I was doing wrong. I still remember the smile he gave me when he handed me back the next exam with an A letter grade after nearly failing the previous exam. A truly inspirational professor, I cousins ask for a better one.

Fotis is hands down the best Professor Ive had during my time at RPI. He is extremely interested in actually teaching, rather than being an inaccessible research prof. He spends a lot of time working to create an interesting class, is extremely understanding, and a completely fair and reasonable grader on assignment, exams, and projects. 11/10

I had his class online over summer 2020. On day 1, he said if anyone wasn't in the country and couldn't attend regular office hours, he would adjust his schedule, even if it meant having to call in the middle of the night. I have tons of really great stories about his teaching (character limit) but he's very dedicated to helping students learn.
Very caring and inspirational professor.
Reasonable professor.

By far the best professor I've ever had. He's extremely chill about due dates and if you do the work, which isn't an extreme amount by any means, you'll likely finish with a B+ at minimum. He's extremely accessible for any needs you have, related to the class or not. He knows a lot so definitely do what you can to learn from him.

Cramer is a genius in the field. Nice person and helpful, if you can keep up with the topics and with him. Moves very fast and skips over some of the basics. Will ignore questions he already answered or that are self-explanatory (check the textbook, its usually there) but if you ask good questions he will start to ease up on the whole class.
Shows little respect for his students and TAs. I went to office hours three times and he commented on my looks each time. Talks really fast and dismisses questions if they are not good enough.

He's all over the place in lecture and I rarely knew what he was talking about.  Speaks really fast and often skips over derivations.  Prefers to give you the equations and let you figure out where they came from.  He's more helpful during office hours.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
very energetic!
He is a great professor. He is genuinely interested in the subject matter.

This guy is terrible. His lectures and slideshows are unclear and confusing. He's technologically illiterate, he's constantly shining his laser in his own eyes and can't even  work the iClickers. The only positive thing about this guy is that he sounds like George Lopez, which is quickly detracted by the fact he has absolutely no sense of humor.

He's a nice guy by I am sooo frustrated with this class!  Constantly changes test format, doesn't tell you much about the test ahead of time, no office hours, does not return email, cancels class often, no book and notes aren't enough for a good test grade. Material is interesting but this class  is going to be the end of me.
No Comments
Really nice guy.  Good sense of humor.  His multiple choice based tests are tough.  Many of the questions make little sense and can be interpreted in different ways.
You will like this guy. He's friendly and a good teacher.  Only downfall is the ambiguity of some test questions, watch out for them.
Teaches the first half of this course. Students tend to do much better in the half that he DOESN'T teach. Somewhat funny. Slow in giving students material to prepare for their tests with.
He uses real world examples in his lectures which makes things interesting. Not too harsh on grading. Would take another class with him again

Foundations - It will be Required for all Civils by 2012. Useful class when you talk to all civil professionals. Class is awful though. Floess uses Powerpoints and does not explain the examples well. Reccomend working in groups on the 6 HW's and 3 projects. 3 tests, no Final. Tough class, need to work to get an A. hard class but you should take it

Good teacher, but it sucked that he didn't have office hours.  Very responsive to email.  Class was pretty hard, but definitely useful.  The projects were real-world examples.  Probably would recommend the class and professor.
AMAZING
Carsten was a great teacher.  Class was boring at some times, but he gave real world examples and projects that proved to help in the long run.
Carsten rules!

class wasn't too bad, sorta boring, just read off slides, gave some real world examples. Projects weren't too bad. 2 of the 3 exams were take homes and fairly hard. the inclass exam was insanely hard.
Accent can be tricky, however, in beginning programming, the online textbook and the labs are FAR MORE HELPFUL. However, you have to mostly teach yourself. Best of luck.
Smart woman, poor English speaker. She simply does not have the English skills to speak clearly at all, much less articulate complicated concepts. Lectures were almost useless as a consequence.

Get ready for some self teaching. Can barely understand professor, but if you can put effort and thought to what she's saying, you may be able to  do okay. Quizzes aren't too bad, around 120-130 slides to review for each.

This class may be less work if you can understand her and she remembers to turn her microphone on during the semester. Students usually have to ask for clarification on study items since weekly quizzes can be on as much as 150 slides of content. Little direction makes the class harder and she doesn't demonstrate much knowledge outside the book.

Despite what you may here, not a bad teacher.  Many just give up or put no effort into understanding her accent.  Tests are fair, however the topics may  easily elude many students (inherently).  Go to class, pay attention and be attentive.
easy A
Doesn't explain things well at all. Mostly rely on book
Tough class but he does a good job of explaining the concepts. Gives out candies to those who answer or ask questions.

Professor Cusatis really really cares about the students in his class. He is not really that great of a professor, but he does everything in his power to make sure that students learn something in his class. Some of the techniques are obnoxious... When you see him in office hours he is very nice and good at explaining the material.
He really wanted to make sure students LEARNED. He was extremely helpful during office hours. Class was boring, but he did his best to help students learn material.

Made every effort possible to reach out to all students, and help them understand the material.  Tests were very straightforward, he made the homeworks himself (as opposed to assigning numbers from the book) so they looked a lot like the tests.  Lastly, he gave everyone the opportunity to move up one letter grade or more if they did well on final.

Well he started off very poor.  Very hard to follow and really fast.  He did make up for some things by offering more points.  Should have focused more on the course itself instead of penalizing for lack of statics. Needs alot of work.
Got off to a rough start but made up for it in the end.  I think he has a lot of potential to be an excellent instructor, look for good things to come as he gains experience in teaching.
Worst teacher ever.  Introduction to Structural Engineering

Adam is the best professor I had throughout my three years here. He is my favorite and is very comical. You NEED to pay attention is class but if you do you will get an A. He wants everyone to get an A. All your assignments will be completed in class and you will never have to do anything at home.
Doctor Zaretsky is very enthusiastic about teaching, and really encourages creativity and self development. He's very eccentric and spontaneous which makes every class unique and fun.

He is THE BEST! He is such a sweet, funny and quirky dude! The assignments are easy and can be done in class, they are also fun! He is very helpful and grades very easily because he considers almost everything "art". He is the coolest professor by far, and if you try you can get a great grade! He's always there to help. LOVED this class!!!

The wackiest and funniest professor I have ever had. Very spontaneous and can make the most boring class the one you look forward to most. If you want more info, just do a quick search on Google images. You won't regret it.
Awesome teacher! The most interesting class I ever took!
No Comments
A weird teacher but very easy!

He has a thick accent, but if you're paying attention it's completely understandable. He understands his material completely, and writing textbooks has made him great at being able to explain. I've never seen a professor lecture so passionately about such a simple(to him) subject.

Don't bother coming to class, his lectures are useless and will just confuse you. The labs are on material you haven't covered yet. The homework is a challenge since he doesn't teach you anything, but it's all out of the book. You really need to go through the Sedra/Smith book with a fine tooth comb. Good luck and get ready for a crappy time.
The whole class is a fail, the TAs aren't strong in the material, he is never there and his tests are on topics that you have never covered in lecture...

There is almost no point in going to class, because he is there less than you and when he is there it is useless. He rambles and rants about Soviet Russia, his notes are useless and you might as well get used to reading the textbook all the time because that is what you will be doing...and you will still get a C.

He doesn't know how to run a class. Pretty hard to understand and very boring. The tests were clearly made using notepad and there's no partial credit, no indication of how much each question is worth, etc.

A great professor ... a fantastic teacher.  He's enthusiastic, responsive to the students' needs, and he's always willing to help, even despite his busy schedule.  He gives tough homework assignments during the semester, and requires you to do research and a final presentation.  He'll ask you tough questions during your presentation, so be ready!
really good and respected researcher but not good for this course. should not take basic level courses. he tries his best to make the class interesting but just cannot

Grade is composed of 4 tests, each one counts 25%. Tests are online and open notes- yet the time constraint makes it very tricky. Make sure to attend lectures and read the chapters ahead of time. Plus, Estrella is very interesting- I enjoyed listening to his stories from working at the Federal Reserve.
caring
This guys is the man. Really successful economist, ask him about what he did with his life before RPI. Class is tough. Get ready to grind and make sure you read the textbook.
Attending macro requires a lot of caffeine, but Estrella is extremely knowledgable so you get a lot out of it. The tests are pretty easy too.

This guy is ridiculously boring. He does not post his lectures online claiming that they are based on the book. He refers you to the Mankiw website where you can find student presentations which are generally more helpful. Exams are multiple choice and can be vague but overall are not hard.
One of the Best Professors, very clear about what he teach
Boring as hell, but a good professor.
He is the best teacher I've ever seen. He is nice and explains things very well!

Definitely the best out there. This guy explains the material REALLY well, and he was patient to make sure that the students understand. Really helpful, in class and in tests. he is one of the rare occasions that'll make you enjoy undergrad at rpi.
Very clear in explaning concepts. Very patient as well. More importantly, very knowledgeable. He's the best prof i have had, both in my home university as well as in RPI.
I had him for Thermals and Fluids. He explains everything really well and is really helpful outside of class
The best prof in RPI. he really helps people in understanding a problem. go ask him questions during an exam and he'll answer

I had him for Dynamics. Assad is the man! Very clear in explanation of new concepts, and deriving formulas. He's pretty neat, and has a bit of an accent, but he speaks very good english, and was probably one of the most articulate professor's i've had here. He has a heart, and curves the final grades generously (at least he did for me).
Nice guy, comes around and makes sure u know how to do the in-class questions

The labs were confusing but separate from the lecture & test material. The lectures were effective in teaching me everything I had to know and tests were designed with learning in mind.
The course grading structure is an odd one but ultimately quite forgiving.
