Lectures and notes posted online, easily accessible through webex to ask questions. Assignments and exams are fair and graded leniently along with solid prep material beforehand, and extra credit opportunities are provided. Would recommend.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment:
He loves teaching. The class was a bit of an experiment, where there was a large checklist of skills that determined the majority of your grade, and the tests were worth 0% on their own, but they checked items off the list, which you could also get from retakes and oral exams.
That said, hard content, meh lectures imo, I struggled.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Overall the grading schema was very good with lots of opportunities to improve on skills. However, the skills needed for the tests and homework were not gone over very well in class. Grading within a reasonable timeframe and the professor's attendance for exams were lacking. Very nice guy, but a lot of confusion involved in the course.

Legend. Great lecturer and genuinely cares about students. The skill-based grading makes it easy to do well. You know exactly what's gonna be on exams, and if you perform poorly on a skill, you can make up the points on rework exams, oral exams during office hours, or the final (all without risking losing points you already earned for other skills)

I had him for CoCO back in Fall 2022, and he was just okay. Taking fields with him has been absolutely amazing. His lectures are an absolute must-attend because he explains every concept very clearly. His grading is incredibly lenient and lets you prove your skills in office hours to get lots of points back.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Lecture heavy

comment: Absolutely fantastic professor. Engaging lectures full of examples and modern applications. Puts lecture notes and recordings online, and promptly responds to questions in webex. He also closely follows the textbook, which provides reinforcement of the concepts. Overall, Rees genuinely wants his students to succeed and supports them consistently.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Prof McDermott is nice but the lecture may be boring. He does do class activities but not for every class. Grades are based on quizzes which are fine if you study the notes and understand the homework questions. He likes to use simple examples to explain course concepts but he sometimes gets off topic.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: Great professor but Operations is so boring, the only thing you need to be aware of is the exams since they are 80% of the grade. They arent too hard if you put in the time studying and you will have probably like 1-2 hours of HW a week max
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Graded by few things

comment: Mr. McDermott was amazing! I really enjoyed his lectures and how he explained the content while being funny here and there to keep us engaged. If you pay attention and do all your work you should be fine in this course.

He gives straightforward lectures, fair homework, and easy exams. His lectures are pretty interesting as long as you pay attention to. He goes off topic sometimes, but I don't really mind. He gives good feedback and has an easygoing personality. Overall I really like his class. Recommend.

There is a lot to learn from McDermott and his professional experience. If you study a few hours the 2 days before the test (especially the notes) you should do just fine. There is very little homework and the subject matter is very practical for anyone who is considering going into business. Overall a great learning experience.
The course material is super boring as the other guy posted. Its hard to stay awake most of the time but he tries to keep you up. Its not the best class.
the material was boring but it wasn't his fault. he tried to make it fun with activties but most lectures were 90 mins of trying to stay awake. classic case of a nice guy stuck teaching a lame topic.

Small class. Starts with just lectures and pivots to being a project based class with presentations and a final paper.
He is direct with his feedback but wants to see students succeed.
Computational social choice is Lirong's home field. He is clearly passionate about the course.
It is unique course offering with a lot of interesting applications.

Possibly my favorite course at RPI and possibly my favorite professor.
I think the curriculum & homework is based on UC Berkeley's version of the course.
Homeworks are mainly based on writing functions to control a Pacman agent. Very engaging. Topics are useful for anyone hoping to build a background in reinforcement learning and AI generally.

The professor is nice, but his handwriting is terrible. His exams are littered with mistakes that they are forced to regrade. His teaching methods are poor, as many students need to consult outside lectures to properly learn. He is aware of this and has made it clear he will give 0's to anyone that uses methods taught outside the class.
Beware of the average exam score element to the course. Overall the professor is a very strong lecturer and the assignments in the class do a really good job of reinforcing the material covered.
Coding assignments are given every 2 weeks and there is no final. Go to classes, figure out the material and the test will be a breeze.
Great professor with a very thorough understanding of the material. Could stand to work on the organization of his lectures, but this was the first time he offered the class.
Just started taking his class. He seems fairly engaging.

Rubenfeld has very boring classes. He gets excited over random math topics and will ramble on about them. Doesn't spend much time on a topic and then expects you to know it. Tests are near impossible. Skill quizzes are easy.

Classes are incredibly boring and hard to stay awake in. He begins every class by saying that he doesn't know how to help us understand the material, and uses the rest of the time to scribble illegibly on the overhead while abstractly talking about a problem. Skills quizzes are free A's and most things are curved tho, so a good grade isn't too hard

Professor Rubenfeld will not help you at all. Lectures are just rambles on the topic, then mostly illegible scribbled problems. Teaching yourself is out of the question too, because there is nothing in the syllabus. Partial credit is all but nonexistent. Avoid him if you can.
This guy is ridiculous.  He complains that your homework is not grammatically correct and has errors in his own grammar as he tells you! His lectures are boring but it is an easy grade.

Ummm.  I am a teacher today not because of his direction, but because of Swinton, who has since passed away.  You should be a teacher first at the level you are training before you try to direct teachers.

He has a real problem deal with problems and issues.  As the director of the MS/NS program he lacks leadership and backbone.  Next time listen to the evaluations of your students and get better proffesors for the program.
Excellent professor, I would take every course with him if he taught them all.  Truly amazing.
Great guy, very entertaining. Hard to understand at times. Gives fantastic feedback.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: He's great, I really think that this professor used to get a bad rep but has since listened to what students had to say and changed his teaching style. He guides you through and helps get you reach a level of understanding that you would otherwise have never reached by mostly teaching yourself.

Cheng Hsu was one of the most helpful professors I've had over the course of my studies at RPI.  As an advisor for my capstone team, he did an excellent job keeping the group on track and focused on the assignment at hand.
From where I see it, he makes interesting lectures of material that could be taught a lot worse.  And he sweats like the dickens.
No Comments
this man is insane. also...he's crazy? no seriously, the class is useless, either you go into it knowing it all, or you're stuck in the dark if you an IME. good luck
Master Cheng is moody.  Unclear assignments and boring lectures.
Great professor, teaches well, really helpful and funny.
Looked forward to every class :)
Very good teaching. Great class

Taught the material extremely well.  He doesn't tolerate cell phones, tardiness, or talking during lecture, which kept everyone pretty focused.  He was extremely helpful during office hours and more laid back than he was in class.
Good :)
Great professor, teaches very well and tests on what he teaches, just a good guy as well.

He sounds like a jerk on the first day. Once the semester starts, however, he's very jocular and helpful. Easy class, imo, and the worst treatment you'll get is if you're late, and he asks for your excuse.

Very good professor. He knows what he teaches quite well, although he does not always have an answer to specific students' questions. He is good at lecturing, always ready to help, answers questions online pretty fast. Homeworks may be hard at times, but usually, they are not. Quizzes and tests are always fair.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Thompson is really nice and friendly. I've taken his courses and he did so much better than previous instructors. He is indeed an educator.

Engaging lectures are definitely not  his strong suit. He tends to over explain things frequently, and will move through the lectures very slowly. However, he is usually quick to respond to questions, and is much better at giving a direct answer to a question than standing and lecturing. His homework submission with an svn is annoyingly redundant.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He's a dull lecturer who frequently gets lost in the details of implementation than getting the main idea out there. However, his tests are fair and he curves very generously. He provides questions from back tests that give a good idea of what he wants.  Leave plenty of time for HW, labs, and back tests and you'll do fine considering the curve.
Very nice guy, but woefully unengaging lecturer, and absurdly hard grader. (There's a reverse curve on a few of the assignments in PSoft where an A is  95 and a C is  90, seriously who does that?)
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Data Structures was the second hardest course I have ever taken. Long lectures were un-engaging and better explained a google search away.  Averages on tests were generally low(50 with 63 the cutoff for an A). Homework was challenging but more so the submission system and automatic grading.  Policy and instruction vague. Shaky on course material.

Despite the fact that he often doesn't have enough time to cover all of his notes during lecture, I would still recommend going to lecture. The example problems in the notes are very helpful when it comes time for the homework. Prof Thompson is incredibly helpful in office hours, though I would recommend getting there early as long lines can form.

Fair questions and comments, can offer guidance if you're stuck. Lenient grader (final grades  mostly in the B- to A- range), vicious if he thinks you're not designing or showing new/useful results. Grading was a black box: it's not clear if the written reports were equally weighted, and there was no way to find our grades for oral reports.

Teaches the important topics plus the underlying math. I learned more in this class than anywhere else. Brutal homeworks make sure you know what you're doing & are heavy on math & physics with minimal conceptual stuff. Tests are fair & similar to HW, but brutally difficult and tricky. Very knowledgeable but makes some mistakes in lecture.
He won't fail you, but he sure as heck won't give you an A either!

Expect a good challenge, going way beyond the basics of the course. He's a good lecturer, throwing in jokes every now and then to liven things up. He writes fast and his handwriting is easy to misread. Tests are tricky but fair, and the homeworks will "make your mind rip itself apart" as he put it.

I had Dr. D for NEEP lab, PNR, and Rad Tech, and his homeworks are way harder than any other professor's assignments I've encountered at RPI.  You have to take really good notes in class and work in groups to have a shot, because all the textbooks in the world won't help you.

Hands down the best and toughest class I took at RPI.  Danon is extremely intelligent and seems to know everything.  The homework is hard, and I would form a group immediately.  You should definitely go to all classes or you will get left behind.

He is very good in the area, tries to include parts which are useful to everyone planning to stay in nuclear engineering. His homeworks and exams are fair, just require some thinking. Dont expect to study a night before and get a B or C . Be regular, and the course is well structured.

One of the few professors I've had who takes the time to learn every student's name. Loves to talk and his lectures are usually either him talking the whole class or the students talking in groups the whole class. Can tell he genuinely loves his subject. Tests are entirely open note and directly from the study guides so basically guaranteed an A.

It's a very lecture-heavy course, but you can learn a lot if you thoroughly read the assigned material. The course grade consists only of the average of three tests. However, Professor Thero will go over the review questions before the test to help you prepare well.

The course was boring a lot of the time and full of droning lectures but that's pretty standard for philosophy courses. Thero is an incredibly kind and caring prof that is very receptive of personal struggles.

He's really nice but personally it was hard to stay focused during lecture since you mostly just listen to him talk. Tests are all open note and he's a really fair grader. You don't have to do the required readings but sometimes there's groupwork where you discuss the reading.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Lecture heavy

comment: I took phil 2400 which was Phil of Bio last semester. I thought it might be too much but honestly Thero did a fantastic job of keeping me and everyone engaged. He talks a lot in lectures but it's really interesting and he genuinely wants your input, even tho I'm not a philosophy/hass major. I went to office hours a few times and he was super warm

Professor Thero is great! This class might be a struggle for someone not interested n metaphysics, but I loved it. He made topics I didn't enjoy entertaining. He can definitely ramble in lecture but it's all interesting stuff. Two papers, and couple discussion forum posts, and midterm/final. You have to have a basic understanding of each topic.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Inspirational--Graded by few things

comment: Definitely can ramble on in lecture. Super easy class, no real tests to speak of (all open note), a couple of essays, but they are short and he grades easy. That isn't to say you don't learn anything, as a fair amount of content is covered. Easy A or interested in learning this is a class (prof) for you.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Participation matters--So many papers

comment:
His slides have all the info you need for Exams. Each class, he assigns summaries for ~2 articles. His accent is sometimes hard to understand.
I'd recommend if you're looking for a CA course & don't like to communicate. The most you do is an interview with someone for a research paper of a topic of your choice. I wish the class was more interactive
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: It truly baffles me how on earth this class is considered a communication intensive, it is very communication intensive for Patrick here but I genuinely did not hold a single conversation with any of my peers on any subject besides Royer does not stop talking. He still also somehow doesn't totally know what he's talking about himself either.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Royer is a great professor. He lays out the course content well with a specific focus for each lecture. 2 hours straight lecture, sometimes with a break halfway. Can be hard to focus, but exams are the pretty basic content. Homework is writing summaries on 10 pages of text per class, but if you do these he will almost automatically give you an A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: Prof. Royer always provided us with interesting and engaging content with assignments that were easy to follow and understand. I would highly recommend taking his classes for an informative elective.

I had a class with Professor Royer my first semester at RPI. His classes were very interactive and he loved hearing each students different perspective. I learned a lot from him and genuinely enjoyed going to lectures. One of the best professors Ive had at RPI. He was very understanding and had very interesting content.

Worst class I have experienced so far. Lectures for two hours straight every class and doesn't let anyone debate in a com intensive class. Of the 20 people in the class maybe 4 are able to pay attention by the end of the lecture. Lot of reading and writing. Does not even answer questions regarding test. No reason to take this class ever.

Royer is very knowledge on the subjects he teachs. The class is pretty easy, although there is a fair amount of reading outside of class and all the tests are essays (and there is a fieldwork presentation). His accent can sometimes be a challenge, but overall there was a ton of content I learned, and it was a pretty easy A.
So i took this class and didn't know what to expect. But as the term progressed, Professor Fohtung made me to appreciate science and Engineering. He is so intelligent and smart
i am a better student because of thus dude. Funny and smart
very smart professor.  Very easy to talk to and always willing to help. A very fast pace course, but he knows his stuff. Please take his lectures. He also teaches IEA extremely well.
Wonderful faculty and person
Very rude. Ignoring your email and talking to people as if people owe him money
Very Smart Professor. His insight to physics and materials science is awesome
He is a gem!
He has to figure out a better system... kids pay 80,000 dollars a year to go to Trinity to  learn not waste their time.

He is clearly inexperienced with the topic and just reading off the slides. Any homework you get will not be graded until the end of the semester. The tests he gives are almost impossible to study for and he refuses to post any study material to help. If you don't have a great memory for reciting facts you'll be lucky to get a C.

He puts the lecture slides on LMS. You don't have to go to class, but he does elaborate on some of the notes he has in class, so go if you can to prevent confusion 'cause otherwise you WILL miss 2 ques. on the exam. Each exam has like 30-80 pgs of notes(I had extra lines between my notes, so like 30pgs)Just read once every day(about 20-60min) ezpz
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Lecture heavy

comment: His cadence makes him hard to listen to and often doesn't have answers for questions that students ask. Once a student asked a question about the material, he said "I don't know man, that's what the textbook says" ?? Anything you need to learn is on the slides/in the textbook. He's a relatively nice, but demands respect and is a little annoying.
His lecture style is just reading off slides that you already have access to on LMS. Tests are 75% of grade so make sure you study and he takes test content from lecture slides.
He is good at keeping the class interested and can be funny at times. He will call you out for being on your phone or talking during class.

Nice enough guy, but does not have enough teaching skills. His exams are convoluted and does not correlate to the PowerPoints and study material. Not many assignments, and they have always been assigned late. Final grade is heavily based on the group project and exams, and information and material relating to them are often ambiguous & confusing.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Group projects--Tough grader

comment: very biased around certain people, especially girls. kinda weird.

i thought the class was ok. my main issue was that dr. callahan didn't really do a good job at answering people's questions - he would just be like "well what do you think" or tell you to figure it out yourself. besides that, it wasn't too bad. group project is fun but takes up a decent amount of time throughout the semester. labs kind of annoying

Dr. Callahan is very personable and cares about his students. His teaching style is very hands-off, though. He will lecture on some topics, but not code. He may provide a resource or two, but when it comes to any code, he does not teach it. The class was fun when I got what was happening, but if you do not like learning on your own, beware.

Professor Callahan is one of the best professors I've had. He cares a lot about his students and if something is not working he's willing to change an assignment to fit the needs of his students. His classes are usually filled with laughs and jokes and a very fun atmosphere. 11/10

Horrible professor. He does not give clear feedback or guidance for coding assignments. He is also a pain in the ass to work with. The class overall is easy but the tests include many curveball questions. I would definitely not recommend taking any class with him.
Very fun and enthusiastic professor. Only a few assignments in this course but all are very doable

Dr Callahan has an interactive teaching style and encourages group projects which makes learning fun and engaging. He is also flexible and lenient with students which makes it easier to learn and understand the course material. He was very knowledgeable on subject matters. Overall, I would highly recommend Brian Callahan as a professor.
Dr. Callahan is a really good professor, always reachable in office hour time, give good feedbacks. Lectures are easy to understand, gives reasonable deadline push, cares about students' feedbacks.

Does not understand the material well and her lectures are just rambling. She rarely understands students' questions, so her answers are usually useless. Definitely my least favorite professor I've ever had at RPI, and I'm a senior - so I've had a lot of different professors.

The course I'm taking is miserable. The students hate her, and I'm pretty sure that the feeling is mutual. A lot of questions directed at her will either be put down or presented with another question. Her presentations are cluttered with useless animations and information. Expect to use the text a lot and do independent study.

She is AWFUL.  Worst professor I've had at RPI.  She doesn't know what she's talking about, and she's mean and rude on top of it.  Her exams are random essays worth 20 pts each so be prepared to spend a lot of time with your textbook (since you won't learn anything in lecture).  And the final is true/false.
No Comments

From the beginning, Professor Koretz seems very mean and very rude. She will criticize students for questions they ask during lecture. She will put down the entire class during lecture for the overall performance on an exam. She can be civil and even helpful individually or at the end of studio when everyone has left. BEWARE!

Koretz is not a bad lecturer, she's just not nice. She is extremely negative and doesn't hide the fact that she intentionally tries to make her students' lives difficult. It's quite obvious that she does not want to be teaching you and couldn't care less if you learned anything or not. Overall her class isn't really hard, just a lot of memorizing.

She's not a nice person and down right mean.  She's just awful to you if you don't understand something.  I've never seen a professor act in this way, or to be so unprofessional when addressing her students.  Her teaching isn't bad. but she's just a horrible, horrible person.
Great class called engineering ethics.  He made the class very interesting, enjoyable and is an expert in engineering and sociology. He also brought us doughnuts and bagels one day.
This dude is the truth.

I don't think I've ever seen anyone as dedicated to an academic program as Dean. He helped build the PDI program, carried the burden of it at its worst times, and continues to pour his time and energy into his classes and advisees.
I just love this guy! He is so helpful and nice and you can tell that he is interested in teaching and learning about the designing world. Also very enthusiastic. I loved this class.
Thoroughly interested in helping his students to succeed and learn!

Great teacher! Great person! I enjoyed PDI Studio 6. In my opinion, it is the best in the studio series for PDI. Kind of a lot of reading / work, but in the end its a pretty easy A if you just put the work in. Awesome!!!!!
The class is mostly writing, but he's a cool guy and wants you to succeed. He helps make sure that the work you submit is quality. He's real passionate about teaching and the PDI program.

Advanced Electronic Circuits lectures were clear and Prof. Saulnier is very helpful in office hours. Homework is challenging and can be time-consuming, but is effective for making sure you learn and understand the material. Exams were open book/open notes and questions were very fair. It's not an easy class, but there are no tricks.
Homework and tests are not extremely difficult (open book open note)
His lectures, homework and exams are very related. His notes are very clear and easy to understand. Totally enjoyed it

One of the best professors in the ECSE department. VERY HELPFUL during office hours and very clear during lecture. He goes out of his way to help you and cares about his students. His exams are very fair (not easy but also not impossible). You will learn A LOT from prof. Saulnier.

Prof. Saulnier is IMHO the best professor in the ECSE department.  His well-refined teaching style involves notes written in class posted later.  Lectures can be a bit dry.  Homework can be challenging, but he will readily give people some slack and some good advice.  Simply put, I felt that I gained a great understanding of the content.

Professor Saulnier is easily one of the most helpful ECSE professors here.  He is pleasant both in and out of class, and will go out of his way to cut you slack on a missed quiz or to give you tips on currently due homework.  Homework and quizzes can be tricky and long, but quizzes are open notes/book and he gives answers to homework beforehand.

Excellent lecturer. Homework was graded lightly, tests were moderately difficult by design. Reasonable curving and very very helpful professor and TA. Would highly recommend any class with this professor.

9 credits worth of work for a 3-credit class. Professor's teaching style and courseload needs a serious overhaul. The "project" is already decided, you can't do something based on your own interests. Very disappointing way to learn, and a complete lack of understanding of how this could be helpful in the real world.
No words to say.
Hardest engineering course at RPI

The lectures during the summer were long and he used the entire 2 hours 5 minutes of class time, sometimes even more. The homework also took way longer that it should have for a 3 credit course. That being said, the lectures were clear and well organized, and he did a good job of connecting the content that we were learning to previous lectures.

Averages on tests were in the 60s, but no curve administrated. For a 3-credit class it was a ridiculous workload, lectures were EXTREMELY BORINGGGGGG. 2 hours of yap followed by an in-class assignment that would be given with 5 minutes left but would take 45 and go well beyond the 2 hour mark.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: This course was a LOT of work, but it definitely paid off to keep up with it.  The lectures were very high-quality and Professor Cagliari's notes were well-organized.  He was very helpful outside of class and understanding about extending certain deadlines.

Would not recommend taking MANE 4500 with Cagliari.  This class does not build a good intuition for control theory nor does it teach a wide variety of useful methods.  It instead focuses on laboriously utilizing needlessly complicated/outdated methods to solve what should be simple problems for a small corner of control theory.

He's a very friendly guy and teaches fairly well. I highly recommend attending lectures because most of the lectures he did were on a chalkboard and were not posted online, especially the example problems he did in class. Some of the homework assignments were a little redundant but not difficult. Also, he looks like Woody Harrelson.

Even though I only passed the course, please take Warner if you want to really learn the material and not suffer alone. Warner is extremely caring with both webex and face-to-face office hours, making him very accessible. If he makes a mistake he will write you email telling you. No worry about learning and grades if you take him
He is the G.O.A.T.
Explained IEA topics clearly and understandable! He's really passionate about teaching and helpful during office hours.

Taking Dr. Warner for IEA was easily the best choice I made in my first semester. He has very flexible office hours, even sometimes on holidays, and always is willing to answer any question you ask, no matter how basic. He covers the content thoroughly but still manages to make lectures light-hearted and fun. Absolutely worth the 8AM.

Dr. Warner is a very good choice for IEA! I had him this Fall, and although the coursework can be quite grueling, Warner has so much care for his students and wants us to understand the material. He also cracked so many jokes and is very fun to talk with at the Union when we're studying for exams. Highly recommend him for IEA!

For being his first time,, he made MEEBal somewhat tolerable. His assignments made no sense sometimes, mostly due to the fact that he knew as much software as we did, but is generally very knowledgeable about the textbook type problems. He his chronically unable to respond to emails for some reason, but if you pester him, he will be very helpful.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Warner taught IEA in a very understandable, well paced, and thorough manner. His office hours are super accessible, and he is always willing to help students understand the material, which can be somewhat challenging at times. Always made lectures interesting and was a very fun professor.

I had Dr. Warner for IEA, and it was hands down my favorite class out of freshman year. We had no issues with pacing and lecture content ALWAYS mirrored what was in homework and exams (even when other professors began to lag behind). Dr. Warner was also extremely kind and able to help with problems during office hours, even on the weekends.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: If you are taking this class purely for Inquiry Credit, it is easy but BORING. If you have an interest in code, or have taken prereq's this class is better suited for you. It is project-based and group-heavy. As long as you complete the assignments you will pass. No need to attend lecture, as it is boring like I said.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Group projects--Lecture heavy

comment: Rough Class. She doesn't know how much her assignments are worth/how difficult they are and seems to assign due dates arbitrarily. She's done none of the work for her class, so she expects students to be guinea pigs, at the expense of their grades. Unity experience highly recommended beforehand, as the tutorials given are lackluster. Do not take.

Very disorganized and unprepared for class. She didn't grade any of the important assignments till very late in the class so I had no idea how I was doing. By the end of the class we were over 2 weeks behind schedule, making it so we had to crunch once she finally assigned the final project.

Pretty fair class, the grading criteria could've been clearer but pretty much everyone got an A. Really interesting subject material. Mainly homework and projects which where group oriented. Probably should have more prereqs but if you already have some AI/code knowledge you should be fine.

I took Dr. Si for AI and society, which was, by far, the most disorganized class I have ever taken. At any given point, 60% of the class had no idea what was going on. There were also ridiculous coding assignments which mainly involved changing variables and had little to do with learning about AI.

Incredibly disorganized and uninteresting. She is VERY hard to understand due to her broken English. She turned a 1000 level HASS into a class where you needed to know how to code at a high level (or have someone in your group that did) to do well.
rating_tags: GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Professor Si took a class that was supposed to be on the moralities and implications of Artificial Intelligence into a "JV" Intro to AI Class. There was no coding Prequisite, but our Final project was heavily code-based. She also did not have a good foundation in English. This class was the sloppiest last-minute put together class I've ever taken.
rating_tags: BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Dr. Bonocora is an extremely caring professor. He grades fairly, gives points back if a bunch of students missed something, and grants extensions whenever necessary. He also gives fairly interesting lectures and will meet with you if you have questions or need help. Overall a great prof!

Dr. Bonocora is great, but he wasn't my lab professor, despite my having signed up for his lab course. As a person, he is wonderful and really understanding. But his grading - or maybe it was the TA's grading - is really unnecessarily tough. Every week, I thought I was failing this course because grades wouldn't come in until 3 weeks later.

Great prof who loves the material. His tests can get really specific into how pathways work but as long as you know the material on the slides, youll be good. He makes it clear that reading the textbook is not necessary. The only things he tests on are the things he puts on his slides.
Solid teacher. Only complaint was how specific the information on the tests were
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Dr. Bonocora is great! He's nice, funny, overall a great guy. The class itself is about average difficulty, though I took it as a senior so the class was very easy. Simple homeworks about every other week, two short essays, a few tests, and NO final! Each class is just a lecture, you don't NEED to show up. I didn't touch the textbook.
He mumbles, so at first it is hard to understand his lectures. He is very knowledgeable though, and available outside of class for help.

Dr. Bonocora teaches the lab portion of Cell Bio, and he's wonderful! He's incredibly smart and very supportive. If you go to his office hours before major assignments are due he will look over your work and give suggestions. He's totally chill.
Shes knowledgeable in her field but I don't think she understands that we're still students
She's a very good lecturer and very passionate about what she teaches! I had her for Microbio, and you can see how much she cares about the subject!

I took Microbio with Dr Barquera and it's clear right off the bat how passionate she is for the subject, which really  does help make learning it easier. She's very accessible outside of class too, and encourages you to ask questions whenever you have them. She does stress in-class participation, but it isn't graded. Definitely recommend!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Graded by few things

comment: This woman is completely inept! Insists on holding online classes because of the pandemic but has no idea whatsoever how to use zoom to let kids into the class beforehand. I have missed every lecture so far this semester because of this, which is extremely frustrating considering the class is at 8 am. Quite the disappointment.

Microbiology was a really interesting class. Dr. Barquera is quite knowledgeable about this field. She is an enthusiastic teacher and truly cares about her students. Her lectures are not only engaging, but also show current and relevant information. Anyone interested in biology would definitely like this class!
Microbio was a fun and easy class. The fact that Dr. Barquera is very passionate about the subject material showed through in her teaching.
Tests were in broken english and didn't match lecture material

I stopped going to class midway through the semester because over time his notes just became more and more convoluted and confusing. A good TA can save you though. He's a nice guy though and grades really leniently

Shkarayev is young but very smart and helpful.  His lectures flow and he uses a steady progression through the material for Diff Eq.  His exams are about the same difficulty as the homework.  He is very available for office hours and for extra questions. If you are having trouble, talk to him, and he will help you.  Many in class examples were good
Cannot teach at all. Goes through his notes and writes the book down. Lots of vague examples and not clear at all on  important matters. TA was the only reason I passed the class

Do not take this "teacher" unless forced. He is simply not a good teacher. He is smart, and a nice guy, but cannot teach. He does not give quizzes and weighs exams heavily. He covers less material the others and basically reads from the textbooks. It is difficult to pinpoint what will be on the exams. He assigns a bunch of hw, which counts only 15%
inexperienced, he frequently seems to have no idea what he is talking about.  "Right, I think that's it."
One of the worst professors I have ever had.  I would recommend that any and all students avoid signing up with this teacher at all costs

Trans Plan Systems - Jose is a tough professor. Little hard to understand accent. I really wanted to take this class as i love Transportation. However this class was poorly organized. Midterm was a day before Thanskgiving. The class is way too theoretical! Very dry class and you can do better taking other Transport classes not with Jose!
Very Knowledgeable professor.
He made the TA do everything, and then changed the grading breakdown after the final grades were done
Professor was very unclear when it came to class.  He changed the grading policy at the end of the course without notifying the students.  He could learn english and keep students in the know.

Extremely helpful and very interested in helping students.  He did give out a couple of unreasonable tests, but he knows his mistakes and will improve upon them for future years.  It is tough to listen in class with his accent, but he makes up for it by bringing in many guest speakers.
No Comments

Out of all of the professors I've had, he is absolutely the worst one by far. He creates homework that has very little to do with the in-class assignments or lectures for that week. His quizzes can (and usually do) contain questions from the lecture that class. At least he responds to emails quickly and is easy to understand.

Very unhelpful and discouraging professor. Perhaps he did not enjoy teaching this course because it was for engineers who had a weak background in MATLAB, and he prefers to teach  the higher level computer science courses. But he showed little interest in helping his students, definitely take Beginning C with a different professor.

A good teacher who assumes no prior knowledge of Matlab, he gives clear examples, and puts his example programs and lecture notes on LMS.  HW and inclass assignments are easy, but quizzes can be tricky and frequently have multiple choice questions worth 15% each.

He thinks everyone knows at least some C programming, which makes it tough for students who have never programmed before.  It is not impossible to get an A, but you have to do your fair share of work and utilize all of your resources.  Professor Todd is easy to reach and his website is very helpful.

Beginning C was a rather easy required class.  Todd's assignments and quizzes weren't hard, but you had to have read his slides or the book to have known what you were doing.  Most people just zoned out or played games during his lectures; may help to listen occasionally.  Final project was difficult considering material taught, but graded easily.
No Comments

You know that you have a bad professor when only 5 out of 30 students show up to class.  She reads off slides, does not care about teaching, and made the class so easy it was not worth the $40k in tuition I pay.  She really hated our class because no one came and never paid attention.  Really not good; I think she is leaving after Spring 2011.
Rambled through 50 slides a class, could not pay attention, very boring. Put very little effort in an still did ok
d

Unclear with assignments.  Only one test (a final) and no information on it so far.  Gets flustered and tells students to stop asking questions.  Nobody in the class seems to know what is going on.  Reads entire paragraphs that are copied and pasted onto PowerPoint slides.

Very good annunciation with her accent.  I was able to understand her but the content was a little difficult for me.  3 tests were difficult (with crib sheet) and final project did not make any sense but I got a B without knowing very much.  Encourages you to ask questions and visit office hours.
Worst teacher ever. YOu cant understand her and the final project due at the end of the semester is impossible as you learn nothing in this statistics class.At all costs avoid this professor!
tough course, excellent professor

Extremely prepared for class and organized during lecture.  Goes the full 2 hrs with no break (EVER).  Attendance optional.  Homeworks can be a bit tricky and no matter how much you think about them will not always get the right answers.  Tests were way harder than the homeworks.  Course was tricky, but professor was very fair and did a great job.
Extremely competent teacher, very clear and helpful. But the material was pretty difficult for an intro-level course.
is very helpful when you ask for it. the class was harder than expected. he spoke clearly and enjoys the subject he teaches very much.

This was a pretty tough course,  but worthwhile. The professor was  actually pretty clear and helpful,  his notes were very good, and he  always made time to meet with  students and help them. The homeworks  were tough but very instructive. I learnt a lot from the course,  and would recommend it, but be  warned that it's a lot of work.

Avoid this professor! Nearly half the class dropped right before the drop deadline. He may know his stuff, but he is a TERRIBLE teacher. He also didn't really seem to pay attention or care if people cheat on exams discreetly... so... take that as you will...
Great professor for DIS Studio 2! The hardest thing was doing all the CAD projects on time but they're really easy once you get a hang of the software.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Group projects--Graded by few things

comment: Jim clearly really cares about his students. Having him as a Studio II prof was amazing; I learned a lot about both rhino and unreal. If you're doing something dumb, he's surefire to call you out, but in the best way. I can honestly say that I learned a lot in his class, and I'm more than happy I got to run my designs by him. Work is tough tho.

Incredible game design professor with a clear passion for games and his students' work. He actively brings students into discussions and makes sure that students excel in their work, especially in creating interesting game designs that use the medium and materials as well as possible.

Had some pretty great discussions. I never actually did any of the reading; I'd just skim their synopsis during the lecture and then talk during the discussion sections. If you're at all interested in the course content, he'll love you and you'll get an A. I enjoyed the class but didn't have to work at all, really.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Would take again

comment: i had taken him for both IT and Society and Open Source, Art,music, and Culture: not too bad. Just make sure you do your homework, and just be prepared to write two essays for an assignment. He gives a lot of time to complete the essays, and is normally available to answer questions. I would recommend taking his class.

I went into this class thinking that it would be an easy HASS class because that's what I was told. 2 BS 2000 word essays. A group project/essay/presentation that will count for about 45% of your grade. Busy work to hand in at the start of each class. Overall not too hard, but extremely annoying. I'm sorry if you're an IT major who has to take it
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: While the course was very easy the professor has the worst attitude ever. Someone will ask a simple question and she will find a way to yell at them. She yelled at a poor girl in my class for using the bathroom. The textbooks are free though which is nice. The class itself is also very easy but I would not take another course with this professor.

I only had Dr. Tyrol for lecture and a TA for recitation, so I can only speak on that, but I found her lectures to be interesting and she really cares about what she is teaching. In terms of workload, if you space out the assignments and plan when to do journal entries and start the final paper, this class is a breeze.

Engaging lectures. Frequently changed the syllabus. Added in-class assignments on the last two days, not outlined in the syllabus (DO NOT SKIP). Altered attendance policy mid-semester. Wouldn't recommend her section—opt for a TA, as they grade more fairly. I had a great experience with my TA, but Tyrol is reportedly a tough grader.

I thought it was an overall good class! A lot of reading and a large essay as a final but not bad if you get a head start on your work! Dr. Tyrol gave several really interesting lectures but some of them were just plain boring!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: Took Sociology with Dr. T this summer. Very fun lectures, participation is critical so make sure you do the assigned readings(textbook is free)& stay active during classes. She doesnt reply emails often, make sure u book appointments w her in person, she's very accesible. DO NOT use chatgpt for anything, she will catch you and you won't learn!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: made me waste 100 dollars

Local History was a super fun class and Dr. Tyrol did a great job making the course as their first time teaching it! Not a lot of homework, except for an archives trip and field trip for the final paper. Not much going on in lecture though you get extra credit if you participate.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Tyrol is really well educated and the topics she chooses to teach are very engaging. She summarizes articles very well and does a good job at looking at multiple perspectives. She's really kind and cares about her students. She will sometimes alter the coursework schedule and/or let students have the day off to give them extra time to work.

Dr. Tyrol was a very nice and caring professor - she made the class very easy and it was a very interesting class. I learned a lot about the way artificial intelligence works, and even though some of the reading was long it was very informative and intriguing.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Caring

comment: Dr. Tyrol cares about her students and will adjust the curriculum and workload of the class to accommodate you. She constantly asks for input about her lectures and is very open-minded. The class is very easy, just read and bring some ideas to the discussions (the whole class is discussion-based). One final essay as a final.

Professor Terrones is not a very good teacher. You usually can't understand a word he says and he never explains anything, he just reads whatever is off the slide and if you ask him questions you'll never get a good response.

He cares a lot about his students. He is very understanding and will help you if you ask. I found the lectures paired well with the homeworks, in class activities and exams. He allows crib sheets and usually reuses homework and activity questions for the exams. He's overall a great person doing a lot for the physics community at RPI.
He just spits out math and no context to anything is given, it's just a mess, and while not particularly hard; it's just impossible to understand what he's talking about.

Lectures contain a ton of derivations, so don't get caught up in them. Tests 4-5 questions, graded extremely tight to the rubric, which felt rather cheesy in some cases; but very fair content otherwise. Speed of class is appropriate for moderate-advanced undergrad. Great at answering questions *IF* you push for the answers, don't give up asking.

He verbatim puts the book on the board. The course is backwards from the most natural progression. It's probably the worst book possible. He is difficult to understand in that he only recites the same facts over and over again. He doesn't seem to understand questions. 2 hours in office hours and no questions answered. Well known as terrible teacher
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: He's a great lecturer. The only problem is with the online hw which usually is not even related to the lecture. Not his fault tho.
I liked her. She has a different style of teaching but once you know what to do and appreciate the knowledge she is sharing it can be very beneficial.

Probably one of the most usless professors at this school. I felt like I was back in not high school, but friggin middle school. anyone with a high school diploma could teach this class and probably better. I found myself constantly pointing out her errors. Bottom line  the students are better at the subject then the professor. Pathetic right?
Avoid
Blah blah blah… a lot of mumbling over nothing. What is she teaching anyway??
No Comments
Bad bad bad
He was very good if not the best

He is the best prof. that I have ever had.  His lectures are clear.  He is smart and he cares.  He is tough, but those who don't like him are people who do not try.  Anyone who is willing to work and learn loves the class.
Nauman is easily one of the worst professors I have had.  His text book is beyond terrible, and his lectures are useless.  I felt like the class was a waste of time.
This man wrote one of the worst textbooks in the world!  He has little or no interest in students - why is he still a professor?
No Comments

He's clear and to the point in his textbook and occaisionally in class when he's explaining the material. The problem is that half the time he goes on long-winded tangents, not explaining the material.

Funny guy, but talks more about his own life than what we need to learn. Easy to cheat on exams but homework is a different story as they're graded harshly. He doesn't really explain how he does the math portions but expects you to catch on right away. I'm not great at econ so I found myself always confused and overwhelmed.
Easy A+ If you cheat on the test so easy anyone can do it its online and just look up answer

The man.  Great presenter, but make sure you know how to do his math portion for the exam! Excellent at keeping your attention, recommend if you like a personable person who is down to earth and interesting, and teaches you as well!
Awesome guy. Knows his stuff and presents it well while keeping you entertained with hysterical stories. He's like a frat guy trapped as a professor.

Greg is one of the most down to earth, knowledgeable Economics professors I have ever had at RPI. He keeps Managerial Econ interesting by relating some of his crazy life experiences with economic topics developed in class. Yes, there are a few class days devoted to the math behind Cobb-douglass equations, but it is well worth it in the long run :D
A little vague but the class was kept interesting. Does some interesting things to keep you entertained. Would recommend.
Had him for several MBA marketing and strategy classes. He's a fun professor, AND I learned a lot.
thorough and hot
Absent minded at best!
No Comments
A very smart and experienced prof, wish he was teaching more often. Has some weird jokes too.
Great to listen to.  Makes any class fun yet intellectually engaging.
Prof. Simons is great. I highly suggest taking Econometrics for any major- it is a lot of work, but you will learn the material very will. Favorite class so far at RPI.
Do your routine work and get an easy A
Brilliant. I highly recommend any course taught by Prof. Simons.

econometrics is a tough class, a lot of work but if you put the effort in it then you can get an A. he's a really nice guy and really helpful. going to the lectures is not mandatory but STRONGLY recommended. you will get decent amount of in class work and a lot of homework so be prepared. overall it's hard but you will learn a lot of useful stuff
I love industry shakeouts
No Comments

Dr Maxwell is smart man but he should teach high level of bio not bio 1. He give too many info in the class that you can't study everyday with him as well as hard homeworks. I used to go to tutoring for help in H.w and I always get 5/10, then I knew from my friends that I was the highest score. Stay away from him if you want good GPA

I would not recommend him since he talks way too much that he drags everything out and at the end of the day you learn nothing but pictures. He is a very tough grader and does not explain why he took points off your quiz
OK

Dr. Maxwell is very knowledgeable about the course, but he is a tough grader. Sometimes the points he takes off seems arbitrary, but he always tries to be fair, is always there at office hours and encourages student questions. Would highly recommend looking over the homework thoroughly and reading the book, as sometimes his slides don't make sense.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Dr.Maxwell is a crystal clear and very interesting lecturer, although he may sound monotone. You have to read the textbook but overall, I learned a lot from the course. Do the homework and do it well, not only for the grade but also because the majority of the test questions are a version of the homework questions.

Genetics was a hard class but Maxwell is actually one of the few professors at this school that knows what hes talking about. He will clarify confusing topics if you ask him for help and hes usually available at his office.
He is a great professor, he helps you out when you need it but is not scared to put the pressure on.
Most entertaining one compared to the other MITR professors.  Friendly & nice to talk to. Thus, take his class for MITR.  The class is structured to be hard anyway.  Can't escape that. =P
Difficult course, great professor, highly recommended. Makes you work but at the end it's all worth it. Miner's very friendly and helpful, especially if you stop by his office just to talk to him.
He is a very good professor due to his industry experience.  I would highly recommend him.  The only negative point is that he payes way to much to class participation.
Highly recommended.  Lots of industry experience, and extremely knowledgeable.  He's also friendly and easy to get to know, unlike some other professors here.  Take his MITR section.
Long winded, but a very nice, helpful guy.  Take his section of MITR.

His lectures are boring and he often goes off on math theory tangents that are irrelevant to the course. Our class is also behind others because he does this. Also doesn't give very good explanations of his notes. Back tests are not really available, and his review packet s are lengthy and don't represent the test well. The textbook is very helpful
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--TEST HEAVY

comment: A fast-paced lecture... We should be prepared for the class... But the professor is really really nice, if there are any questions, just go to his office hours!!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Get ready to read

comment: Good

Awful multi-var professor. The TA should have his job. Don't bother going to lecture because it doesn't make any sense and he makes a massive amount of mistakes during them. Tests are somewhat similar to the review tests he gives but there will also be random conceptual questions there too. Had to make quizzes harder because we were doing too well.

I literally had no idea what he was talking about almost all semester, not to mention he just speaks in a horribly monotone voice for two hours without stopping to let people ask questions or anything. Just straight lecturing
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Taught Linear Algebra in a way that highlighted understanding concepts rather than computation. Accessible for a non-math major. Homework can be tricky, but Prof. Wells is very helpful in office hours. You will have to think about concepts to get the answers, but it is well worth it. Textbook isn't absolutely necessary, but is a good reference.

Dr. Stillman was an amazing professor. He took the time to communicate, discuss, and thoroughly explain any and all questions I had. This is my second year at RPI, and he is by far the best professor I have had thus far in my college experience.
Very good profesor, teaches for a ful hour before starting lab. This is extremely helpful.

One of the best professors I have had at RPI. He teaches you exactly what you need to know. If you have any questions, he is an e-mail away, and responds to those e-mails EXTREMELY promptly. He truly cares about the students he teaches. I attribute my A in this course to this man. Get him if you can!

Professor Stillman is by far one of the best teachers at RPI! He is amazing at making the class fun and making his students smile even when he knows they don't like the material. I wish he was the head of the department because he has great ideals. I am going to miss him! Definitely try to get him!

Great Professor. Really loves to teach and help the kids learn the material. If you get a chance, take a class with Prof. Stillman. Will try to relate the material to you in any way possible. Will go out of his way to give you extra help during any hours of the week.
Probably one of my favorite professors. He is cracks jokes and really tries to relate to the students, making this otherwise terrible class bearable. Very enthusiastic and I would highly reccomend

The nicest professor I have had at RPI. Extremely empathetic and caring. Has a lot of fun stories from his earlier career too. Lecture slides are busy but he wants you to understand the big picture and actual applications, not just memorize formulas. The first part of the class is hardest, don't be discouraged because it gets better from there.

One of the best professors at RPI! He is an extremely good lecturer and will make everything entertaining. He is also a very nice person and gives really good advice even outside of class, helped me out a lot with career stuff.

Had him for 2 classes, both were excellent. His extensive real-world experience shows in his lectures and adds a lot to the course, especially in prod dev. Grading criteria is confusing but I mostly blame the TA for that. Take a course with him if you can.

Professor Mohamed is one of the real gems of the BME program. He is extremely caring, passionate, and involved in his classes. You can tell that he really loves Biomedical Engineering and even goes off on inspirational tangents to motivate students. He is just great and I wish he could teach all my classes.

Dr. Mohamed is one of the best professors I've ever had in my academic career. I HIGHLY recommend him for any class, every class. I've had him in-person and online, but during the COVID-19 pandemic, he was one of the most caring professors, and completely re-did his class setting to cater to us. 100% the absolute best.

THE NICEST PROFESSOR EVER! Had him for product development and he was so caring. Definitely should talk to him one on one. Grading can be a bit unexpected but he prefers you to be succinct and to the point. Definitely recommend.
Great professor, the class isn't necessarily difficult but his grading is harsh and feels random at times... He also looks just like Andy Kaufman!

Prof. Belanger is by far one of the best professors I have had in my time at RPI. He is very prepared and knows the material well. I would highly recommend taking any class you can with this professor!

Professor Belanger isn't the professor to go to if you want an 'easy A,' or a free class, or a good time in lecture, or easy homework, or fair tests, or nice TAs, or even a reasonable grade at the end of the semester. But he is the professor to go to if you want the hardest semester of your life, and to actually learn some physics. I recommend him.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: HE'S AWESOME!
Incredible, so good at explaining electrodynamics you wouldn't belive
Gives good lectures, doesn't hesitate to engage in real-talk. Lecture slides aren't the best but I can't fault him on that.

Professor Patterson is one of the most caring professors in RPI. He goes to lengths to make sure you're learning and make sure the class is forgiving. He makes topics interesting as well through projects. Overall just an awesome guy

Patterson is a good professor, lectures are engaging and on-topic. Patterson talks about ECSE career planning, which was useful for understanding the breadth of ECSE applications. Pick good group members & do omega labs, they are a lot of fun and the second/third ones are graded nicely if you put in the effort. Course is simple and useful.

Overall, Prof. Patterson was great. The class was a lot of work outside with the labs, however doing the labs and attending lectures prepares you well for exams. Also, optimizations on the labs and proof of skills allow for you to raise your grade if you make mistakes and slack off during the semester.

Lectures are optional last I checked, the course is a lot of work outside class but a very solid foundation.
While the course has really too much to grade for the TAs, he really cares about his students and wants the course to be graded fairly.

Professor Patterson was a very knowledgeable and enjoyable professor. I learned a lot throughout the class and it further solidified my love for EE and circuits. Labs are very easy to understand and the option to opt-out of the final was very nice.

Professor Patterson is very understanding and friendly. We had forgot to submit a lab, and he was happy to give us an extension to submit it. Material isn't too challenging apart from Proof of Skills at the start of the semester, which was confusing at first.
Professor Patterson is very approachable and wants students to succeed.

Dr. Patterson is a friendly professor who gives clear lectures, however, he cannot structure a course. ECSE 1010 was extremely confusing, in that the first three weeks are wasted with "Proof of Skills" and labs had unclear or nonexistent instructions and confusing "Proof of Concepts" as the reports. This course is frustrating but isn't too hard.

Patterson was a great teacher and was really understanding. I remember I felt overwhelmed by all the Intro to ECSE work and I emailed him and we figured out how I could get back on track. He was also a good grader and helped you understand a concept you might have trouble with. I also asked for additional material to self-study and he gave me it.

Awesome guy.. "Call me Neil".  Computer music was great, and he's the perfect guy to teach this material, as he's been a part of developing that scene. he commutes from NYC, and brings energy and fun to what could be a solely technical class.
I found rolnick to be the most condescending professor I have run into thus far at RPI. The class is really easy, and as long as your TA is helpful everything will be fine.

Neil knows what he is talking about but had a hard time keeping everyones attention for 2 hours. You never really get to work with him in this class, only the TA's. That was OKAY by me, they were much more helpful. If you are into music, especially ambient stuff, you'll like his class.
Booooooriiiiingg.All he talks about is stupid sounding music.
Excellent & experienced professor.  Give good critiques and helpful.
Neil really knows his stuff, he can do music programming, he can compose, make aesthetic judgments, critique and theorize. His voice is a little on the quiet side.

Bruce is a phenomenal professor and teacher. His lectures are very thoughtful. If you ask questions and pay attention in class he visibly appreciates it. Focuses on concepts, but you get a good dose of hw problems too.

Professor Watson is one of the best professors I've had. His lectures are super interesting and he really puts forward the effort to make sure you know the material.  Tests are pretty straight forward, just stuff from the class notes. The homework can be a little difficult, but he always leaves time in class so you can ask questions.
Fantastic
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Prof. Watson is a great guy, I learned a ton in his Geochemistry course. He really wants you to learn, and it shows. If you attend class, think about the material and ask him questions, you'll do fine on exams. Remember, if you have any questions, just go see him - you'll be glad you did!
No Comments
No Comments

QPI is pretty tough, especially if you don't have diff eq experience. He is aware of his accent and it can be rough sometimes but he tries to help out students. The TA my year was really bad, so if you have a better TA it might work out better. The tests are fair but can be tough if you don't study.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Required attendance with in-class exercises making up a sizable chunk of the grade. He's fine. I feel less like I've learned physics and real world things and more like i've learned how to solve specific types of exam problems. :/
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: QP1 is a tough class regardless of your teacher, but you can't get much better than Lu. He's a great lecturer (getting used to his accent takes a week or so) and is clear about what he expects of you. Tests are hard but fair, and there's no curve so you have to do a lot of work. Read the textbook, go to class, and ask for help and you'll do fine.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: I can hear from his words that his mind is full of knowledge, but he fail to consider the average level of students, it is very unwise to take his class directly after you took PHY 2 honer or PHY 2, if you want to do well, you better read some book or ask some experts about quantumor your life will be hard. also he did not give curves.

Few reviews so cramming into char limit. Super nice. Clear lectures w example problems. Gr8 @ explaining, ask questions! Makes tough QP material easier. HWs graded very tough by TA. Tests well-made & fair. Best quality is his enthusiasm. Loves what he does, smiles a lot, very inspirational. Pay attntn, bring pos attitude, & QP will b ur fav class.
If you get used to his accent, he's not bad at all.
So, this is a very hard course, regardless of who teaches it. TAKE TIANYI CHEN. I have not seen a better grader than this professor. Very fair and gives a lot of extra credit.
A well-organized class with clear grading criteria. The pace of the lecture is a bit slow at the beginning, so some advanced material does not be covered at the end.

This is a math-heavy course for me. But Prof. Chen did a great job in explaining things well. He is also a caring person that can accommodate diverse student backgrounds and individual needs. Recommend to students with the weak mathematical background to catch up on the probability foundations.

Very clearly isn't prepared for lectures and directly copies from Prof. Radke's old notes. He doesn't even explain it well and his notes don't make too much sense. At points when he fails to teach material, he forces you to watch youtube videos just to learn material for the homeworks due that night. Try and take with Radke!

Prof. Chen's course covers all the important topics in ML, an excellent start for students from different background. The lecture are clear, homework are practical. He also includes some ideas in research, very inspiring. Prof. Chen is a caring instructor. He is patient, helpful. You can get support easily. Grading is kind if you spend enough effor

Prof. Chen is a junior professor in RPI. It is first time I attended his course. The lecture is clear, well-prepared. He is very approachable after the class as well. High recommend for ECSE students who want to learn ML.

This class was probably the worst class I have taken at RPI. The professor taught a lot but when it came to homework and tests, it was likeI didn't even attend lecture. The test average was a 40 but he added 20 points to everyones grade to make it look like we did better. Test 2 wasn't better. He assigned homework during finals week.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: He's great! His english wasn't always the best, but he is so clear in his explanations of things it wasn't an issue for me. He is so sweet and wants everyone to do well, so he reviews sample questions each class about the last lecture's content. I always thought the test reviews were super helpful as well. Definitely ask him for help if you need!

I loved professor Zhang! His lectures were easy to understand and our section consistently did better than other sections on exams. At the beginning of class, he often reviewed questions from past exams (pertaining to the previous lecture) which turned out to be super helpful. As long as you study back exams, this course isn't difficult.

He is insanely passionate, you can see his face light up when he gets to a topic he likes. He is extremely accommodating and understanding and although work can sometimes be hard he wants to help you. He is great at adding interesting tidbits to the course without veering away from the textbook too much. So it's still easy to catch up if you miss.

Though he does not speak very good English, his mind is clear. This course is very easy to pass and get A as long as you review all the points taught in class. By the way mastering physics is so awful !

Most lectures come straight from the text, but it can feel like something is lost in translation between the book and the chalkboard.  Use Griffiths as your primary resource but come to class to ask questions and take the quizzes.  Prof Zhang is super helpful during office hours if you find the lectures muddled or are confused about something.
Physics was not my strongest subject. Although he is hard to understand at times, he is very helpful. If you email him with questions or concerns about your grade he is willing to help.

He's wildly different in normal classes from the studio, we didn't have any homework this semester. He would spend the entire class time lecturing, asking us questions, and giving very good life advice. Sometimes it was hard to stay awake, but that's just how soft-spoken he is.
Professor Titus is an inspiration to me and will be for many years to come. He cares about each and every one of his infant architects.

This man is a walking talking architecture model, and you will become one too because of how many freaking models he made me do. I hate even looking at glue now it reminds me of the countless all-nighters this man cost me. Also he does shrummies.
Fantastic professor. Inspiring. Eccentric, a kind of arcane, mythic figure or illusory enigma...

Prof Titus is a gifted designer, painter, and educator. Expect to be constantly challenged in studio, but also expect to mature as a thinker and produce profound work. Anthony puts a student's interests and education first -- which is all too rare. Seriously and genuinely committed to architectural education. A transformer of minds.

A fantastic studio professor. Is both extremely committed to and extremely knowledgeable of the subject matter. Wants you to do well. Is willing to come in on a Saturday to help you with your work. Only major complaint is sometimes he's not the clearest with what he wants for an assignment. But he knows this, and will try to re-explain if you ask.

I took solids with him at NC State, the class is fine with the exception that he doesn't respect his students. Completely wrote off our concerns about a test question nobody knew a formula for, wrote off the fact that we didn't think the formula sheet was helpful. He doesn't take feedback into consideration at all. KNOW YOUR REVIEW, he tests you.
Do the homeworks! Exams are normally old homework problems/the method is the same. Ferede does a good job explaining problems in class and accommodating for most issues.

This was for Strengths (ENGR-2530). Kind of mid. Not the easiest to follow during lecture, although his slides were decent for later review. Do the homework! It's 20% of your grade and will help you with the exams. I'd probably consider taking this with someone else if possible.

ENGR 2530, (Not in the drop-down menu for some reason)

Great professor who knows what he's doing. There are in-class assignments so go to class. Also, HW is worth 20% of your grade so do it religiously since there are only two tests and a final.

Has some of the most unclear grading criteria of any professor. He will specifically tell you to include one thing, then will doc points for it the next day. Very rarely gives grades above an 89. During presentations, be ready to get severely criticized. So hard to understand and would not reccomend

Professor Ferede is very articulate and puts a lot of effort and detail into his lectures. Great at teaching and explaining things, and always takes questions from students. BUT ENGINEERING DYNAMICS IS SO BORING THOUGH. It's a shame I have such a great professor for such a dull class because I'm actually in a coma for like 90% of these lectures.

This class was an overall meh. The lectures are not great, consisting mostly of rushed examples read off a PDF (you will probably have to read each PDF at least once on your own). The tests can be extremely difficult and count for a massive portion of your grade. The homework is similarly challenging, so be prepared to spend several days on it.
While clearly passionate about the subject, she clearly has no idea how to teach clearly. The lecture notes were clearer.

CSCI-1200 will always be a very difficult class, but Prof. Plum did an overall good job of teaching the material. Her lectures were generally well-organized, and her explanations of concepts were usually pretty understandable. She is also very good about helping students outside of class, either in her own office hours or Discussion Forum Q&A.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Lectures are decent, but very dry and boring, and the lecture notes are usually what I referred to. With the homeworks, its a lot of self teaching and grinding, so just be ready for that. Tests are hard, but are usually curved decently.

Spring22:Labs15%,Homeworks35%,3Tests10%each,FinalExam20%
Heavy difficult homework, 20-30 hours weekly, expect long nights working on it, start early. Weekly labs are 2 hours, but collab is allowed and its released early so it's often far less. Online lectures are boring and not super helpful but show up to earn allowed late days on the homework.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: This professor never interacts with students and clearly does not care for their student's wellbeing or time. They assign overly complicated homework that has material which is either not on the lectures or is not clearly explained. Tests are made so difficult that the majority of the class usually fails and heavy curves need to be applied.

I took Investments I and Personal Finance with Paulson. He is a great professor with years and years of experience. He loves teaching and truly tries to give a value-add to his students with concrete advice on how to invest your own money. He stays away from quantitative stuff in class and expects you to learn it on your own. Very easy otherwise.

Took Investments I just as his wife past away. Did not get to take the class the whole semester with Professor Paulson, but when he was teach he was interesting to listen to and had a vast knowledge to teach us. Grade based completely off group projects so find good group members
Really good professor.  Teaches you a lot without having to do much work.  I definitely recommend him.  I've taken three of his classes.

I had him for both of these classes. He is one notch down from Ensley on the bad teacher scale. He comes in thinking he knows everything and teaches us nothing, while having no justification for grades. An A in INV II isnt so hard, but an A in RISK MGMT requires A LOT of work in a project that I had no idea how to do because it was never taught.
No Comments

Will teach you anything you want to know about money and give you awesome stock picks at the same time.  Make sure you actually listen to him.  Risk Management is really hard, and Investments 2 had one **** of a project.

He is near retirement, so he is full of stories and a bit lenient in grading. He is very smart and knowledgeable, but does go off on several nested tangents. However, as someone who loves knowledge, information and a good laugh, he is one of my favorite professors. He is a great research adviser too.
Nicest guy you will meet at RPI. He's much more in his element in his MTLE courses than in strengths. Intelligent, fair, and open.

Prof Wright has a very bad teaching style, he copys pages from the book and puts then on slides to present to class in a droll manner. He was a leniant grader though, and if the test was to hard he curved it up alot.

Not a bad guy, but his teaching style got on my nerves after awhile.  Taught off of powerpoint slides and stuck to straight theory, instead of using example problems, which made homework a lot harder.  Recommend to go to his office hours if you have trouble - he's easier to understand then.
Fair grader, but horrible teacher.  Strays from the class material during lectures and uses photocopied pages from the book for notes.
Decent guy, grading is pretty fair. But his teaching style is horrible. Just photocopies pages out of the book and puts them in powerpoint. Very hard to learn from class.
