Professor Rice is super friendly, understanding, a nice grader, and very knowledgeable about music. Overall great professor, and if you do what he asks of you, you'll have no problem getting an A. He does give a good amount of work though, but not bad at all compared to other courses at RPI. He's laid back and easy going, definitely recommend!

Professor Rice was an absolutely amazing professor! He made every lecture very fun and entertaining while keeping learning prevalent and interesting. The class was slightly fast paced with one song due per week, but he was more than willing to work with anyone to accommodate for unforeseen circumstances. If I could give him 6/5 stars, I would.

Dr. Rice is friendly and has a welcoming/casual atmosphere in his classroom. The class is pretty much writing a song each week and presenting them, as well as having lectures and other assignments occasionally. Participate, show up to class, and turn in assignments on time you will get an A. The difficulty depends on how you choose to write songs.
He's very nice, and it's amazing that he was a professional singer. But writing one song per week is not easy at all.

Palermo is great. Very clear lectures, no funny business, and also a very communicative guy who makes sure to answer any question. Accessible outside of class. Excellent lecturer and no qualms to be found in anything else really.

Awesome guy. A very intelligent individual. He s very clear in his lectures and makes this stuff really interesting. The tests are no easy feat but he will answer any question you have and is willing to explain stuff until you understand. Do yourself a favor and take Mat Sci with Professor Palermo.

A truly wonderful person. He is very intelligent, has fantastic lectures, and is great at explaining the material. Knows how to provide solid context to make seemingly confusing material feel natural. Very understanding and sympathetic of your time and work schedule. All around super cool guy. Hard tests though!

He knows the subject matter really well and his presentations are top notch. He knows how to make the boring stuff seem interesting. He is always looking forward to help you out. Tests aren't easy, although As are attainable.

He clearly knows what he is talking about content-wise, this class was really just a question of if you could understand his explanations. He is very nice and is definitely willing to answer questions, I just never really knew where to start. I would recommend taking this class with LaGraff (he filled in once for my class and was way better).

Professor Shi has a bit of an accent so don't be afraid to ask him to repeat what he said. TAs lead most labs and activities, the workload is very light for the class overall as long as you pay attention to the material. Tests are mostly based off the homeworks due every week, so an easy way to prepare is just through reviewing slides and notes.

Professor Shi was a good professor. He had a thicker accent but it never stopped from understanding what he was saying. Sometimes his explanation of the course material was confusing, but feel free to ask questions since he'll always try to clear any confusion if you ask.
Overall decent professor, but there are better.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Materials Science for Engineers was straight forward for the most part. However, most stuff in the lectures were not presented clearly and I learned most of the material from the text book. Teacher has very thick accent and just read from power points.  Weekly short quizzes were pretty straightforward but longer quizzes tended to be tougher.

Prof Henshaw is difficult. He assigns weekly homeworks and you can expect to need over 10 or 15 hours to complete them. He does not share his notes or follow a textbook for this class. You have to go to lecture to learn. If you miss class, you will regret it because he will tell you to get notes from a classmate. Would not recommend.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Writes on chalkboard exclusively, no online notes. Luckily the homeworks follow the book nearly exactly, although there are some things that the book doesn't discuss and he only goes over in class. Material isn't  difficult to understand, but homeworks are time consuming.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: I'm an aero major so the types of problems we approached in class were outside of my comfort zone and most of my friends agree. The homeworks can take a lot of time. I found my TA immensely helpful for these assignments. The tests are reasonable in that they contain similar problems to the homework or lecture.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Lecture is useful and not very hard to understand.

Purdue - BME 21400
this class is evil - the teaching assistants do not even know what they are doing. the review sessions are useless because most of the time the actual answers are wrong.

dr. chan wants to make everyone fail

Purdue - BME 214
This course was 80% exams which is higher than it should be. The homework should be worth more than 5% as it takes a significant amount of time. I did not find the exams to be completely different from the homework, but they required studying and the written ones came directly from the textbook. 
The final exam was curved 20%.

BME 214 - Awful professor. Never in my life have I taken a course so awful. Exams and quizzes combined are 95% of your grade, and homework (which takes 5 hours+ per assignment) is only 5%. If this sounds crazy, you're right. All exams are wildly different than the homework. This professor is out to get you. She does not care about your well-being.

Dr. Chan is so so so nice and if you ever have a question she's there for you! You can use your HW and crib sheet on quizzes and tests but tests can be hard! Questions are just like the ones from the textbook so if you can do each question from there you're good. No curving so you get what you get which sucks but all in all she's super nice. Study!

I love Lupita!  She's always been extremely helpful in everything- advising, independent research, class material.  You can tell she really cares about her students and does her best to improve her courses to suit student needs.
OMG, are you kidding me?  Really, I am certain she doesn't understand half of what she is teaching.  Very narrow and everything gravitates to her research interest.  Not recommended.
Tough professor. You can really tell she cares about the students and is passionate about what she is doing. Dont take this class if you dont want to put in above and beyond effort
No Comments

Shamz can't teach at all.  He loves to be lanky and eat terrible food.  It's astounding.  Sometimes I walk into class and he preaches excerpts from the bible, basketballs flying everywhere.  It's astounding.  I can't help but get bruised. I hate playing defense. The oreos, gamecube and dirty laundry is everywhere. Someone help me. It's astounding.
Easy class, don't even need to come, teacher doesn't show up either sometimes

Don't need to come to class, all homework online, taught me that if Teemo stands still and takes no action for 2 seconds, he becomes stealthed. Taking any action will break his camouflage, granting him 40% attack speed for 3 seconds.
Easiest professor ever, never came to class, just play league of legends for homework

Akshar is the most amazing TA I have ever had at RPI. He made such a major impact on my life by not only teaching me but going above and beyond every step of the way to help me on a weekly basis for both semesters! I am so lucky to know him and if you can get him for ochem lab I highly recommend it!!
best TA ever!!!

ochem lab sucks, especially with moore as the professor. but akshar made this lab so much fun, especially coming from javier the first semester, i learned so much more with akshar. best TA i've ever had at RPI and probably will never be topped. if you miss out of the experience of having akshar as a TA you've missed out on an amazing experience.

Akshar is the best OChem TA there is! I had him my first semester in OChem lab and I miss him so much this semester. Even though he is no longer my TA I go to him all the time for help. I know he's done TAing after his second year in grad school but he is just so so so awesome!
She is self-centered and tends to elevate her image above that of other students. I have personally experienced her criticism, and she often makes harsh remarks.

Great professor overall, notes are clear and concise and if you pay attention in class, everything should make sense. Very open to questions and will answer them well. Homework is very similar to what's covered in class. There are outliers here and there but they're specific cases you won't really see in exams. Homeworks are very similar to exams.

She gives you what you need on the slides and that's about it. Lectures often boring. Skips through example problems leaving you lost. Homework will only get longer and most times does not correlate to what was taught. Tough exams, although sometimes generous partial credit. Only 2 midterms; you must study for these, as anything can show up.

- Lectures are very well organized and easy to understand. - Graded in-class problems every lecture that are graded so come to class. - Exams are reasonable regarding difficulty and material. - Homeworks take a while so start early. - Highly recommend this prof and I'm taking a class with her again this semester.
Very good lecturer
Professor Phil is my fav professor! My friend had something he didnt understand, and he asked him on the class discord and professor Phil recorded a full 20 mins video just to explain it for him.
LOVE HIM
great

Professor Vanderhyden was excellent at teaching both the technical and creative aspects of visual effects (and Houdini). The projects he assigned were highly effective to this end and afforded us ample room for creativity and experimentation. Additionally, his feedback was very insightful and allowed me to improve as an artist.

Professor Chakrapani is teaching T&F for the first time this semester since 2018. This class took a lot of hours for me to do well in. Funnily enough, the hardest part about this course is using English units. The dimensional analysis gets really difficult and most of her exams have more problems with English units than SI. She lectures very fast.

Professor Chakrapani, for courses in her focus (electrochemistry), is incredibly enthusiastic. She loved the material; making the course much more enjoyable. She is very understanding and approachable.
She knows what shes talking about but the class is mad hard. Not the worst TF1 professor but definitely not the best.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Material gets more difficult as semester progresses. Final given in class.
He definitely makes you do your work, but the tests and quizzes are pretty straight forward. As long as you do the homework, you'll be fine.

I love Professor Schoch! I read a lot of scary things on here before I took his class, but he's actually an awesome teacher. He's really nice and will work with you if you need help. He sticks around during studios to help. He works at a fast pace, but it's not too hard. BUY THE BOOK! All the quizzes and tests are open book so make sure you have it
No interest in the students, leaves lab shortly after assigning studio. Powerpoints are short and incomplete, no repetition. Do not take this class

Professor hardly teaches. Completely unclear in wording questions/expectations, rude to students and TA's, assumes people already understand programming, many students have to the take class multiple times to pass, tests do not reflect the course material, you can know how to code perfectly and fail the tests. avoid him unless you already know VB.

He's actually an adjunct at SUNY Albany as well, I took his International Economic Relations class and it was super easy. Very knowledgeable professor, great guy, easy to understand if you pay attention.
easy easy course.

Easy class.  He teaches from the book, but knows what he is talking about.  Gave 5 bonus problems at the end of the semester.  They were 2 percentage points each on your final grade, which pushed me to an A.
Great Instructor. Knows his stuff.
Prof Sharkey is awesome. He is a great teacher and is willing to help students provided you go to ask him for help. Almost always curves HWExams if the average is below an 80ish.
Good at teaching. very clear. If you pay attention in lecture then the materials are fairly easy. Tests can be harder than expected but there are curves.
He is comprehensive with his notes. He makes class interesting as well!
Awesome professor.  Relatively new to the department but teaches better than anybody.

She's really good at explaining everything. Her powerpoints are great. I take notes in class and sometimes don't even revisit my notes because she explained everything so well. AP Chem helped prior to this class, but she still did a great job. Her office hours are always helpful. Don't be intimidated of her, she's actually really nice!
Awesome, awesome professor. She is so good at explaining things and is always willing to help and answer additional questions. I learned a lot from her.
She is the best general chemistry professor here! My friends with other professors rely on her notes to learn the material. She is charismatic and pretty so listening to her is very easy!

Excellent professor. Clear explanations. You can follow her ppts and not read the book b/c they follow the chapters. Class is boring sometimes b/c she takes her time explaining problems, but she tries to make them interesting w/ in-class experiments. She has office hours each week and will try to help you succeed in her class.

Barb is the kindest professor I had during my time at RPI. Not only was she a great professor, but she also did a wonderful job of running the writing center, COMM+D. I learned a lot about communication & rhetoric and how to improve my writing in an environment that was incredibly comfortable and welcoming.

She cares about her students and wants them to do well. She is very lenient with deadlines and grades pretty easily. I learned enough about writing for me to get by at RPI, and I would definitely take a class with her again
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Caring

comment: There were only three papers we wrote the whole semester, and she gave plenty of time. She kept pushing deadlines back because she was late with giving feedback, haha

Professor Lewis is one of the best professors I had classes with in RPI.  She is willing to spend  time to discuss with each student after class individually.  Her class was appropriately paced and well designed that  not only helped students learn writing but also encourage them to think about their future development in career and academics.

The stuff we went over in Writing for Games was immediately applicable to my Game Dev 1 class, which helped me feel like I was helpful even as a writing concentration. You basically do a project for each step of the game writing process (pitching, beat sheets, and scripting) and you learn about industry tests, aka how you would actually get hired.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: I hesitated between 3 and 4 because the class was very good but way too easy. Some students got very good despite their lack of work. But apart from that, Professor Suckling knows what he is talking about, he is on my top 3 at GSAS.

Maurice's Intro to Game Storytelling is great. Easy A. I took it during a tough semester and it gave me a nice break from my other classes. He assigns several short essays throughout the semester and pretty much your entire grade is based on the quality of your writing. He's a pretty chill dude. 10/10 would take again.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Caring

comment: Had Maurice for Intro to Game Storytelling and Game Narrative Design. Very nice professor, his classes are mostly based on essays and as long as you stay on topic (focusing on the narrative), then you'll get good grades. Game Narrative Design you literally just play board games in, probably the best class I've ever taken.

Dr. Hunt makes lectures interesting and engaging. He uses a mix of videos, slides and breakout talks during lecture which is unlike any other professor I have seen at RPI so far. His quizzes and exams were somewhat challenging because of a few obscure questions but there were a lot of other easier assignments that helped boost grades.

The best professor I have had at RPI. He cares about his students and actually tries to get to know them. He understands students have a lot of work in other classes and will listen to students' input.

Hunt is a great professor, he is very easy to talk to and cares about the success of his students. His tests are very memorization heavy so get ready for flash cards but other than that the course is fairly easy.
Great professor, not a lot of homework. You do need to study for the exams because they are a bit confusing.
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Presentations and essays are easy assignments but beware of class "discussions" (basically Brian talking about his thoughts on the weekly readings and shooting down students who disagree). You can definitely get away with not doing the readings.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment:
Even though I enjoy discussion & humanities based classes, the same can't be said for Design, Culture, and Society.
Prof Tolle was really difficult to work with. He regularly (and loudly) interrupted students during discussions and gave zero guidance on grading criteria (despite grading harshly). Some topics in class were interesting, at least?
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Course is entirely based on in-class discussion.  Brian is a very knowledgeable, caring instructor.  He does have an annoying habit of cutting students off right after they begin talking, but otherwise he is great.  Overall, this is a super easy course where you can learn a lot.

Politics of Design is a fairly easy and straight forward class, but is very reading heavy. Tolle is an easy going and sociable professor, but he can come across as full of himself. He often cuts students off to insert his own opinion and he does not like granting extensions. The course is very thought provoking & supports a cooperative atmosphere.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: She's not the course coordinator so she may not have as much insider knowledge, but she is SO caring and kind. She made MAU slightly more tolerable, and she will take all the time in the world to explain something if you don't understand it. Her lectures are slightly discombobulated at times, so just keep asking questions.

Of the MAU professors whose lectures I have gone to (her, Shenogin and the german guy) she is the only one that lectures via ipad notes and then shares those notes afterward so I definitely recommend her, especially if you skip lectures.

She teaches well and her notes are easy to read. The class is taught at a relaxed paced so it never feels like you're lagging behind (unlike some professors who like to speedrun classes). She is very helpful during office hours and makes sure you understand the material.

Dr. Agca Aktunc is one of my favorite lecturers at RPI. She is extremely knowledgable, especially in statistics and data science. MAU is a math & theory heavy course, but she explains all the concepts very in-depth and clearly. She is kind, polite and always willing to help students, all of her office hours I have been to were extremely effective.
Not a fan. Friends warned me not to take a class with her and I regret not listening to them. Persoon admits that she is the hardest PDIII teacher.
Good class, got an A without much work.  Also, she's pretty hot...
Easy class no need to do any work at all, Good teacher.
No Comments

Funny, good lecturer, useful information, interactive lectures, really loves medicinal chemistry. Straightforward exams and homework. Definitely recommend this class to biology, chem, chemE, and pre-pharms.

This class was hard but I loved it--he's such a great guy, always willing to help and able to contort his body into many 'atom' shapes...seems he was always using his limbs to describe hydrophilic pockets or binding sites, really brought the class to life for me!
No Comments
No Comments

Bob is responsible for my interest in communications. I use some aspect of my classes with Bob every day in my professional career and personal life.  His ability to apply strict scientific focus while observing the big picture sets a high standard. I am glad to see he is annoying his neighbors with his music! Rock on Bob.

Bob is mad chill. He has a good sense of humor and his lectures are always informative (although not limited to course material.) It is very refreshing taking a class from a professor who is interested in teaching well and communicating in a manner that students are receptive to.

Krull is a cool guy.  He's funny, very intelligent, and gives a lot of feedback on assignments.  Unfortunately, his lectures seem to just barely scratch the surface of what he expects us to know, and he sometimes goes off on tangents that you assume will be important aspects of the test, and aren't.
Robert Krull is the man, very understanding and very  smart. On the downside his instructions are sometimes vague. But hes a great guy just make sure to clarify your work.
Prof Borton is awesome.  He makes you think, and in big ways.  Out of all the professors at RPI, he's in the top 3 in my book.  Take his course!!
This guys loves to push his beliefs in class. Not that bad to get a good grade... but you will want to take a swan dive off the CII stairwell listening to his boring lectures are

I can't believe this guy has been teaching at RPI as long as he has.  I have never seen a professor trying to push his own personal agenda like this guy has.  Whenever you ask a question which challenges his personal agenda he quickly changes the subject.  Miserable teacher-an embarrasment to RPI!

An old-school loon. Cares about sig figs but doesn't allow calculators! Very one sided towards solar energy. He'll just ask you back any question you ask him.The worst is that he is soooo full of himself.

Obrien is a very nice teacher and a very easy grader. You basically cannot get below a B+ or above an A-. Attendance is required and the class is quite a bit of work but most of it is easy although can be time consuming.
Teacher is knowledgable about the material and does not waste time with pointless work as some other teachers do
He's a great professor, he really cares about his students. His lectures are kind of boring, but he definitely knows a lot :)

Not that intense of a professor when compared with others for this class.  Lectures were bland, but he kept them interesting enough.  Really easy to do well if you participate every now and then, and he grades relatively easy on the presentations.
Dr. Sprague is helpful and friendly. She has some fantastic stories and often jokes around lightly, but will quickly smack you down if you cause trouble.

She is very kind and knowledgeable. Always willing to help students improve understanding. Easy to reach outside of class, responds to emails quickly. The labs graded by the TA's are not all graded the same, so meet with the TA grading the lab you're on if you want help. Strict about lab rules but fair.
Very nice but almost completely useless when it comes to preping the class for a test(She doesnt even know what is on it).
No Comments

He is very knowledgeable about using Python for problem-solving, but he had a lot of trouble getting his point across. Compared to other professors teaching the same course, he barely does quiz preparation. It is also frustrating that this course is so disorganized.

I originally had him as my Numerical Methods teacher but switched to another because I couldn't handle his teaching style. He tried his best to explain concepts but sometimes just ended up reading off lecture slides without elaboration. He's accessible in office hours and emails which helped. He looked out for students but I wouldn't take him again
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: This class is all back work. If you have the tests/homework from the previous two years, this class will be easy for you even if you don't know whats going on. He is helpful at office hours though and if I wasn't a senior, I may have put more effort into the class. Class notes are pretty helpful for understanding the backtests.
Very helpful outside of class and is willing to help you with homework. Tests were somewhat tricky, but redoing the homework for practice makes such a difference.
rating_tags: BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Wastes much of his lecture time on anecdotes / untestable material. He doesn't show enough examples to learn the material. His handwriting is also terrible which doesn't help. In addition, 3 out of the 4 exams we were given had multiple errors on them, and corrections were made haphazardly during the exam in order to make the problems solvable.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Test heavy

comment: During lectures it is difficult to get a firm grasp on the concept being taught (a combination of his bad handwriting and quickly going through example problems), however if you go to his office hours I find he is extremely helpful and knowledgeable about the topics covered. If you take charge of learning the material, he will help you.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: lenient grader (becuase of his own mistakes), but does not teach a single thing.

Olson is quite possibly the worst educator I have ever met. Thermodynamics is an incredibly difficult class, and it doesn't help that Olson REFUSES to teach it. I learned nothing from lectures, his notes were riddled with mistakes and he had typos and missing information on 2 of his tests. AVOID THIS PROF

Doesn't actually teach the content, so often need to use other resources to know what's going on. The hw doesn't relate to exams, and he has a huge ego. He isn't much of a teacher. He never explains topics, just gives you the equations and expects you to already know the material and how he got to his answers.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Bro does not teach, nor wants to teach. Lecture consists of 3 or 4 power point slides about global warming and nothing else useful. I learned everything through chegg.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Online Savvy

comment: Prof Kemp is an incredible teacher and such a caring person. Keep in mind attendance is absolutely essential to pass this course. She gives good feedback on projects but grades more on effort than quality. Definitely recommend her course.
Amazing professor, cares a lot about each student and their work, and I genuinely improved my drawing skills. Will be continuing to take classes with her. She's very kind and understanding as well.
Very sweet and kind, could give more feedback and be more harsh, considering it is an art class

Amazing professor. I came in with no experience and came out knowing how to draw. She is really caring and wants all her students to succeed. Each of the major projects are designed to help grow certain skills. The class was a lot of work but it was very rewarding.
It was extremely difficult for him to understand students' questions.

For Engineering Dynamics, Professor Diagne has a very sloppy way of teaching. He frequently goes back and forth between different subject matters and does not clearly explain concepts to the students. His handwriting is also hard to read at moments. I would not recommend him as a teacher.
BRO, HE IS THE BEST PROFESSOR I HAVE EVER SEEN. I WOULD CALL HIM DAD IF HE ACCEPTS ME AS HIS SON. I LOVE HIS TEACHING AND I WOULD TAKE HIS CLASS AGAIN!!!!
For Dynamics, it was a bit of a train wreck. He was all over the place. Clearly cared and wanted us to learn but his communication was lacking and he was never able to understand students' questions.

His notes are very detail and often have examples that are useful for studying for exams. He does a good job introducing new topics/ concepts,he provides good background information and motivating factors for new concepts. His grading is very fair, you will do well as long as you demonstrate that you understand the applicable course concepts.

Professor Panneerselvam is one of the better professors I have had at RPI. He is knowledgeable about what he is teaching, and most importantly seems to enjoy teaching it. I had him for 3 separate classes now and have enjoyed all of them. Courses are hard because they are generally new concepts for engineers here. Would highly recommend.

Although his lectures could be a bit more clear, he does provide extensive content (example problems w solutions, HW solutions) that you can use pretty effectively to do well on the exams. Kid below me probably just had a rough semester and chose to take it out on Dr. Paneerselvam. He is genuinely a really caring guy and wants students to succeed.

He cannot lecture to save his life, doesnt like to do hand written notes. Is far too softspoken when lecturing making it hard to understand him. does not like to do more than 1 example in class when it should merit many more. Syllabus and what he says in class conflict many times. I am actively avoiding taking a class taught by him ever again.
He's really sweet and actually cares about how his students are getting along in the class.

Prof. Ji was helpful and enthusiastic.  The biggest drawback to taking one of his classes is that he has a thick accent, and is a little hard to communicate with.  His classes are hard, but if you can handle it, I certainly recommend him.

great lectures + intelligent professor. his lecture notes are better than any textbook. he's a tough grader but outside of class he's extremely nice and helpful. i'd say he's one of the best teachers here in RPI.
Nice guy who knew his stuff, but boring & quiet in lectures and a tough grader. Accent's not strong, and he really warms up to anyone who tries to get to know him  outside of class.

Avoid him if you want to grow in your career. He is very selfish and he will treat you like a slave through constant belittling. His exams were extremely tough and he is a tough grader. Better stay clear of him or your career will be ruined by him.
He is knowledgeable, but has no interest in imparting that knowledge to his students. He looks down upon his students and many leave him for that matter.

Jian Sun is very smart and you will learn a lot.  However, his leadership style is horrendous.  He berates students and deems them as slaves.  Many of his students leave for (and even completely change the field!).  He is smart and much can learned from him but not at the cost of losing years of life due to stress and fear.

A well-known professor in his area, but avoid him unless his class is critical to your research focus.  He set unclear expectations, didn't use the required text at all, was difficult to reach, and has a way of berating and denegrating his students.  I feel that he has no genuine interest in teaching or providing mentorship to his class.
Did a decent job covering the material. Only had 2 tests & 2 quizzes for grades that were fair.

pretty hard to understand, but no homework, she tells you that you don't have to show up to class.  quizzes and test are VERY similar to the back work that she gives to you.  again there is some difficulty in understanding but overall very easy course
Come again? In English this time..That sums up the whole semester. Stick to the book and dont bother to go to class
She is a very nice person but her grading can be hard to understand sometimes because she always seems to change the scales for everything. I liked her class Writing for classroom and career though.

Professor Gordon is a really nice person and genuinely cares about her students. Creative fiction writing was a fun class, positively impacted my writing style, and was a really nice, low-stress break from all of my engineering classes.

You should only take Creative Fiction Writing if you have a strong interest in writing fiction. That said, it was an awesome class. You spend much of each class period writing, and there's only an hour or so of homework per week. Basically, if you put in the work, you will get a good grade, and the class is very low stress.
The best professor I have seen at RPI.
By far the best professor I have had at RPI. Uses simple example to demonstrate every single concept and is fair with the grading.
Systems and Synthetic Biology: He was very helpful in explaining all of the concepts and was very friendly and great at explaining concepts at his office hours
Good professor!!! Recommend!!!
rating_tags: BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--Clear grading criteria

comment: Good professor, tried to let everyone focused and participated, but failed all the time; has a think accent as posted before, but it was understandable. Some pop-up quizzes and you can drop one. Better than other Accounting for DC professors.

Prof. Wu is a nice guy who knows what he's talking about, and the accounting class I took with him is easy.  He has a thick accent and isn't always clear, but I can't complain about his class.  He does try to get the class to participate, but it usually doesn't work.  The material just isn't engaging enough, I think.

Go to lecture, she goes over a lot of incredibly key concepts there that she tests on. Overall, I thought she was a great professor - the material isn't the easiest to take in from lecture. If you go see her outside of class she will sit through it with you until you understand it. Good luck!

Probably for her first teaching she was a bit shy but also very patient. I went there a lot and she could always wait to fully understand my question(ESL student lol). Sometimes lectures can be dry at times but her very well organized ppt could save the time for you from reading . boring textbooks.

There are very few factors that contribute to your grade. This class is not easy. Homeworks and exams graded very harshly. She is very nice but very monotone and grades hard. Take classes with other professors if possible.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Group projects

comment: Great professor with a lot of energy! Her classes are engaging and she uses changes in her voice to communicate. It was an 8:30 class, but she was kind even though I showed up 5 minutes late. She is available to help and her office hours are very helpful. Very kind and makes me smile. If you have the opportunity to take her, do. You will learn.

This class was super heavily group project-focused (her other classes aren't necessarily like this). But she does an amazing job of making sure you learn, without leaving you floundering and confused. I feel like this is one of the few classes you get real-world IE experience! 10/10 <3

Her class has exams with open book and closed book sections. Recommend to pay attention in class and understand the content. Her content on exams is based on the homework and whether you understand the concepts. Her lectures are engaging. She cares for her students and is willing to help you. I would take another class with her again.

The content of AIM is really outdated, you don't learn anything that will be useful or that you haven't already learned in high school. It's a shame, it's a waste of time. The good thing is that it's an easy A.
Very irresponsible as an online course instructor - does not give lectures at all. Only posted links to online tutotials which are generally not well presented, some of which are dated.

Arts for Interactive Media is a gem with professor Nideffer. The course is not a large amount of work, you can get away with only really working on the weekend. This class was one of the most fun I've had due to the sheer creative freedom I was able to experience. Top recommend.

Overall great professor who is super knowledgeable. The homeworks can be time consuming and tough to get and the project at the end of the year isn't easy. Made SFM very interesting and I am looking to do research with him in the future as a result.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: This was his first semester teaching SM and it was one of the best classes I've taken at RPI.  Professor Singh is very knowledgeable, has very well-prepared lectures, and is very helpful during office hours.  Highly recommend this class and professor.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: In his first semester, things started off a little rocky after the first exam, but after taking in feedback the course became much more manageable. There were some growing pains but Professor Singh was very understanding to everyone and by the end the class was much better. The lectures were a drag and the project was difficult, but overall not bad

I love this professor. He is really funny, and I go to all of his office hours and this helps me do well on all his homework. The homework takes a while, but they directly relate to the exam, and he is always available for questions. He is so enthusiastic and truly cares. He wants everyone to understand the material and enjoy it as much as he does.

Would never take again. As difficult as CS1 very bad homeworks, very bad, that take forever and the tests are extremely difficult. Lectures are not helpful, doesn't explain concepts well, and acts like cares for students difficulties but really does not. Avoid if possible.

Took this professor for both ISYE 4600 and ISYE 4960. I did a lot better in ISYE 4600 because the content is easier. His lectures last the entirety of the hour and fifty minutes if not more. The homeworks are long. But he is a fair grader and wants to see his students do well. He gives a lot of bonus points and extra credit to help you succeed.
skibidi toilet

Very smart but you have no clue what's going on in her brain. Can be really good at explaining things for a few minutes then starts skibidi toilet fizz for the rest of the class. Spends too much time riding bikes and is late to meetings, sometimes do not show up to ofice hours.
This class should not be required. This dropped my Aquatic Activities GPA down to Davy Jone's locker. Would not recommend, still cant weave underwater.

I've never had a professor who was so inept at teaching. Take this class with someone else, even if you have to go to a community college to do so. HE IS NOT HELPFUL. I approached him for extra help and was forced to redo every assignment (even though I was getting all A's), putting me behind in everything else for the class. AVOID HIM

Tough class if Visual Basic is not your major (it certainly wasn't mine). Use your book as the bible, always go to the TA sessions, that'll get you through the homework. If you start to fall behind, get his attention otherwise he'll never know. Nice guy, but it isn't his full-time job, so he really isn't pouring his heart into the class.

Nice guy but not extremely helpful. Hard to pay attention during lectures and got most of help from outside class. It seems like if you have no knowledge of programming, this will be a very hard class. It's also hard to find people to help you since it's VBA and not C
hard. aggravated. useless.
Had to learn everything myself.
Makes a potentially interesting topic very boring. He seems like a reasonable guy as far as workload goes.
Covers the basics.

Doesn't know his students. What he is teaching is useless to the class. Also, gave all assignments at the end of the semester, when all students are already very busy. Teaches useless proofs. Mocks students and never tries to help them. A looser.

Pretty helpful professor though difficult to understand at times. Weekly homework assignments. Tests and quizzes are relatively easy other than multiple choice on the tests. Overall pretty easy course with Ha
Do yourself a favor, dont mess up your gpa really really hard
No Comments
Head of the Dept for a while, kinda looked like a little weasel, very accessible to students, always around to help but that doesn't mean I learned a damn thing.

She was so nice at the beginning. Then she started to give us so many assignments/projects/essay at the end of the semester. There was one time that she gave us two presentation in three days...... But easy exams. She basically gave all the answers in the review documents.

One of my favorite professors. She is understanding and cares about her students. Exams and assignments are fair. Study and you will do well in this class. Professor Freeman is very knowledgeable in human resources.
Very nice and wants everyone to do well, overall easy class and gives extra credit if needed
tests are long but straightforward and fair, very low exam averages, homework helps for exams, office hours help if you go
bad lectures

Prof Collins is very intelligent and challenges students to answer their own questions, but she is unclear when teaching topics and does not emphasize what will be important to the laboratories.  Attendence at lectures is mandatory due to regular quizzes.  She becomes emotional about unprepared students, yet her disorganization does not prepare us.
I had him for my capstone experience, but wanted to have him for another experience ;)  As a Professor, he expects alot, but he give his students alot too!
Awesome teacher :)

Had him for Air Vehicle Design (Capstone).  He is an excellent professor who loves the subject, but he expects a lot from you.  Pay attention to his suggestions and comments, because he will ask tough questions during your presentations based on them.  You will definitely learn something... if you want to.

Professor Huang is great, but the labs and exams don't seem to correspond to the material being taught in lecture. During lectures, she makes sure that you understand what is going on and has a lot of relevant information and stories to share, but when you get to the assignments, things do not seem to match and it becomes difficult to navigate.

Some people complain about her accent but I had no problem understanding her lectures. She draws connections between the details and the big picture and sends digital notes to follow her lectures. Always willing to answer students questions, TA was also very helpful. Quizzes are straight forward (one every other week) as well as homeworks.
Class is easy, many people find her pleasing to look at

Took Semiconductor Power Electronics with Prof. Peng in Fall 2012, when she was a new lecturer who was also working a job at GE.  I thought her unengaging lectures and sometimes unclear grading policies made it difficult to learn much of the time.  She was also very hard to reach. Would not recommend taking a course with her.
tests are fair but she is not a good teacher. Very hard to understand at most times
Bad grammar, hard to understand, no fixed office, and has no interest in the students at all.

She was the most empathetic teacher I ever met at RPI, and she really took into consideration every student's individual struggles. Oftentimes my classes were so packed I wouldn't have time to each breakfast or lunch during the day, and one day I legit cried real-ass tears because she let us go early and I was able to grab food. I'll miss her a lot

Seeley is a phenomenal professor. She doesn't care necessarily if you're a "bad" writer; what she cares about is that you improve over the course of the semester because she genuinely wants your writing skills to grow. There aren't many hard deadlines for this class, so it's easy to juggle, and she's very accessible to go over drafts and questions.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: A caring professor who loves to provide outside assistance when students need help. The course material help my communication skill a lot. Would defnitely take her class.
tries to be engaging during lectures and checks in to make sure everyone understands the content. lectures content is usually very similar to homework assignments.

This professor is a understanding guy who's actually a great teacher and lecturer. Unfortunately, his exams are extremely difficult even though they are open notes. I do feel like I learned a lot in his class, but he is certainly more difficult than other professors.

He's a very thorough lecturer, taking time out of class to ensure everybody there understands the material covered. Tests are hard, but graded kindly. Weekly homeworks take a long time but provide a good grade boost. Overall solid professor, don't let the amount of work dissuade you, all thermals classes give tons of work.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: ohhhh Shirley, u haunt my dreams with your receding hairline. When I first gazed upon that massive foreheead i thought "no way her husband lets her outta the house looking like that", but then i remembered shes a life and money sucking leech and her husband def has no say in what happens. This woman is awful truly awful.
highest wage in us took ur money and do not care for the school and u

Dr. Jackson, who is often called by her students The Honorable Shirley Ann Jackson, Ph.D. President, Professor of Physics, Applied Physics, and Astronomy, Professor of Engineering Sciences, is a great teacher. While her teaching methods are unusual, we definitely learned a lot with her. Some disliked her power lectures, but RPI is better with her.

Easily the best prof at RPI. Took him for aerodynamics and again for propulsion systems and not disappointed. As others have said he gives very good lecture notes and the quizzes are generally tame. P.S. Don't blame professors for grades being late, that's the TA's job.

Had fluids lab with him. It's the end of the semester and he did not even grade half of the reports. The quizzes he gives us are based on very random and useless information. I think he has the capacity to be a good professor but he just does not care to try. Would not recommend having him.
Highly recommended for Aerodynamics. Easily one of the clearest and best lecturers here.

I had him for Aerodynamics when he first taught it in Summer 2021.  Very straightforward open-note exams (averages were high 80s or low 90s).  Lectures were well-organized and easy to follow.  Overall, great professor.

Good-heart and understanding the suject/topics very well. Good at delivering knowledge and techniques clearly. He is a great professor and he is willing to teach you everything you need to know if you work with him in labs.
One of the best lecturers I've had. He explains difficult concepts very thoroughly and methodically. A lot of the time I did not even have to read the textbook.

I had Dr. T as my lab instructor for both Chem 1 and 2. He always does a great job of explaining concepts. I always understand what he teaches and he is the reason I am not doing terribly in Chem. He once dedicated a lab session on going over a back exam so that we could do well on it, when he was not required to. He is also very friendly.
Demands hard work and creative thought.
No Comments
No Comments

Class activities and homework and useless and confusing.  I have gained no knowledge on how to right professionally.  The course itself is fine, but she completely disregarded the set syllabus and turned the class into something it should never be.  She also expects your life to revolve around this class.

Unclear with assignments, there will be a small acknowledgement about part of the tremendous amount of hw, but you would need to be a mind reader to know what was due. Acts as if her class is the most important class at RPI. Grading is based on foggy premises highlighted after the essay has been graded. Classwork is dry and has no function.
Absolutely a horrible teacher. If you value your grade or your education, get somebody else.

Worst prof I've ever had at RPI. Raging feminist. When covering racially-charged material actually called out several students out to talk about their experiences being black---MESSED UP. it was totally awkward. She consistently picks on certain students she chooses to dislike. Tries to be tactful but is just a tool.

She is too tactful. She tries to be all nice and interactive, but actually just turns people off. Her reading assignments are lengthy and usually not very worthwhile. And the papers she requires you to write are about topics about nothing. She wants to help, but doesn't know how. She's also very picky on the papers. A minor slip and there goes an A

Her stories were really tangential, out there and mostly about Africa, but if you thought about them they made sense. The course itself is pretty stupid, but I'm not sure if there's really any way to make it interesting. Definitely an easy A.

Casey is the best for PD3. Gives good feedback for all presentations, be they solo or group. The class is fun and really useful for different situations that may be encountered in the workplace. Wish this class would have been taught before IED. Only tough part of this class is that the quizzes are a bit tricky.
he is great

Casey is one of, if not THE, nicest professors at RPI. He cares a lot about his students and tries to talk to us about things we're involved in. He's not necessarily an easy grader but he does give really great feedback and he's flexible with deadlines (to a point). Casey is a funny and engaging lecturer. A+ teaching.

Branden and I go way back and the guy really knows his stuff.  Can't recommend him enough for one on one work.  The work assigned for his classes (I have taken MBE and Malware) isn't just busy work and it really does help you understand the subject on the whole.

Few instructors at RPI are as passionate about teaching as Professor Clark. He really gets into the details of what he is talking about when he explains all the techniques and security exploits in the class. He also got a few guest speakers in from world class security companies. Definitely want to take before you graduate.
great dude
Homework is optional and not for credit. He's a pretty good lecturer, explains a concept then teaches by examples. Nice guy, would take another diffeq class with him in a heartbeat.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--TEST HEAVY--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Klobusicky is freaking amazing. His lectures are easy to understand and his homeworks cover the material well, are easy to understand what is expected of you, and are graded fairly. I can't recommend him enough
No homework + tons of examples
Professor Shi wanted all of us to pass and was quite an easy grader. He made lectures enjoyable and I learned to like the content because of him.

Quite a nice professor. Many interactions between the professor and students during the class, and he is always well-prepared fo the class. Will give much assistance with learning and exams. Not a tough grader.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Really great guy, lectures go by very quickly and he will always help you out after class. Tests are very similar to back exams, but you need to understand the concepts to be able to do well on exams. TAs grade the homework extremely hard, but it's only 10% of the grade, and tests are 90%; don't cheat on the homework and you will do fine on tests.

Dr. Shelley is one of my favorite professors I've ever had at RPI. He is extremely understanding of the course's content and its difficulties and is always willing to help his students learn. If I could leave him a 10,000 star rating I would. I highly recommend taking any class taught by him! Dr. Shelley you're the BESTTT

Though Intro to Mass Spectrometry is a hard subject to get into, Dr. Shelley makes each concept digestible and easy to understand. The quizzes are helpful to keep you on track throughout the semester and his homeworks are few. He is accessible at office hours and always makes time for his students. Mama! Don't sleep on this class!

The mass spectrometry lectures from Prof. Shelley were amazing! The lectures are like story to capitivate me. The in-class quiz motivates me to review what I have learned. He is an excellent professor to delivery knowledge clearly and concisely. I really enjoyed his lectures. Highly recommend students to take his class.
Great guy with lots of experience. It's an easy class, but you learn a lot.
So good

Unlike most professors, Ballinger actually has relevant experience. He teaches through real world examples, has a good sense of humor, and is extremely inspirational. It is impossible to do poorly in his class if you put the slightest bit of effort in. Most classes are extremely fun so attending isn't even a chore.

I had Dr. Cadieux for my spring 2023 semester and I enjoyed the class. The exams were a bit challenging but as long as you paid attention and obviously studied, it should be okay. She's very knowledgeable and kind and I always found her lectures engaging. The labs weren't bad either, I found them more tedious than challenging. I liked the class.

Dr. Cadieux is always incredibly nice and reasonable with grading. This class was super lecture and reading heavy, but she always tries to make the material engaging. Overall, really cool class and great professor

Took this class for my science requirement. She has very engaging and clear lectures and seems very passionate. The textbook used was online, and no purchase was required. Exams were tough but fair and we had ample opportunities to improve our grades. She was also friendly and tied learned concepts to everyday experiences. Would recommend.

Her lectures are just her reading off her slides. The slides often have too much information on them and it seems like sometimes she doesn't even know what is going on. She is really nice, but when it comes to the lectures, it is near impossible to sit through them and actually understand what is going on.

Fundamental concepts were not clearly explained, rather focusing on a few specific examples. Tests were more memorisation of people, dates, etc. than anything else. Clearly knowledgeable and passionate about the subject but doesn't know how to teach at an introductory level

Very professional and collected, she clearly knows her stuff. Enjoyed her teaching style as well. Subject material was very interesting and she did her best to tie the relevance of the material into our daily lives. Recommended.

He was a great lecturer with understandable slides. The exams were fair but you definitely needed to study a lot for them. We had extra credit but you need a 95 for an A. TA review sessions were extremely helpful and Rojas was helpful in office hours. Grades took a long time to be put into LMS but overall biomaterials is a good course- just study!
The course was obviously going to be heavy, but this teacher made it very simple and had us understand all of the material. He was very caring and this class is very manageable for 4-credits

Dr. Rojas is a good professor. Not a lot of homework. Definitely cares about his students and is very approachable. He rushes through lectures but the slide material is good and easy to review. He is sometimes unclear about content for assignments/quizzes. Tests were difficult but awesome TA review sessions and forgiving grading helped a ton.

Professor Rojas is new to the school in Fall 2024, and I had him for bioengineering and material science. From what I heard, he is very knowledgeable and is way better than the other professors who teach this class. We had four assignments, two tests, and four quizzes, with one of the quizzes being dropped and a group paper and presentation

Without question, the best professor I have had at RPI. He is approachable, relaxed, patient, interesting, and cares about his students more than anyone I've ever met. Lectures are well-organized and never longer than they need to be. If you can take a class with Professor Bevilacqua, do it.
Great guy, fairly laid back.

This professor is one of the BEST at RPI. Fair/EASY grader. Fun and outgoing. Can laugh with him and hes cool among his students. Hes one of the best if not the best professor I have had at RPI. DEFINITELY TAKE CLASSES WITH HIM IF YOU CAN!!!! Even the CAPPSTONE class was fun with him!!

I've heard my classmates talk about how awful this subject was but Aniket makes this class very engaging and I came out of it understanding Thermal and Fluid Dynamics like a pro. I believe Aniket is the best professor in this subject and you should make sure you sign up for his section! The tests will be a challenge but there's usually extra credit

Professor Tekawade, although new, is a great professor. Thermals and Fluids 1 is a difficult course, and Professor Tekawade was able to present the course material in a concise, understandable manner. He is very approachable, and will always help you if you email him with problems or go to his office hours.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Would take again

comment: Professor Tekawade is a new professor, and I took Thermals and Fluids his first semester teaching (Fall 2017). That being said, he does an excellent job explaining concepts and doing examples in class, and is very accessible during office hours if you need extra help. The tests and homework are challenging, but doable.
He is old and a bit quiet, but a good man.
worst  experience, can not see his notes, lecture is so boring, can not focus more than 3 seconds.
make me lose interests in cse major, especially with cpu

Sounded like he prepared the 2 hour lecture 10 minutes before class started. Often, he would repeat the same idea with a different wording as if it would help teach the material. Sounded like the part in The Emperor's New Groove where Kronk talks about the poison for Kuzco. There are random, graded in class problems. Hard to take notes.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Had him for Intro to Civil and he couldn't care less about it. When we gave presentations he would look up information about our topics on wikipedia. He didn't even know the info well enough to ask us questions!
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: His lectures were not very clear in explaining things and he tends to repeat the same thing several times without adding any new information. There are in class problems that need to be turned in so you have to pay attention. The final grade is based on a standard deviation so make sure to be better than everyone else.

Professor Cunha is a really nice professor and he's very knowledgeable in CFD but he's not very good at teaching. His lectures are very hard to follow. They're mostly math equations without any explanations on how the answer is reached. He assumes it makes sense to all his students. Most of the knowledge I learned in this class came from CFD forums
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Horrible explanations, references a lot of outside material and doesn't explain them. You have to look them up on your own and figure out what it means. Homework includes questions that he doesn't teach or cover and those questions are difficult to answer. Assumes everyone already knows the material and skims over everything.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Well meaning professor but his explanations are kind of incoherent. Hard to keep track of what he's talking about.

CHD is too similar to CANOS, at least currently. Only difference is CHD focuses more on the datapath, and you actually design processors in Verilog. If you've taken CANOS and want to actually learn things, skip to Advanced CHD. Liu Liu is a mid lecturer, but seems to genuinely care. The class is not much work and fairly easy (if you've taken CANOS)
A really awful professor. He will teach you how to do the lab after the deadline.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment:
Difficult to understand and quiet during lecture

Grading is very poorly done. E.g. he said you lose 20pts max if you don't do an in-person checkoff for the last lab. Once grades went out, he switched it where if you didn't do an in-person checkoff you can't get an A-/A even if you were above the threshold

Also curves down so getting 93 means a B+

He teaches directly from the textbook. There is little understanding of what is expected on exams and quizzes. His homework is just to perform textbook problems. His notes are copied 1 for 1 from the textbook. He does not clear up uncertainties and his lecture ability is overall awful

get ready to teach yourself relativity

Quizzes are nearly impossible to ace. He does not go over helpful material, just the examples from the book. I feel like I lost knowledge taking his class. Just stick to the book and try to do well on homeworks and activities. One open book final, but doing well on it doesn't really bring your grade up if your quiz average is bad.

The course material is extremely challenging but the best thing about him is that he understands this, so his homeworks and exams are pretty straightforward. Understanding the concepts is much more important than solving crazy amounts of problems
The coolest Prof at RPI!
Very helpful and insightful Professor. Very research oriented and really cares about his students. Lot to learn from the course and extremely well structured.
Most awesome Prof. ever !!!

Course material was very interesting. I gained most knowledge, however, from the text, not the professor. Use of slides was excessive...which to me exudes laziness of the professor. Tests were pure memorization. 1:4 exams (that bearing the worst grade) is dropped prior to final grade, which is a nice perk. Dr. Ligon is pretty relaxed, friendly.

Ligon is a super nice lady and is willing to help her students. The material is very repetitive from other classes, so it does seem very boring. She offers extra hw assignments to help boost grades, and overall I would rate her as a better than decent professor.

She doesnt sound as if she knows what shes talking about EVER. No lie, she said umm 91 times in 20 minutes! And yes, I was so bored that I counted! Don't put yourself through this! I felt dumber every day I went to class.
Highly do not recommend
Tough quiz, easy exam.
No tests besides the final, but have to give two presentations on cases. Not difficult. Graded generously
Fun, fair grader, makes at times dry material interesting, has great fashion for a professor

Can be difficult to access outside of class, often has trouble interpreting students' questions. Engages with students in class. Can come off as abrasive, but he's super nice. Emphasizes actually understanding the material's real-life applications and shortcomings (this is a HUGE boon). Provides great mix of casual and formal vocabulary. Really fun
Great guy. Really great classroom experience. Makes the effort to get to know each student!

The structure of this class was confusing. There was no guidelines for grading of the homework or exams. We didn't use numbers in calculating anything and it was quite conceptual. He also tried teaching us Python to help with the homeworks but it only made it more confusing. All the other professors had different content that was much easier.

The most confusing grader I have ever seen. Graded either on HW or tests, whichever was WORSE. I can appreciate at the bare minimum that he exposed the class to a bunch of concepts that were useful and not covered by other professors. However, material comes from his head and is written on a chalk board with no hope of recovering lecture notes.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Probably deserves mercy since this is the first class he's taught but he didn't give me or my capstone group any so RIP. He opened the first class with some basics on space vehicle design but the rest of the semester was spent grilling each group and not providing any advice on how to improve. He seems like he wants students to struggle. Don't take

Personableapproachable guy.  Charismatic lecturer, with plenty of knowledge and insight.  Sometimes makes small algebraic mistakes.  Classical thermo is boring (not Garcia's fault) but stat mech is much better.  Charitable test format offers up to 120 points but is still graded out of 100.  Includes some material outside the text.

Garcia is a great professor! He's very good at teaching the basics of the course, and is more than willing to help when it comes time to do the labs, which can be very difficult. He definitely knows what he's talking about. His section had one of the highest average test scores. He's very friendly and approachable. Only a slight accent!!!
He knows how to push the students to participate in discussions. Classes are well prepared and he is very knowledgeable about the subject. He takes very long to grade course assignments.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Excellent instructor. He has lots of experience and knowledge on the subject.
Very good teacher considering the complex nature of the material.  Very helpful with any student who needed extra assistance.

Nice guy, knows his stuff, can be scatterbrained/tangential at times. In-class exercises and homeworks are nice for reinforcement, some border on busy work.  Tests are hard but he is honest about what he asks. The material's heady, some of this is/was his research, it's understandable if you get lost, just speak up when necessary to get help.
He is hard to understand and rude to students. Plays devil's advocate but never gives proper feedback.

Worst professor Ive ever seen in my life... nobody understands what hes talking in class, he uses the worst slides and basically just read them the entire class. Sometimes he doesnt even know how to do his lab. Homework, lectures, exams are totally not even the same thing. The difference between Back test and his actual exam is huge.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: The out-of-class work was really awesome, the in-class was pretty slow. Made for a good class, especially when classmates were engaged.

Professor Dentz was by far my favorite professor at RPI. She extremely knowledgeable and I learned much more than I was expecting to learn in her class. She is not only a professor but also a friend, and very open, willing to help, successful, and intelligent. I would retake her classes if I could

This class was incredibly difficult with some very strange theories that are taken for fact. The distribution of reading assignments was skewed and some days you had to read a five page essay about feminism and the next you would have to read an entire book. Half the class glazed over while she was talking.

Dr Anicca definitely knows what she's talking about! She's a great professor and very easy to reach out to. I loved her Women's Writing class, and although it was a lot of work, it was very rewarding!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: Taking Professor Lonn Combs was one of the best experiences I've had at RPI. He sees students for what they will be capable of in the future so yes he will push you for your best but don't get discouraged.

I'm angry at the fact that when class went online the difficulty and course work stayed the same/increased. It is disgusting that ALL architecture professors are tone-deaf to the situation students are in right now with the virus having major effects on students lives. I don't care about class when my parents are going broke from the virus.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Literally, GPA killer. Unclear grading Cretiera, he doesn't even give clear reasons of why he taking your points off. Also a bad lecturer. Anyway, just don't choose his class.
Enjoyed my time in Professor Hoffmans class for Inventors Studio 1, just be prepared to write and give oral presentations to the class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--So many papers

comment: The class starts out pretty easy with Business Modeling, but as you move to harder topics like SQL and Advanced Excel techniques, going to class and practicing the techniques is beneficial. However, I rate his class so highly because the projects, workload, faced paced work is very similar to the career world. Highly recommend this professor.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. McKinney is a good professor with lots of knowledge. My only complaint about this class is that the lectures go extremely slowly which makes it difficult for you to want to be there. Only grades are exams, each worth 20%, it starts really easy but they get significantly harder to complete as the sem goes on. You need to study!
rating_tags: Test heavy--Graded by few things--Online Savvy

comment: Class included group discussions, notebook writing, and in class presentations.  The structure of the class has, reportedly, improved over time.  Actually try and you should do fine.
Showed up routinely late to class, but assignments were easy.  The grading is subjective and she doesn't appear to enjoy giving As.

David has helped me with resume/interview skills, getting motivated to study (hugely), navigating the career fair, and put me in touch with a couple people I should talk to about network engineering jobs. I can't really say I've learned a single networking concept from him. Very approachable and helpful in many situations though.
Has a refreshing desire to help everyone with anything. Even though he is the director of various cisco courses he will sit down with anybody if ever asked.
Writes so quickly that by the time one board is copied, he is three boards down. Handwriting is barely legible. Hard to understand.
No comment

Traffic Eng - Jeff is great for Traffic Eng. That is his background. Uses Powerpoint but does examples in class. He is very helpful. It will take you a week to understand accent, but he is great. Go to class as you will take notes. Do HW in groups as they are hard/long. no Final, just 2 tests. One TransCad project at end. Reccomend for all Transpos
Professor Ban is a new professor, but teaches as if he has lots of experience.  Knows the material and very helpful.  Take transportation classes with him if available.

If you're unsatisfied by your work of architecture for the first 2 years because it doesn't make you feel meaningful, go work super hard in his vertical studio. Be out there, immerse yourself, get experimental. He values the thought of a person, the sparkles of wisdom and creativity, and unusual approaches to the discipline. He can free your mind.

Very "out there" in his thought process. As an artistarchitect, no surprise. Particularly intrigued by strangenew concepts of "what architecture is." Lot of students take advantage of this by not really doing anything. Can be a bit esoteric, but genuinely loves the work and wants to help. Very honest. Interested more in process than final result.
Lots of anecdotes, which keeps it interesting, but you might miss out on some material.
Great guy, incredibly helpful and funny too. Go to class, he takes attendance and takes to liking you if youre good at materials science. Offers Undergrad research opportunities

I asked for help once on a project and he was extremely rude. I knew that there was a simple answer but no one in my group could figure out what what he was asking so when I asked for clarification he scoffed at me and treated me as if I had no right to ask him a question. He knows the subject matter but he does a very poor job of teaching it.
posts lectures online to watch before going to class

One of the best professors you will ever take. He tells you his expectations are unreasonable, and they are. He will push you to reach goals you never thought possible. One of the best people I have ever met. Take his class if you ever get the chance.

Professor would not work to aid students after meetings, stressed to be professional and was not himself (often late for class etc) and He also would not grade groups according to size. Did poor job of communicating what was expected from students.

A decent professor. The homework assignments are very time consuming, but very important to passing. Do the homework, and study hard for the tests. I got a decent grade by working very hard. Overall, a reasonable professor who knows her stuff.

If you get 1 portion of a prob wrong, you will get the rest wrong. She makes errors while grading my assignments and told me that she would only take a look at HER mistakes if my grade was crucial. Due to HER mistakes my grade has suffered an entire letter grade (-A to-B). Never got any points back. Take the other professor teaching this.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Tests are tough

comment: Yury is an overall good professor. Your grade is heavily dependent on long and difficult homework problem sets, but Yury is always easily available on email or office hours to help out. Lectures and in-class exercises are often too long and dry. However, as long as you have a decent idea of what's going on, you should easily get an A.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Graded by few things

comment: Yury is a God

Dr. Intes is clearly extremely knowledgeable of his field. He moves fast, so it can be hard to understand him, but his lectures are very detailed and he does his best to simplify complex topics. Difficult exams but easy homework. You need to use MATLAB. The TA, Harrison, was amazing. I enjoyed the class.

Such a sweet and smart guy! It's an intro class so you learn a lot of the basics and it's super concept heavy. Read/memorize the slides and you're set because the tests are OK but they test the smallest things. TA is great and Intes is a super approachable guy who curves too, just don't procrastinate and absorb the slides as early as you can!
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria--Tough grader

comment: Professor Choi's brilliance regarding the subject matter cannot be paralleled, there is no question to that fact. Classes were lecture-style slide heavy. All question asked after class. Weekly essays  graded for the format, subject matter, and artistic organization. Slide info barely shows up on tests Only what she spoke about during the lecture.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: The class itself is an interesting one and was enjoyable. However, the grading, as expressed by nearly all of the students, was way to harsh. It's one thing to receive low grades when putting in no effort. However, a majority of students placed a genuine effort and time into assignments just to receive not "Good," but "Satisfactory" grades.
Had him when he was a new professor and I was in my first semester, a really nice professor, office hours are super useful.
A very caring professor.
This is a 2 credit class but he gives as much work as many 4 credit classes. Instruction is poor and non substantial. You will not learn anything of use from this class.

The whole class feels like someone is trying to convince you witchcraft is real. Nothing of actual use is discussed, everything is hypothetical, and what is discussed is almost more "spiritual" or something of the sort instead of actually substantial. Complete waste of a class, execution is poor as well. Mandatory class unfortunately.

Professor McFarlane was an alright professor. It was primarily the structure of the course being that it was taught online for the first time. You have to get lucky with the TAs because the rubric for exams is very strict. However, Professor McFarlane's lectures were straightforward, even if they were boring.

Overall McFarlane is an ok professor. His lecture slides were for the most part good with good examples. He explains the concepts fairly well but I cant help but fall asleep during his lectures. He does example problems on his Doc Cam but theyre barely readable. Hes a good guy and means well for his students but can come across as condescending.

I really enjoyed Docs, and I enjoyed having Professor Miller. She's quite lax about grading as long as you show that you care and put in effort, and she wants to see all her students unlock their creativity and find their passion within the realm of documentary filmmaking. Pretty easy A, and some pretty interesting content to boot!

Took her documentary class, and kinda slept my way through it. She gives good feedback, so if you take this class seriously (unlike most of the class) you'd actually learn. Just show up to class and you're good.
He honestly cares about his courses and really tries to keep everyone engaged. I encourage everyone to take history and culture of games as well as his world-building course!

Great Professor. Clearly states what must be done, the grade you get is the grade you work for, encourages actually learning and doing assignments (you can choose which you do). Learned a lot, and low stress. Great and flexible class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Niemiec ran a very fair and structured Aeroelasticity course. As with many engineering classes, the course was test heavy. However, they were very fair exams. His lectures were all directly related to the exams and we were never tested on anything we did not go over, or did not take notes on. Very fair professor.

GOOD LUCK! This class was a nightmare and a waste of time. Class was set up as 75% exams and 25% HW but there were only 5 hw assignments so each one is worth 5% of your grade and he grades them rigorously. Only upside is that your final replaces your worst exam (which you're gonna need). He grades on a curve at the end which might save you.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: The setup for this class is an absolute disaster. He seemed like he was teaching another professor's materials and he wasn't super great at doing it. The tests are absurdly easy if you do the back exams. The time commitment for labs is annoying but doable. If you feel like you never know what's going on, that's ok, no one else does either

I think this professor is a really great person but this class setup was awful. It seems like he is using material from other professors and doesn't fully know what is on it. You have to figure it out on your own. Unfortunately this class is required for ECSE majors, but I don't think I learned too much that will be helpful in the future.
Professor Ramirez did a great job teaching the class. The notes and slides are clear and easy to understand and the projects, labs and class exercises really help you learn more about the material.
